reviews.review:
İn restoration. Be informed about the sections that are in restoration SO that dont be dissapointed !
İt's the richest archelogical museum !
Cyprus,lebanon,Anatolian,Frigian, Troian and most important Constantinople finds
Wow!. Absolutely amazing! I've seen photos before but there is just no comparison to seeing it all in person. The size and scale is just not the same and definitely intimidating at times.

Well planned, well laid out museum. There is so much history in the archeological museum, it could lead to boredom, but it doesn't. The museum has an amazing collection and is laid out in a way that one can see everything, or choose to skip areas of low interest. We went on a rainy day and it was the best way to spend time indoors. Came out with a renewed appreciation of the past civilizations of the region. Well worth spending a few hours.

it's worth the trip to Istanbul. Actually it's worth the trip to Istanbul, I spent there a full day... then, as I was not completely satisfied, I got back for another half day. This is a real world gem!

Hitit clay tiles. I am not much of a history person, however I was simply blown away with Babylon gates and Hitit clay tiles with translations available just by their side. Being a child and reading school history books with glossy pictures of artifacts I did not imagine I would have a chance to see them real. The best part the museum was not even crowded during a weekday.

Amazing archelogical pieces - Incluing the Troya treasures. Amazing archelogical pieces - Incluing the Troya treasures. It may take several hours. If you want to paya a few liras, get a guide to take you thru the best areas
Excellent museum, well planned.. I thoroughly enjoyed my visit to the museum. It is well planned and it has a good layout. The displays have great descriptions and the Audio Guide is easy to use.

Brilliant. What an awesome museum. I was impressed by the building even before we got inside and once inside - what amazing treasures. I was especially impressed with the panels from the Izmir gate - (Babylon). Unfortunately part of the museum was closed for renovation, but this was not so bad as we spend half a day in the part that was open.
Impressing Place. This museum is the one of the most impressing Place in Istanbul. History is everywhere. You can almost see every century's information. Also about Istanbul's amazing history.

Interesting museum.. I'll be the first to admit that I'm not the biggest history buff, but I found this place to have very informative and interesting information about the eras of Istanbul. There was a lot of information which was overwhelming ( but still interesting ) at times. The architecture on offer is a joy to behold. Worth a visit for an hour or so if you're in the city.

Amazing collection that is a must see for museum lovers!!. Lots to see in here so plan on staying awhile. I am not a museum lover myself, but enjoyed viewing the artifacts. There are places to sit and rest inside when you need a rest. Enjoy!!!

Just an Average Museum. The Museum is interesting, but it is only a small one with a limited collection, especially that they are rennovating it right now. Do not expect to spend a long time there. It took me 30 minutes to see it. But it depends on how you do it.There is no informtion about the statues outside in the garden.

What a collection!. The museum has a collection of 1000s of artefacts from allover Turkey and of course, from the own town's history. See statues from Assur, Hittites, going over Greek and Roman to Byzantine and finally visit the special building for Ottoman Art. What a collection!

well set out . As someone with an interest in archaeology this was enjoyable however to the average person may be a little tedious as not much is explained just a basic general overview. Alot of areas were also closed for restoration but it was included in the Museum pass that I bought for 85 Turkish Lira that can be used over 5 days so well worth going to.

EXCELLENT FOR FAMILY AMAZING PHOTOS. Well we traveled quite a bit but this place was fascinating! I enjoyed our time here got some fantastic pictures am happy snappy I cannot cope with out my camera only cheap but 20mp and 35gb lol back to on we walked round for a good while I loved this place will return. Also would recommend it for families I think teenagers might get bored! But if they are interested definitely add this to your bucket listFriends and family would also recommend this experience.Regards Peter.

Under construction. The museum is nice. It is under construction so the display seemed fragmented, and not well presented. A lot of entrances, blind corners, stairs, and the heat of the winding down summer. Yet, to see the rest of Turkey, Effesus, Troy, without first visiting this museum would be incomplete.

Istanbul Archaeologial Museums. In this museum you can see many archaeological things from different myths Egyptian ,Greek and Anatolian historical statuses and many other things it is one of the interesting attraction and its located near Topkapi

Very Historic. If you are interested in Archaeology than this is right place for you. Its on walking distance from Sultanahmet metro station. If you buy 5 days museum pass than its entry is free along with other museums. Staff is helpful and friendly. After main security enterence you may step up on left side stairs and enjoy part 1 of museum than get off the building and have tasty cup of turkish tea/coffee from beautiful museum cafeteria than pop in to second building for rest of show. Must see. Enjoy...
tour of museum. Didn't want to leave this museum . So much history and artifacts that I could not ingest it in one hour. Loved it !!!!

Best Archaeological Finds!. Enjoyed this museum and it helped me understand the historical events of this Great City. The garden museum was my favourite, first time for me to see such big stone carvings of old bases of pillars. Truly amazing.

Impossible not to visit. Well, a must visit to understand the rich history of Turkey. It's like traveling through the different periods and the four empires. It took me some time to see everything but it was worthwhile. I was fa instead by the different civilizations and the unique collection resembled here. Just great !!

Very nice. When I went to the museum,part of it was under renovation still it was very interesting to walk around the museum and discover Mesopotamian and Egyptian civilization. The museum contains a huge number of beautiful and impressive status. there is cafe in the garden where you can rest between the different kinds of status and beautiful trees. I highly recommend this museum to be visited.

Cats!. Ok, so there's more than cats but the cats which inhabit the cafe garden at the museum delighted the kids. The tile kiosk here is the best way to see and understand the unique style of Iznik and related tile art. The main building is under renovation.

Impressive collection!. I was very surprised to find such an impressive and massive collection of artifacts. And I do mean massive, in size and quantity! Plan on spending a couple hours just wandering around. They had a very nice exhibit that displayed where in Istanbul the artifacts had been found. It really gives you a better understanding of what the city would have looked like hundreds of years ago.
Nice Museum... very nice museum , but some part are under maintenance now. however most of the part is still open for public.

A little bit boring. It was nice, but it was a little bit boring. Too many stones and not so many explanations for them. The most interesting part was the grave stones and coffins made from sculptured stones.
Nice. Lots of renovation going on. But still worth a visit. Maybe so encourage and hour at most here. Steep climb

Nice but nothing truly special. This museum is nice and worth attending, but if youre avid archeology fan, dont expect anything special. Ancient Greek, ancient Anatolian civilizations, some stuff from Persia.

Truly amazing. If you are into history, and times that are considered ancient to those who live in the "very young" United States, this is not to be missed. I could have spent days going through this museum (renovation or no renovation, worth every moment you have there). The sarcophagus rooms were incredible; hard to believe those have survived that long that well. Approximately 1/2 of the museum was closed for renovation when I was there, but I still spent four hours just wandering the hallways. I cannot wait to go back again when the refurbishment is complete.

Fantastic. Amazing place to visit. Keep an eye out for the cats running around outside. Magnificent exhibits. Needs a lot of time to make the most of this place. Recommend getting the headphone recording as the exhibits don't have great details about what they are.

One of the best museums. Since the Ottoman Empire had most of the antique ages wonders in its borders, most of the precious archaeological findings were found in the late 19th century to be displayed in this museum. It has such lots of wonders that, you surely spend a day inside it. Don't miss the upper floor if not under renovation

Best Historical place in Istanbul. Well, if you visit Istanbul and not been here then you saw nothing...The tour here is a travel to past and to other places....since you will see so many antiques here that belongs to different times and places that not only belongs to turkey but to the whole middle east, So you can see antiques from Mesopotamia like Sumerian cuneiform tablets and Babylonian lions as well as antiques from Levant, Egypt, Persia and Greece..The museum designed to 4 buildings and every one of them worth every moment you spent there.Audio guides and maps are also available in many languages.

Neil Williamson . Well worth a visit. The exhibitions are well presented and easy to get around. The cafe is set in a shaded garden and it is easy to spend a little time the. Cost wise not to expensive for refreshments.
Great building, a good collection. Another surprise in the historical peninsula of Istanbul. You can find a quite interesting archeologic collection there.

Must see. Thie may not be an activity for everyone but if you have the slightest interest in History, Archeology, Mythology and Civilizations, make the visit to the Archeological Museum a must. Everyone has a different Opinion but this is definitely one of the Top Archeological museums in the world, Definitely.

An interesting museum, a certain part under reconstruction. A great and interesting museum with major attractions, but some part ist under reconstruction. I recommend to visit. Visiting fee costs 20 TL (entrance is free with Museum Pass). We recommend visiting the same day with a visit to Topkapi, because they are close to each other.

Amazing exhibits. The museum is pretty big. While we were there, they were undergoing renovations so it was a little bit of a mess. But it was still amazing. The large amount of exhibits could easily eat up a couple of hours. Outside the museum, there are nice places to sit and sip tea. This was another museum that you could enter using the all-museum pass active for 5 days.

One of the best museums I have visited . Let me just say, if you like history, you can spent hours and days here. You will see over 1mln exhibits presenting different nations and countries (even Egyptian mummies). We have spent a full day there but I am sure we could spend several days more. You are allowed to take photos unlike many other museums, which is a great opportunity to have a photo with the king of Sidon (around 4000 years old mummy). My favorite exhibits are the stone manuscripts which have their translations as well. It is so nice to see that even after 2000 years the human problems remain the same :)
For history buffs. Not very big, but with some nice archeological objects from different eras and different peoples...Nice place if you like history.

SOO MUCH TO SEE- But could be better organized.. The Museum is absolutely ginormous. This museum is filled with fantastic relics from Turkish and middle eastern civilizations of the past. It is staggering the size and quality of these remains. But having said that, I don't feel like I walked away having learned something, despite having spent at least two hours there. If you are short on time, I would stick to exploring the city and taking your dose history from the nearby Topkappi palace. The museum is located in the same complex that houses the Topkappi palace. It is housed in buildings that were once a part of this palace. When I visited it was under construction, but there were four buildings/sections open, with a courtyard in between the first and the last three. The first building/section contained the relics from early civilizations in turkey and the middle east, including the usual pots and trinkets and even some partially rebuilt temples. The courtyard houses the second building, which is a small tiled house displaying some porcelain work through the ages from Bursa and Iznik. The building itself is also decorated in tiles. The courtyard has some additional (unmarked) statues and when the construction has finished, I am sure will be quite striking in itself. The next section is very easy to miss and after following a long taped off tunnel of tarp can be found to contain old marble sarcophigai. The fourth section can be found by once again entering the courtyard and entering another almost hidden entrance. This housed the history of the city itself. This was the most historically interesting part but it was so expansive and it was hard to follow its multi-floored, nook-filled layout. It also didn't seem to be 100% chronological, which made it a bit confusing. If I were to do it all again I would have only visited the first building, the courtyard, and the tile house. Maybe after construction the final two buildings will be more clearly marked and better organized.

Museum Experience. Museum is pretty big and museum lovers will like it most probably. We were there just because we had the pass. Ticket price is 45 Lira. But I would recommend mates to buy 85 Lira worth museum pass which can be used for 5 Days in many main palaces like Topkapi, Sophia Etc.. You don't need to stand in the queue as well. If you are first timer in Istanbul definitely you will need this pass even for one day its worth.

Must See for History Buffs. Amazing museum full of all those things you studied about in Art History and Archaeology classes. A must see. A bit hot inside and lots of "stuff" to look at. Wish there was a guide or videos and more information to break it up and put things into context. Still worth having a look.
History at its best. you should not miss the golden opportunity to visit this place while you are in istanbul. A place where you can experience the beauty of ancient history through the sculpture.

especially the fore yard.... this museum is a must, if you are staying more than 2 days in istanbul. easily reaceble by all public transport means including marmaray... the sarcophagi with high relieves very impressive...

Don't miss this beautiful museum, so much to see. We had seen all the other museums on several trips, but this one remained. Gorgeous, quiet, spacious grounds and so much to see we were overwhelmed. Don't be put off by the renovations signs on the main building; there was still plenty for us to gaze at on the upper floors. Check out the tiled interiors. The Museum Shop is also a great place to buy stylish gifts
Awesome. Some of the best Byzantine, Egyptian, Roman Ottoman artifacts I've seen. I loved the sarcophagus museum, great collection.

Great art, neat buildings, lots of kitty cats. The Archaeological Museums in Istanbul are well worth a visit for anyone who is serious about loving art. The Museums are in Gulhane Park right by Haga Sophia, so they're easy to find. (And the park is really pretty too.) The collections are in more than one building. Some of the buildings were under restoration while we were there, but the building with glass display was not covered up and the building itself was beautiful. Oh, and they have part of the Ishtar Gate--awesome! There is a big cafe outside by the buildings, so you can relax and have a coffee with some of Istanbul's stray cats (they are very well cared for by the people of Istanbul, don't worry).Cost/hours: 15 TL or use museum pass. Daily 9-7.

For the love of people through the Ages!. I was very, very privileged to be guided through the Istanbul Archaeological Museums by mr. Cengiz ALATLI - a lawyer and architect. He brought the stones and monuments to life! I was enthralled by the experience. Thank you to the Turkish Monuments Council for opening these doors for the world to step through. Here one experiences the various cultures of the Middle East through-out millennia.
Very good, but half closed due to renovation. A good museum, as you would expect from one of the worlds oldest countries, but large parts of the museum closed for renovation.

One of the most historical museums I've been to.. The Istanbul Archeology Museum is by far the most complicated museums I've been to. The history that lies here is incredible. From the original first contract, the first love letter and so much more it really is a must even if you're not into historical artifacts!

Archeological Museum. This museum was fantastic. It is hugh and has everything from early writings (lookout for an early wedding certificate, and an early divorce certificate), and an ancient mummy. Fantastic
Usually great.. This summer so much of the museum is closed for restoration that we were disappointed by our visit. It's still a great experience.

Ripped off. About 80% of the place is shut down for renovation now. There is a small sign on the window saying some rooms are closed but this is not the case. All of the main building and upper floors are shut down. They do not give you a fair warning about this and just take your money. Avoid unless they guarantee it is all open.

Very good. I only went to this museum because of its close proximity to Topkapi Palace but I was pleasantly surprised. It comprises 2 buildings and an outdoor area. The first building is a bit of a so so but the second building is the charm. The statue collection outside is also very nice.

Greek/Christian Civilization Collection. Not as much pre-Greek Artifacts as I hoped it would be. I wanted to see more of the earliest civilizations-I think one must get to Gobekli Tepe and some of the other outline states to get that. However, it is a nice collection. Worth the visit, sumarian tiny clay scrolls were the best thing of all:-)

Milion days in one building . What to say ? Huge ... huge and very interesting. You can see so many different details from the past that you willl ask yourself how is that possible to make ( and probably just with two hands ... there was no machines like today ) or who invented that. Nooo...look at this. Omg who made this. Buliding full od surprises. Dont miss to visit.

Impressive Collection. The museum had an incredibly deep collection of ancient artifacts including many from Mesopotamia. While we were there, an exhibit containing the first every political treat was on display - incredible history. It is currently under renovation so a bit hard to navigate around, but generally recommend.

Historical treasure. Amazing place, full of history. There are three main sections: a main museum, an Islamic art museum, and a section containing sarcophagi and tombstones. One can easily spend 2-3 hours exploring all the treasures contained here.

Renovations in progress. Like many attractions in Istanbul, the Archaeology Museum is undergoing renovations; the Tiled Pavilion and Museum of the Ancient Orient are fully open, however (all on the one ticket). I'd say 3/4 of the Archaeology Museum is closed, which was very disappointing, although several of the top attractions are still on display.Still worth a stop when you visit the Topkapi Palace, a little up the hill.
nice garden and museum. great great perfect museum .You need to go there july jazz festival time .If you are lucky they choose this place as a festival area.

Excellent Tile Museum. This is a collection of Museums and it appears that the main museum is currently under construction, One of the museums in the complex had a superior display of gorgeous tiles from the Izmir period of tile production. This was a small museum whose collection was displayed on one floor. The building itself is part of the Palace complex and in my opinion this collection is not to be missed. The viewing takes about fifteen minutes or so and can be easily combined with the rest of the museum or palace sights.

Amazing artifacts . I am not a big museum goer but I found this museum engaging. I loved all of the statues and historical artifacts from thousands of years ago. I went early and was glad I did, before the crowds came.
Best of best. I really shocked about the rich potential of the museum. It is very near to other touristic and historical places. İ Recommend you to start to visit museum early in the morning.
Great place for history lovers.. For Real history lovers, these museums require atleast one and a half day. For casual visitors, at least half a day is recommended

Fascinating, fabulous, WOW!. This is a group of 3 museums, one of the museums was closed for renovation when we were there. They were on the Istanbul museum pass, so we went. I would have gone anyway, they are that spectacular. The statuary outside in the garden cafe is enough to stun you from the start. Then once you enter, there is more of that plus fabulous tile work, ancient sarcophagi, tons of incredible things to see. This is right up there as the "must-see" things about Istanbul. I am so glad we had the time to go!

Highlight of our trip. We could have spent 2 days here, there was so much to see. The main museum is undergoing some renovation, but the displays were still great. The Greek statuary was a highlight. The Orient Museum building was our favorite.
Medusa. Was excited to see medusa ruins but unlucky to have visited on the time of close for renovation maintenance

Undergoing restoration. Currently being restored Some brilliant pieces but very dated curation Hopefully this will be addressed when restoration complete Don't miss the first gallery up the steps on the right as you enter one of the highlights
Incredible Sarcophagi collection. Wow, this place is amazing. Great coffee shop in the courtyard. Go straight into the sarcophagi collection, the collection is remarkable.

Worth a visit. We spent a few hours at this fascinating museum. So much to see and we didn't see everything despite a lot of halls being closed for renovation. We will definitely visit again on our next trip to Istanbul.

It Felt Like Going into the Harvard Museum in Raiders of the Lost Ark. I visit many museums but rarely is there one where there is too much to see that you can barely turn around, so close you can touch, and in such spectacular condition. I really shouldn't even be telling you about this because I'd like it to stay a secret but it should not be missed if you like archaeology.

Don't Miss It!. There are three buildings at the Archeological Museum, and my favorite is the first one inside the gate, guarded by two lions. It presents a marvelous introduction to the wonders and history of the Middle East, including works from fables Persipolis. The 2nd and biggest of the buildings houses many Greek and Roman statues, the so-called "Tomb of Alexander" which is a masterpiece. The third building deals with ceramics and I have never quite made it there. Be sure to take Turkish Lira, as they do not accept foreign currencies.
Great museum. There are three museums full with artifacts from the 4.-6.th century. The collections are extraordinary. It is worth to visit.

Its great collection especially Great Alexander Sarcaphagus... There are so many rare objects into museum and especially Great Alexander Sarcaphagus amazing art .. you can watch hours to see all details of the carving...

very interesting. The collection of Greek sculptures (in main building) is stunning, so is the collection in the Near East building (first when you enter). Unfortunately, the Alexander sarcophagi was not accessible during our visit (due to renovations), but we saw it in a previous visit (and this by itself is worthy the visit).

Much interesting to learn. The Museum is under reconstruction, but there were much to see. The beautiful china, the enormous tombs and the collections, which showed Istanbul's history were all very interesting. To visit both the museum and the Topkapi Palace in one day is a bit too much!

Impressive museum. This was one of the most impressive museum I've visited. The collection is enormous and there is much information about all the objects. If you are a history lover just like me, this is the place to visit.

Best Museum in Istanbul. This museum is even better than the Athens, Greece archaeological museum (except Athens had far better pottery and vases). It is well worth a full day of your time especially if you read the plaques describing the various areas and objects. They have a display of artifacts from the Lower Paleolithic Period (1 millions years ago); the 9 Troy settlements (earliest was about 3,000 BC); some villages currently underwater by the Black Sea shoreline; beautiful, intricately carved sarcophagus'; intact statutes from the Roman period, an extensive Egyptian collection, and artifacts from the Ottoman Empire area, Arabian Peninsula, the Balkans, Africa, and Mesopotamia. In fact there were more intact statutes of the Greek gods here than in Athens - probably due to the statutes in Athens being desecrated by the early Christians/other conquering armies. The descriptions of Homer's Odyssey and Troy were particular interesting to me. May be the best museum that I ever visited. Far better than the New York Museum. Makes me want to plan a visit to the London Museum.Another plus is that it is part of the Museum Pass - the best bargain in Istanbul.

Maybe we missed a bit. So we couldn't find the 'new' part and think we missed so pretty ace stuff. The rest that we did see was ok but was poorly signposted - the explanations mostly bombard you with pointless facts but fail to provide any context whatsoever.

Stunning treasures at the archaeology museums. I very much enjoyed my experience at these museums. There are quite a lot of artefacts from the different eras in the land of Turkey and neighbouring countries, I was blown away and educated! It was great and poignant to see some artefacts from Palmyra which as we know has suffered so much destruction in recent years. I also enjoyed the tile museum.

Ugh. I'm not embarrassed to say that this place bored me to tears. Our guidebook highly recommended it but it is really for archeologists (duh) and researchers. I know that the broken statues and carvings are important but not a priority for me. Monotonous although the mosaic building was a bit interesting.

Impressive. We were impressed by the rich collection. I think this museum is not on the top list of " things to do in istanbul " but it should be. its near the Sultanahmet Square, so it was our first stop before the Topkapi palace. Highly recommended.

Blast from the Past!. NOTE: traveled last June 2012
If you enjoy history as I do, then visit this place.
A stop here will give you a historical vibe that will let you appreciate of how the world evolved, and keeps on evolving.

Interesting and being renovated. A bit dated but being renovated. Interesting artifacts with explanations written in English. Must be very interested in archaeological museum to enjoy. I especially enjoyed the tile exhibit. The grounds are nice to walk around. There is so much to see in the area that I would put this as an interesting time filler

A must for history- and art-lovers. Even the grounds surrounding the Archaeological Museums are packed with classical history – tombs, columns and other assorted, durable artifacts from diverse ancient Greek and Roman sites in both European and Asian Turkey were arrayed in the open air. As was the case with many of Istanbul’s monuments and public buildings, much of the museum complex was under restoration. Not being terribly interested in weapons or crockery, we focused on two sections, going first to the Tile Pavilion. It was even better than I had anticipated – and I had had high expectations for it. The colonnaded structure was devoted to tiles and ceramics, each piece displayed distinctly and lit so that its features could be duly appreciated. Texts in Turkish and English explained the origin of each piece and its place as an exemplar of the development of Turkey’s ceramic art. We learned how and when various colors – notably the rich red, green and turquoise – had been added to the original blue and white Iznik glazes and how wax and multiple firings had been used to keep these later, more varied colors from bleeding into each other.The second building we explored was the famous section of Greek, Roman and Byzantine sarcophagi and other funerary items, most of them white marble. Some of these exhibited exquisite, artfully realistic carvings depicting highlights from the life of the deceased or scenes of an idyllic afterlife. Equally interesting, though less showy, were marble plaques explaining who had commissioned a given tomb.

Near Topkapi Palace: Worth a Look if You've Got the Museum Card. Not something we'd typically visit, but it was included with the museum card. Turned out to be quite interesting. Several buildings with displays featuring all types of antiquities. Asian, Egyptian, sarcophigi, mummies, Greek/Roman sculptures. We spent more time here than we expected we would. Lots of opportunities for interesting photos.
Look into history. One of the best archaeological museums in the world. The highlight is the sarcophagus room. A must visit in Istanbul
Amazing Collection!. History buffs can easily spend hours here. Not to be missed at the end of a visit to Topkapi Palace.

large display of archaeological findings. this place is large. There is a tile museum, then you can move to the archaeological museum. I found it a bit sad that some items were left outside. /the place is still under construction which would explain why things are rather unstructured.

Excellent collection, boring museum. The museum is stuck in the 1960's. Boring displays, enormous texts to read. A shame, because the collection is well worth being displayed in an interesting way. They should hire a museum designing expert!

Mind Boggling!. We have seen various archaeological museums around the world, but this is easily one of the best. Each room was better than the last, ending with the sarcophagus room that was positively mind blowing. I have never seen so many almost intact sarcophagi, especially in one place. I didn't know there were that many in the world of that quality!Note that the museum is under renovation, so some parts of closed for work. There is still plenty there to occupy you though.

Brilliant Museum. If the thought of an archaeolical museum makes you yawn, well think again. This one is a stunner. And one is allowed to take photographs - and they will turn out looking superb, as each piece is lit to perfection. Afterwards you can sit and relax outside in the charming cafe, surrounded by rare artefacts.

A lot of artifacts piled up. Tiled "Kiosk" is nice.. Very oldfashioned "museum like" exhibitions with A LOT of artefact mainly wall decorations and sculptures.Expected to get away with a bit more knowledge about the historic development in Tyrkey and the surounding areas. My impression was that artefacts stood in the way of focused stories / history.Allmost averything was texted the same way in Tyrkish and (sort of) English.I do not know the empires and roulers of the Middle East by hart and found it a bit confusing being presented the same "cultures" or empires or eras several times .. I think depending on the material exhibited and not the history and/or the people behind.There are no audio-visual effects or small films explaining things for the guests and the main building apears worn down, to express it politely.The "Tiled pavillion" or "Kiosk" is worth a visit ... especially if you have the Museum Card ;-)The museum contains fine and probably important artefacts .... and probably knowlege of these.As I experienced it they do not seem to take pride in communicating the knowlege and the stories to a public used to media and fascinating/entertaining communication.

Beautiful archeological treasures in a poor setting. This museum has beautiful and famous sarcophages. And many other historic items from roman, egyptian and other areas. It is ashame that it is displyaed in such an outdated and not appealing way. It takes away part of the exitement and joy one could have. Now it is more a museum for professionals and diehards in this field and not for a curious family like us.Time for a total make over!
Unrivalled history. There is so much to see, from so many cultures and so much history, from the east and the west I would say that it rivals the collections in england

For history lovers only. As a history and museum lovers, me and my wife usually visit every museum we can get. In Istanbul we had a good time in the archaeological museum. We hung out for nearly 3 hours in this museum, considered the biggest in Turkey. You can find lots of history of the region, from ancient Egyptians and assuriets, to Romans and byzantnies and to ottomans and Turks in the last millennium. The most interesting part for us was the history of the middle east where we found a nice section about the history of our own people, the Palestinians and the kanaanites. In conclusion, don't miss if you love history.
holiday. A lot of the museum was being renovated and it wasn't easier to get around for some with walking difficulties.

What's there is OK.... ...but as mentioned below, the place is under massive restoration and the best exhibits are closed. If you have the Museum Pass already (a good deal) and an extra hour it's worth a look, but at this time the place isn't worth an extra admission fee or a special trip.
Under renovation when we were there. This could be a really interesting place but as it was under renovation large sections were closed and the exhibits were difficult to appreciate.
Well Maintained Museums. Archaeological Museums surprised me with the upkeep and maintenance of the place. Good for students of Historical background. Do visit if you like to experience past eras.

A look into the past with special exhibits. This gives a true and great view into the past and is awe inspiring. Be sure to make the trip to the third floor where they have the various levels of Troy displayed in separate displays and a well recored history of the site. Plan to go the Troy after viewing this exceptional exhibit.

Buy the Museum Pass first!!! Great insight on the surronding attractions and some further away.. This went into more depth on some of the local attractions I had already been to, ie. the Spiral Coolum and some of the artefacts found at Troy (I had visited the day before). It is a great place to see and discover some of the ancient history surrounding the country. One of the Roman life size archways was covered up with a photo display and I was a bit disappointed, as you could not even see the description/history of the archway. The photos were more modern art, nice but slightly out of place here.

Great treasures of Summerian and Assyrian cultures. I found this musuem fascinating having learnt about these civilations in high school. It seems to be about the only place where it is safe for western tourists to view treasures from these civilizations. I exspecially loved the Babylonian gates tiles and the coffee shop garden with all the columns statues and sarcophagus placed around.
interesting collection. conveniently located nearby a whole lot of other attractions, worth a look to see a lot of well preserved items.
Best museum in Istanbul. This museum was a real find and is very close to the Topkapi palace. Amazing collection of artefacts - allow plenty of time to see it all.
Great Collection of Egyptian and Mesopotamian artefacts, including a Mummy. Good place to visit for those interested in history and archaeology, with a free shuttle from Topkapi Palace

Perfect for the rain. This activity was a perfect thing to do when it started to rain. I didn't want to miss the outdoor activities, at the same time I really wanted to visit this museum for its interesting sculptures etc. Therefor I enjoyed it extra much because of the rainy weather!

Great pieces full of history . The museum offers very special pieces but the display is confusing. Some areas were under renovation during the visit. The ticket also includes access to the "Tiles Museum" with lots of examples of turkish tiles over the time. If you have visited the most known venues and still have some time this is the place to include in the program.

So much to see.. The museum was undergoing some renovation and so one of the halls (Alexander the Great) was closed but there is so much to see that we would not have had time for it anyway. I loved the tile exhibits, both the exhibits and the beautiful building. My son and husband were impressed with the Troy exhibition hall.

Could use some modern features. Having spent numerous days in Smithsonian museums, many of which are interactive and visually trendy, my trip to three of the museums at this site were rather boring. They reminded me of old 1960's museums of my elementary days. Looking through windows at dozens of similar pottery jugs, similar knives, similar earrings, similar statuettes, etc, with brief tags labeling the date, did not make for a vibrant experience. Most of what we saw, including the classical statues, we'd seen elsewhere, and with much better presentation.Our tour of a photography exhibit ( about to close down) was more baffling than enlightening. The theme was people living on a border. Unfortunately, without any captions or explanations, all we had were the photos of forlorn looking people at their jobs or at rest, with no explanation about them or their situation. We also didn't know their location. What borders were they on? Perhaps the purpose was existentialist, but the meaning was lost on us. Once back at our hotel, our concierge told us the Ancient Oriental Museum was the best one. Unfortunately, we didn't get to that one.This collection of museums isn't a site I'd return to if in town again.

Historical spot. Museum is stunning with it's sculptures from Roman and other periods. Amazing. It has a sculpture of head of the Alexander the Great as well as the sarcophagus that it's supposed that belong to him. Place where you can see lot of items from Roman period. Amazing. If you're history fanatic this is a place for you.

so small. probably because the main building is closed, it was so small and not much to see! Perhaps we are too used to the fact that museums in U.S. are so huge. We were disappointed that we only needed 30mins in a museum. That is a first time experience.

Very impressive, worth seeing. We enjoyed the museum very much; it's quite large and has a lot to offer (which is stating the obvious given the extremely long and rich history of the area), so reserve 4+ hours if you want to see everything (and you'll need a few breaks here and there).One criticism: the museum is very old fashioned, meaning that it has none of the more interactive / immersive features of more modern museums, with presentations, movies, etc. It's very much in the old style where you walk from one room to the other and admire the items exhibited and read the explanations (Turkish / English, with the English version rather crude and broken occasionally, which was quite surprising). In addition, I did not see the typical "map" of the museum at the entrance, which normally describes how the museum is organized, what is where, etc. So we had to walk one building after the other, one room after the other and were occasionally puzzled by the jumps back and forth in time / region.Still, absolutely well worth seeing. And it was not crowded at all (in March).

Time travel . The museum is undergoing renovations, but still worth a visit - especially on a rainy day. Keep in mind that some parts of the museum are closed due to being restored. (Which they don't tell you at the entrance.) The museum has lots of artefacts and you can spend a lot of time here. The exhibits are very informative and also well displayed. Once the renovations are finished I will definitely come back for another visit.
Much to admire here.. Leave plenty of time for this museum. There are many exhibits and lots to read. It is part of the Museum Pass.
A museum worth visiting . A glimpse of history ranging from approximately 2 500 B. C. up to modern ages. Leaves the visitor in an awe to the previous civilizations at their height.

Under the restoration, but worth while to visit. The museum is now under retroration, so half of the buildings are closed, but it's very worth while to visit here. This time I took some time to see famous sarcopahagus of Roman era. There were not so many people visiting in this section. Why? They are treasures of Istanbul! You may find more interests to visit here after reading a guidebook of Archeological museum.
Hamdi. Very fine and interesting place, You have to get a lot of knowledges about Turkey and Osman Emperior

fantastic. Lots of archaeological museums leave me cold but this one was great - statues ( and some massive ones too) from 2000 to 3000 years ago. There is so much some are just lying around the grounds. Slightly off the main tourist drag so not too busy either. Really worth a visit

A travel thru the history from Constantinople to Turkey .... a very informative and well put together museum. If you have the Museum pass...this is covered...so keep a little extra time after the Topkapi palace..
Excellent collection of Artifacts. There are several museums here and they have lots of artifacts from various points in time. My least favorite was the pottery museum.

Great potential. The museum is undergoing renovations and stabilization so it is not completely open We saw one floor of exhibits that was very well done, informative and very attractive. They had other interesting items on display and you could examine statues quite closely. I was glad to have visited they had the world,s first know mutual protection treaty there.

Just not very good. Over half of the museum is currently under renovation, and the other half mainly consists of poorly labeled gravestones, tablets, and other knick knacks. Some parts of the musuem are done better than others (there was a sense of stylistic inconsistency from section to section), but overall, until they reopen all of the wings under renovation, this museum probably isn't worth your time. Hard-core archaeology fans may still be pleased, but casual visitors should save their money. On that note, one of the few positives is that admission here is quite cheap - only 15 lira.

Well worth a visit. Although undergoing extensive renovations this museum is a definite must-see. It's a treasure trove of antiquities and really sets the scene for the region's archaeological history. Lookin forward to visiting when the renovations are complete.

Nice. The Istanbul Archaeological Museum is housed in three buildings, the first part of the collection that we visited was the Museum of the Ancient Orient, the highlight of which was the glazed tile panels with lions, bulls and dragons. The main building houses the archaeology museum and the third building is the tiled pavilion.

Such great exhibits, so poorly displayed.. The museum has lots of exhibits of all ages of the area, of course, most of them not being Turkish, but Greek, Roman, etc, but they are very poorly displayed. Many of them had absolutely NO info or description displayed, while wherever there was a description, it was just a handful of words, best case. Such a waste....

For Alexander's sake. This is where the famous bust of Alexander the Great is kept as well as many Greek and Mesopotamian treasures. Look at the snake head from the famous Serpentine column brought back from Delphi--history is alive in this museum. The building was being retrofitted in August 2015 (some rooms were closed).
Lost in time!. It's huge with a large number of historical items on display. Great collection of Greek statues and artifacts.
Amazing!. This is a great museum! The section on the history of Istanbul was excellent as was the collection of sarcophagi.

So much to see. This is an absolute treasure for archaeology and history lovers with floors of interesting artifacts to enjoy. There is a lot of ground to cover and it can be quite hot inside so I would recommend planning for several hours here if you want to see it properly and spend time reading about the exhibits. This is very close to the Topkapi Palace so in theory these could be combined in a day however both take several hours to see.

Some area are still under renovation. Its a very interesting and old artifacts. I love their cookery artifacts. Some parts of the building are closed so too bad unable to see the rest. Overall I love to see all except the tomb section. I would suggest you dont go there alone coz the place is very spooky with that dim lights and dark corners. I have to follow other tourists just to feel comfortable.

Visit if you like history. Not very well organized. Some chambers were closed for restoration during our visit. I did not like the fact that most of the exibits, although ancient greek, were refered as romans. Still a nice place yo visit.
Relics from the past. There was a lot to see in the museum and it bring to life the history of the area. This is another example of the variety of things to see and experience while in Istanbul.

Mind-blowing!. This museum is actually an ensemble of three museums, The Museum of Archaeology, Museum of Ancient Orients and Tiled Pavilion. These museums hold the artistic and archaeological treasures of the palace collection. You can find these three buildings located between the Gulhane Park and the TopKapi Palace. The Archaeology Museum holds interesting collection of statues, sarcophagi and exhibits on the history of Istanbul. Among these the best pieces are the Sarcophagus of Alexander and the Sarcophagus of the Mourning Women. The Museum of Orient hosts the pre-Islamic pieces collected from the length and breadth of the Ottoman Empire. The collection labeled 'Anatolia and Troy Through the Ages' is worth seeing. In the Tiled Pavilion you can see tiles and ceramics dating back to the 12th century. You can see Seljuk, Anatolian and Ottoman exhibits here. This building itself is a beautiful historical masterpiece.

Under reconstruction, but go anyway. A bit tough to navigate while being retrofitted, but the exhibits are great nonetheless. A lot of Roman era sarcophagi, bits from every period in history, including stuff Schleimann dug up from Troy. I loved the little Hittite exhibit too.

Archaelogocal Museum. It was very interesting for us to see this museum. Really worth to find time to see. We liked the old books of Koran, and were talked lokal children who come to see the Museum in their free time, what was very nice!

So much to see. The Archaeological Museum was also included in the Museum Pass and is also within the grounds of Topkapi Palace. There is a huge collection of ancient artifacts housed in two separate buildings. We enjoyed the display of the statue of the Gods. However, the air-conditioning in the museum was not really functioning which made it really stuffy (Did not enjoy and just breezed through the collections). Also, part of the building was under renovations so some collection are not accessible.
Must visit!. Quality collection. Professional display. Lovely garden cafe. I visited twice during my 5 days stay, despite the ongoing renovation! Will definitely return on my next trip.
Probably great once renovations are complete. Missed the vast majority of the museums due to massive renovation. Many of the top items are closed to the public, so would recommend to skip
Great collection. Museum has very nice collection. I enjoyed this visit very much. Be prepared (plan) to spend at least few hours there.

A Great Collection preserved for generations. This museum is big. Allow yourself plenty of time. I followed a school group in but let them move through and then it was quiet within 20 minutesIt is well organized level by level chronologically and for the most part was well signed in English. If you appreciate antiquities this is a definite stop. There are artifacts from many ancient civilizations that made their way through the area. I think the entry fee was only 15TL and you could spend a full day here. Well worth it.

one of the world's great archaeological museums. Situated in the First Court of Topkapi Palace, the Archaeological Museum has one of the world's richest collections of classical artifacts—the Sumerian, Assyrian and Hittite exhibits are rare and impressive. Dozens of galleries also hold Greek, Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman tiles, ceramics, mosaics and other treasures (some objects aren't very well displayed, and the galleries are not always open). Among the highlights are the Treaty of Kadesh, said to be the world's earliest surviving peace treaty, and a carved sarcophagus from Sidon, Lebanon, that, according to legend, held the remains of Alexander the Great. There's also an educational section especially for children.
Disappointed . I was very disappointed and unimpressed during my visit just waiting to be wooed round every corner but sadly not

Great Collection of Antiquities. These museums are very interesting, well-maintained, and organized. Plan on spending several hours there, as there are three separate buildings. The main building is currently under renovation, but there is still plenty to see. This was also quite inexpensive. It is within walking distance of Hagia Sophia and Topkapi Palace.
History wow. Few museums within the vicinity and so much to see..keep a few hours to see all the museums..was amazing to see so much history especially pre islamic roman and ottaman...
History Lover. A lot to see there and refreshing our memories, what we learned in our school.Associates answer of any question you might have.It's worthy to go there and spent some time.

Restoration in progress. We went to the museum only because we paid for the museum card and this one was included. It is half closed due to restoration. As we were tired from the all day walking around, we sat down by the Troia section where TV was playing the Troia story, very good to watch.
One of the authentic points of Istanbul. Old Greek and Byzantine samples of archaeology art really impressed us. I think Turkey have to be declared as The Only Inheritor of Byzantine Heritage

A beautiful museum. Although one section was being renovated, there was plenty to see. A series of buildings with different exhibitions/displays. The museum's collection was enormous. Plan to set aside an entire afternoon. The kittens keeping warm in the museum store were cute. Keep track of the day the museum is closed. A nice place to visit when the weather is not cooperating.

Be Prepared to Spend at least Four Hours.... So Many Artifacts to See, A lovely Garden to Sit.. The Archaelogical Museum is an amazing space encompassing over a million artifacts in three separate museums, representing many eras and civilizations in world history. The Alexander Sarcophagus, made for Alexander the Great, is among the most prestigious of art pieces from an ancient civilization. The museum houses a vast collection of Turkish, Hellenistic and Roman artifacts. In the garden one can sit and enjoy artifacts and see the cats soaking up the sun.
Amazing museum. An amazing collection of ancient artifacts not only from Asia Minor but from Syria, Cyprus, Mesopotamia, Palestine etc. Highly recommended for people interested in ancient history.
trip. very big exhibition through time. it is funny to see how much turkey had in common with the old greece.
nice. went to topkapi as well as this museum and it was very interesting. if you like history, you should visit it
Allow at least a full day.. We only had a limited time to visit the museums but one should allow at least a full day to be able to enjoy the many wonders on show.
Worth visiting. Many of the galleries were under renovation and there were gaggles of noisy schoolchildren visiting, but otherwise the museums were well worth visiting.
Selected great artwork. Small museum with some fantastic sculptures from greek and ellenistic period. For Troy fans the reconstruction of the layers
Awoesome experience. Great place to dwell around in Istanbul. Going through all the artifacts. I felt like i was in the times of ottoman emipre. Really enjoyed

Museum Has Great Cafe with Cats and Old Byzantine Stuff Lying About. We really enjoyed the museum but the really highlight of the day was the courtyard cafe with the tables set amongst old byzantine sculptures and columns. There are a couple of intrepid cats who were dead-set on eating my pistachio cake. The rest of the cats were pretty cool. The museum itself was pretty empty. I wish there was more byzantine stuff, but they're doing renovations so maybe that section is a little smaller than it normally is.
Amazingly empty of tourists. Sterling collection of antiquities through the ages. Small but well-stocked gift shop and separate cafe. Wonderfully peaceful way to spend a few hours.

Splendid complex of three museums. Do not miss this attraction if you have time. There's a lot to see of Istanbul outside, so leave the museums for a rainy day. I didn't plan to go, but that day the Grand Bazar was closed. I do not regret going. The old wall tiles of Babilonia are awesome! Top attraction! But there's a lot of classic statues, anatolian period art as well as antique civilizations exibits. Splendid!

Must visit. This place is a must - visit. It's so full of archaeological treasures we can't believe why it's not as popular as the other attractions. Be prepared to spend at least half a day if you plan to see Everything. We were especially fascinated by the elaborate burial tombs on display which had so much information along side each one. Unfortunately there was a section of the Museum closed for renovation. Definitely worth another visit.

Decent size and full of artifacts from Turkey. The museum is under renovation and expansion. It has multiple buildings and exhibits. Too many to see and study in a few hours. I like that each item has enough description to give you an idea where it came from and whether it is original or a copy. Many other museums don't even mention of the statue is a copy.You will need around 2-3 hours to tour this museum to see most displayed items. Next door to it is the ceramic museum. You can access this museum from outside of the Topkapi palace, just go to the right of the carpet museum and keep walking a couple of minutes to get to the Archaeological museum. Also, you can reach it from Golhan park.Also, I recommend you buy the 3 day museums pass for 80TL. It covers this and many other museums. Saves you a lot of money and waiting due lines.
It was interesting.... A city museum, great collection of relic pieces and very well set out in a variety of buildings, no aircon, so quite warm....

Nice Sarcophagus You Got There. I only had an hour here, which wasn't nearly enough. Still, better to see something than not at all. I enjoyed reading the detailed historical & geographical descriptions, the sarcophagi, and the mosaics.

An Archaeological Paradise. If you like history or archaeology, this museum is for you. Artifacts from throughout the entire Ottoman Empire were taken here. I personally enjoy the most the "Istanbul Through the Ages" exhibit, which is buried deep in the museum. You will find here pieces of Constantinople / Istanbul that are not visible outside the museum, but were very important in the city's history. For example, you can find here artifacts of the Holy Apostles Church which once was one of the most important churches in this important town for churches. It was leveled, but pieces of the church can be viewed here.
Nice but not well organised. The museum is quite full, but lot's of things are still not catalogued and there was a mess in part of the exhibition.

Interesting. This museum was a pleasant surprise. Not sure what I was expecting but I enjoyed several hours here. I'm doing a masters degree in ancient history and found enough to keep me interested. Many things for people of all interests and knowledge levels! It was being renovated when I visited so am sure that facilities will be improved shortly.
time travel in one of the top ten museums in the world. if you wish to travel in time, follow old civilizations in a real museum campus this is the place to be.

learn some thing new about old Turkey. The museum is an opportunity to understand better just what the Ottoman empire was and where it came from. The museum is full. I do wish the renovations were done, but the stuff displayed is amazing!

Under Renovation. The museum is undergoing fairly major renovation so quite a few exhibits are closed right now. The exhibits that were open are good and interesting. Audio guides in multiple languages are available and general signage within exhibits is in English and Turkish. Signage on individual objects is poor at times leaving a viewer wanting more detail. If you want the detail bring your own written guide. Probably not fair to rate it low since all buildings have to be repaired from time to time.

Poorly organized. This is a place that has been poorly presented. They need to consider the outlay. Could have gladly missed this, but due to being archaeology student before, I was curious. This is a city with amazing history and fortune, unfortunately this museum doesn't represent it well.

Sort of a strangely organized collection but great pieces.. This is a nice museum. It's organized in a weird, weird way but that could be because it's kind of open and kind of not open. They're clearly renovating right now. But at the same time, it's not chronological (which would make some sense). It's more like here's a collection. Cool collection! Here's another collection. Oh, cooler collection! Their Mesopotamian stuff is fabulous. But it's Turkey. So I'd have loved to seen some of their Turkish pieces. But I ended up with a ton of Greek and Roman (ok, Roman of course, and also Greek) stuff. But it wasn't Greek and Rome from Turkey. So, odd. But still enjoyable.

Don't miss it.. The museum helps to tell the amazing story of Istanbul and Turkey, including the conquest of 1453 and the Ottoman era. My only complaint is that the Shiloah Inscription exhibit, the oldest surviving Hebrew inscription, has been closed a long time so though I have had several visits, I still haven't seen the inscription.
Worth a visit. Not as busy as the bigger tourist attractions. . Very interesting an old. Have enough time to spend here before you decide to go.
Not very big. Exhibition is small. May be due to renovation works in the main building. The logic of the disposal is strange for me (not chronological basis).

Short and sweet visit. We went in on a very cold, snowy day and enjoyed the Museum of Ancient Orient. We did not have time to go to the other two museums (out of three making the Archeological Museum). The one we visited was great. You can learn a lot and see real interesting exhibits. We loved it.

Under renovation as of December 2015!. The Archaeological Museums are really three museums, the Museum of the Ancient Orient, the Archeology Museum proper, and the Ceramics Museum. I liked the first and third a great deal, but I had trouble with the second, largely because it was under renovation. The Museum of the Ancient Orient features artifacts from ancient Egypt and Mesopotamia. If you have seen really strong collections, like the ones in Berlin, this one won't impress you too much, particularly if you are stranger to the subject, like I am, and need good signage to appreciate this sort of thing. The signage is not very informative at all. The Archeology Museum, with its Roman statuary and Byzantine artifacts, was more my cup of tea, but it was under renovation, making everything hard to appreciate. The Ceramics Museum was small and lovely. The three museums are clustered around a little square with a lovely café. They can be reached either by coming down from the Topkapi Palace (clear signage marks the way), or by entering the gate near the Gulhane tramway stop.

Plenty of history to be discovered. Be prepared to spend some time here if you want to just soak in all the history that has happened right on top of the land Istanbul sits on.The entire museum brings you through various historical periods of cultures on and around Istanbul's soil. This would be a bonus if you have previously been to Athens and seen their museums.
Nice!. On your way back from Topkani you pass this museum. Not many people go in. It's large, very divers and worth while!

Interesting collections. There are several museums together in the same compound the main one of which currently appears to be undergoing some extensive renovation work at present. That said, most of the collection is still able to be seen and there are some impressive objects which make this worthy of a visit. I particularly liked the ornate sarcophagi.

So much history here. Allow several hours to just wander through this magnificent place which will take you back centuries in time. There are artifacts that are here that just take your breath away. Beautiful. If you love history and some of it is ancient history, you will fall in love with this place.

Interested in history? Go here!. Very nice museum with a lot of pieces found in Istanbul and the former Ottoman Empire. If you are interested in history, then you should go here. It gives you an idea of the different areas of the Ottoman Empire and Istanbul in the old times. Nice to spend some hours!

Visit and review Istanbul's diverce ancient past. Istanbul's past is not simple terms of religions and cultures. It was once part of the Roman Empire, was once Christened in terms of religions, and has many mosques to visit today.This diverse past has produced many artifacts from ancient and historic periods and different cultures. This colorful mix can be seen here and is brought in an order such that visitors can understand the historic context and visit artifacts from Roman and Islamic cultures/times.The museum is rather old in the way collections are presented. It lacks some visual aids such as computer animated maps with historic contexts, videos to watch while taking a break, or other visual guidance that helps putting everything into context.But otherwise its a great collection to visit. It requires a few hours if you want to review all items in full.

15tl fee. Great value. Up close access to ancient pieces. Fascinating .. We really enjoyed getting up close to such huge pieces of ancient Roman ,Byzantintine, Egyptian carvings burial chambers and coffins. Mind boggling old. Good value.We ate outside in the cafe which attracted an incredible 17 cats to my tuna sandwich. Hilarious scene. Never seen so many.  We enjoyed reading messages about the people buried written by their families . There is a fine Medusa head. A skeleton . A teapot from Roman times. There are 3 buildings. One of which is closed for renovations. Very glad we went to this .
Overwhelming. So much history in one place. If you're a history buff you need to see this place. Have tea in a garden full of ancient columns.

Could be improved.. This museum should be modernized. Even tagging of sculptures suggest little has been done to improve this place for years. Video should be added with interactive displays, and descriptions made more beautiful and readable. Its like a bulleted summary now. Who wants to read that?
Very disappointing !!!. The museum was very poor with nothing interesting to see there. It was very boring and costed lots of money as well.
Family holiday. Absolutely amazing!!!!!As a Muslim the articles here bought tears to my eyes.Thousands of years of history.A wonderful visit.

Great collection. The first thing I saw upon entering the grounds is the massive restoration work undergoing at the Museum. Apparently, I learned that many items on collection are not accessible right now due to the renovations. There are plenty of prehistoric pieces on display that left me speechless. The first floor especially was interesting. The second and third floor displays however looked like 1970s displays and need updating. We visited the building near the gate and saw the Egyptian mummy (that was interesting). For the price of 15TL, I think it's worth it. Would have been disappointed to pay more. Tip: Best to wait until after the renovation is completed.
One of best. Be aware of what your go to see, because there is an awkward way of displaying items so look for the period and work.
Some cool stuff. We are not great history buffs or museum lovers yet there was some interesting stuff here We tend go to what we are interested in and there's plenty of rooms to see

Amazing collection. This museum is huge and is divided into 3 buildings (we didn't see everything). I'd recommend 3 hours to see it all, but with a break in between ! The museum houses many impressive and massive scultpures, tiles, bas-reliefs etc. I've visited many History museum worldwide, but this one left me in awe. I definitely recommend it.

It was just ok. Visited this place only because it was part of the Istanbul Museum card that is sold for TL85. I would have skipped this if I had a choice; I have seen better collections in London for example, which was completely free to enter - I'm saying this as I don't have any particular interest in archaeology and I'm just speaking as a tourist. Most of the building was also under renovation during December 2015 so I don't think it's worth the entrance fee.

Alexander was there. This museum has a great collection, including many representations of Alexander the Great who passed this way. It also has one of the snake heads from the serpentine column in the Hippodrome. To someone who has been to Athens, it is interesting to see how Heinrich Schliemann's efforts at finding Troy are represented - very little. His name is mentioned, but that is all. He was after all a Hellenophile. The exhibition area devoted to Troy is nonetheless informative and intelligently curated. We have went to the nearby tile museum.

Shame so much was being renovated. Right now, Dec 2015, the museum are undergoing large renovations, mainly on the outside, but also inside a large section was closed off in the main building. All this said and done, the museum host a large selection of historical items ranging from the first settlers of Turkey up to more modern times.Items from all periods of Troy were on exhibit as well as many remains from Greek and Roman periods.In another building they had a selection of Mesopotamien and Egyptian items as well. There is also a selection of items on display outside, however, at our visit it was rather cold and rainy, so we decided to skip these.If you are a history buff with a keen interest for the development of this part of the Mediterreanan, this place is well worth a visit. Included in the Istanbul card, but only 15 lira admission.
hishamabdullah. This museum houses a very ancient monuments from all eras Collectibles in from all the surrounding states, Turkey Good view
good place to see different history. nice place to visit to educate kids on various civilization. Many interesting statues, pillars and artifacts

The finest pieces from Turkey and the Ottoman Empire. The museum houses finds from all the districts of Istanbul as well as finds from sites in the old Ottoman Empire, some of which have now been destroyed by ISIS. The Hittite material is awesome.

Vast museum worth a visit. It is very close to the Topkapi Palace, almost on its grounds, but many people bypass it because by the time they are finished with the Palace, they are too tired to visit. It is a huge museum on several floors, parts of it seem to be still under renovation. Great collection of Greek statues and artifacts from archaeological digs both in Istanbul and elsewhere in Turkey. Allow at least two hours.

Istanbul Museum Pass is valid here!. Even though parts of the museum are under renovation, there is a lot to see here. The exhibits and video on the excavations at Troy were fascinating. Do not miss the little ceramic museum just inside the courtyard. The little tea room is quite cosy.

Treasures from all over. This museum houses an impressive collection of both local artefacts and those from across the Middle East. Especially with the current destruction in Syria, this collection is more valuable than ever.

Lost in time. it felt amazing to see and read about all of those ancient ruins
This really helped me to take a closer look on the history of Istanbul.

travel in time and places. great place to visit in Istanbul. you can see a lot of reach things an statues a lot of ruins and historical valuable things.highly recommended to visit if you are interested in historical an archaeological places

one of the must in Istanbul. Most people miss Istanbul Arkeology Museum thinking it is the same as in the other countries, dull, dark but it gives a chance for those stepping in even it is under restoration recently. You feel like passing through the history from ancient times.No word indicate how fantactic place it is, you must see..

Very good insight into history. This is just next to the Hagia Sofia but much of the museum was closed for renovation. There was still plenty to see and gave an added insight into the history of the city and region.

Don't bother unless you have to!. Very bad organised museum, with main building being reconstructed and all beautiful archaeological items left unattended in the middle of nowhere. The area itself is amazing and beautiful but in a poor state of existence.

Variety of items on display. A must see if you are interested in archeology. Its huge with a large number of historical items on display. Very interesting is the Chain that was used to barricade and close off the straits !!

Probably the best sculptures in the world!. This museum is HUGE! So much to see, you could spend a long long time looking at it all.At my time of visit, there was a fair amount of restoration being done so some bits I had to miss out on - but even then, the amount to see was a lot. So much history, with Roman history, Byzantine and Ottoman empire history - absolutely mind boggling. For history buffs - I think a day would not be long enough here. For everyone else, who probably won't read all the little excerpts, it'll still take you a long time!Information about the Hippodrome is here as well as the serpent head which is displayed in one of the rooms. (In the actual Hippodrome the serpent head is missing but it is kept at this museum.)So many sculptures to view and be amazed at. Best to buy the Museum Pass which will let you jump any queues and works out value-for-money if you visit only 3 attractions!

Really great museum and no lines!. Ancient Egypt to Ottoman Empire--it's all here! We enjoyed thee Egyptian exhibits and the history of Istanbul thee most. We only visited two off the buildings but we loved it. Great rainy day or crowd skipping advventure!

Interesting, but perhaps incomplete exhibits for political reasons. Some good historical exhibits, but the history represented by the exhibits seems to ignore the existence of cultures and peoples presently out of favor with the current Turkish regime.

One of the best archaeological museums in the world!!!. "Must visit" for those who interested in art history. One of the best archaeological museums in the world for me!!!
I visit this museum twice and still dream to visit it again :)

Largely closed for renovation. I am sure that had it not been largely closed for renovation (and with many of the headline exhibits unavailable for viewing) I would have given it a higher rating.This is another place which falls under the Istanbul Museum pass (recommended for those visiting multiple museums).There are in fact three museums in this complex. The archaeological museum, Ancient Orient Museum and the Tiled Kiosk Museum. The main archaeological museum was largely under renovation but still had a part open which included some wonderful artefacts.The Ancient Orient Museum however really got the historical juices flowing. Here we found extraordinary artefacts from hundreds to thousands of years BC. The entrance is close to a tram stop and can also be accessed from the Topkapi palace.Thoroughly recommended for anyone with an interest in ancient history.

Amazing collection. I was astonished by the amount of ancient pieces that the museum has, beautiful and huge cuneiform tablets, and I was happy that the museum host so many pieces of Assyria, Palmira,and Hittites places. Also a beuatiful collection of manuscripts of the Qur'an.

a trip back in time and holy lands. a must to history buffs and those fascinated with ancient near eastern archaeology! best visited with the istanbul museum card for 85TL which also includes topkapi palace, hagia sofia, hagia irene, etc. easily reached thru public transport.

Amazing collecton but under construction. I love this museum. I was there 15 years ago and it was the first place I wanted to visit on my return. There was so much to see that we went twice. And a lot of the building was closed for rennovation. I was especially interested in the Hittite and ancient Babylonian section. There are also wonderful things from the Greek era.Some of the highlights were closed for rennovation. That gives me a reason to return to this exciting city.

Good museum but not outstanding. Perhaps i expected too much after visits to museums around the world, but the museum was disappointing. This likely would not have been the case it it was one of my first archeological museums, but it replicated material found in the rome, Athens, London, Los angeles and Chicago museums. It was also hindered but extensive renovations going on which limited ones choices. Not a bad experience. It was free with the Topkapi palace museum pass which made things better.

Where were all the best bits?. One of the highlights of our recent visit to Istanbul was to be the Archaeological museums. The star exhibit is the Sarcophagus but oh dear it was not to be seen. The main part of the museum is closed for-renovation? and as this contains the sarcophagi from Sidon including the famous "Alexandrian" sarcophagus the heart has been taken out of it. The unexpected bonus was the smaller building with the mummies and a splendid collection of Babylonian exhibits including the splendid tiles from the Ishtar gates and some moving early bas reliefs from Iraq.

One of the Top Museums in the world. If you like history and archaeology, this museum is a must see. We think it is one of the best museums we have seen in the world. It has three different buildings. The sarcophagi in the main building are amazing. Huge and so detailed.The building dedicated to the tiles and stained glass are a must see.

Excellent museum adn worth a visit. This museum is a gem. It has an excellent section on Assarian, Egyptian, Sumerian era and some excellent greek statues. Only had two hours and totally ran out of time.

Interesting collection. The old archaeological collection are from old times and historical place. I am amazed by the history, but I hope that they are in the original places instead of displaying in the exhibition hall in the museum. The great thing is we can see them by not flying too far away.

World class museum not to missed. Even though part of this museum was closed for renovation I was still overwhelmed by the size of the collection. You need to allow plenty of time for a leisurely stroll around and prepare yourself for a number of jaw dropping exhibits. I was particularly impressed by the tiled representations of animals from ancient Babylon.

For history-lovers. I am very happy I used the opportunity to visit Istanbul Archaeological Museums. Initially I thought it was only one building but it turned out to be a complex of buildings. They are currently undergoing restoration in some of the buildings but there is still plenty to see. Staff is very friendly and pleasant, there are areas to sit and enjoy the inner courtyard of the complex, and there is a little cafe located between statues in that courtyard. It is very charming. If you have time on your hands and you visited major sites in Istanbul definitely leave some time for these museums.

Wow! Even if your interest does not embrace archaic art.. Truly extraordinary pieces will overwhelm a visitor, presenting a rich sense of the history of this continuously occupied piece of real estate. Parts are superbly presented, others, not so good, even those renovated a couple of decades ago.

A Must for any one visiting istanbul. This museum has so many artefacts is amazing...it would take at least half a day to see the entire museum..the egypitian part is so rich in collection its unbelievable...its like visiting an museum in egypt..There are several museums in istanbul, and the best way to see them all, at an economical price is by buying a museum pass for only 85 turkish liras, and visiting them in the next 5 days...

Definitely worth a visit.. was under renovation when i was there. a section of the museum was closed. It costs 6euros. They were all well maintained and arranged. I really liked the tombstone section. The inscriptions written on these tombstones were translated and was interesting for me read them. the sculptures on these tombstones were amazing and were in various sizes. One of the buildings had nice tiles, and ceramic pottery.I didnt find anyother interesting or spectacular items on display but the other artifacts were definitely worth seeing. maybe after the renovation it will look even more better.
Amazing collection, you need more time than you would think. We left this for the last day, and were very surprised at the extent of the collection. wish we had more time.
Great if you like relics. Sadly, the Tomb of Alexander the Great was not open when I was there. It's been closed for about a year already for repairs.
Museums. So many ancient sculptures and pictures to view, this was a really historical visit. Many things to be amazed at

High Marks for Historical Treasures. Although this museum is in dire need of the remodeling that it is currently receiving, the treasures inside more than make up for the poor signage and aging (not gracefully) buildings. The Gezer calendar and Siloam inscription are on the top floor of the main building! They have a large collection of ANE statuary, Nabondias' seal, and artifacts from around Istanbul. World class historical treasures in a so-so building.

Interesting, worth another visit when restoration work is completed. This was my first visit to the museum. Lots of interesting pieces but the experience would have been enhanced with more “signage” especially to key pieces.
