Also, there was much restoration work on-going and so the museum was effectively divided into two parts. This with the lack of signage meant we almost left the museum without visiting both parts of the building.

Istanbul Archaeological museum. The Archaeological museum is a complex consisting of three museums 1) Archaeological museum(Main Building) 2) Museum of the Ancient art and 3)Museum of Islamic art located between Gulhane Park and Topkapi palace.The present site of the museums actually belonged to the outer gardens of the Topkapi Palace and the museum was founded by a Royal decree in 1891.The exhibits of "Mummies" and Sarcophagus's fascinated me.The museum has a large collection of Turkish, Hellenistic and Roman artifacts.The "Alexander Sacrophagus" is the most prominent ancient art exhibit in the museum.. Outside the museum building in the Courtyard were numerous statues of the Hellenistic period.

Large collections of relics and wonderful. There are renovations happening however there is much to see and it is a well curated museum with a beautiful area of Mesopotamian artifacts, a Tiled Pavilion that was exquisite and the large building with a survey of Turkish relics from prehistoric era through Greek then Roman then Byzantine then Ottoman eras. Beautiful and worth seeing, could spend many hours there. We bought a MuseumKart and this museum is included - it is on the grounds of Topkapi Palace and should be on the ToDo List.

A full history of the Great empire from ancient times. Keep a few hours to stroll through and see the well laid out museum with good captions. The sculptures, especially of Venus removing her shoe, are very good. Apollo, Menderes, and other gods are also of high quality. The tile museum is amazing for its breath-taking colours and high quality.Though some parts are closed for renovation it is well worth a visit.

Under Construction. Majority of this museum is under construction/renovation. I only checked this place out because I bought the Museum Pass; otherwise you can skip it and head straight to the Topaki Palace.

A crash course in world history.. A visit to this museum is like a crash course in World History. It walks you through the very ancient civilizations with a vast collection of artifacts that are quite impressive. I really wanted to see the sarcophagus of Alexander the Great, but the time we were there it was under restoration. This Museum is included in the Museum Pass.

Great collection.. Great collection of artefacts on display. I particularly liked reading the translations of some of the inscriptions on the stone steles - they really helped to give the display a human connection. The museum buildings themselves are quite beautiful particularly the tiled kiosk.

Excellent Museum. This museum is currently carrying two separate and extensive exhibits. The first is covering ancient Greece, the second Mesopotamia and Byzantium. In the latter, there is a mummy, which is pretty cool!

Extensive Displays. The Museum was under renovations when we visited so not all displays were available. What we did see was very extensive. Due to the renovations we were disappointed that we could not view the Alexander Sarcophagus.

The Museum was good but staff were rude. I was happy with the content inside the museum but, I found the staff to be extremely unhelpful and rude - and they were all on their mobile phones not interested in looking up at all! Very annoying when you've PAID for a ticket!

Wonderful finds on view. This museum has loads to offer: you can spend hours strolling through rooms with the most wonderful archaeological finds: from Persia, ancient Troy, Roman finds - we especially loved the sarcophagi, which were fantastic.

Don't miss Ishtar Gate treasures. This museum is a bit of a mess, at least it was in Oct. 2015, when much of the main building was being renovated. There are no printed brochures, so it is very difficult to know where to find things at the Archeological Museum. There are (at least) three buildings in the same complex: the huge main building, the Ancient Orient building, and the Tiled Kiosk. To me, the best things were located in the smallish Ancient Orient building, which would be easy to overlook. This building contained incredible finds from ancient Sumer, Babylon, etc-- including many huge tile murals of animals from the Ishtar Gate. These are amazing, along with other things from the same collection. So don't miss the small Ancient Orient building. The Tile Kiosk is small and has some lovely things, too-- can be seen in a few minutes. The main building was just a mess, and much of what was on display was a seemingly endless collection of Greek and Roman sarcophagi and grave steles. I love Classical art, but this collection got monotonous in a hurry. This building also had an Istanbul thru the ages exhibition. The artifacts in it were generally uninteresting, and the information isn't that much more than a good intro chapter on the history of the city in a good guidebook.
A MUST for museum lover. If you are a museum lover, you'll love the place. There are so many thing to see from pre-historic, Romans, Arabs, and Turks.

Fine museum. There is a big renovation going on the main building but still so much to see. All items have also English text and audio guide is available. And so many cats at the yard and the small museum shop.

Some brilliant artefacts, some overload. The sarcofagi we're excellent, but very poorly lit (as was much of the Museum). The Babylonian and Hittite stuff was fabulous. The area that covered the city of Byzantium was really interesting- giving a very good picture of the layer upon layer of history to be found here. We'd looked forward to the section on Troy most of all. This was the most disappointing part- loads and loads of pottery ( from Troy I to Troy X)- with a few fantastic pieces of jewellery thrown in.They could really do with a 'highlights' leaflet (like the one at the British Museum) so the casual visitor doesn't get bogged down with the stuff that a visitor interested in the minutiae might like to see.
Exteremely well done,. This is a sight for those seriously interested in the ancient history of the region, as opposed to the Ottoman era. It is an enormous and well displayed and curated collection.

Currently under construction (2015). Since parts of the museum were under construction, we couldn't see about 30% of it.However, the museum is still worth the visit!The sculptures are amazing and the sarcophagi are beautiful.

Amazing works, poor presentation. They have some great works of antiquity here, but they really do them a disservice by not providing more information and context. There are some renovations ongoing so perhaps it will be better when the first floor is reopened. Despite the poor presentation, it is very worthwhile to visit, but I would recommend bringing your own guidebook.

Totally worthwhile. There are alot of worthwhile antiquities to see in this museum. It is well curated and I recommend that it be seen early in a visit to Istanbul. Visitors should take their time and look at everything.
Interesting collection of good artifacts. Great collection of statues, artwork, and manuscripts. My kids (ages 12-19) found it very fascinating. A lot of really well-kept antiquities.
great for history buffs. this is in the same enclosure as the topkapi, turn left before the gates and part way dn the hill. it's not too busy and does a great job of showing turkey's history

Under reservation but good value for money. The musea display an impressive collection of roman, assyrian, messopotamian and other culture statues, earthware and various other objects. A real treat for those people who love old cultures. You could wander the site for 3 hours easily. When leaving the entrence cross the street for the free photogalery.
Interesting historical museum. Amazing Museum if you need to know more about the history of Turkey. Excellent sections of different eras and countries. The artifacts and statues are well preserved.
Nice. Nice museum but small. We were with a tour guide.had a short tour and then time on our own. Good for relaxing day of sight seeing.

under construction. Part of the museum is under construction but the most important items are still there. The collection is excellent especially the Mesopotamian and the the Greek/Roman funeral statues.
A must see Museum. This Museum is amazing for history lovers. They have wonderful sections & most Famous Alexander The Great Bust. Every time I go to Istanbul, that's my spot to go first! Love it!
I spent some time there. It was raining and this made me visit the museum ahead of my original plan. To spend an hour. I ended visiting it for three hours.

Informative!!!. Located on walking sistance from sultanahmet district. This miseum is part of istanbul museum pass and is worth seeing if you have interest in history. You need atleast 3~4 hours to completely visit the museum.

A must. A must
You have to visit museum, it has a lot of great things to see inside it
And it is accessible by using the museums card

Amazing collections in different buildings. The Archeology collections are housed in several buildings. After reading reviews here I gave myself about 1 hour to wander through. I could have spent 3. The collections were fantastic, dating back to Neolithic times, fantastic story of the history of Istanbul, the tile museum was exquisite. Well worth a visit for those who have a fascination for archeology and this history of Turkey and surrounding areas.
One of the best in the world !. The building itself, the contents, the display make this museum a not to be missed attraction in Istanbul.

Surprisingly poor collection. Poor collection; non-informative, very basic descriptions. Very few truly unique items. Navigation between halls and buildings is virtually non-existent. Many sections are limited for visiting now (Oct/2015) due to ongoing maintenance work.
Great Museum. This was definitely a great museum. There were some restorations, but yet, I really enjoyed it due to the various items from all over the old empire! Fantastic!

Different buildings to wander through.. One exhibit I enjoyed was the tombs, and sarcophagus of the ancient peoples and many exhibits had stories about the individuals who had died and their loved ones that created these monuments to them. There is also a beautiful sculpture garden on the property, made up from broken artifacts from the region. It’s worth the trip to the museum just to see the garden.

Renovation. Located within the walls of Topkapi Palace, the Archaeological Museums comprise three separate collections: the Archaeological Museum itself, the Ancient Orient Museum, and the Tiled Kiosk Museum. Together, they comprise a world-class collection. Some of the most spectacular displays are the glazed bricks from the Ishtar Gate of Babylon depicting in bas-relief a series of aurochs (a wild ox now extinct), dragons (the sirrush, sacred to Marduk), and lions (sacred to Ishtar). It is the most complete collection of such creatures outside the Pergamon Museum in Berlin. The so-called Alexander Sarcophagus is even more significant but, unfortunately, is not on display. Indeed, most of the Archaeological Museum is closed for retrofitting and restoration, although one still can see a head from the Serpent Column in the Hippodrome and a fragment of the porphyry statue of the Tetrarchs in Venice. The closure of most of the halls will nevertheless be a disappointment to someone visiting for the first time.

Forget this museum - don't waste your time!!. I read some of the negative reviews on tripadvisor and despite this, decided to visit the museum. We had a Muzekart and luckily we didn't waste money on the entrance fee. It was a waste of time walking up the steep hill pushing a stroller along a cobbled road to reach the entrance; and a waste of 15lira on the audio guide.Most of the museum is closed for renovations. We couldn't find out way to most of the items highlighted in the museum audio guide. We visited in October 2015. I would rather enquire as to when the extensive renovations will be completed before venturing anywhere close to this museum!

Mummies! Sultan's Tiled Pavilion, Oldest Love Poem in the World!. A bit tricky to find by car/taxi, just above the Gulhane Tram Stop. They are renovating the buildings but the archaeological finds are amazing! The oldest multiplication table, and the oldest love poem carved onto cuneiform tablets thousands of years ago amazed. The lions and mythical creatures with snake tails that lined the road to Babylon are still vividly colored. Sumerian and Hittite statues and altars, beautifully carved Syrian tombs(even one skeleton) and the Egyptian mummy, will interest teenagers as well! The Sultan's Tiled Pavilion is beautiful, the geometric Arabic letters are interesting. The rare yellow and green tiles as well as the recessed, ornate fountain featured in Osman Hamdi Bey's painting are gorgeous.  There is a cafe serving pastries and few hot selections in the shaded courtyard. Prices are much more reasonable than at Topkapi Palace and service is friendly-do watch out for the aggressive kitties that will climb on the table and swipe your food. The pistachio cake and the generously sized latte were delicious!  There are no lines here, even on days when Topkapi Palace has dozens waiting to buy tickets. The 85TL five day Museum Card is sold here and at nearby Hagia Irene if you want to avoid the long lines at Topkapi or Hagia Sophia. HANDICAPPED VISITORS, there is a golf cart that will take you from the bottom of the hill next to the Gulhane Stop up to the Archaeological Museum and then further up to Topkapi Palace. Unfortunately there is only one golf cart, it doesn't seem to be running on a set schedule, and doesn't run during lunch hour.  During tulip season, walk down from Gulhane Station to the restaurant that has a beautiful terrace hanging over Gulhane Park.

very interesting. You can spend there hours! So many interesting exhibitions, so many interesting artefacts. Istanbul Archaeological Museum is must see for everybody who is interested in Istanbul and Anatolia history
It was okay. Much of the museum was under renovation, so it will probably be better when that's completed. Check out the tiled building!

Good but chaotic display, no free guides and lack of tourist info. Good display but as it is housed in several buildings a free map should be included in the ticket price. It is a pity that many halls are closed for restoration. Lack of information ( exit signs, WC etc). Some artifacts are poorly fixed and are in danger of being damaged ( for example I witnessed how close to tourists passing buy us located a gravestone ( display number 87.80) which has a crack in the foundation and is shaking when tourists are passing by. The 2nd floor has no seating area at all, I was glad a security offered me a chair to rest where I witnessed her answering the same question of tourists ( which way is the exit? Which way are the toilets?) over 50 times in 15 minutes. The museum management should definitely invest in posting the signs for guests' convenience.

Gorgeous!. A lovely museum next to the side entrance of the Topkapi Palace grounds. Well-worth spending time, but some is currently under renovation so you may not be able to enter all buildings. Anxious to visit during my next trip as ran out of time.

Under Renovation...Will be better when completed. We visited the Istanbul Archaeological Museum on our last day in Istanbul in September. Here is a summary of our review:PROS:• Mesopotamia Collection & Roman Era Artifacts. Although we had already visited other museums throughout Western Turkey, we did see unique collections here that we had not previously seen. We favored the Ancient Orient Museum exhibits, especially the Mesopotamia Collection. In the New Building of the Archaeology Museum, we were in awe of the Roman statues and artifacts of that era, especially the museum's displays of some of the very large intricately sculpted sarcophagi .CONS:• Under Renovation. Unfortunately, the museum is under renovation so portions of the Old and New Archaeological Museums are closed. And it appeared it was a considerable amount under renovation. After visiting the Ankara Ancient Civilizations Museum, Antalya Museum and Istanbul Turkish & Islamic Arts Museum, we were disappointed what small amount of collections that were on display. The Museum is actually divided into four buildings which seems a bit disjointed and can be confusing if you do not have a map and understand this in advance. Not sure if this is because of the renovations? • Don't buy the audio tour! We paid the same price for the audio tour as our admission ticket. We were so disappointed! Although it was in English, there were very few exhibits that offered audio. And if it did, the audio messages were usually very short, repetitive with the displayed signage and offered no opportunities for further in depth audio information.

Must be visited if you have interest on history. A huge, massive museum near Topkapi palace and Gülhane park. If you have a deep interest on archeology and history, you should visit this place and see the cultures of old greek and mesopothemians and many other old civilizations.

Troy artifacts excellent. A small part of the museum is being remodeled, but major pieces from that area are still on display. I recommend the audio tour (15TL) to give some structure to the huge exhibits. The exhibits from the many layers of excavations of Troy should not be missed.
A good mueusm. An interesting museum if you are pressed for time you could skip the upper two floors, I would have enjoyed the experience more if I had read up about it

Tranquil gardens, museum undergoing rennovation. We went there because all the guide books recommended it as the place to buy the Museum Pass (which, in fact, is freely available at slot machines all over the place). However, we enjoyed sitting in the gardens with a coffee and visiting most of the museum. It's very much an academic's museum.... you learn a lot.

One of the great museums. This has to be one of the world's great museums. The displays were excellent and the organization superb. The exhibits covering the different excavations at Troy were especially interesting as well as the sections on the Hittites. Worth as much time as you can spare.

An often overlooked museum.. This museum is well organized and easily navigated. In the Hittite section the Treaty of Kodesh is displayed. This is the first known recorded treaty, a copy of which resides at the United Nations in NY.
Archeology tour. If you appreciate the archeology, you must go there.Please stay at least 30 minutes there to analyze every ancient body.

A comprehensive museum of antiquities and relics from Turkey and the surrounding region. The museum is very large and hosts a number of exhibits ranging from the various dynasties that have called Turkey home; the Hitites, Lycians, Phryians and Ionians. There are also Mesopotamian, Assyrian, Greek/Roman and Egyptian exhibits as well. Definitely give it a couple of hours to get around it all. A great thing to do on a day where its raining. It was 15tl in, but again, you could use your Museum pass (85tl) to jump the queue.

Not for me but others may enjoy. I was bored, really bored here. No atmosphere, building works going on everywhere and everything very samey. A museum should entice and excite you wanted you to learn and discover more which this just didnt do. I would not recommend or return

Great things to be seen in this complex!. I won't say 'forget the Topkapi palace' but leave some energy for this collection. Right now it's being upgraded, but most things are still on show. There is also the appeal of an outdoor area strewn with mainly roman era ruins and columns with a cafe where you can take a break. It is far less crowded than most nearby places, and therefore less exhausting and frenzied. A highlight is a collection of items from the frieze on the approach wall in Babylon: the Ishtar Gate. There are sculptures, stonework, ceramics, tiles, etc, and good signage in english. You could spend several hours here easily.

Istanbul Archaeological Museaum. This museum has some wonderful artifacts. But they're under re-construction and it's a bit of a mess trying to get around the sites. Consider this before going and check updated reviews to see if the work is done.

history through the ages. for a building of this standing not well signposted the main building on the left deals with history through the ages statues ect impressive then tiles in next building over the road under renovation is another building still open to the public

Incredible artifacts - overwhelming collection. This museum is overwhelming! In a good way :) It is filled with literally centuries worth of artifacts of all kinds. Unlike the usual US museum, you can get right up next to many pieces (no touching please!). Since the museum is huge and there are so many items, it's rare that you have to rush. The entrance fee is low ... however, in this case, you might want to hire a guide or go with a group. I did, and it significantly enhanced the experience. Without a guide, it can be hard to knit a story together behind the pieces, since although they are well labelled, there are so many of them and so many intermingled cultures that it is easy to lose focus. If possible I'd suggest visiting more than once.

An illustrative lesson to the city's history. The museum provides items and illustration boards to explain the interesting and rich history of Istanbul. The nearby tile pavilion has beautiful tile and porcelain collections that is not to be missed.

Impressive collection. This museum has one of the best problems a museum can have: a massive collection that would daunt the most dedicated archaeologist or conservationist. It's only 15TL to get in, and while there is a significant portion of the museum currently being renovated (October 2015), there is still an impressive amount of items on display. That said, there isn't to much contextual information with the displays, mostly due to the haphazard nature of Archaeology at the turn of the century. If you're into antiquities, definitely worth an afternoon. The courtyard is a great place to take a break. The museum could definitely do with a guidebook.

Incredible collection, lighting needs improvement. Spent about 3 hrs and enjoyed every minute of this incredible place. 4 hrs would be ideal, but few places to rest and the garden cafe had no seating on a rainy day.

A pearl. We visit this museum 20 years ago and now after partial reopened we don't want to miss and I highly recommend for anyone it's interesting very professional arranged and the trip between the historical monuments was just unforgettable

Disappointing Archaeological Museum . We visited this museum as part of our Museum pass. Many (most) sections were blocked off. There were no signs giving instructions or directions and it was poorly curated with very few English descriptors. It had some great statues, stone sarcophagus etc but we had to guess re the history, location found etc. perhaps that's why it is under renovation - however it appears the renovations have stopped and it may be a long time before they are completed.
Unique pieces. For archeology lovers, look for Alexander's sarcophagus and other unique pieces, well organized and explained
Detailed historic review of Turkish archaeological findings. Nice museum, well organized. Placards in Turkish and English. VERY detailed place- felt I was back at University. Uses Museum pass

Ottoman Collection of Artifacts in Several Buildings. The Ottoman collection of archaeological finds is worth seeing. It's part of the Topkapi complex of buildings, and there's a nice cafe and book shop outside. The courtyard with cafe is serene and beautiful, and there are other re-purposed Topkapi structures to visit as well, depending on the collection and location.
Interesting . While you have a museum pass, have a try. Some interesting artifacts but nothing mind blowing. Like most istanbul museum very few information without guide.

Informative.. Very very informative and I think if you'll have a field trip, better go here and you'll get to have a lot of info about everything. This is included in the muzekart worth 80 lira. It's close to hagia irene and topkapi palace.
MUST SEE if you spend 3-4 days in Istanbul. Unfortunately worldwide underrated, perhaps because of the modest funds available for impressive displays, the contents are absolutely amazing.

Great content, but presentation needs upgrading. There were wonderful things to see, but you were not always certain what they were. Sometimes there were labels, but not always in places that were easy to read. If there was an acoustiguide, I missed it. Lighting was highly variable, with construction and renovation ongoing. I think when it is finished that will make a major difference. Even so, the complex, just outside of Topkapi Palace, should not be missed. And better air conditioning would be great - the day was over 90 degrees, and the AC was limited.

Muddled and confused Museum during renovations. We visited the museum at the end of September and "now" is perhaps not the best time to visit as the main building is undergoing major renovations and the exhibits in that part of the museum are a bit haphazard.There are three buildings making up the museum, one seemed to cover very early history, one is an old mosque which shows many examples of the area's ceramics and then the main building undergoing renovation. The first two are pleasant enough but the main building is currently a bit of a let down. Istanbul has such an amazing history through the millennia but the museum just doesn't manage to capture any of the excitement of the amazing history of the city.Perhaps I am being unfair and once the renovations are complete this might be a great place to visit but at the moment it is just a bit boring. An OK place to spend an hour or two on a wet afternoon (as we did) but considering it is next door to the Hagia Sofia and in the grounds of the Topkapi Palace, it could be (and perhaps will be in the future) so much more.

A really good museum to visit. This museum has some magnificent relics from the past - what you would expect in Turkey considering the amount of historical sites in the country. Located near other key attractions such as the Palace, Blue Mosque and Ayasofiya Mosque, this is a museum worth visiting to see some truly ancient artefacts, armour, weapons, etc.

Worth going just to see the Sarcophagai. This is included in your museum pass and is a series of 3 buildings holding different artifacts. The furthest building from the entrance holds an amazing collection of Sarcophagai from across the Middle East, from Mesopotamia to Lebonan and of course Egypt. The many crypts and tombs carved from marble are amazing and there is an interesting collection of stone grave markers carved in the likeness of the deceased (in the first building). Worth a visit.
Great Collection. While the collection is great, it's very poorly exhibited. In fact half of the museum is closed due to restorations
Amazing. This is a must visit........has the sarcophagus of Alexander the Great & so many other incredible displays. Free too

One of the great museums of the world.. This is a fascinating museum with artefacts from 5,000 years ago. Learnt more about that Assyrian and Baylonian empires, and the advent of writing. We spent 2 hours and had to rush through history of Istanbul and pottery exhibits. Could spent all day here if you were interested!
super. This is a little hidden gem on the grounds of the Topkapi palace. Definitely worth going and seeing, not really big but very interesting!!!

Museums to help gain some perspective on the history of Istanbul!. For lovers of history, this Museum is a must and helps one understand how modern Istanbul and Turkey stands at the crossroads of civilizations - and has for thousands of years. A nice, modern museum with modern displays and excellent lighting. Still under renovation!

Wonderful experience. Fantastic collection......would take more than one visit to take it all in. Rent the recorded info for better understanding and richer experience. If haven't eaten lunch, don't wait too long as café is small and runs out of many dishes.

World class collection spanning a few thousand years. there are 3 sections The main museum ,the Tiled Pavilion and The Museum of the Ancient Orient
Many priceless statues, sarcophagi ,are shown as well as Egyptian Babylonean and Mesopotamian
exhibits abound . Another highly recommended attraction
Go back, back before the time of Christ. It is close to impossible to take in all that this one of a kind museum provides so give yourself a lot of time. I suggest you go with a guide.

A Few Highlights, Not Much More. A museum full of Roman busts and navy-colored bowls, there's little that separates the Istanbul Archaeological Museums from its competition. There are a few exceptions: the Babylon mosaics that lined the entryway into the ancient city are a must-see, and I thoroughly enjoyed the sarcophagi, but the museum itself is poorly curated and the exhibits feel outdated. Furthermore, the museum was undergoing a large construction project at the time of my visit - hopefully, the renovations will enliven the museum and make it more engaging for visitors. The descriptions of each item were incredibly lengthy poorly written - I just didn't want to read them. Not the sort of environment a museum should strive for.This is a great activity if you are stuck with a rainy day or a few hours to burn, but there are certainly much better attractions in the city.

Fabulous collection. we started our Topkapi experience at the Archaeological museum : all the rest of the tourists seemed to be following tour guides doing anti-clockwise, so we more or less had the place to ourselves at 9am.

Amazing. So much history in all the four museums in the vicinity...wish i had more time to explore but was very thorough due to time....its right near the gulhane park and topkapi museum and a must do if your interested in history....pre islamic roman byzantinian ottoman etc...so much to see and amazing

Not Very Impressive. Half of it was under renovation and closed. If you have been to some of the major museums, like British Museum, MMA, Louver, or Hermitage, this one is not even close. Not too many, a few, master pieces. I would recommend it if you have some extra hours and no other plan. Museum pass is accepted here.

A must see for visitors. While this museum was under construction during my visit, several sections were open to visitors. it offered, as expected, a unique insight into the history of Istanbul and Turkey. The staff could have been more helpful or less...rigid but overall a pleasant experience.

Not what we were after but oh well.... So we were looking for the palace and came through a side entrance along the tram line (not the front entrance). We entered this place thinking it was the palace (clearly missed the sign above the gate...haha). We took the audio tour which was handy in some parts and completely useless in others. A lot of the place is closed due to restoration/renovations. It wasn't what we were after but we don't regret going.

Excellent museums. Situated by the Topkapi Palace. Not to be rushed. Nice to have time to time have a coffee in the excellent cafe in the gardens. There are quality items in the archeological museum and the Oriental museum. there is also a small tile museum which is pleasant.

Items without a story. This is not well curated. It is difficult to put any timeline or continuity to the items displayed. The time becomes viewing a series of items without help understanding the importance to history.
Worth Visiting. A very large collection, but parts of it are now under renovation. it is located between Topcape and Gulhan Park.

A fine collection of antiquities..... There are three museums - the Archaeological museum, the Ancient Orient Museum and the Tiled Kiosk Museum (my favourite) all based in the same complex.During the time of our visit in September many of the areas were undergoing renovations but we managed to get a flavour of the periods covered.Entry is covered by the museum card. Unlike other venues in Istanbul there were no queues and it was a pleasure to be able to view the exhibits in one's own time. Unfortunately, the comprehensive museum guide included in the ticket price had run out (the English version)Two of the buildings have several steps but there is a ramp to enter the Sarcophagus.Be sure to view the Karaman Mihrab (beautifully tiled), the Alexander Sarcophagus and the Treaty of Kadesh tablet which is the world's earliest surviving peace treaty.Archaeological finds dot the shded, restful grounds and there is a lovely outdoor cafe as well.Due to time restrictions we spent about 2 hours here but to do justice to the museum about 4 hours is recommended.
Fascinating place. Highly recommend. The important historical items on display are amazing. We spent a couple of hours and could have stayed all day. Would definitely go back.

So much history!. The Istanbul Archeological Museum is amazing! We must return to Istanbul to completely view the entire museum. The centuries of history held within this one building can be overwhelming. Luckily we had a guide to help sort through the rooms. A must see when visiting Istanbul and plan adequate time.
Nice. Nice place to be there we were there with friends very good arkeoloji place if you have a time you can visit...

It takes time to see something so fine!. Although the museum is under reconstruction presently (Sep2015), there is a lot to see and absorb! Remarkable, but it takes time to see such wonderful history. Luckily they have a coffee shop/café and place to rest weary feet. Recommended when you are not in a hurry to go somewhere else.

Lots to see, but not all in English. This museum was just okay. It's quite large and the English translations are a mixed bag. I really enjoyed getting to go through and look at everything, but didn't always grasp the historical context because most everything was in Turkish. It rained most days I was in Turkey (December), so at least this was out of the cold!

Not to be missed. Intetesting collevtion, especially the Mesopotamian objects and the Hittites orthostats. The museum was still heavily under renovation as of September, but many objects on display. I recommend a visit anyway.

Many of the galleries are closed due to extensive renovation.. Compared to the Museum of Anatolian Civilizations in Ankara, which we visited a week earlier, the Istanbul Archaeological Museum palls by comparison. Perhaps this is because a good two-thirds of the galleries are closed for renovation, which isn't expected to be completed until the end of 2019. The museum's collection of antique tiles, in no way compares to what we saw in Topkapi. The Archaeological Museum of Istanbul has the potential of becoming one of the world's best places to view sculpture from Classical Greece and Rome, but because so many of the galleries are closed, I'd wait several years before going back. I'm sure the renovation, which is quite extensive, will provide the museum with a good deal more exhibit space. As things now stand, many of the galleries are closed and not that well curated.. .
Average. Worth a visit on a wet Sultanahmet day but not a sunny day.I visited as part of the Musuem card. The mummy section is superb but the rest is dull.

Great Museum!!!. Wow! They have the whole history of the area here; hittites, Byzantium, Romans, you name it. It's under construction now, but still quite a remarkable place. You can get up close and personal to all the amazing works of art. Don't miss this if you are a history buff.
hard to believe antiquities. Artefacts and sarcophagi more that 2000 years old - some just lying around, some on display in different rooms - but all up close and personal! Unbelievable!

Great Museum, Doing a little construction. I was excited to see this museum as archaeology is one the reason I wanted to go to Turkey in the first place. The museum is made of a few buildings surrounding a cafe and courtyard. So it's got a nice layout and the cafe is quite a nice spot to sit and have a coffee or something. The content is mainly house in three buildings. The collection has some absolutely amazing things, statues and mosaics, seals and tools, a section of graves and sarcophagai (or -guses or however you pluralize that one) seals and tablets. Some of which date back to the beginnings of recorded history. If you like archaeology, this is definitely worth checking out. It's also in the complex with Topkapi Palace and Hagia Irene, so it's easy to roll into the day.

Fascinating and endless. Go back in time and get lost in the fascinating and well presented exhibits. So much to see and soooo interesting , I love this museum especially the hundreds of Roman statues of Constantinople , pre historic remains of civilizations long dead, and just a beautiful setting and lovely garden ! Love it - even watched Escape from Seraglio performed there twice !

Down Hill from Topkapi Palace and worth a visit.. Located just down the hill from the entrance of the Topkapi Palace, this Museum has so many archaeological treasures it makes your head spin. I visited after spending quite a few hours at the Palace and perhaps did not do it justice to take in all the fascinating artifacts on display.At the time of my visit (September 2015) there appeared to be a bit of the Museum closed off for renovations - but there was still plenty to see,

Middle East Archaeology. A visit to the Istanbul Archaeological Museum will give you great perspective on the archaeology of this part of the world. If you want a great contrast go to this archaeology museum and then make a trip to the modern museum. you won't see anything like this anywhere else in the world...ancient to modern.
unexpected delight. This was an unexpected delight. Not too big but full of incredible things. This is located behind Topkapki Palace.

great treasures...!. great archaeological treasures to be seen! the exhibits cover a large collection even though most of what they have they cannot display - and currently a large section is under renovation so it is limited. nevertheless its a great museum! make sure to also see the mosaic museum and the other museum in the complex as well.

Good museum but undergoing renovations. This museum is currently undergoing renovations so a lot of the exhibits are closed or require a revamp. However the exhibits itself were very interesting.
What we were impressed with was the amount of detail. They went into a lot of history of Turkey which is great for people who don't have a detailed background.
Overall good museum.

a good place to visit. It is about a big museum showing archeological items from many historical eras, usualy this place is not crowded and easy to visit, I personaly liked most the statues section, while visiting istanbul give this place a visit it's worth it.
Must see. I am happy that I have a chance to visit this museum. It has outstanding collections of ancient artifacts. It worth the time to see.

Fifty Percent is Under renovation. Wife really wanted to see the Alexander the Great portion of the museum. As of August of 2015 much of the museum is under renovation and the Alex part is totally blocked off. That said, the remaining portions were interesting and with good English information. There are four floors so there is much to see. The elevator is for handicapped only so be prepared to climb a lot of stairs. We still spent over an hour seeing what was accessible. The museum is located below the Topkapi Palace and above the Alemdar Cad. So you have a climb up or down...happily they provide a free 'golf cart' ride in both directions. While we were there it was in the high 80 degrees F and the driver took us up and to the exit of the Topkapi Palace exit. While the ride was free I did tip him a couple of TL of which he seemed pleased. Good service should not go unrewarded IMO.

A definite must see. As archaeological museums go, this is a good one. We spent about 3 hours there for about 7 Euros each. They only take cash.They check backpacks,etc. but not purses. The explanations of the pieces are in English and Turkish, so that was welcome. In August, it was warm in some rooms, but there are stand alone air conditioners in them. Parts of the museum are air conditioned in the standard way, however. Many antiquities and several floors to view in several buildings. We could have stayed longer. There is a little cafe on the grounds and we had lunch there. Kind of expensive, but it was adequate for our needs. Not much variety. There were several cats roaming the cafe, looking for food-just like the pigeons hang around the water areas in many places.

Best of the museum card ones. I spent 3 hours inside, just because I had to hurry for the other ones. If you are interested in history this is going to be very interesting, especially the oriental history room

Best Museum Ever. Having read a few of the reviews on here, I was a little apprehensive: would everything be closed, would the English-language signs be of poor quality, etc. having now visited, I can say that these negative reviews are absolute rubbish. This is easily one of the best museums I have ever been to (on a par with the British Museum, for example), with so many amazing things that they have ancient monuments strewn in the gardens around the café and the palace more generally. When other reviewers have mentioned contradictory information next to the exhibits, I can only assume they must be referring to the section on the various contradictory myths about the city's founding. I assume it will be clear to most why the information here will be contradictory in nature.The ancient orient building was brilliant - my favourite bits were the actual friezes from the gates of ancient Babylon, but there was loads more here including an actual Hamurabai Code!The next building concerned Anatolia through the ages, in which we learned about the evolution of the representation of emotion and of specific individuals in sculpture, as well as seeing a fragment of Constantine the Great's tomb and the chain put across the Golden Horn to stop the Ottomans in 1453 (oops).Building #3 was all about tiles, and was equally brilliant.Finally, hidden behind signs (and smells) for the toilets, we found another building full of ancient sarcophagae (?) and a couple of reconstructed temples. This really was indicative of the whole museum: so understated, and yet full of amazing things.Brilliant!

Under extensive renovation, but what is available is still worth a look . Definitely worth a look of you buy the museum pass. Maybe less so if you pay a standalone ticket. It depends just how much you like historical artefacts and the documentation of shifting civilizations and cultures, which is really highlighted very well at this museum. 5-day museum passes were being sold for the same price as 3-day passes because, I think, all of the renovation currently (sept 2015) going on not just in this museum, but in the Hagia Sofia, the Harem at Topkapi Palace and a few of the other museums.This museum has a great collection of busts, friezes, reliefs, statues, earthenware, ceramics, and prehistoric items not just from the anatolia region, but all around Greece, byzantium, and the neighbouring middle east. I enjoyed it, but there's still only so many pots, statues, and shards a person can take and I did get museum-weary after a few hours.

Amazing Collection. It's currently undergoing restoration work so some pieces were not available, but even with that in mind...the current exhibits are amazing quality pieces. It definitely rivalled the British Museum in quality for me if not in quantity.It's just a short walk from Topkapi and so quiet in comparison! A nice contrast to fill an afternoon personally. There are 3 buildings to visit in total, a neat gift shop and a small cafe in the central area that does the basics.Toilets are situated in the museums and clearly sign posted. It can get quite hot in there so be sure to stay hydrated :)Best picks - Hittite collection in the Orient museum, head of the serpentine column in the main building (rest of which is in the Hippodrome).

Restoration is underway and this spoils the impact. There are some very lovely and quite outstanding objects in this museum, including a Medusa head like the ones in the Basilica Cistern, but this time in good light and the right way up. There is extremely good signage all round but reading through it all would take all day and the section on the artefacts from Troy is simply too overwhelming to take in on just one visit. However it is peaceful and tranquil without too many visitors so there are plenty of reasons to enjoy your visit here.
Good museum. Good museum with nice exposition. Some really rare items can be found there. Some part of the exposition is closed due to the renovation.

Huge amount to see here. MuseumThe Roman section is currently closed. There are four buildings and some exhibits outside along with a reasonably priced cafe with shady outside seating and a museum shop.Toilets located at the end of the garden. There was only one building that we could see was accessible with a ramp the others all had steps although there may have been an alternative enter acne we did not see for disabled.It was well laid out in regions and time periods and most exhibits had an English label. There were more detailed explanations on a separate board although these were often poorly translated There is some beautiful Ottoman pottery and mosaics, a huge display of sarcophogi and displays from Hittite period we have not seen in any other museum. There is a big section on Troy. There is an audio tour available

Interesting . Quite a large museum didn't see all of it but enough to helpYou understand the age of this beautiful country and where and what and how everything happened. Quite an insight into turkeys history. I'm not a huge museum buff but enjoyed getting more of an understanding of the age and artefacts and importance of such history. Definitely worth the walk through and you can use your museum pass.

Soon-. This was an excellent showcase of a wide variety of artifacts from multiple historical periods, and was a great way to get an overview of the rather intimidating amount of history Istanbul and Turkey in general represent. I will add though, that it is currently under work, so not all areas of the museum are open, there are quite a few dead ends and closed off areas that I'm sure will be great- eventually. There is also quite a bit of walking, and the air-conditioning is (currently at least) single units that work wonderfully when standing in close proximity, leaving large areas of the museum rather warm for summer visits. Still, it was a great experience and I would have loved to go back and take another look if time had permitted.

Another civilisation. You realise about another civilization only when you see it. The Imperial museum is huge, nicely kept and well maintained. A must see during Istanbul visit. Buy the museum pass, works out cheaper and you do not need to stand in long queue.

Empty but cool. That museum is close from Topkapı palace and I do not know why but it was empty. I was almost alone there whereas it is a really good museum, perhaps one of the best for history stuffs.

Fascinating if you like 'old'. Great tip allowed us to buy our museum pass here and avoid queues and so we visited something we otherwise wouldn't have.Glad we did, as hard to appreciate the age of human life in the region until you see it.

step into the ancient world. this museum stands out of one of the best I have visited. There are no interactive elements for children which is ashame but what is in the grounds and under roof ... a must see.
What an amazing place. The museum was fascinating. I was impressed by the kind of relics on show. It was excellent. We thoroughly enjoyed our visit.
Istanbul Archaeology Museums. A really good museum showing many archaeological and artistic pieces from Istanbul and Turkey. Parts were under renovation when we were there.

Excellent and informative. we visited after Topkapi... this is a well designed museum... well divided and you get enough information in english... so many places to sit and relax if you are tired... so a perfect place for kids and elderly interested in history...
Close to Gulhane Park. Visit all 4 museums, some under renovation and then enjoy walking in Gulhane park , you can dine there or walk to the end and have tea

an interesting museum, worth spending a couple of hours. The archeological museum complex can be accessed from the same courtyard as the Topkapi Palace. Here you can see a series of Hittite, Egyptian, Hellenistic and Ottoman artefacts: the peace treaty of Kadesh, objects found during the excavations at Troy and, the piece de résistance, the sarcophagus that is said to have held the body of Alexander the Great.For more info on what to visit in Istanbul try: http://theplanningmonster.gq/Theplanningmonster/English/Entries/2015/8/29_Istanbul_-_Where_The_East_Meets_The_West.html

Delighted.. Istanbul Archaeological Museum is the proof of the richness of its history on this land. thousands of years back it goes and all of a sudden you feel so happy to be witnessed and a part of it. I was delighted.

Visit if you have extra time. The entrance fee to the museum is 15 TL per ticket. The museum is big but part of it is under construction, therefore there's not much to see at the moment. They have quite a number of interesting exhibits. It's not necessary a place that is must visit when in Istanbul. Furthermore, since the big part of the museum is under construction, they shouldn't charge a full ticket fee.

NOT to be missed. My only regret is that we did to leave enough time for this spectacular collection. There are treasures from antiquity on the ground floor and a very well laid out informative collection that is quite an education on the upper floors.
Istanbul Family Trip. Amazing collection at this museum, it ranks with the top museums in Europe and should not be missed, along with the museum of Islamic art near the Hippodrome.
Rainy day visit. Very big museum, you can see artifacts from Troy, Gordium, and other ancient sites. Great to visit on a rainy day.

A door opening to great history. It is one of the best museum that I have ever visited. From the many sections in it you can travel through history. You can find things from Anatolian, African, Mezopotamian Civizilations and etc.. You will definitely enjoy visiting this museum

Full of history!. beautiful building, full of sculptures, pictures and history! even has mummies!!
needs time tough.site was also under partial restoration in April 2015
great view into Turkish history. It consists of 3 building all featuring different aspects of history of Turkey. Plan on at least 2 to 4 hours here, it's big.
So so. We went to there's but simple place no need to go there's better go other place we dont like it.. its not special place nothing more. ...
Masterpiece. A long journey into rich historical heritage spanning several thousand years. Unforgettable experience.

Istanbul's complex history in a huge variety of exhibits. I'd like to have spent time over several days in order to take everything in, but sadly this wasn't possible. There is a huge amount of material from every period of the city's history, and for many of the surrounding areas, all very well displayed and explained. Parents take note: this is a museum for adults. There is none of the child-friendly, interactive, dumbing down that seems to be compulsory in British museums these days.Admission is covered by the General Museums Pass, which can be purchased at any of the participating attractions, and gives you reduced ticket prices, 10% off purchases from their shops, and fast track entry.

An Interesting But Dry Museum. Apparently featuring over 1,000,000 individual artefacts, the museum itself certainly occupies a large space!Highlights would be the Tiled Kiosk and its collection of ceramics, as well an impressive collection of sarcophagi. If you are particularly interested in the history of Istanbul, it is well conveyed with supporting displays.If you opt for an audio-guide, be sure to read the plaques as well, as they contain more in-depth information.

Reminds me of field trips in school. I had access through purchasing the 5day Museum Pass, otherwise it is 15 lira separately purhased. It is at the south of the Top Kapi Palace and directly across the Gülhane tram station. Contains treasures of the TopKapi, with plenty of sarcophagi and steles, and samples of Turkey's architecture from centuries back.Putting together that collection is seriously hard work. Medusa's head is a center piece at the stairs. Overall, it is the museum experience you'd recall as a child in primary school, quiet and "too educational", but it feeds a hunger for curiosity and information. In that, it becomes a beautiful experience.

A Llovely and Most Interesting Experience. This museum is in a very easy reach area. In-between Aya Sofia and Blue Mosque.It's not as crowded as the other two but, most captivating. Allow plenty of time to enjoy. Once you are in, you'll find yourself just keep wondering up and down, in and out, not wanting to leave as the display and layouts are beautifully kept in different sections and spread out in 2/3 floors. The air-con here is very strong. Some of the smaller halls might be quite cold.We went in a late afternoon, just around two hours before closing. So there were few people around. Recommended.

Great but needs time.... Very interesting collection but it needs time....maybe if u like to take ur time, spare 2 to 3 hours...
Watch out: some areas are badly airconditioned if u are going in this period and it is under big renovation works so same areas are closed...

Extensive and interesting. This museum really needs to be given a lot of time. I would recommend setting aside at least a full morning/afternoon to really get to grips with the place. The cafe is overpriced. I would not recommend this as a visit for families with young children as there are no interactive exhibits although there may be once it has been refurbished. There is huge amount to see and it is, in most parts. well set out and largely accessible.

Future archaeologist. Im studying Archaeology, and was something very beautiful to visit this Museum for me. I appreciate the opportunity. I went there with friwnds and most of the parts of museum were closed for public, but this part that we were able to see was very nice!

Incredible must see. Despite being half closed for (very extensive) renovations the Museum still provided a wonderful coverage of the incredible archaeological history of the region, covering 3 empires, and enhanced by very detailed written explanations of the displayed items. A world class must see.

Worth a visit. Renovation work going on to make the buildings earthquake proof so only partially open. No discount offered on the museum card mind. Spent a couple of hours wandering around and there was plenty to see and read. Useful way to find out history about the city. Nothing interactive whatsoever - maybe that's what the renovation is really all about... though I doubt it!
Very interesting and good museum. Very interesting and good museum with amazing collections. Bring some time to see everything and enjoy the area around the museum.

Lots to see. There are many items from important archeological areas throughout Turkey stored here, such as Troy, Pergamon, and Ankara. Not many areas with air-conditioning, but everything is inside. Most signs also in English

Highs and Lows. Due to the renovation, it really took away how nice the place can be. Very nice, classic , REALLY old arrifacts. Walking thru a "garden " of old marble statues was awesome. Will go back....when renovations are done.

multi building complex w thousands of fascinating artifacts. This multi building complex houses thousands of cultural artifacts that range from a plethora of centuries, highlighting the complex history of the modern day Turks. Particularly meaningful where the pieces housed in the exquisite blue tiled pavilion, with its detailed mosaics and gorgeous stained glass

Excellent!. The Istanbul Archaeology Museums is a group of three archeological museums located in the Eminönü district of Istanbul, Turkey, near Gülhane Park and Topkapı Palace.The Istanbul Archaeology Museums consists of three museums: Archaeological Museum (in the main building) Museum of the Ancient Orient Museum of Islamic ArtIt houses over one million objects that represent almost all of the eras and civilizations in world history. Plan a spending several hours in here. Highly recommend if you love learning about history.
Loads of history here. The museum has loads of things to see from dozens of empires that ruled the area. I especially liked the detailed explanations that accompanied certain rooms and artifacts.

Very well presented historical materials. This is a complex of several museums including ancient middle east (with very interesting exhibits from Babylon and elsewhere), tiles, a "new" section with Greek, Roman, Turkish and ancient materials, and an "old" section that focuses on burials and sarcophogi. The main museum is undergoing restoration and renovation so large parts are closed off (entry to the old museum is via a back stair near the toilets!) but the materials on display are beautiful and well presented. The time period covered is enormous and there is sufficient information available to appreciate the context of the exhibits. A very nice feature is the cafe set in a garden of ancient stone artefacts and overlooking the park below.

Well-worth the visit-loved the Tiled Kiosk!. There are several sections to the Museums-the Tiled Kiosk is full of amazing mosaics and stained glass windows, plus all kinds of ceramic vases, tiles, etc. In one of the other buildings, there are statues and stonework from the Mesopotamian region. If you like old history, this is the place to go!

Great collection, exhibit chaos. There are truly mind blowing artefacts in this collection. But it is hard to find them. At the moment they are retrofitting the main buildings to make them earthquake proof. This really changes the experience. Most of the contextual displays are quite dated and it seems like you can only access a small maybe 50% of what will be open once complete. However, what we did see was amazing. It is very much an old atmospheric museum, like Kubrick meets Night at the Museum. Little context notes on the majority of artefacts. But the best, as ever speak for themselves. Do visit but only after Hagia Sofia, the blue mosque, the palace and the cistern.

Lots of history! . A lot of hsitory to see, I would say more than in Hagia Sophia and topkapi... Must see! For science don't waste your time with the Islamic science and technology and the maritime museum. Skip directly to Rahmi M. Koc Museum!

History of istanbul. It's a wonderful place including so many things made by (stone-marble-wood-iron-metal) which will amaze you .you can find there a lot of historical things from Egypt-Iran-Syria,..it has a several building to visit and each one takes time about 1 hour and totally 3 hours need to visit it but don't remember to take Audio guide (different language Persian-Arabic-English-Turkish,...)

Perfect if you like this kind of thing. The museum was only 15 tr which is around 8 aud. very good value for what was inside the museum as it as absolutely everything from around troy, Ephesus, Babylon.p, etc...It was under renovation when we were there which was the only downside.

Great Country Geography Results in a Great Museum. The geography of Turkey places it in the center of world history - from the earliest civilizations in Mesopotamia, through the Hittites, Alexander the Great, Greece, Troy, Romans (Constantine), the Byzantine empire and finally the Ottoman empire. The city of Istanbul was critical to the speed of Christianity (Constantine) and Islam (the Ottomans).With this history, you would expect the archeology museum to have great artifacts and they do. But equally impressive is the organization and presentation of their incredible collection. My wife and I spent 4 hours going through four buildings (with a stop for iced coffee in the lovely garden restaurant) and enjoyed all parts of the museum. The exhibition goes back 400,000 years with artifacts from hominid settlers (well before modern humans left Africa) and has an extensive collection of materials from early civilizations including the Babylonians, Assyrians, Greeks, Romans, etc. While not as slick as the Archeology Museum in Mexico City, this was one of the nicest archeology museums I have ever seen. Certainly better than the Egyptian Museum in Cairo.

Lots of interesting things. I would give this a 3, my husband gives it a 4. He thought that the items in the museum were especially interesting, including the world's first treaty (admittedly that was pretty cool) and other early cuneiform documents. I was less impressed, most due to the fact that I have found other museums in the world to have a more robust collection with more widely varying items; and that a ton of the museum was under renovation and closed off to the public. Still probably worth a visit if you have the time, which you will need a lot of. We tried to get through it relatively quickly and it took us forever and we didn't even see everything.

istanbul archealogical museum. Almost overwhelming in volume of material. This venue is frequently overlooked but well worth the time if you have it.not only for the wealth objects but of the ancient middle east..but I..wish there more documentation of "the chain"... It should be clear that I am very prejudiced and love Turkey...and Istanbul...and find both eternally fascinating. Taxi drivers are another story! Avoid if at All possible!

Must See - The one of the things you shouldnt miss, no matter of your interests. This is the place that has WOW effect. First time I was there I stayed 5 hours. i was blown away. Second time, i stayed for 4.5 hours. Its like all cultures, all places in the world are put in one place- one place to amaze you. Second time I went there Alexander's sarcophagus was in basement, reconstructed and hidden from public.

Excellent Archaeological Collections. This is a quality museum with some excellent collections spanning many historical civilisations. It is huge and you need to commit at least 3 hours to do justice to some of the artefacts, realistically you could spend longer. This is one of the best things to do in Istanbul.
Just ok. I expected more. Of course, I'm sure much is sitting in museums in other parts of the world. But there was some interesting things. Audio was quite week on information

So many beautiful artifacts. Mind boggling collection. Spent over an hour in the Ancient and then realised that it was a mere precursor. A large section was closed due to earthquake works but the rest still required the rest of a very long day to appreciate the thoughtfully laid out exhibits. Loved the Troy segment

One of the best museums I visited. I love history and I didn't expect to see that many things in this museum. First of all, you have 4 museums and another one is in restoration.The museum is in the Gulhane Park, near Topkapi Palace. They also have a terace where you can eat or have a tea/coffee if you want to take a break. You have a lot of interesting things to see, one of the building is only with sarcophagi, two with findings from different areas of Turkey from different times and the forth with tiles. The entrance fee is 15 TL, but it's included in the Museum Pass.
Interesting Museum. Many wonderful archaeological finds and fun for a few hours to explore. Would only go here if I were staying in Istanbul and had extra time to kill.

I would recommend skipping Istanbul Archaeological Museums. On our 2nd day in Istanbul, 24th February 2015, after visiting Arasta Bazaar we visited Istanbul Archaeological Museums at 1:15pm. As the name suggests, it is a set of museums, all situated next to each other, the details are: ARCHAEOLOGICAL MUSEUM: Opened in June 13, 1891, Extensive collection of classical statuary and sarcophagi plus a sprawling exhibit documenting İstanbul's history. TILED KIOSK MUSEUM (Museum of Islamic Art): (Çinili Köşk Müzesi): About 2000 artifacts belonging to Seljuk, Anatolian and Ottoman tiles and ceramics dating from the end of the 12th century to the beginning of the 20th century.ANCIENT ORIENT MUSEUM: (Eski Şark Eserleri Müzesi): This 1883 building consists of the sections of Pre-Islamic Arabian Art, Egypt Collection, Mesopotamia Collection, Anatolia Collection, Urartu Collection and Cuneiform Documents.Together, this is a huge museum! So huge that its difficult to go through it in one go but as it has a combined ticket thus you are obliged to do so. Although I like history and museums but there was a lot of non-interesting stuff present there. I mean unless you are a history student, you might skip through 60% of the artifacts on display there. What I liked was TILED KIOSK MUSEUM but that was also because I had not visited any Ottoman building by then, after visiting various mosques, I felt there was no need to visit TILED KIOSK MUSEUM. So unless you are really into history and you have ample amount of time, I would recommend skipping Istanbul Archaeological Museums.Location: 41.011704, 28.981420 (İstanbul's Sultanahmet neighborhood, on the Osman Hamdi Bey slope connecting the Gülhane Park with the Topkapı Palace) Opening Time: Tues – Sun, 09:00 – 5pmClosed on MondaysTickets Booth Closes at 4pmTicket: 15 TL (Included in Museum Pass) Time Required: 4hrGetting there: Use T1 to reach Gülhane Terminal

Prehistoric treasures in Istanbul. I very much enjoyed my visit to this liitle bit less visited part of the Sultanahmet area, the place has many different pre-historic objects and the stories are well told. I especially enjyoed seeing those babylonian plates. Parts were closed when I was there, but still it was a gret treat to walk around there and the place still had a lot to offer.

Well worth a visit but currently undergoing renovations. This museum has some wonderful pieces and is always worth a visit . At the moment it is undergoing some major renovations and a large part of the exhibit halls were closed.
Huge. Tons of buildings that were museums. It had alot of historical artifacts and most of the statues had a nose job

Definitely worth the time and entry fee . For only 15 Turkish lira you get three museums, a small, medium and large. Could spend hours here. The collections ranges from prehistoric to thru ottoman, with roman, Greek, Babylonian, Hittite and more. Very interesting. Major restoration underway in main building but still very good for less than $6 U.S.
History. This museum is well organized, quite modern and well explained. If you are interested in learning more about Turkish history, which I was pretty ignorant of, it is worth your time.

Incredible step back in time. This was truly an great visit. I would not miss it. There was a remodel going on during our visit so not sure what we missed. However, there were lots of great exhibits and the marble statues were truly amazing. Made you pause and wonder at what it took to create these incredible pieces.

amazing museum. the most beautiful thing in this museum it is the museum itself is historical from ottoman age and inside this old museum oldest things like istanbul gate alexander tomb mome tombs and if you art lover you will adore this museum you will see millions of arts by the way i spent about 4 hours in this museum and didn't finish it because i read about everything and they close near 6:00 pm as i remember

A MUST FOR ART LOVERS. Too bad that the sarcophagus of Alexander the Great was on restoration but worth the visit. Housed in three buildings, its exhibits include ancient artefacts, classical statuary and an exhibition tracing İstanbul's history. There are many highlights, but the sarcophagi from the Royal Necropolis of Sidon are particularly striking.

A wonderful museum. A wonderful museum of historically significant items.A very enjoyable and impressive location in Istanbul showing history, culture and the ancient world.I highly recommend visiting this site

Nice. Huge place with plenty to see..nearby topkapi precinct leading outside gulhane. ..this place was a delight..however..only if one is into statues and interested in this form.of.history..It was informativeWe enjoyed but also realised that this was our 6th museum we were seeing..by this time..one is kinda bored seeing almost same things..one just tends to sift through it..Guess I am not such a history buff after all..I want it all..bit of this Anda bit of that to make it more complete for me

Collection of the Orient. This museum is next to the Archeological Museum, full of collection of the Orient. Highly recommended things to be seen are collection from the ancient Egypt and Babylon. Worth visiting! Keep in mind, be quiet when you look around things exhibited here. Other people are trying to concentrate on seeing.

Only when you have time to spare. Went here with my instanbul card. The museum contains a lot of pieces but it is also exhibited in an unorganized manner. The descriptions in English are written in bullet points, which are very difficult to follow.In June it was also under construction. There center piece (Alexander sarcophagus; a sarcophagus with engravings of Alexander) was not on display.disappointing. so spare the time an go to Topkapi palace; it gives you more insights (although it is also a bit 'coloured' in its descriptions)
if you have time... the place is very interesting if you are an archeology buff...otherwise you can just head for another beauty of the city...

Great if you know where to look. The archaeology museum is currently undergoing restoration, so there are sections completely closed (including the Kings tomb). The first building I didn't find very interesting at all, however, the building to the right contains some amazing Egyptian crypts! They were the highlight!

Huge and diverse. I went when there was restoration and I think I missed more than half of the good parts, but still that took me a good hour or two to finish the building. Some stuff you will be familiar with if you're a frequent museum visitor, but other small exhibitions in the nearby buildings make the trip to this venue worthwhile.

Needs some better organisation. They've got so many beautiful and interesting things but they are poorly exposed and all mixed out. If you go there thinking that you may find particular things that they've moved there from some archeological sites in Turkey, you'll probably lose 2 hours for looking for it and then you'll find it that it's not even exposed...

unforgettable impression. to tell you the truth this is one of the most interesting and beautiful places i have ever visited; and what might be interesting for tourists the entrance fee is very reasonable only 15 TL, and believe me you'll get tremendous pleasure from visiting this wonderful museum, of course if you are interested in ancient civilization and history...i have spent almost the whole day there, visiting some exhibition hall more than once... if you get tired or hungry you can rest and have some refreshments in the museum garden... i am simply in love with this spot and i will definitely visit it again if i have a chance...

See ancient collection then enjoy the sculpture garden at the café . When traveling with our family we try to plan something for everybody. I suspected that the archeology exhibits would appeal to me and our son but was pleasantly surprised that the outdoor setting of the museum café, dotted with hundreds of ancient sculptures, would prove memorable to us all.

A very poor showing . You'd think this would be one of the most important stops in istanbul but alas museums are not generally well done in turkey. Holding nonetheless and important collection I encourage a visit. The musuem is very poorly maintained and has a musty 70s sense to it. It is down the hill from the Topkapi palace and is included in the price of the musuem card, so you might as well visit if you have the time. If history and archeology are not on top of the list don't bother at all. 1-2 hours for the full visit.

Glad I went.... This was an interesting museum with some unique pieces from all over the ancient world. The audio guide was good, the museum well laid out and reasonable compact. We had 5 days in Istanbul but if you've only a limited time in Istanbul, I'd give it a miss.

Good collection. A good collection of artifacts but we were unable to see everything because of some of the renovations going on. Still had some very good statues and examples of columns from each period

Glad I went. I nearly didn't visit and am glad I did. The museum is spread over a number of buildings and not particularly well marked as to where you're supposed to go, especially given there is renovation work in progress. However, the contents are very interesting including the Sidon sacrophagi with their facial detail, the glazed panels of lions & other animals of the Ishtar gate and the tiled pavilionI also enjoyed the short exhibit on "Mendel-Sebah documenting the imperial museum" and the hanging display of photos of various holdings.

Museum of many cultures. Istanbul has a vast and beautiful history with many cultures contributing. This museum shows the influences. The pieces are beautiful. If you love History. This is the place to see.

Under renovation & time consuming, still compelling.... Some parts are under renovation and it houses few museums together. Its better to use museum pass (3 or 5 day) to visit museums in Istanbul. History buffs can spend a lot of time inside, even if one just passes by all artifacts it will consume more than couple of hours. They provide audio guides which are worth trying. There are a lot of categories of relics and having a idea (use their official site) before hand is advisable.
quite fascinating. the visit to the museum was very exciting. It was the journey of the Turkish past. It was very nice to visit and quite exciting for those who loves the history.
Great complex. Very nice complex with 3 different museums. A journey through the turkish past and very informative about Istambul.

Exquisite for history and culture. This museum has one of the most important collections in the world. It is a must visit. From Sumerian to Ottoman civilizations, it has almost everything! The Code of Hammurabi, the Treaty of Kadesh and mummies are the most important artifacts.Absolutely do not miss!

Fascinating, though disappointing not to see the Alexander sarcophagus. Thoroughly enjoyed this museum, despite the lack of any English language brochure/maps (they have French, German, Turkish etc — we got by with schoolgirl French). There are fascinating antiquities in the first building (on your left past the ticket booth), including the first love poem, recorded on a clay tablet in Sumer in 2037-2029 BC, as well as brick tile lions from the processional street in ancient Babylon, and the oldest recorded peace treaty. Disappointing not to see the Alexander sarcophagus — and worse, to only read the reason for its absence from TripAdvisor rather than from any information at the museum — but still, an educational and amazing morning away from the big crowds.

Be aware: Renovation and missing pieces, but interesting.. Interesting museum but due to major earthquake prevention/stabilisation renovations, there is lots of pieces missing and parts of the museum closed at the moment.

Highly recommend!. This is a great museum! So many different time periods included. You can see Egyptian, Roman, Byzantine, etc. Plan to make lots of time, because there are multiple buildings. There is also a nice cafe on the grounds.

Great Visit in the Old City. I have been to a lot of museums around the world, but this one has some things that are just unbelievable. How about mosaics from the gates of Babylon! The Tiled Kiosk is a site that can be seen nowhere else. Same with the the collection of ancient sarcophagus. I would give it 5 stars but the Alexander sarcophagus exhibit was not open.

great museum. we didn't have any plan to visit this place but after seeing topkapi , it was on our way so we went in and thanks god we found this place with really great statues from the past. you can see great historical statues , it's great to take photos or sit and draw the statues ...

Good stop after the Topkapi Palace. The museum is a great place to visit after the Topkapi Palace and should not be missed if you have the Istanbul Museum pass (that also gets you into this museum along with the Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace and many other museums in Istanbul). There is a vending machine to purchase the Museum pass just inside the outer gate of the museum. The place has relics going back several millenniums, including Egyptian, Greek, and local civilizations. If you are looking for a huge collection of sarcophagi, you need to visit this museum. The ornate features of many of the sarcophagi are works of art and very impressive. All the information about each exhibit are in Turkish and English.If you do not like crowds or it is very hot outside, this is a good place to avoid both a swarm of tourist and the heat.

Worth about an hour. It's currently under restoration, so some buildings are covered in scaffolding, but you can still go in. The first building has Egyptian relics and statues, but not of the same quality as in The British Museum. The tiled building is lovely. Some interesting tiles and the peacock fountain is really nice. There's a cafe overlooking Gulhane Park too.

A hidden gem on the Topkapi Palace grounds. If you are an archeological buff or if this is your second or third visit to Istsnbul you should include the Archeological Museum . On the grounds of the Topkapi Palace it houses some of the best finds of Turkey. And if you've never ponied up the extra fare to go in the Harem on the grounds of the palace put this on your list too.

Don't miss the first ever peace treaty!. 3 museums which are all co-located and free entry with the museum pass. Just a couple of minutes walk from Topkapi Palace and well worth the visit with pieces covering 5000 years of history starting from the pre-classical world. My favourite pieces included the first ever peace treaty (the treaty of Kadesh) on a clay tablet signed between the Egyptian pharaoh Ramises II and the Hittite king in 1283 BC that ended a conflict between these two great ancient empires. Also a lion sculpture taken from the Mausoleum of Halicarnassus which was one of the 7 ancient wonders of the world. Generally first class exhibits throughout which you could spend hours viewing. I went in the morning and it was not busy at all but towards lunchtime it started filling up as I imagine people who had just been to Topkapi Palace started to arrive. Therefore I'd recommend spending a morning at your leisure (if you have time). Enjoy!

Amazing place!.
