For only 15 TL - less than otherwise more famous places like Topkapi, Dolmabahce and the Cistern Basilica - one can see marvelous tokens of human history and civilization, directly from the craddle of humankind. We've spent some amazing six hours visiting all the collections and the exhibits this place embowers. Took meanwhile some breaks for a coffee, tea and refreshments at the little garden coffee house. We've made a lot of pictures inside the museum - unlike Dolmabahce or Topkapi. Definitely worth a visit.

must to see. the archaelogical museum of istanbul is two steps from ayasofia, topcapi etc in the hrat of the hostorical center of the city.located in two seperate buildings in a very nice garden, with a wonderful cafe.

Great museum. Although we saw many archeological museums during our trip through Greece and Turkey, this one was certainly up there with the one in Athens in terms of impressiveness both in terms of size and the collection. It is a far better museum and cheaper than the Islamic Arts museum and we were amazed at the variety and quality of the exhibits, especially in terms of the geographic areas covered.

Some of the most amazing archaeological finds all in one place.. It's incredible and extremely humbling. One of the highlights for me (and for my husband) was the Egyptian–Hittite peace treaty, carved out of stone. The buildings are gorgeous and the breadth of history shown in the pieces here is exquisite.If you're interested in historical artifacts, this is a treasure trove spanning many eras and cultures, and paints a gorgeous picture of times gone by.I would highly recommend if you're in Istanbul that you visit this diverse, wonderfully preserved and curated collection.

See the entrance in Babylon. There are many well preserved artefacts here, an impressive sarcofagus collection and so on. The most interesting part of it I found to be the lion decorations on the entrance to Babylon. To see this still exists in our day and it's so well preserved - it's amazing.

Despite restorations, there's still a LOT to see.. We had a couple of hours for this museum, which seemed reasonable given that it was largely under restoration, but could have spent a lot longer here. Lots to see, and almost all of great interest.

If you're into history, you shouldn't miss this place. It's not a very busy place, but definitely get a Museum Pass in advance to skip any or little lines at the entrance. It's got several buildings, each dedicated to a different part of the history of Turkey and the area in general. From the Museum of Oriental history to the building that has exquisite examples of Turkish ceramic art. Absolutely visit during an afternoon.

still the best. to understand the turks and their their ancestors in anatolia hattis,ionians,lidians,hellions,byzantians,etrucians,troy,assurians the cultural mixture before and after islam with accepted arabs and hebraeish people from spain,and of course the history of Istanbul:the only capital of 3 empires...

Museums inside of a Museum. There's just a ton of history here and it's absolutely amazing to see. When we went we didn't have to wait in a long line. We were skeptical at first but had gotten our moneys worth in just the first museum. I'd highly recommend visiting!

A view of Istanbul Archaeological Museum. The Museum situated on way to Topkapi Museum on left of the ramp is gated and entry into it is subjected to payment of entry fee. A ling queue id found of the people wanting entry and that includes male, female, young, elders and children. This is a very good experience to visit it. It contains lot for the people interested in archaeology. Guide literatur is available that makes the round more informative. I recommend people to visit this Museum as a MUST part of their tour of Istanbul.

A museum with several museums and many artefacts of interest. Entry is part of the "museum Pass for Istanbul". Surprisingly there were no lengthy queues to see this sight on the day (closed on mondays). There are several buildings (museums) on the Museums site with categories of many historical artefacts. When one imagines they are back in the time, one can visualise going through that time in history. Suggested tour time is 2 hours, we stayed for 5 hours. Good value for money.
Very well set up. There is much to see here covering a wide historical span. The history of Istanbul, a separate area is an eye opener as to all that took place there.

A treasure missed by many visitors. We visited this museum at mid-day, and found many ancient items on display. Very few visitors find this museum, and they miss many antiquities. We recommend searching out the 2 buildings.

Under renovation and needs updating !. Easy walk from Galata bridge area to the 3 buildings plus Topkapi garden with leafy cafe. Unfortunately compared to Ankara's or Antalya's similar museums, the treasures lack modern display technology,signage and lighting. Some of the famous pieces are in wings closed for renovation. Lines are much shorter than for Topkapi Palace ,Blue Mosque orDolmabahce Palace,so enjoyment is greater.

Under construction but still worth a visit. Wonderful examples of Hittite period, portal lions and a cool Ushabti exhibit in the Egyptian portion. It was a nice place to spend about 45 minutes since it's being restored so a large portion was closed during our visit.

Great collection. The museum was being renovated so certain sections were off limits, but I still felt like it was an extensive collection and I got to see heaps. Make sure to visit all the different buildings to see the variety of collections. I spent 3 hours here. The section on the history of Istanbul was excellent as was the collection of sarcophagi.My only comment for improvement is that it could have been better structured - a little guidance on what direction to walk to see the collections in order would have been helpful. I didn't purchase the audio guide and just read descriptions which were offered in English and Turkish. Entry was 15 lira. The audio guide was 15 lira also.

Average and disappointing. Some sections still closed for renovations. Am a museum freak....but this was disappointing. Had wanted to see the museum in full but some sections were still in renovations which to me, it felt like such a rip-off to charge the full entrance fee.

Excellent glance into Turkey's past. This is a great museum! I was so happy to have spent the morning there (and you could easily stay the whole day). They have great collections of artifacts from the middle east giving you a good idea of where civilizations first developed. I also enjoyed a lot the section on Istanbul, there are many panels that take you through the centuries of this beautiful town. This museum is definitely well worth a visit.

WONDERFUL!!!!. What INCREDIBLE & BREATHTAKING collections!!! It is definitely forth a visit, if you love art/history/culture!!! The site is quite big so do plan a 2-3 hours visit!!!! In addition, it is very quiet too :-) : there is no need to squeeze between people in order to see artefacts....that is a big bonus!! Free entrance with Museum Pass - however, do bear in mind that during very busy times, museums run out of passes!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Good and bad. The museum itself is wonderful....although under construction in areas.....and is easily accessible. I particularly liked the oriental art section which contained many Assyrian stone reliefs along with varied antiquities including a small Egyptian collection. The location is convenient with a view of the park from the coffee shop. We sat down to have lunch there, but 75% of the items on the menu were unavailable even some of the pastries. Seemed strange not to have food to serve....difficult to stay in business. One other problem. On this busy day, only one person manning the ticket booth while another tinkered on a computer next to her and another (supervisor?) stood behind her watching as the line grew longer by the minute. All in all...enjoy the collection and hope you have more luck with customer service than we did.

Another whole day !. If you like historical museums this collection beats most. From Alexander the Great's sarcophagas to the collection of ceramics in the Tiled Kiosk there is something for everyone here. There are three museums at this site and each is worth a visit. The exterior of the buildings is impressive but just sitting in the square enjoying the peaceful sunshine is lovely. The cafe is too small to cater for large numbers and seems to have only one waiter who very kindly ran after me to give me the jacket I'd left over my chair.

Stunning!. Wow! So much to see and such interesting artifacts! If this is your particular interest, this museum has much to offer! Beginning 2 or 3 thousand years B.C. And covering all the different periods. Even if you are not a fan of arqueologie, do visit quickly and do not miss the tile pavillion.

Great collection. This museum has a fine collection of artefacts from the ancient times in several buildings nestled next to one of the best parks in Istanbul. Well worth spending a couple of hours to learn more about these times.

Hidden gem. Wow. This place is a must see. The exhibits are fantastic, giving another dimension and understanding to the average person as to turkey's place in the world's history.  Place you could spend hours in, even if you have no specific interest in archeology. It will give you a deeper appreciation of the many tourist sites in istanbul and turkey .

Wonderful collections. This is well worth a visit. It's a massive place and even with some areas currently being refurbished you need to target particular areas you want to see. The history of Turkey is complex and the museum covers all the civilisations in modern day Turkey, Eastern Turkey and the middle east .The quality of the collections is amazing - right up there with, say the British Museum.

Good for history buffs. We came here to finish off sight seeing for our first full day in Istanbul. Maybe it's because we were tired, or because we aren't really history aficionados, but there was nothing really special about the museums. A lot of pieces throughout history, but nothing wow to be honest. One visitor told us that Alexander's tomb was not visible to the public due to the renovations.Overall, it wasn't really worth our time.

Culture without crowds. Situated in the shadow of the Topkapi Palace, this is an entirely different experience. Don't expect jewel-encrusted daggers - the exhibits here may not be crowd-pullers but they are just as impressive. Exhibits not too miss include Babylonian friezes which rival those in the British Museum, the Treaty of Khadesh and numerous Greek and Roman sculptures. There is a pleasant outdoor café situated among statutory and columns in the courtyard. Despite renovations, this museum is still worth a few hours. I do agree with criticisms about the lack of signage though.

Worth a visit but not essential. I had the pleasure of visiting the Istanbul Archaeological museums with my partner on a snowy day in February 2015. Built in what was previously the Topaki palace outer gardens, it is a complex of three archaeological museums, all covered by the one ticket priced at 15TL or included in the Istanbul museum pass. These include(1) The Archaeological museum – This house a fantastic collection of Turkish, Hellenistic and Roman artifacts. A real highlight is the alexander sarcophagus, believed to have been prepared for Alexander the great. (2) Museum of the ancient orient(3) Museum of Islamic artDespite the three buildings this museum isn’t enormous and can be covered in around 3 hours. However, despite its close proximity I would recommend against visiting this place on the same day as Topaki palace, as this would essentially turn into a whole day of museums which may prove draining. There was a large amount of renovation work occurring when I was there and numerous closed exhibits which was disappointing.It is probably worth visiting, but I wouldn't be placing it high on your 'must sees' of Istanbul. I think it would rank around 6-7 in my book. Refreshingly, this attraction doesn’t see the same level of tourist traffic as Istanbuls other tourist attractions. It is important to remember that like most museums it is CLOSED ON MONDAYS.

Nice museum. This museum is near the topokia museum,a park, and the blue mosque so its worth doing it at the same time. There is not masses to see, which is a good thing if you have already been to one of the other museums, too many museums in one day can be a bit much. It was only 15 turkish monies so not expensive, and if you have the museum card you might as well take a look here too.

Under renovation and barely open. This museum suffers from neglect and minimal significant objects. The best, most significant artifacts are in other countries museums. The museum was barely open as they were doing renovations and the main sight that we came to see, the sarcophagus wasn't even on display.

A massive trove of archaeological treasures. This first rate museum has treasures from Neolithic through medieval times concentrating on the Middle East, Rome, Byzantium, Greece, Egypt, and other cultures. See artifacts from Troy, a piece of the chain across the Golden Horn that kept the ottomans at bay, and sarcophagi galore.

A hidden gem in the midst of tourist area. This museum is under renovation and you can only see half the objects. For example you cannot see Alexendar the Great's sarcophagus. When we were in Istanbul no one recommended this and the crowds are sparse. But they have some of the best collections of antiquities from the Mesopotamian era. The cuneiform tablets of Sumerians are truly amazing. So if you have a bent for finding out more about pre recorded history don't miss this. I hope they will fully open the museum soon enough.

Centuries of Civilization in half a day. Museums in the France, UK & USA have larger and more elaborate sections and periods of civilization evolving but most of those artifacts are from other countries. Turkey is closer to where the early civilization began and one can see, visualize and relate to how it all happened. Walking through Turkey first and visiting the museum last helped. The renovations going on put a dampener to an otherwise worthy visit.

Do go. Wasn't planning to visit here, but when leaving Topkapi Palace it was enroute (on one of the prettiest back streets). Certainly worth the visit. The Mosiacs were brilliant - some of the brightest I have seen and closest you could get, the asephogus (bad spelling) was an incredible collection.Included in the Museum Card - but well worth the extra TL if you haven't got one of those.

A must see for historians and cultural buffs. This museum is part of the 3-5 day museum pass. It's located behind Topkapi Palace. It contains 20,000 years of artifacts documenting the rise of western civilization. Very well organized. Displays are divided into several buildings - allow plenty of time to observe, have tea and observe more (unless you have restless children).

Good experience. We went here to escape the rain so started ticking off the museums covered by the museum pass and it turned out to be a great detour. The museum has a large collection and it is all well labelled. The audio tour is reasonably priced (the headphones are easily shared between 2 ppl) and it gives lots of additional information. The museum is undergoing some renovations be we only came across 1 statue that wasn't where it was supposed to be. Overall a very enjoyable and educational experience.

A LOT to see!!. There are 3 different buildings on the Topkapi Palace property. Tile Museum, Ancient History & More Modern Weapons & Culture. Very well marked in Turkish & English. You can easily spend 3 hours.
Unbelievable. Archeological finds of history and culture. Wonderful place to visit. You will love to see all those finds.

Worth Visiting after the renovations... There are three parts to this museum: the Museum of Archaeology, the Ceramics Museum and the Museum of the Ancient Orient. We were very interested in the first two and had planned on spending at least half a day there. There were very few people on the day we visited. This may be due to the fact that many parts of the Museum of Archaeology are currently under renovation. We did see a good collection of sarcophagi, but the more important ones such as the Alexander Sarcophagus, the Sarcophagus of the Mourning Women, the Satrap Sarcophagus and so on were all closed to visitors. The upper section for Ancient Troy was poorly lit and there were only small clusters of museum employees chatting in corners and a handful of visitors. Generally speaking, there are a lot of other artifacts and statutes on display, but we found them to be presented in a haphazard manner (perhaps due to the extensive renovations?), the heating was also on whilst we were there, making it fairly uncomfortable and we left after an hour or so.We also visited the Ceramics Museum. This small museum (one floor) houses a nice collection of tiles, including İznik tiles from the period between the mid-14th and 17th centuries.

One of a kind Archaeological displays. The Istanbul Archaeological Museum was pretty great! We were told to go there from a taxi driver in Croatia and it certainly didn't disappoint! There are displays here from all over the ancient middle east going back to something like 5000BC. The Egyptian displays were amazing. There were some exhibitions that were closed due to renovations for earthquakes though.

Sidamara Sarcophagus, to be seen.. Located within the historical area of Istanbul, the Museum displays a broad collection of Ancient Greek and Roman artifacts. The best pieces, my opinion,are the sarcophagus of Sidamara. The museum is under-going renovation , which makes the museum map irrelevant and the visit difficult. Collection of Nimrut artifacts.Maybe to be seen again once fully available and renovated.

nice. This place is a hidden-gem in the back streets of Gülhane Park and Topkapi Palace. Archaeology Museum of Istanbul is the first organised exhibition center built by the Ottomans in 19th century. There are over one million objects mostly from Anatolia, Middle-east and Mesopotamia. The museum consist of three different sections (1) Islamic Art Museum (2) Ancient Orient Museum (Pre-Islamic period) (3) Archaeology Museum-main building. Average visit takes about 1.5 hours. Yet if you are interested in the history of archaeology and the objects you can easily spend hours or even days at this place. The venue has a serene courtyard and a cafe. Istanbul Archaeology Museum is among the favourite places of both adults and the children.

Getting Up Close to Priceless Artifacts. This museum is really 3 museums for 15TL: the museum of the ancient orient, the mosaic museum and the archaeological museum! Due to this, it's very good value and one of the cheaper things to do in Istanbul. Also, with one million artifacts, there is so mud to view and learn here, that I'm not really sure you can cover it all in one afternoon (the 3rd floor alone covers Troy and Istanbul through the Neolithic times down to the modern era, so you can imagine how much info and artifacts are there)! My favourite part was being able to get nose to nose with ancient monuments like Hitite statues, the animal mosaics from the Gates of Ishtar from Babylon, hieroglyph tablets from Ancient Egypt and Roman Imperial era marble statues and actually being able to touch them, and feel them, as they are not inside glass cases. I've never seen that in other museums. They have audio guides available, if you want more information or prefer not to read the wealth of info that they already have posted. It's a great way to spend a whole day in Istanbul.

Archaeology museum under renovation, but still worth the visit. The museum is under renovation right now, so that about half of it cannot be visited. Still, and excellent collection is on display. The signage is a bit old-fashioned, and not too surprisingly is much better in Turkish than in English, but there is still enough for a visitor to get a good sense of the evolution of cuneiform and the deep history of the general region. The building at the back of the courtyard seems to be getting overlooked by most tourists (the entrance is not as clearly identified - head up the long ramp), and has some stunning pieces.

One of the best antiquities museums. A really great collection including gems from Babylon and Troy! A history nut would love it, but you don't have to be one. There's just so much to learn in here. Everything most cool

Wonderful museum but check listings before visiting (renovation work ongoing in 2015). This is a fantastic museum with a vast collection of exhibits covering thousands of years of Turkish history. The full collection is well worth five stars and an entire day of your time.At the time of writing however (April 2015) extensive renovation work is ongoing and many of the museum's most prized pieces are not on view. Hence 3 stars on this occasion.That said, even half closed, it's still well worth a visit. The ceramics exhibition, sarcophagus museum, Treaty of Kadesh and history of Istanbul are all open. Some reviewers have criticised the 1970s feel of the main building but it reminded me of the UN building in New York (all wood panels & sweeping staircases) and has a real James Bond circa Roger Moore vibe to it, which I loved!Set aside a couple of hours to properly appreciate.

Nice Complex, Okay Collection. I think I may have been expecting more for this museum than they could have offered me. It is called one of the top Archaeological museums in the world, but it is not up to the standards of the Egyptian or British museums in my opinion. The buildings that make up the complex are lovely especially the one housing the tile museum. The collection is just repeatitive in nature, save the burial collection in the old building. Go if you have the time, not too expensive just 15 TL.....

Sarcophagus Galore. Interesting museum. Unfortunately most of the major artifacts were not on display due to renovation in progress. However, if you're into sarcophaguses (or is that sarcophagi?), this is the place for you! The Tile Kiosk is particularly interesting primarily because of the building the collection is housed in. Ottoman architecture is lovely.

Wonderful. I had not known before how magnificent this museum was. Unfortunately I had only a day to visit it. The holdings are extensive and to the last one, most interesting. It is in the class of the Athens and Mexico City archeological museums and like them is strongly concentrated on classical treasures. The highlight is the Alexander sarcophagus with its extraordinary half-relief carving that is as fine and maybe even finer than that of the Parthenon pediments in the British Museum (being in higher relief I think and not a copy). For me it is the singular most impressive archeological treasure (not excluding those in the Berlin Pergamon museum) after the Chin emperor's army in Xian, which exceeds it only in immediate visual impact. The Topkapi Palace seems a bit gauche and over-the-top after this.

An avarage archeology musem, nothing very special.. Having visited many archeological museums in the past, this was nothing special. Very big so I lost interest on the way. Similar kind of pots and jars go on and on.The statues downstaris were the most interesting part of the museum. So all in all I would say that this is an awarage museum, nothing special, but if you are into archeology, might be worth a visit, specially if you have the museum card (admission is included to the museum card).

Under restoration. I loved the interactive aspect of the museum which makes it a fun experience but in terms of collection it has all the classic stuff ranging from Greek, Roman to Turkish History which is all good but hampers when the information is not sufficient enough to help you understand the things that you are seeing. A guide in which case become sort of essential. Depending upon your interests the tour can be a short one or hours long of walking. View from up here is also another impressive part of the museum.

GREAT COLLECTION...EXCEPT THAT IT NEEDS TO BE MORE MODERN AND UPKEPT.. THE PROS : THE WEALTH OF COLLECTIONSThis is one of the greatest museums in the sense that it has a GREAT collection of Sumerian and ancient Babylonian antiquities. I was fascinated by the great collection of cuneiform script on multiplication, economic documents, daily lives of farmers and citizens. Furthermore, the complex of museum houses a great array of pottery and tools from the Troy excavations. THE CONS : OLD-FASHIONED MUSEUMThe museum needs a face lift and a revamping of the antiquities information and placard. I think that the pieces are too great to go unnoticed with little / small / unclear placards of information. I also think that the museum is starting to look old on the inside and needs a more modern touch in the way antiquities are displayed or preserved in glass cases. It needs more interactive technology to engage the younger audience. A simple video that plays on loop in a room is lacking of technological advancement in museum studies.

Istanbul Archaeological Museums. An excellent day out but quite hard on the feet so make sure you have very comfortable shoes on! There is a lot to see but the Museums are well laid out. Notable items - the carved tombs which are quite fabulous. Much enjoyed but could do with some seating so one can rest and just gaze.

If you really like ancient stuff. This is ok to stop in; we were done in about 30 minutes, while the guidebook said figure on spending at least 2 hours. Depends on how interesting you find ancient sculptures. Especially worth popping in if you have Museum Pass

Potential to be very good or great, but for now average. The collection is big and housed in a converted palatial home of one the Sultan's advisors. The permanent collection includes Alexander the Great's sarcophagus but part of the building is being renovated so that was closed to the public as well as a significant part of the collection. There are signs in English at the entrance of each gallery with some explanation, but on the displays they are brief or absent. I rented the audio guide but was disappointed as the number of displays for which there were commentaries were few, plus the descriptions were actually briefer than that found on the walls; this is different to my experience with most museum audioguides. Still, i believe this is a work in progress as it seems to be a new feature in the museum. It is actually triggered by location as there are detectors in the entrance of each gallery that will trigger the guide if you step into a room. This is not a common feature even in more modern museums. The history of the kingdoms of anatolia and assyrian and hittite people on the third floor are interesting but lacks sufficient depth of explanation as one would see in well-curated museums of natural history. I think this museum has the potential to be very good or excellent given the wealth of archeological finds in this historic part of the world. It is just for now a work in progress

great place, surly staff. Wonderful place to visit. Especially the garden with all the statues, gravestones etc. Downside: surly staff: they kicked everyone out at 16.30 even though the place closes at 17.00. Thanks to them I missed a whole exhibition room. So, if you come here, plan your time carefully, as the place won't be open till the official closing time.

Scratches the Ottoman itch...but how about just a little organization?. After visiting (and loving!) the areas of the Hippodrome/Blue Mosque/Hagia Sofia, on day three we ventured up to the Topkapi Palace exhibits. For everyone complaining about the entrance fee, the site is an absolute bargain for 30 TL. Don't be deterred, you can spend a half day here easily if you take your time. Yes, they charge and extra 7 TL for a special side exhibit called the Harem Room, but if you've ever been to Turkey that's par for the course. We didn't do it and had a great time anyway.The best part of the museum is furthest from the main entrance. Just keep walking back, back, back...and you will find yourself on a large terrace overlooking the Bosporus. Truly magnificent. In that are you will also find some perfectly preserved Ottoman palace rooms and antechambers, and several very nice courtyards. These areas are by far the highlights of the entire museum.If Islam is your area of interest you will have several exhibits to enjoy that really play-up the role of the Ottomans in spreading and protecting Islam. In one area in particular, while reviewing artifacts, you get to hear someone recite the Koran over the PA system. It is not obtrusive and adds a nice mood to the experience. A few things are a bit over the top. They claim to be displayed the Sword of David, and the Staff of Moses. Seriously? There is so much hokey about that I don't know where to begin, but people seemed to be oohing and aahhhing plenty, so hey, as long as they're happy. Now, the bad...I know Istanbul is an international city, but how about some kind of crowd control? Some kind of flow to the exhibits? Several of the exhibit rooms consisted of one way in/out with no direction once in the exhibit space, so a throng flooded the room and everyone maneuvered to get a look at the artifacts in casings on the wall. Wait your turn, you may think? There is no turn. He/she with the sharpest elbows and rudest tendencies get to see what they want, while the rest of us civilized folks wonder what all the fuss is about. This is easily fixed with some $20 velvet rope and some arrows on the ground. Just establish some flow instead of the free for all that exists currently. Overall, this is well worth the trip and expense. The Hippodrome area is wonderful for the Roman influence and to get perspective for what Constantinople meant to human history (more that you can ever imagine), but you need to visit Topkapi to get a feel for the Ottomans.

Awesome collection. Although it is currently under renovation and parts are closed off, we found the Istanbul Archaeology Museum an awesome visit. We spent most of a day and found it almost too much to take in. A massive, incredible collection of Near East, Greek, and Roman artefacts. We highly appreciated that it is an "old school" museum with tons of actual items on display as opposed to a so-called "modern" museum with interactive exhibits, touch screens and ipads and such.

excellent exhibits. Easily spent 3 hours without noticing the time.We took the audio tour which made the understanding of the exhibition more enjoyable.Unfortunately the Alexander exhibits were unavailable to be seen due to renovations.There is still plenty to see and there was no wait to enter the museum nor was it crowdedMaking it a very pleasant experience.

Pleasantly Surprised. This perhaps isn't the sort of place we would visit on a city break, but we noticed that it was part of the 3 day museum pass and much quieter than the overbearing crowds at Topkapi Palace so gave it a go.Some of the areas were being restored, but we were very impressed with the artefacts that we did see across 3 floors.

OK for a rainy day. This museum is on the grounds of the Topkapi Palace and includes 3 buildings. The larger building at the back right should probably be toured first. It contains several floors of artifacts from old Istanbul including the chain that was used to block the Golden Horn (inlet separating old and new districts) from invaders, many sarcophagi and tomb stones, and pottery from an excavation of Troy. Toilets are found in this building but the women’ s toilet was in poor repair with only two stalls and only one European-style toilet. The other buildings contain tiles and ancient artifacts from neighboring countries (eg Egypt, Iran). There is a small café in the center of the complex where you can sit and count all the stray cats that wander the complex.

Limited artifacts available for viewing. Given Turkey's rich history, the artifacts currently available at the museum was quite disappointing. It might be worth a visit once they reopen the main collections to the public. Unless you have a museum pass, it's not worth paying for a visit as it is now.

Gives You a Bit of A Chill (and a Thrill). Istanbul's Archaeology Museum feels surprisingly unpolished. Hundreds or thousands of sarcophogi, friezes, statues and more from Roman ruins all over are displayed in vast rooms, and you can walk unfettered among them. It's a bit like sauntering through a graveyard. Lighting is generally dim, and there's little more explanation of what you're seeing than a name, 2-3 word description and place (as if you were looking at flowers and given common and Latin names only). Much of the museum was under renovation when we visited which severely limited my options (because I'm mobility challenged and the ramps/elevator were in the area being worked on). But the pieces are beautiful (many of them) and the overall effect is to make the Greco-Roman world seem more real than it usually does.

Lots of renovation. Did not get to see everything, the place was under renovation, so we didn't get to see alexander the great's grave. However, there are very few tourists here- most visit the topkapi instead. Shame, because this is definitely worth your time.
Interesting, Unique. Its a great place to spend 3 hours on a rainy day. Interesting and - for me -unique museum. It is easy to find and easy to understand.

Amazing, world-renowned artifacts. The archaeological museums continue to undergo renovation, so you will likely miss out on some of the exhibits. That being said, you will see artwork and artifacts that are studied all over the world – many of the highlights from my old textbooks can be found in this museum. It's an amazing place with so much history. For those who haven't studied the art, definitely do some research beforehand to make the most of your visit.

Some Interesting Items but a lot unavailable due to restoration work. All the Guide Books told me that I should look out for the Alexander Sarcophagus, the Palmyran Mausoleum and the snake head from the Serpentine Column. None of these were accessible due to the fact that more than half the museum is closed for renovation.The Museum of the Orient building has wonderful Hittite carvings which are well worth a look, and there are panels from the Ishtar gate in Babylon. I found a lot of the rest of what was open to the public rather dull, as is often the case where a museum attempts to put every single they have on display.

Extremely Interesting. Even though about a third of the exhibits were closed for renovation, we found the museum fascinating. It is absolutely amazing to contemplate the sweep of civilization(s) represented. You can actually touch artifacts from 1,500 B.C. It also gives a great overview of the history of Byzantium and Anatolia. If you are headed to Troy, the museum provides fascinating background. You will also learn lots about the history of Istanbul. We spent over three hours there and it went by way too fast. The audio guide was not worth the cost. All written materials (and there are a lot) are provided in English.

not worth it. As I read other reviews it seems that the best parts are closed currently.However two floors were open and boring. Beside the exhibition objects (which were 90% pottery from different times) there are walls of text. There was no chronological system that made sense for me (call me stupid), no interactivity and no overview. If you don't know about the history of Turkey already, you may be lost with the different empires and times.This museum should be in another museum that shows museums from last century.PS: entrance was 15 TRY, Audio guide costs another 15 TRY.PPS: few things were cool, like the letters and contracts written in stones.
Under renovation . Not really worth the visit due to extensive ongoing renovation. They should reorganize the artifacts and make the tour more interactive and informative. Slightly Disappointing.

Really Interesting. This is a great museum with an extensive collection. It makes a big difference if you can go with a knowledgeable guide (not one of the guides that hang around in Sultanahmet trying to pick up customers). They are easy to find at one of the dozens of tour/guide companies in the area, although some advance planning is necessary. We went with an archeologist who was very good, and who made the visit absolutely fascinating.

Nice if you have the right expectations. We ducked in for a visit after lunch, still trying to avoid the cold/snow. We weren't expecting to see the greatest archeological exhibits ever, so we enjoyed what we saw. We are both lawyers, so we spent quite a bit of time looking at cuneiform tablets and reading the translations. Most of them were legal contracts. Some were even funny. Some interesting information about the attempt to locate Troy. We wandered around until the museum closed. It was fun for a couple of hours.

Sarcophagus collection redeemed it. They have a vast collection but poorly curated and as a result very underwhelming.The Ancient Orient Museum has the beautiful fragments of Ishtar gate from Babylon.My recommendation for the main museum - Start with the sculptures from the Ancient Age on the ground floor of the main building (unfortunately part of this was closed for renovation when we visited in Feb. 2015). Move on to the Sarcophagus collection at the end of the building. Come back to the main building for visit of "İstanbul Through the Ages".Visit the Tiled Kiosk Museum next.Go back to the main museum for "Anatolia and Troy Through the Ages" collection on the second floor and the "Surrounding Cultures of Anatolia: Artifacts from Syria, Palestine and Cyprus" collection on the third floor - ONLY if you have time.

Renovations make for shorter visits. Many interesting objects, although poorly presented. Last time I visited, 8,10 yrs. ago, it was spring/summer and many of the most interesting objects had been sent out to other museums. This time, the renovations kept many of the best exhibits from us. Ah well, there were a few things and this way the visit didn't take too long. I wonder why museums don't charge less during extensive renovations, it would help for visitors to not feel that they were being "ripped off".

don´t expect to see Alexander the Great´s Sarcophagus or... whatever. The museum itself is nice. Easy to understand which period is where and very interesting presentation of ancient civilization like the ones of Mesopotamia. The entrance fee is cheap but what is misleading is the poor information about the museum, like for example the claim that you can see Alexander´s Sarcophagus while it´s not.
great museum. The museum is incredible - with ancient artifacts (of course). The facility is beautiful, and the gardens just outside the museum are not to be missed.

Amazing Artifacts. The Istanbul Archaeological Museum is place you spend some time. Many of the artifacts from the site of Troy are on display along with a comprehensive history of the excavation. I also enjoyed the area outside the museum which is full of remains spread out in a garden like setting.

Shame about renovations. We've visited this museum before and were fascinated so we were disappointed that so much is now closed for work and there seems to have been so little attempt to ensure visitors still get a good deal. The signage is very poor and the staff less than helpful. A shame.

RENOVATIONS RESTRICT VISIT. While there are some great exhibits in the museums in this complex some are no better that in museums at home. The main Archaeological Museum was a bit of a let down due to refurbishment/rearrangement work, although like the smaller museums, there was still some spectacular items on display. A pity such a large area in the museum was inaccessible - surely a less restrictive method of work could be arranged to minimise the adverse effect on the visitor? The exhibits in the outdoor spaces arguably rival some of those housed in the buildings.
Lots of history. The museums were packed with ancient artifacts and information. I enjoyed many of the sculptures and special artwork. If you are a history buff, you will be glad you visited.
take your time. a bit lost behind Topkapi Palace. It has a very nice collection.I prefer to go alone there because who ever I'm with always goes faster then me...

"under renovation". The musea is undergoing extensive renovation and most of the exterior walls are shrouded in sheeting, which is a shame as it is a beautiful building from photos we've seen. The signage is missing in a lot if the myseum so we were going backwards! Not a problem, it is a very interesting museum with some great artefacts. I am aure that once the renovations are complete and they can display more of their extensive collections, then it will again be a super top attraction. The tile building in particular is really beautiful

Disgraceful handling. We got to the Museum at 16:00 on Sunday, and we asked if we had enough time to visit it (otherwise we would have come another day), and the woman at the entry said that 1 hour was enough, because the Museum closes at 17:00.At 16:35 we were at the second building and the guards start telling us that they're closing at 16:40 and to please leave the rooms. The 17:00 closing time affects only the yard!So we ask where the alleged Alexander Sarcophagus is, and we're told that it's not accessible because of ongoing renovation: half the building was indeed closed.We paid the full price and we were lied about the available time and we were not told that a big part of the Museum was closed to public. That's at the very least deceitful.The only reason I'm not giving the worst possible rating is that the few pieces we saw were interesting and well preserved.

Very impressive museum. We have been there with friends in the end of 2014, i was very surprised to see thousand years old tiny objects and cups reserved under the ground we step up in our daily life. Discovery Location info was also provided, it was quite surprising to see some pieces were found during the construction of courthouse in Şişli.. I loved the tablets found, some were for marriage some were commercial agreements, it teach me a lot. Do not for get to step by the gift shop, you may find several replicas of jewels or tablets, i bought myself an amethyst silver ring and have been wearing it with the memories of this awesome museum.

Has it all. If you are curious about history - be it Europe, Middle East or Asia - you find it here. It's a multi-story building that has it all. Don't forget to combine your trip with Topkapi Palace to have it all :) You'll be a little tired but really worth it. You can buy a single entrance ticket or an Istanbul Museum Card if you'll be visiting more places.

Artifact on several floors of Ancient Greece and Roman times and from Istanbul different rulers ,. Fascinating place . Amazed to see plundered Greek and Roman artifacts from many places . A full look at Istanbul history . History covered is over 5,000 years items are well lit and well labeled , this is 3 buildings , I liked the most the ,Egyptian sarcophagus which I saw 4 of. This was the trading center of the ancient world so items came from all over , A must see.

Simply crammed with fantastic artefacts from all over the former Ottoman Empire. This is one of those wonderful museums that is absolutely packed with all manner of archeaological artefacts, from small pieces of pottery through to truly monumental stonework. Although some of it has the feel of a Victorian museum (cluttered and old-fashioned), most of it has been modernized (within the original buildings) to tell a much more engaging story; this encompasses the entire geographic footprint of the old Ottoman Empire, including cultures as diverse as Troy, Rome, Lydia, Byzantium and the Ottoman Turks themselves. There's an awful lot to see, so if you are interested in any one era/civilisation in particular, you should probably focus on that, as you could easily spend half a day on something like Troy alone. The collection of monumental sarcophagi was a real surprise, unlike anything I've seen before, and truly spectacular.Entry is free with a Museum Card.
locals. better go now before the war from the south(Syria Jordan and anothers...)is spreading to the North or maybe all over the beautiful once a great empire,country...hope it's not gonna happen.

Under renovation... But interesting!. I learned a lot about the historical buildings of Istanbul. The museum closed some parts due to it's construction when I was here. It is worth visiting, you will learn a lot about Istanbul.

Sarcophagi Everywhere. This museum is definitely worth a visit, and right next to Topkapi. it's very conveniently located. You will need some time though, as there is a great deal to see, with multiple different exhibitions inside, not to mention all the different pieces outside. You won't need a guide for the interior exhibits, but you might want to get one for the tour of the grounds. There is just so much to see here.

sarcophagus, sarcophagus, sarcophagus. The main exhibition is arranged very professional. No guide needed.It's better to have a guide for outdoor part and sarcophagus part of museum.IMHO sarcophagus are best part of this museum.

Take your time - it is massive!. Not being an admirer of history and arts, my expectation of this place was not too high. This thought changed immediately after spending time in here. There are several sections so do take your time. There is an immense collection in here of artefacts you can barely dream of. Some repairs were being made in one section. Photography is limited inside. Should be visited in İstanbul.

Take your time and enjoy. Istanbul has a wonderful and long history, which you may want to furthermore explore by visiting the Archeological Museum. There is a lot to see, especially if you are a reader (not only looking at things), so you may want to spend around 3 hours on this one.

STUNNING COLLECTION!. This museum is incredible and has so many incredible pieces that i would say that is definitely worth a visit before leaving Turkey! Vast Greek and Roman ruins, to Troy ruins, and ancient Turkish treasures. Can easily spend 3 hours here, for an average person. A day for those very interested in historical artifacts. Free on the musuem pass too, so definitely get one and GO HERE!

Very Interesting Museum near Topkapi. Having seen some of the major "must see" sites in Istanbul we decided (due to heavy rain) to visit the Archeological Museum. The Entrance is a little hidden left to the entrance of the Topkapi palace. Several showrooms give you a deep inside of the history of more that 4000 years. Especially the ancient section (first to the left after the entrance) was impressive and our personal highlight of our 2 hours tour. Ticket price: 15TL, however you can save money with the Istanbul Card (available for various timeframes) which you can buy at most of the scenic places.

Amazing museum and endless history. . This museum was amazing and I was glad I took the time out to go and visit. Everything was well labelled and displayed. Yes there are renovations taking place but don't let this put you off. I visited on a rainy day and was delighted to notice heaters on in nearly every room i visited, it certainly wasn't a cold draughty museum! There are plenty of places to sit too if you need a rest from walking around. Great visit but try to go on a different day than your Topkapi palace visit to make the most out of it.

take the time and feel the history. For someone like myself who has always enjoyed history , this covers all the bases. Well displayed, easy to maneuver, impressive pieces.....the museum is in 3 buildings and please see them all!

History unveiled in so many ways. This place is under renovation but it doesnt matter because there is so much to see and take in. We spent a few hours here because it is bigger than we expected. There is something for everyone if you just look beyond the obvious. Read some of information labels and you learn allot. There are sooo many great photo oppertunities if you explore different perpective angles. At one point you feel that you you have seen it all and its getting boring, but as you enter the next building its a whole new experience. Good value for money and a pleasant few hours spent

Fascinating. Although the building is under renovation the museum was fascination. Thankfully when I visited it was empty so I had the place to myself. So many exhibits especially in the garden where one can actually touch pillars and stones that are hundreds of years old. The building housing tiles and pottery was an oasis of calm and quite delightful. Again a Museum Pass was well worth the money.

Tons of things to see. There are literally thousands of artifacts to see in this museum, and the entrance cost was only 14 lira. High value for money. To see everything you may need at least 4 hours. Of course, not everything will be interesting and you can just pass by them. The most interesting area for me were the roman and Hellenistic statues and figures with their stories of myth and legends. An audio guide brings the stories to life, you may want to consider getting one.At this point several rooms are under restoration, so you will be missing out on some artifacts if you visit now. Also, one of the main highlights of the museum, the Alexander sarcophagus, was not available for viewing, much to my dismay. Regardless of this, the museum is still full of interesting stuff to see, so I recommend u to make the trip. Especially if you are a history buff.

Do not visit while under restoration. I visited this museum over ten years ago and remember it as a highlight of my visit to Istanbul then. Unfortunately many of the prize exhibits are not now on display and the ones that are are presented in a very boring and unattractive fashion. Let us hope that the visit will be enhanced after the restoration is complete.

So many layers of history. We were recommended to visit the Archaeological Museums by a local friend and spent a wonderful morning touring the various exhibits. Probably could have spent days there as there is just so much to see and absorb. One of the best aspects is that many of the larger relics are out on display and not locked away in glass cases or even in a roped off area. This means you can actually touch and feel objects from 4000 or 5000 years ago.The coverage and spread of the displays really reinforces a comprehension of the major political and cultural forces that have swept through this part of the world over the course of human history.One of the best exhibits in Istanbul - and also one of the least crowded.
Part of the pass - well worth the visit. After visiting the Palace we went to the "museums". There were 4 different buildings to visit and each was unique and interesting.

amazing museums. just adding to a couple of the other reviews what also was cool is the original archaeologists handwritten notes, books and drawings with the real artifact specimens right there! Again it would take a day just to see these museums, lots of stair climbing.

Awesome collection of ancient artifacts. Three of us toured the Istanbul Archaeological Museum which is accessed from the grounds just outside the Topkapi Palace. Their collection is extensive and it takes several hours to go through it, even moving quickly. The material is organized very well and takes you through the many historical periods. There is a visual show at the beginning that helps you understand everything you will see. It really helped to watch that. This museum is well worth visiting. There are occasional benches and a coffee shop outside, should you need to rest.

Excellent collection - under restoration . If unable to visit every corner of Turkey, definitely make a stop in this museum. It gives a nice glimpse of the diverse history that encompasses Turkey.The vast collection are kept in separate buildings, make sure you visit each one. Quite a few areas are under restoration and not sure what I've missed out on.The porcelain is beautiful on its own along with its contents.The large number of stone sarcophagii from the various civilizations is amazing. They really show the wealth, craftsmanship and attention to details. I did not get the audio guide but I think it would have been worth it for additional 15 Turkish Lira.
Excellent service with a lot of humor. The service at the entence was full of humor. The tickets it self looks like Money notes, just more bright and colorfull.
A lot of incredible exhibits. There are so many incredible exhibits there, that it`s really difficult to make a top 10 of them. You need at least 2 hours to visit all the halls.

great collection. Really great collection of archaeological findings, not just from this country, but neighboring countries as well. We used the museum pass and started the tour fro right to left visiting each buildings. the first one was my favorite because I had a chance to see findings from the Troy excavations and my all time favorite Heinrich Schliemann, then the great spectacular sarcophagus in the third building...the second one containing the Alexander the Great general sarcophagus was under restoration and the last of the buildings has a great collection from Egypt, Greece and Roman Empire as well. It is open till 16 o clock .

A wealth of material, but in the throes of renovation. The museum is in the throes of renovation, currently (as of November 2014), and can be a bit disorganized in its presentation because of this, but the museum does have artifacts from all of the civilizations that occupied Turkey throughout its history - Hittites, Greeks, Romans, Byzantines, and Ottomans. The museum complex is larger once you get inside of it, than it appears when you enter.

Amazing collection, currently under restoration. I would have definitely given this a five star review if it hadn't been for all the construction at the time of our visit at the beginning of December 2014. We didn't get to see the Alexander or the weeping women sarcophagi because they were under restoration. If you are hoping to see these at some point in the near future, I would hold out until restoration is complete or at least call and ask. That being said, we saw some INCREDIBLE pieces and the audioguide was great at giving a decent amount of detail. You could spend a whole day here or look out for the audioguide symbols and see a good picture in 2-3 hours. The Orient collection and the items in the Old Building are the best in my opinion, definitely don't miss those.
Nice !. not very big but a very nice Museum with sooo much to see extremely beautiful and well preserved tombs in marble.

Historic Istanbul. We only had one day but it was wonderful. We intend to return in 2015. We visited the Sulimaniye Mosque whose garden over looked the "Golden Horn" It is worth buying a group pass, and going in the morning.
Rich collection. Probably the best museum in Istanbul and maybe Turkey. Newly refurbished with more historic collections. Skip the museum store because way overpriced.

Must visit museum #1in Istanbul. Istanbul Archeological Museum is the definately most visited museum in Istanbul, together with St. Sophia, located at Sultanahmet Istanbul. You would better to arrange min 3 hours to spend and purchasing a Museum Pass is recommended before your visit...

Under significant construction. There are several museums located throughout the Sultanahmet part of the Old Town that are wonderful; however, this is by far the most interesting museum of all.This museum has three wings: The Museum of Islamic Art, the Archeological Museum, and the Old Orient. The Old Orient wing has many displays associated with the original people of the region to include Hittites, Assyrians, and Sumerians. The artifacts in this wing are upwards of 4000 years old; however, a significant portion of the museum (downstairs) is closed for renovation.The Archeological museum is absolutely tremendous. The display on the history and creation of Troy is fascinating (2d floor) but the collection of Sarcophogi is not to miss. The featured sarcophagus is the one that depicts Alexander the Great; however, that particular piece is out for conservation. There is also significant construction throughout this wing creating several detours.For as much construction currently underway the museum should charge a lower price. The entrance fee is 50TL which is rather steep and one of the most expensive in the entire Istanbul area. If you are here for several days (minimum three), consider buying the museum pass for 85TL. If you happen to visit three places that charge for entry (Hagia Sophia, Topkapi with Harem, and the Archeological museum), you will easily find the value in the museum pass purchase. Also, the museum pass allows you to skip the queues at most sites.

Definately Worth It. First, if you are planning to visit Troy on your Turkey trip, this place is a must see. They have a whole section dedicated to Troy and there are extensive exhibitions of each of the several layers. It also provides excellent historical background of the sites you will see in Istanbul.As others have noted, the sculputures are amazing. I also enjoyed the various collections of early tools and the harbor chain.It's not as crowded as other sites and will easily fill a morning or afternoon.

Worth to see. Very interesting Museum divided into three parts, one in which you can find the Archeological Museum, another in which you can find the the Museum of Old Orient and another more in which you can find the Museum of Islamic Art. This last is the one I have appreciated the most. Not expensive ticket. Three hours neeed!

It's huge. Brest visited with a Museum Card v that keys you combine several key Istanbul attractions over 3-5 days, the Archeological Museum is spread over several wings so be sure to allocate time for all of them.The Hittite Stone tablets are fabulous. The writing, if one can call it that is simply tiny but the translations are well worth a read. The artifacts are arranged in such a way that suddenly the rest if Istanbul comes together. For instance, the head if the serpent column which is on the Hippodrome is here. If you are a museum buff you might end up getting overloaded because there is so much here. Most tourists tend to not make it here but it really is with spending some time here.
Wonderful sculptures. So many treasures, there is an avenue of "leftovers" outside. Extraordinary collection of Roman sculptures.

Very impressive. A wonderful step back through history but be warned you need to have a few hours as there is soMuch to see, very well laid out and large boards in English explaining exhibitions. We paid for the audio tour which was a total waste of money as I would have to say this is the worst audio tour I have ever attempted to use. The orient exhibition was well worth a look.

FABULOUS Archeological Museeum but under vast construction. If you have any interest in archeology, this is a wonderful museum even when it is under heavy reconstruction for seismic activity. There are choice items from centuries of important eras. To us, one of the most interesting parts was items from Schliemann's discoveries at Troy, because most of his things that had been in the museum in Berlin we "stolen" by the Russians after the WWII and will not be returned depriving anyone from seeing them. While the collection here is small compared to that which had been in Berlin, it is still fascinating. Also of great interest are the drawings depicting the various (I think 7) levels of Troy that were discovered while digging at Troy both by Schliemann and other who continued the "dig" after him. Sadly, it is difficult to find a sense of direction while the museum (several buildings in all) is under reconstruction.

A Must See for history buffs. If the region's history is of real interest to you, this is a "must do" attraction. the scale and depth of the collection is mind boggling. I (unfortunately) had very limited time, however as digital cameras are permitted, I was able to photograph many of the pieces I would have preferred to gaze at for longer. I especially loved the history of Istanbul section because it shows the layers of history which are only partially visible now.

Excellent museum. The museum is currently undergoing restoration so the Alexander the Great section was closed on the day we visited, but there is so much more to see here and it is definitely worth the visit. You can get in with the museum pass and skip the line. We especially enjoyed the Oriental building and its very ancient collection, including fun erotic tiles and a great collection of cuneiform legal agreements, both proving that people don't change, only their technology. Great sculpture garden in the courtyard, excellent sculpture hall in the main building, and the tile house is not to be missed. So close to Topkapi Palace, you could spend a day just visiting these two locations.

Istanbul Archaelogy Park. Wander through thousands years of history in this fascinating museum. Many exhibits are situated in the outside area & you are free to walk amongst them. Make sure to check out the Sultan's kiosk (very posh garden shed). It's opposite the main doors of the indoor exhibits. Entry to the Park is included on the Istanbul Museum Card.

Stunning. I am a museum junkie so I have seen a lot.This is a place which should NOT BE MISSED. It is in the old city and reasonable close to other important sightsThe collections are incredible even to those who have seen countless statutes & heads.DONT MISS ALEXANDER THE GREAT TOMB. Stunning

Lovely & the best. It is just 5 min away by walk from St .Sophia church and the topkapi palace . It is very huge buildings . While you enter from main door on your left there is one building in whicih the world first agreement , the treaty of kadesh that was done between the hitties and Egyptians phararoh emperor , Ramses II , was can be seen . Just for that you have to visit . On the right very huge building ,two floors , there are ancient gods status , tombs and the most famous tomb is called as the alexandria the great ' tomb . And you have a change to visit the gallery that is full of byztantin stuffs . When i get bored i will visit and fill of peace . In that museum what you see is only a little part of the museum . In warehouse there are lots of items , still are waitinf for to be visitied by visitiors . All over world , you can not see such lovely the ancient items that are be found form Anatolia land.

Overwhelming Collection of Exhibits. This is a three building complex of prehistory through Byzantine and Ottoman treasures. I especially enjoyed the Hittite exhibit featuring the Treaty of Kadesh, the earliest known peace treaty between the Hittite Kingdom and Egypt, in the 13th century BC and the artifacts from the excavations of Troy. Lots to see -- unfortunately the museum is not air conditioned and it was very hot inside. Also, the Archaeological Museum has a lot of competition nearby including the Haga Sophia, the Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern and of course Topkapi Palace.

ANCIENT STONES IN COOL SHAPES. I'm not going to pretend to be cultured. There are really old pieces of rock carved into the shapes of people and stuff. That's what it is. BUT.. I do like that stuff. There are 3000 year old chests and skeletons in the ground and stuff. Pretty good. It's not laid out in the best, most amazing way, but honestly, it's pretty cool.

Admirable collection. It was very impressive the collection of artifacts they have in this museum, from the first written law plaque to ceramics that are thousands (several, not one or two) years old.It is soo much, you can not really enjoy to the maximum detail everything. however you will find plenty of things to do and see and learn.... highly reccomended.

Fascinating. despite the fact that lots of best artifacts are outside Turkey. The museum has interesting collections, interesting audio-guides. You can also find lots of information written under each artifact. I loved the collection of coins from different times and regions of the country. You definitely get the spirit of ancient Turkey....

If you have enough time.... We visit the so called archaeological museum of the city as we had some time to spend and also as our hotel is near this region.We havent seen any reviews about the place but to tell you the truth we were not surprised at all. Most of the place was under restoration so as we think we have miss many parts of the museum.Apart from this the rest as we noticed has to do with a great collection of things from other civilizations like Egypt, Cyprus, Babylonia, Assyria, Phrygia, Sumeria and many other. Its good to know things from all the civilizations and is very interesting for all but apart from this there is nothing special to see.Good area for rest and coffee.Go there only if you have enough spare time or else skip it from your program.

Worth Visiting It. The museum is under renovation and as a result some parts are closed, there are detours, temporary walls, etc. It can be visited together with the Topkapi Palace. Its collection consists of artifacts from different cultures and civilizations such as Africa, Anatolia, Mesopotamia, Afghanistan. Renting the audio guide is very helpful.

Worth the stop and money no matter how long you spend there. I was a bit bummed that the main thing I wanted to see wasn't opening when i visited in early Sept. The Alexander section was getting worked on and I wasn't sure if I wanted to go still...I'm so glad I didI could have spent a lot long than I did but so due to work in the building and my time limit I moved quickly though the buildings. However, feel like i got my monies with worth and got to see some amazing artifacts. The sarcophagus took my breath away when I walked in and tried to see them in the gallary, I was still able to see a majority of the ones written about in the tour books. They are AMAZING and well worth the trip to see. The rest of the museum has great marble and stone, has pieces from the time of different points in Istnabuls and the area's history. It was towards the end of our trip so i already had some context of where and what happened to place these objects. In the main part of the museum. The front and lay out of the building really goes back to the build up and development of the classics and birth of Archaeology and those fields- feels very much in line with what 1800-1900 men across Europe were building to house items brought back from there explorations. The tiles museum was really quick and a worth seeing, but after the Mosque and other stops was only so much tiles one can look at. The front of the building is amazing not to be missed or a few vantage points. The far east section has some great pieces that for those not traveling to other parts of Turkey (I wasn't) gives a nice look at the eastern traditions, art, and history. can be done rather quickly as well. It made me excited to explore the other archaeological museums around the world. Reading Sharon Waxman's loot was a reason for me to go to Turkey, and was great to bring that full circle.
Well worth the trip. Excellent museum. You are in the cradle of civilization here. World class collection of sculpture and artifacts.

Amazing collection!. We first visited this museum with our tour guide, who rushed us past items from Babylon, Egypt and other ancient civilizations. We went back the next day by ourselves, and still did not have sufficient time to explore this collection of wonders. If you have studied ancient history, this place will blow your mind. I never felt like a museum had too many artifacts before! The surrounding areas are cluttered with ancient items like statues and columns. The collection is utterly amamzing....I recommend getting a pass and spending a few days taking it all in.

A must do!. Visitors should not miss this hidden gem. So full of historic displays including an Egyptian woman mummy with a child still in the coffin! Wow!! Entry is only 15TL, well worth it. Nice resting grounds around with a cafe in the midst of ruins columns and trees. Beautiful!

It deserves a visit. This is a very well presented museum. It shows a variety of tombs and monuments including a beautiful preserved one with representations of Alexander the Great which seem to one of the attractions of this museum. Other Greek sculptures displayed worth the visit.

Barely worth visiting. Sits in the Topkapi palace complex. Very poor things on display given the history of the country and city. Barely worth visiting. Seem to have no interest in anything to do with Byzantium?

Amazing museum - Ishtar Gates are stunning. The first thing to note about this museum is that you will have to queue to get in, and it will likely be a long queue, because only a certain number of people are allowed on the museum premises at once. Of the various sites we visited in Istanbul, this museum had the slowest-moving queue. While we waited though we were amused by a girl who kept taking photos of and selfies with an otherwise placid black cat. So there should be something to keep you busy while you wait!The museum is actually a number of museums, all located in a central area. There is a small and not very well-stocked cafe on the premises - though it did do excellent baklava! - and you can amuse yourself while you eat or drink by watching all the Istanbul local feline residents meandering around. One inside the Archaeological Museum, the collections are amazing - particularly the Ishtar gates. I had never seen any of the Ishtar gates before, but I was completely taken by them (many photos and selfies on my part later). There is also a very strong collection of sarcophagus, statues, tiles, a coin collection, and a history of the city and empire. Well worth a visit - wear comfy shoes and carb-up beforehand!

Greatest archeological museum ever!. For archeologist this is Mekka! So many presented attractions, that after 2 hours of sightseeing I was tired and wanted to see more. In normal museums parts of exhibitions would be the biggest attractions. There you are not able to remember everything. Just amazing!
Archaeological museum. Has some good exhibits. A section of the Babylon wall. Good place to buy museum card. About an hour.

Amazing stuff in a rather run down facility. This place is a diamond in the rough. They have statues out in the rain and just some odd stuff. We spent a few hours here with kids. I loved the building with the tiled door and amazing tile on the inside. Get museum card as it is included.
Amazing!. Very interesting experience. Wish to have more time to also visit the 3rd floor. Allow at least 3 hours to really enjoy the place. The use of a guide or Audio guide is highly recommended.

Less line, more interesting than other attractions. A personal preference, but we actually enjoyed the archaeology museum more than things like the topkapi palace and hagia Sophia and blue mosque because there were more interesting things to look at and read and learn. The other monuments were mostly architectural and more just viewing than learning. The museums were very empty around lunchtime on a weekday and we browsed at our leisure. Air conditioned and a nice relaxing place amidst all the tourism.

With so much history. here there was never doubt that this museum was going to be fabulous. It is important to see when here. Depending on your level of interest it's a quick flyby or multi-hour stay. We fall into the latter category. But regardless, if you are here you must stop in.

Its okay.. but nothing out of this world - skippable. The archeological museum was OK. .. but it wasn't anything amazing. It was a good walk thru and had lots of roman stuff... lot of statues everywhere... a little bit of history and a few other things.However it wasn't a blow me away place. My girlfriend was a bit disappointed... and I thought it was just okay... a bit of the same stuff after an hour or so and go repetitive.If you have a lot of time it could be worth a visit, but otherwise I would spend more time in the Topkapi palace instead.

Good Collection of artifacts. This museum is located just next to the Topkapi Palace Museum near gulhane park . It cost us 15TL for entry and another 15TL for d audio guide. The museum comprise of 3 different museums ie the ancient orient ,tiled kiosk and archaeological museum. Many great artifacts can be seen here but it was unfortunate as the hall 8 displaying alexander sarcophagus was close as its under renovation works. The museum has a nice outdoor cafe if you would like to take a break in between the viewing.

Complete chronological history of Troy. My favorite exibition is the complete chronological exibion of the seven historical periods of Troy, including the probable Troy immortalized by Homer in the Iliad. Impressive is the collection of marble sarcophagi. The Alexander sarcophagus (the name comes from the figure of Alexander on the side of the sarcophagus) is impressive. Sad are the wonderful marble scultures mutilated in the faces because of religious intolerance.

Restoration really gets in the way. So much was inaccessible and we were there late morning on a weekday, so the little that was open was choked with school groups. The hall was quickly a screaming echoey mess and it was impossible to reflect on the works available. I enjoyed the ceramic house very much though.
A lot more here than you'd imagine. Planned to go for quick visit and pick up Museum pass. Lots to see. although some renovation ongoing. Good background to history of area...

Well worth the Effort. First, be aware that at the moment there is a major restoration programme on site, but this does not stop you visiting. Essentially, after you pass through the main entrance you will be faced by a building on your left - well worth seeing the displays of ancient artefacts including oldest peace treaty about 2500 years ago. Then there is the tiling museum building - again, worth seeing. On your right there are two sections with tombs, and with Greek and Roman statues. The cafe area is a delight, shaded by trees or inside. NB you can use a Museum Card here if you purchased one, and it is also separate from The Topkapi, not within it.
Restorations ruin everything!. Very big and complete museum! The only downside was that almost half of it was closed for restorations so it really ruined the experience!

Treasure Trove. Archaelogical Museum (istanbularkeoloji.com) is considered the world's finest collections of classical artifacts as well as treasures from the pre -classical world (Treaty of Kadesh, Statue & Bust of Alexander the Great, Alexander Sarcophagus, Karaman Mihrab, etc). There are 20 galleries housed in three stories plus a basement that is being remodelled. Two separate buildings on the same grounds consist of the Cinili Pavillion of Turkish tiles and ceramics, and the Museum of the Ancient Orient. Suggest to focus on a Gallery of Interest & go solo.

All the goodies are here. This was one of the last places that I visited, and it was cool to see all the goodies from the different archaeological sights that I had visited. They have a large section from Troy. There is also a nice display of tiles and pottery.

Amazing Experience. Besides the obvious sights and sites in Istanbul to visit, this must surely be very near the top. It is one of the great musems of the world, quietly tucked away in the Topkapi Palace grounds. I am trained in archaeology and found this place an awe-inspiring experience. There are 6 levels of eye watering exhibits.However, you must know what to look for there are some gems hidden among the collection. The Museum of the Ancient Orient was certainly my favourite. Rarely do you ever see exhibits from what is modern day Iran, Iraq and the near east, Syria and Lebanon. But they are here. Glazed tile images from the Ishtar Gate of Babylon are here and artifacts from the necropolis of Sidon which you must sit down and study to appreciate the amazing detail of these works. There is also the The Kadesh Peace Treaty (1258 BCE) (the worlds first ever peace treaty). When I visited in late September 2014 the buildings were being modified to ensure they withstand seismic activity. I would surely visit Istanbul from Australia again to visit just a handful of sites/sights and this would definitely be one of them.

A must in Instanbul. Everything you read about whilst as a kid on ancient history, those pics you saw in those old text books, well you will find them here. This museum (actually has 3 museums in one) has a vast collection of ancient artefacts and statues. They have so many that they leave some out in the open. Alexander the Great's sarcophogus is the highlight but it is currently closed because the room is under renovation (Sept 2014).

Half of it was closed for restoration.. Two museum pet peeves: if all the good stuff is being restored, charge people less for entry to see the "leftovers". Two: have signs please. Decent signs. Not everyone has the time or patience of getting an audioguide, which is exactly what they're trying to do - get you to rent one. E.g. There are two giant sarcophogi outside that had been the final resting place of two Byzantine emperors. They are now - unceremoniously and in an undignified manner - the storage place of garden tools. They are also unmarked. And no one knows to whom they belonged. Come on, people.

Not worth it at all. The outside of the building was gorgeous - the inside looked like a 70's airport with barely enough items on display to keep us there an hour - and what was there paled in comparison to other museums - and others must know this too because I think I counted 10 people there total. Not worth the money or time.

A fabulous place, almost too much, great buildings. The Archaeology Museum in Istanbul is in Topkapi, near the palace. There is a long cobbled road up to the museum, which is very atmospheric in autumn. One day they may be finished with their endless restoration work. On our last visit the Museum of the Ancient Orient was open, so that we were able to see such items as the Kadesh Treaty, whereas on our prior visit it was closed. The Alexander Sarcpphagus this year was not on view, but many other pieces were, and we saw and took pictures of this on our last visit. Also, they have a museum of tiles, not a great collection, but a beautiful building, the oldest secular building in the city, dating from 1452.The English explanations are perfect, and one can read them easily. Also, this museum is somewhat less popular than the other attractions here, like the palace and Aya Sofia.
Average. Most of the rooms are now closed to visitors due to ongoing renovations. Therefore it is now impossible to see the main attractions. Visit only if you have the Museum Pass.

Don't miss it.. If you are visiting Istanbul, and you are fond of history and archaeology it is a must. It is located in Sultanahmet, close to Topkapi palace, and I did not have to stand in line to get in. There is a small entrance fee of 15 lira. Definitely worth it.
