The exhibitions are divided between the new and the old building, and range from prehistoric era, Anatolian ancient architecture, royal necropolis, sarcophagi, Greek-roman, byzantine, troy and ottoman, to mention some of it. Some of the area are temporarily closed due to renovation. It is really magnificent. The artefacts are interesting, beautiful and diverse. And there is information in English. I highly recommend going there.

Surprised at the Breadth and Depth of the Collection!. We spent a couple of hours in the museum (collections housed in three buildings) and could easily have spent more time here. An amazing number of artifacts are on display with enough of the history in the signage (Turkish and English) to give one a picture of the many ancient peoples who lived in this part of the world. Fascinating! A must-see for any history enthusiast. This museum ranks high on our list of favorite attractions in Turkey. As others have noted, it is less visited than other attractions in the area and therefore offers a respite from the crowds that are a feature of the Sultanahmet.

Nice morning at the museum. This museum is much less visited than the others in the area so it was a welcome relief from the masses that we had encountered the day before. It has a great collection of archeological items and they are arranged in an easy to see manner. Explanations are provided in English. Lots of sarcophagi and pieces of temples. It was very interesting.The museum is undergoing a seismic renovation so we did not get to see Alexander's Sarcophagus but we did enjoy the rest.Also, don't miss the Tile Kiosk and the Ancient Orient museums located on the grounds (included in your admission). They were small but informative and interesting. Overall, it was a great visit and should not be missed if you have time.

Nice quiet day trup. After days spent braving the bazaars and grand mosques of the city, it was lovely to take a day in this shockingly expansive museum. Located centrally next to the topaki palace and the former rose gardens, this museum harbors an impressive catalogue of ancient sculptures from Egypt, Mesopotamia, Syria, the Anatolian region, and even Troy and Palestine. The museum cafe was beautiful (appropriately named "garden of antiquities") with good lattes, fresh juices, and reasonable prices.

Must Visit This Museum. If you are in Istanbul, you must visit this museum. I have been to Istanbul several times, walked by the museum several times, but did not have the chance to visit. We made it there this time. With half of the museum closed for renovations, the collection was quite impressive. The sarcophagi in the collection is amazing! The museum is not as big as the British Museum or the like, but if they actually had their collection from the museums around the world, this would be the largest museum of it's type.

Yawn! The collection is not worth writing home about.... Between the renovation/construction and closure of the most important artifacts and the otherwise "meh" collection, this is not worth going to.It is possible that the artifacts were found in random locations thereby it not being a cohesive collection, but even then, an archaeology museum usually depicts a story, a theme, a way of life. This museum does none of the above. It seems more of a random collection of items not organized or arranged in any specific era or region. It lacks insight into what can be a fascinating era to study and get to know. It was more of "we dug up some stuff and here it is.. enjoy!". Well I for sure didn't enjoy it that much.

Istanbul Archeological Museum. This is a small museum compared to Le Musee du Louvre or Le Musee d'Orsay, but contains wonderful ancient artifacts. Has relics over 2,500 years BC. You can complete this museum in probably one and one half hours. For its size, it will not disappoint.

Not very big. But still worth it. I bought a museum pass, so I went to this museum. It's not too big so you can see it in a short time, which is probably what you want to do if you have already visited other museums and walked a lot.

Humanity's history including cats.. Up there with the best museums I've seen. Work was being done on parts so things were a bit jumbled from a timeline point of view and I didn't get to see the 'Alexander sarcophagus' sadly, but the rest of the museum was amazing. Some of the signage was a bit sparse but I guess that's to make you hire the audio guide.The resident cats were a highlight as it was a chilly, wet day and the staff kept having to chase kitties out of warm, snug hideyholes among the exhibits :)

Archeology. Visit this museum on the way to Topkapi - next to each other!Presentation is very good and exhibits are of high standard, however the museum is presently undergoing renovation, which means that several main exhibits are not available, presently.

If you like ancient history, this is a must. 3 different buildings (mosaic one is quick and you don't really see anything more interesting than what you would see at Topkapi palace). However, the two museums focusing on ancient history and multiple civilizations of Turkey are very interesting -- I haven't been to anything similar so maybe I was overly impressed but I loved the layers of history and artifacts. In fact, the Troy portion of the exhibit was very more interesting than the actual Troy site. I would maybe skip the audio tour -- hard to find some of the exhibit numbers and there wasn't much on the audio that you wouldn't get from looking at exhibit signs. Check when open (I think it's closed on Tuesday when most places are closed on Monday).

The famous Alexander Sarcophagus is not available to view; renovation underway. I found out only after getting to my various destinations, there's a lot under renovation and restoration in Istanbul in September 2014!I toured the Archaeological Museums (9am-10:30am) before Topkapi Palace, but that's my fatal mistake. First, wish I knew BEFORE entering/scanning my Museum Pass the famous Aleander Sarcophagus wasn't available for viewing so I could have planned my 2nd-day itinerary better, and believe me I spent quite a bit of time researching my Istanbul stay. Second, the Museum Pass I spent 85 TL only allows you to enter once (they are scanned) so I couldn't jump over to Topkapi for a few hours and return to the Archaeological Museums at the end of my day, this was a frustrating limitation! Third, I felt rushed at the Archaeological Museum knowing I had to get over to Topkapi Place and the Harem before those lines got too long. So let me repeat this: The Famous Alexander Sarcophagus was NOT Available To View in September 2014 and with the Current Restoration Underway Doesn't Look Like It Will be Available For Awhile.Visit Topkapi FIRST and make the Harem your FIRST stop once inside Topkapi. The lines are very, very long inside and the Museum Pass doesn' t help. The Museum Pass only helps you avoid the line to get into Topkapi Palace.My favorite displays at the Archaeological Museums were the mummies, the earliest know Peace Treaty (Kadesh Treaty), and the Tiled Pavilion is a lovely sight.

Definitely worth a visit but give yourself time . This is a must visit for any history buffs. While the sarcophagus of Alexander the Great is being restored we saw his bust and then so many other amazing things along with learning the history of the areaThey have some amazing artifacts in the museum and even if you just did the "must sees" it's worth the visitGet the audio guide

I was stationed in Ankara, Turkey, but landed in Istanbul First!!. Istanbul was a very Exotic City, what with all the Bazaar's, The Food & the Aroma of all the many kinds of Incense, just like in the Bible that the 3 Traveller's bringing Goods to the Baby Jesus, in Jerusalem, The aromas of Frankincense, Myrrh & the Smell of Turkish Tobacco!! Got to see all the Historic Monuments in this Ancient City. As they Greet You in Turkish, Merhaba Yeni Asker!!

Disappointed - wasted opportunity. I watched people walk around this museum and you could tell people did not really retain or learn a thing (although they were taking a lot of photos). It's a shame with such a fantastic collection that it is presented so poorly. The presentation needs to be modernised. Unfortunately we found this to be true with a lot of the museums in Turkey. Real shame
A must. Wow! I didn't know Turkey holds such a rich archeologic pieces that trace its history. Amazing site and a must see. It really expose old civilizations

Archaeological Museum. Incredibly interesting and comprehensive. Well laid out. Various separate buildings so make sure you have seen all of it. Good snack bar too on the site. Excellent collection of sarcophagi and also exhibits from Troy and Palestine and Tile Pavilion.

Top 1 in Istanbul: Best collection i have ever seen. Chamuraphy codex,Istaura's gate,sumerian art etc. Here you can see the craddle of our civilisation.the collection is so unique,that it is definitely a must to see. Dont miss the oportunity to visit this incredible museum,which has no comparision in the world.

Impressive collections from classical times with lovely Oriental Museum. Located within the Topkapi Palace grounds.There is a separate fee for admission here,which is covered by the museum pass (saves waiting in line).Some areas are closed for renovation(including,disappointingly,the Alexander Sarcophagus).Much else to see nevertheless.Huge collection of sarcophagi dating back to Egyptian times.The Oriental Museum has some beautiful artwork and inspiring design.The al fresco cafe is very nice but overpriced.

Istanbul Archaeological. we purchased a Istanbul Museum passthis prevents you from waiting in lines at the attractionsthis is not crowded and most people dont visit itvery impressive collectionnot worth the audiomissed Alexanders the Great sarcophagus, that part was closedhuge collection finally saw Hittite artifactsif you like walking through history you will like this museum

A great overview. We spent an afternoon here on our first day in Turkey. It served as a great intro to the riches of history that the country has to offer. We did rent the audio guides, and that was very useful, although the buildings are a bit difficult to navigate since the property is so large and is really three-museums-in-one. We enjoyed a sandwich and a soda out on the patio, and were visited right away by the ever-present cats who tried to pry a bite from us with their persuasive ways. Of course, we gave in. :)

great collection of artefacts. the collection is really impressive. you start with Egyptian mummies and sculptures of gods, go throught large collections of Shumeric and Assirian artefacts in very nice conditions, enjoy with Turkish mayolics, huge collection of Greek sarcophages, sculptures, artefacts, the large hall for Troyan culture, nice collections from Syria and Cyprus. all what you saw in your schoolbooks on history here you can see as real, since 5 century BC till 10 century AD

Half of it's Closed! But great potential. The whole ground floor of the museum is closed. This includes Alexander's sarcophagus and most tourist attracting pieces. Quite disappointing but all for the good I hope. Don't get an audio guide because with the work it's useless in the main museum.

Interesting to understand the past. A lot lot lot of statues, antics, stones.. For those who love the past and ancient cultures, the museum is really well made in a quiet park next to the palaceEntrance is included in the Istanbul museum pass

go alone. There are so many amazing displays that meaninful time is needed to absorb them, for those really interested in the content of the museum a single visit can only be accomplished if your concern is what you asre seeing not where your traveol partner is... so no matter what go it alone and meet back at the hotel.
Old school museum!. A pretty large museum, with lots to see and read. Lots of little interesting tidbits throughout the museum. Worth it if making the most of a museum card.

Worth a Visit. How can you rate an archaeology museum other than by its historic content, quality of the grounds and buildings, and the aesthetics of the displays. On all fronts this museum is a solid 4 stars - but watch out for the renovations that are under way and the areas that are closed off. Three smaller buildings contains artifacts going back 10 centuries (give or take a few centuries). Nice cafe to rest at between buildings. Allow several hours for your visit.

Learning Experience. A unique experience to travel trough ancient history with this remarkable museum. Be shure to visit the Egypt area wich it's worth the time. It's a unique learning experience that will last forever. Some of the areas where closed to public, but still the areas that where open made it for them. It will take around 4 to 6 hours to get to complete the whole museum. Worth the visit.

Visit Antiquity!. We bought the "Museum Pass Istanbul" (http://museumpassistanbuldistributor.com/) from the ticket booth when we visited Topkapi Palace. It allows you to visit each of museums on the pass once in a 3-day period. You should try to visit these museums during the week, as weekends were visibly busier. However, in my opinion, if you have the time, I wouldn't try to cram in as many museums as you can in the three days, I would space them out just a little bit (and thus skipping the pass). That being said, though, we are the type of people that like to take our time, take photos, notice details, and we also like to purchase the guided audio tours. We were probably at the Archeology Museums for about 3-4 hours (and part of it was closed for construction). There are 3 different museums: Archaeological Museum, Ancient Orient Museum, and Tiled Kiosk Museum. If you are short on time, I think you'll still want to make it to all three, so pace yourself! Ancient Orient Museum has some AMAZING pieces...walls from Babylon, tombs from Egypt, and MUCH MUCH more! The Tiled Kiosk Museum doesn't take up too much time, but had some beautiful pottery, and it's most famous feature, the "Fountain of Youth." The Archaeological Museum is where you'll need to pace yourself the most. Part of the museum was under construction when we were there, so we did not get to see everything. There were a lot of sarcophaguses and tombstones, then plenty of ancient findings. Honestly, this was my least favorite of the museums, but still incredible! If you are only in Istanbul for a few days, I would not consider this a "must-do," but if you are planning a full trip in Istanbul, then I'd definitely add it to your itinerary!

Intresting. I history fanatic I went through half of the museum and it definitely worth it. my only regret I couldn't complete it due to a personal reason and if I have the chance in the future I will definitely go back.

Informative and Beautiful. I visited the Istanbul Archaeological Museum with my mother, who grew up in Istanbul and had not been to this museum since she was in elementary school in the 1960s. There have been extensive renovations to the museum and it seems like they are doing a great job. Even though some areas were closed, the areas still open were excellent. I adore the Mosaic Museum, such a delight to see! The color schemes are superb. Visitors will take away much knowledge about not only Turkish/Ottoman culture, but also the culture of the greater Middle East and Northern Africa. Everything is written in English and Turkish and the English descriptions are articulate. There is a lovely tea garden (cay bahcesi) on the grounds.

The most important Antiquities of Turkey - but old fashioned exhibition. The archaeological museum is - like many other museums in Turkey and Greece - under restauration and not everything is accessible (2014). Nevertheless, there is still more than you can see within a 3-4 hour visit. In fact the museum is dispatched in three different buildings: ancient cultures of the near east and Mesopotamia, the main building with finds from Troy and many other important sites in Turkey and a presentation of Istanbuls history from the paleolithic to early modern times and a Fayence museem in a pavillion where the architecture alone requires a visit.Its a pity that the presentation is - with few exceptions, for example the sarcophages from Sidon - not modern and indeed quite old fashioned. If you are a fan of archaeology and history the enormous finds on display are impressive and you will be able to see some of the most important finds from Turkish Archaeology, but you should have same basic knowledge of Mediterranean and near eastern archaeology to enjoy this museum. Nevertheless, the garden cafe of the museum is quiet and peaceful place in a crowded city.
Fascinating. This a must see when visiting Istanbul, the artefacts and history will astound you. Could have spent the whole day there, and then visited again and again....

Some areas closed ....... Great place but some areas are closed for renovations. However what was open was great. They sometimes have special exhibitions, which were not on when we were there, these "specials" can be great. We had bought a museum ticket which covered the entry fee into here, well worth while to purchase

A very modern museum with a wide variety of exhibitions.. The museum, or better said the museums (because there are three museums: the Mosaic Museum, The Museum of Turkish and Islamic Arts and the Archaeology Museum itself) offers a wide variety of information about the culture of Turkey and also about the culture of Egypt and the Middle East. It is a perfect place for history lovers. The exhibitions are impressively modernised, so it is very nice to see them. Don't miss the Archaeological Museums if in Istanbul !

A really great museum. For a person who likes history like me, this museum is actually the best attraction in Istanbul. The collections are really great and historical. The museum itself is really big. For a history-lover, you would like to spend about 3 hours there. However, if you are not a history-lover, 2 hours of visit would be enough.
ARCHAEOLOGICAL MUSEUM. they have a lot of great history for people to go and see. When you go there and visit you should make at least have 3 hours to see everything that they have to offer.

Under restoration. Disappointed to find that most of the Classical sculpture galleries were closed for restoration, and so some of the major attractions (such as the Alexander Sarcophagus) can't be seen.
Historic. Was surprised with their renovations that ancient pieces were hauled outside into the surrounding grounds. Interesting but in retrospect would have skipped

A lot to take in. This is a very broad and deep museum dedicated to archaeology. A good 1-2 hours is probably enough for non-archaeology aficionados, as it gets to be a lot of the same, regardless of which region/culture/group the exhibits are related to.

Hidden next to Topapi Palace. All three buildings are well laid out and differentiated. in the large main building there is a very concise history of Troy being chronologically detailed long before and after the Battle of Troy. Another building dedicated to superb mosaics.

Amazing. Lots of really interesting stuff. Although some sections were not open it's still worth a visit. You learn a lot about ancient culture. We could have used a bit more information and better directions.

nice to see. many people seemed to miss it cuz it is on the way out from top kapi. it is to ur right as u go out. it has lots of things to display.
after u finish it and are leaving turn right and walk downhill for 3 minutes and u will be at gulhane park.

currently under renovation, but still worth a visit. I went here on my first day in Istanbul (after a long overnight trip) so I wasn't in the best frame of mind. I wished I had had a guide (but I cheaped out on the audio guide) so I got the highlights. I loved the sarcophagi and much of the statuary, but I was less interested in what was on the upper levels. Were I not so tired, I would have enjoyed it more. Get the audio guide or research beforehand, so you get the best experience. It was also very hot in there. I recommend this as a second tier priority for visiting, after more obvious must-sees such as Sultanahmet Mosque/Aya Sofya/Topkapi Palace/Grand Bazaar.

Great for History Enthusiasts. The great building houses many artefacts and historical items from thousands of years. Statues from the arabian area, Egypt, ancient Rome, Syria and Antalia are present inside the museum. It is definitely worth a visit if you are around the Topkapi or Hagia Sophia. Also after visiting the museum you may sit in the Gulhane park or in the first courtyard of the Topkapi palace which doesn't require a ticket.
hidden gem worth a visit. this place was massive and had soo many amazing giant statues from the greco roman era and hitite era, it is well worth a visit and ony short stroll from Topkapi palace

informative & overwhelming. many centuries of Turkey's rich history highlighting the Roman, Greek, and ottoman influences. Female goddess featured as prominent in Turkish history. Small building to the side with different types of mosaics which was my favourite part of the museum.

Impressive. This was one of the best things i visit in Istanbul. The Archeology Museum is right now compose from 4 buildings. Every one of the buildings represent a diffrent history. The first one it's about Mesopotamia, the other one it s about i think Suleymanie, the third is full with sarchopagus and pices of architecture and the forth is about the evolution of Istanbul.Every piece that is inside that museum is intersting.You must go to the Archelogical Museum is worth the money and your time.
Nice. Wonderful pieces of history. Definitely the place to go to see interesting grave stones and such. They also have a nice cafe to rest in and enjoy some of the sculptures.

It should improve when renovation is complete. We were there during renovation and while many exhibits were still open, there seemed to be a lack of continuity or perhaps we saw too many archeological museums before Istanbul!

Istanbul Archaeological Museum. I loved this Museum. It was amazing! You must visit if in Istanbul, Turkey! There is a fee to get in. Not sure how much. We prepaid, that was in a package deal with an excursion we had taken with our Cruise Ship.

Come back when renovations are done. A lot of the museum is under renovation right now, and unfortunately many of the exhibits have been impacted negatively, with major things missing. Also, the noise of the renovation makes it difficult to enjoy what is on view. There are some very cool things to see still (the Alexander Sarcophagus, for example). The separate building housing the mosaics is also a standout. However, if I had brief time in Istanbul I'd probably spend it elsewhere.
Visit with TopKapi if you have time. Shows old stones and statues from ancient ages BC. Not that interesting if you are not fond of ancient history.

Well worth a visit. This was my third Istanbul visit. I spent 6 hours here including lunch in the indoor/outdoor cafe. Like most museums, there was a portion which was closed. The booklet which was included with admission could have been more clear regarding restrooms and which portions were undergoing renovation. I did look forward to seeing Alexander the Great's tomb and am not sure that I actually saw it is as the signage in that wing was not clear. Non flash photos were allowed. The museum store was good. The cafe did have a limited menu.This really is an amazing museum.
Amazing collection of artifacts!. The collection is huge we weren't even able to see everything (had 3 kids with us)! Hubby was in awe of Medusa's head statue. My kids didn't get bored.

Wonderful outdoor venue, disappointing food. Sitting in the outside terrace of the archeological museum in Istanbul is certainly a pleasant experience. Very sad that the quality of the rather dry and uninspired sandwiches do not live up to the venue.

Mostly closed and what was open wasn't great. Over half of the museum was closed when we went but this didn't become apparent until we had paid for entry-no discount. The amended guide described many of the treasures that were nonetheless closed even though the guide was supposed to take this into account. This included the Alexander Sarcophagus, apparently the best treasure, though we didn't see it. The only cafe we could find open was expensive and only had a limited range of pre-packed sandwiches. We did the whole museum that was open in about 2 hours and had been told it would take all day. We understand that museums need maintenance but it should have been made clear how much was shut before you go in and a discount given. Very disappointed!

So much to see .... This is a large museum but well worth taking the time to explore. Exhibits are thoughtfully arranged, although clearer external signage (maybe part of the current renovations?) would be helpful. I had visited a number of the sites that exhibits came from, which I think was more helpful than visiting the museum without that context.

.An excellent collection of Greek and Roman antiquities. A warning: the Museum is at present under heavy restoration, which means that some of its greatest treasures (eg. the Alexander Sarcophagus) cannot be seen. When finished, it should be one of the great Ancient Museums of Europe

Amazing museum. This is an amazing museum with an impressive collection. It is very organized and even though it is under construction, including the section where the Alexander Sarcophagus is located, it is worth it. Make sure to see the oldest known peace treaty in the world, the Kadesh Peace Treaty from 1258 BC. It is close to the Topkapi palace and a 3-4 hours are needed to see the museum. A cafe and restrooms are available.

Mesopotamia,Arabia and Mediterranean history . The visit will require around 2-3 hours minimum as this is a multi floor venue with plenty to see from ancient greek to phoenician and mesopotamian artefacts,tombs and scriptures from early mesopotamia and the first Phoenician alphabetIt is equipped with lavatories which makes it easier to stay longer inside despite the heat in certain areas Cameras are allowed but no video nor flash light After the museum try the neighbouring markets much cheaper than the bazar right behind the museum (some shopkeepers are actually from Aleppo multilingual and very friendly

Incredible collection. WOW!!! This is truly the best museum I have ever visited. I especially loved seeing the clay tablets with the world's oldest love poem, and the Code of Hammurabi. My husband loved the Kadesh peace treaty - so many historical artifacts, many of which were several thousand years old. I literally got chills seeing in person things that I've only ever read about. We did all the typical tourist activities while in Istanbul, but visiting this museum was by far our favorite.

Under construction. The museum seems to be very good and with a very big collection, but half of it is closed for a construction. I payed 15 tl and the visit was very nice, just missed the opportunity to fully visit it.

Watch out for ripoff taxi drivers. St Sophia's is fantastic, a definite must see. But beware of cheating taxi drivers. Taxi driver pulled a'switch' con on me, when I gave him a 50TL note he swithched it to a 5TL note, then said I did not give him enough. Turkey seems to be typical Arab culture, they think it is OK to rip people off!

One of a kind.... İf you travel to İstanbul, this place must be seen and spent at least whole day to cover all. Also museum cafe is very good place to take a rest in the living history. İf you miss this place you will be very regretful...
Renovations going on. If you have museum pass it's a place worth to visit after visiting Topkapi palace. Iznik art collection part is really rich and nice.

Plenty of culture to take in!. A very interesting visit to the museums, which have plenty to offer. There are three buildings in total, each of which showcase many different artifacts from various ages. We spent half the day here and didn't make it to the third building, but I enjoyed everything we saw, as well as the cool air conditioning of the buildings on a hot day! The gardens are also very pretty and we enjoyed a tea and a (slightly stale) muffin in the shaded cafe outside.

Very extensive and interesting. Although a large portion of the museum was closed down in august 2014 due to restauration (incl. the Alexander sarcophagus) this was a place to spend hours of rewarding time. Be overbearing with the English translations.

Wonderful museum. This is an absolutely fantastic museum, separated into three parts: ceramics (beautiful porcelain decorated in Arabic style), Classical (Roman/Greek findings incl Alexander Sarcophagus) and the best section, the ancient Orient, which covers ancient Mesopotamia, Sumeria etc.

I love the Tiled Pavilion!. I went for the Tiled Pavilion and was not disappointed. Fabulous building. Wonderful Unique blue tiles, more modern than in the mosques. The building has fabulous details, room ceilings were wonderful, gorgeous windows. Ceramic displays were also very beautiful and unique. Rest of the buildings were interesting, but my focus was the tiles. Under renovation but still lots to see for TL 15. Nice little gift shop and outside cafe as well. Great place to sit in the shade.

A terrific museum, with one typical little misunderstanding. OK, it's a great museum; i particularly liked the Hittite Lions that are still snarling after 3000 plus years. There are several buildings containing fantastic artifacts from different areas and eras, societies and walks of life. You could easily spend a day here, particularly since the little cafe in the center courtyard has not bad basic stuff, and is surrounded by gorgeous artifacts they simply can't fit under the museum's sizable roof, so they just kinda leave them sitting outside around the cafe. The ever present cats are friendly, so you won't lack for company while you take a break from the breathtaking glimpses into the past the museum offers. And the fact it seems to 'highbrow' for the cruise lines doesn't hurt the line situation either-there wasn't one when we visited, huzzah. OK, the 'one thing': It's not Alexander the Great's sarcophagus, it's a sarcophagus WITH depictions of Alexander on the outside. It seems to be a common bit of confusion, and some disappointment seems a common complaint. Other than that little bit, and the lack of A/C, it's a flawless, don't miss gem.
extraordinary. this is honestly one if the best museums i have ever visited. not sure why more people dont talk about it. stunning collection
beautiful. needed more time, a wealth of information and beautiful displays. Near the Topkapi museum. You can go as part of the Musea card 85 TL.

good museum. Have been here before and really loved the place and collection.this time we visited and were confronted with a partially closed for renovations museum.the best parts were not accesible.alexanders sarcophagus which I had raved about was not to be seen.very annoying.

A real treasure!. Besides the beautiful location in the Top Kapi compound, the museum covers all the history of Istanbul and not only, fantastically organised, don't miss the Orient part, which is Superb!

Fantastic Historical Display. The museum is close to Topkapi Palace and both should be done together to give an insight into Turkish history. The museum is well set out with explanation plates in Turkish and English. Some of the archaeological finds from the ancient world are stunning. There is also a big portion of the museum dedicated to the historical story of Istanbul. Well worth a visit.

Excellent Artificats of Ancient and Middle Eastern History. Because the Ottoman Empire stretched over much of the Middle East, they acquired priceless artifacts throughout their history. This is an impressive collection, particularly given that the museum is not the size of the Louvre or the British Museum. Inside you will find an Egyptian collection, ancient Babylonian and Assyrian relics, and artifacts from the places such as Troy, Constantinople, and the Holy Land.Of particular highlight were the panels of the Ishtar Gate. Anyone familiar with these blue tiles will be amazed that they still exist! Also, among the collection are old writings (such as the first peace treaty in human history), a piece of the enormous chain that guarded the Golden Horn, and weapons from throughout history. If you are in anyway a fan of history or antiquity, this is a definite must. Though much of the museum was under rennovation when we visited, there's still much to see. There's even an entire building dedicated to gorgeous tilework.It's just down the road from Topkepi Palace and the Hagia Sophia; however, as most people don't seem to visit here, there's a lot less people inside.

Old style. İ was very expecting before I viisted this museum, but dissapointed. I think its collections may be enourmous but I couldn't see so many things. The facility is old and display is old-fashioned.

Don't miss the Tiled Pavilion. If you are a history enthusiast you will probably love all 3 of the museums, they certainly have plenty of exhibits, but for me the Tiled Pavilion stood out as one of my favourite places in Istanbul. It is an amazing showcase of tiled patterns and highly recommended.

A break from the crowds. We visited this museum as it was one of the places on our museum card. Less crowded than other attractions, it was very interesting, well described artifacts (some very creepy ancient mummies) and gorgeous tile work. The outdoor cafe under large shade trees with friendly waiters was a great and inexpensive place to re-fuel. Go early for best selection though!

Great place to spend 2-3 hours!. Tremendous history in these well-designed museums. They will take you 2-3 hours and is a LOT of walking, so I wouldn't try to do it the same day as Topkapi Palace. Its right inside the entrance to the Palace grounds, on the left down the hill. Get the audio guide, which tells you the most important stuff as you walk, as there are too many plaques to read within a reasonable amount of time. Stop for a coffee or tea in between the individual museums at the overpriced cafe-- your feet will thank you!

Nice but not great museum. Not a very large collection and it does not compare with the museum in Ankara. Still, it is worth a visit. The statues from the classic period are beautiful.The nearby oriental museum is also worth visiting.
Good collection. Surprisingly good collection. Not too big to be accessible. Garden cafe. Not too crowded either. Got ticket as part of Museum Carte package. Worth a visit.

Very big. The building itself is worth seeing. Unfortunately most of the sections are closed due to the restoration. One or two hours will be enough now. After the restoration, you definitely need a half day in the museum. Do not miss the Orient museum at the entrance. The first peace agreement of the world is there.

Fascinating. Massive - Turkey's archaelogical history is so rich, deep and explansive you will need at LEAST half a day to take in this amazing, interesting museum. Seriosuly, should not be missed. Near the Topkapi Palace - I suggest spending half a day at each.
one of the interestin sightseeing. Archeological museum in Istanbul one of the biggest in the world - the second after the British Museum.
Good visit. I adore antiquities, so of course, I loved the museum. We stumbled onto it while walking in Gulhane Park and really enjoyed it.
Best Museum in Istanbul. If you like history you can not miss this museum. There are too many highlights to list. It is MUST DO for any Istanbul trip for any history inclined person.

Could have spent the whole day in there!. What an amazing collection of sculpture and artefacts - really takes you back in time. The sarcophagus were beautiful, so were the busts of Alexander, Marcus Aurelius, Athena... and so much more. Really felt like a gallery of greats coming alive! I could only visit one wing in about 3 hours. To make the most of your ticket, give yourself a nice long viewing span. Spoiler alert: The Alexander Sarcophagus isn't really his.
Lots of interesting displays. Needs a bit of updating but stil has lots of really good ancient ruens of the many civilizations that started in Turkey.Well worth a visit.

Great collection but disappointing. Half the museum was closed, signage was poor, lighting was poor, overall presentation was lacking despite a lot of great stuff. Must see the small tile museum, it is beautiful!

reasonably priced vast collection in a building site. even though its a building site there are large sections still open. they have cut the price down to account the smaller selection yet it still seems to be big and a little confusing narrative. Along the way you forget that you are looking at over 8000 years of history. amazing.

Disappointing. We were disappointed as the museums appear to be poorly laid out with no clear signposting or information. There is renovation work going on which may have been a factor but an extremely disappointing visit. Topkapi was far more interesting from an artefacts point of view although I appreciate the museums are not like for like. Personally I would only visit if I had the time

amazing what they have here. This museum is one of the best in the world if you love Roman and Greek sculpture. There is a collection of sarcophagi which is fascinating and includes the Alexander Sarcophagus, well over two thousand years old and almost pristine. The carvings of the soldiers were coloured, who knew they wore such bright colours and looked relatively modern. However, we went last week and the museum is being refurbished so much, including the Alexander tomb, is not on display. We still enjoyed it though.

A truly magnificent museum!. I spent many hours walking around the 3 buildings that comprise this archaeological museum. The displays are well laid out and the number of exhibits is quite extraordinary. Easy to walk to from Sultanahmet, I highly recommend a visit.

One Our Best Experiences in Istanbul. We took our kids and spent the whole day there. It is consisted of a series of buildings filled with ancient artifacts and each building is devoted to a different era of history from Babel to Persian, Greek, Egyptian and Roman empires to more recent tile, glasswork and pottery of Ottoman empire. You can see mummies, skeletons, sarcophagus, and many tablets and drawings there. Unfortunately a big part of the museum was under renovation but still we managed to be there for a whole day. One of the good things was the electronic audible guide the we rented at entrance that you can enter the number next to artifacts and it gives you a complete description about it, also it has sensors and some of the descriptions play automatically when you are next to an artifact. I recommend the audible guide since the staff there are mostly guards than guides and the descriptions next to artifacts are very brief.

Fascinating: The very first civilization.. You will find the history of thousands of years in these museums.
The Topkapi has relics of the prophet. the Name-i-Saadet,
3 hairs off of mohammed's chin... I saw and photographed a letter written by very the hand of Mohammad the prophet, threatening all of the Coptics... Convert or die.

full to the brim with artifacts. this place is really packed with history on three floors. There are also three different buildings, i went to two.getting a museum pass, does get you a bit museum tired, but if you have got a pass check this place out.i enjoyed the classical status, and the Tiled house, I didn't spend as much time as i would like there, but this place if worth a visit if you enjoy going to museums.
Okay. Some nice bits, but was being renovated which made it a mess and hard to get around (like forcing you to walk back round the entire building to get back out). Staff were not friendly at all.

Excellent museum and beautiful grounds. Right next to Topkapi, the Istanbul Archaeological Museums are not to be missed, with impressive exhibits and beautiful grounds to enjoy. You can choose to go into one building or all three, but you will see some amazing artifacts and recognize the importance of Istanbul throughout history. The room detailing all the districts of Istanbul and their historical artifacts is a must see, as well as the Egyptian and Mesopotamia rooms.

The City. Visited Istanbul as an Independant traveller intending to spend a short time exploring the sights, ended up spending our whole holiday there (14 nights) as the culture and sights where unbelievable, from Mosques to Museums to Palaces to Galleries to Eateries, the choice was endless, B&B Prices were reasonable depending on your requirements and no problem in finding accommodation. Local food is inexpensive but alcohol is expensive. Travel by local authority transport (trams ,buses,boats)is cheap if you buy top up contract passes. Be prepared for a stewpot of cultures.

Even better when renovations are done. Parts of the museum have been beautifully renovated and the presentation of the artifacts is excellent. Other parts are still awaiting work and rather "dusty", but the museum is well worth a visit if you have any interest in the subject or simply appreciate beautiful works of early art.

a lot of history. I'm not the typical person to visit archaeological museums, but this one is really good. There's so much of the culture of the area gathered in one place. I think there were some renovations going on so we might have missed some things
One of Best on World. Istanbul Archaeological Museums are one of best museum on the world , many historical statue from central anatolia and front Asia,
Museum. The main part is under refurbishment and you pay 15 Tl full ticket to see small part of the museum And they don't tell you that on entrance .

Needs time. I was a bit surprised how empty the museum was compared to the rest of the area. The collections are overwhelming, there are areas about most of the important old civilizations, too much to see if you don't have much time.The tile museum is also worth a visit.

Some amazing peices of history. Spending the morning wondering around the mueseum is a fantastic way to grasp some of the historical and cultural heritage of Istanbul. Make sure to visit if you have time.

Half shut!. We arrived to find that half the museum was closed for renovation work including one of the main exhibits, the Alexander Sarcophagus. However, there was no reduction in the entry fee. The café was awful, with a very limited selection indeed. This "all day" attraction took us less than half a day to go round as even more was closed than was claimed at the entrance.
Renovation. Under renovation. Alexander's sarcophagus could not be viewed and the major treasures were crammed in to a narrow area.

Fantastic collection, but some areas closed. This museum is worth a visit of at least a half day, even though it's under renovation, and some areas are closed. It's wasn't crowded like the Topkapi palace, so you can take your time to really enjoy the exhibits. We paid for the audio guide, which points out the main highlights, but doesn't really have more information than the posted descriptions, which are in Turkish and English for the most part. If you are counting your pennies, just skip the audio guide and read the descriptions.There are a lot of stairs and the elevator was not functioning when we were there, so check on that before you come if mobility is a problem.Also small cafe in the garden is a lovely spot, but they had run out of most items by the time we came to eat lunch, so maybe it's a better spot for a coffee.
was ok but didn't like it. The museuam has some old architectures and monuments from different eras all from the istanbul and surroundings civilixzations.
Make time for this. Another attraction that was partially under renovation but worth the time... took me about 3 hours but I'm a slow poke in museums.

Well with the time. Really interesting and worth the hour or so to walk around. there are some excellent artefacts. Buy your museum pass her or the mosaic museum and save yourself a lot of queuing at the major attractions. It also gets you out of the sun for a little while if you need to do so

Time well spent. I totally enjoyed the 3 hours that I spent slowly wandering through the three sites of this museum. It was an oasis after hours spent walking through Istanbul's tourist sector.I started in the Museum of the Ancient Orient, which is on the left when you enter the complex. It's beautifully laid out, and was very quiet, peaceful - until a group of school children entered and raised the decibel level considerably, but fortunately after I'd been there about one hour. I hastened to the Archeology Museum which is being renovated (July, 2014). While I couldn't find some of the artworks mentioned in my guide (probably due to the closed areas), there was so much to see and enjoy, such as the Istanbul through the Ages exhibit.Finally, there is the Tile Pavilion. Personally, I love mosaics and tiles. This was a (relatively) small space - yet, I enjoyed it immensely, attempting to grasp the various types of tiles and ceramics that it had to offer.

Impressive Collection . This is one of the best Museum I have ever visited. With more than a million collection in it from many different period of time. The architecture of the museum is really amazing, I felt it took me to the era where the collection was created. Different architectures in different kind of collections. This is the must visit in Istanbul and must be on your list. To whom don't like museum will definitely change their mind when enter this one. I love it, Istanbul Archeological Museum.

Spectacular exhibits, but under renovation. We arrived quite late in the day and started with an iced coffee in the amazing shady courtyard cafe surrounded by ancient columns, statues and relics. Then went through the oriental and main galleries and were stunned at the quality of the pieces on display. Information about the museum was almost non- existent in English but most of the displays had English and Turkish explanations. The gift shop was closed which was a shame as it had some quality items we hadn't seen anywhere else.But it still had the wow factor and I would happily return.

Only one word to describe this: Great!!. This was an awesome museum in Istanbul. the price of admission is included with the museum card. You can easily spend a whole day here if you want looking at the various artifacts. It is in close proximity to The Topkapi palace and other sights in Istanbul.

A must see. Not as crowded as the Topkapi Palace, this is yet another must see in Istanbul. The collection is extensive and well presented. Allow yourself enough time to see the entire collection. Of particular note are one of the three snake heads from the serpent column located at the nearby hippodrome and the chain used to block the Golden Horn. The Roman sculpture gallery and ceramics museum are also noteworthy. After visiting the museum, be sure and stop for a drink in the sculpture garden.
Nice.. But could be quite boring if you're not really a history enthusiast! It tells a lot about the amazing, rich history of Turkey.
Spend a whole afternoon there! You won't regret it!. The amount of treasures...covering all the 4 major empires..all in 1 room. You absolutely cannot miss this place.

Where did all these artifacts come from?. Interesting buildings and good descriptive signing of displays. Some exhibits closed (blocked off) made navigation a bit of a maze. Audio guides enhanced the visit.

Expected more, but still worth the visit.. Glad to see that this place is under renovation - it could definitely use some new technology and greater interaction to lift it to a world class attraction. Plenty of interesting materials, information and artifacts. Mistake was to purchase the :audio guide" - there are not many items available in the audio guide (maybe one tenth of the items had audio numbers) AND there was MORE information printed in English on the wall associated with each exhibit.

Surprising Find of a Museum. If you are staying in old Istanbul walk to park main entrance. Take the right fork in the road and go up hill. Initially you will find a sort of Greco art building and along side the road are loads of Roman/Greek remains. Once you get to the museum entrance and pay your entrance fee you will find many sites with truly good exhibits. This is as site worth seeing. Additionally you can walk up this museum to the Topkapi Palace.

One of the world's Best. An entirely unexpected treasure of riches from Troy, the ancient Middle East, the Ottoman ceramics and the history of Istanbul itself through the Byzantine era and on. Other wonders include rarest sarcophagi from Sidon as excavated and brought to Istanbul by Osman Hamdi Bey in the 1880s. The so-called Alexander sarcophagus is an astonishing masterpiece of historical narrative carved in Greek marble and thrills the viewer with its hidden expectation of ancient events to be eternally appreciated. The museum is under renovation and much of it is closed. But what the knowledgeable visitor has at hand is so enticing that a good two hours is a minimum.

History at it's best - again. I ran out of battery power in the camera during my visit, but that didn't stop me from wandering through the exhibits and having a wonderful time just looking. There is so much history within the walls of these buildings, only wish more people could give credit when it is due, such wonderful intricate work over all the cultures that have made Istanbul their home

My Favourite Sightseeing Location in Istanbul. There is so much to see in Istanbul - you can't do it all justice within a couple of days. But if there's one spot that I'd recommend visiting, it's this Museum. There are 3 different buildings and Museums is this area. The Archaeology Museum, the Ancient Orient Museum and the Tiled Kiosk Museum. I only visited the Archaeology Museum - and it blew me away.The depth of it's collection is amazing. As I wandered between the different halls and collections, I just couldn't believe the historical artifacts I was viewing. I spent a couple of hours wandering around, and next time I visit Istanbul, I'll pay this museum a return trip.The building is also impressive, and after the heat and crush of walking around the neighbouring Topkapi Palace - the peace, calm and air conditioning of the Museum was a welcome respite.I had a lot of fun touring the city's sights, but my trip around the "Arkeoloji" Musuem is the one I recall most frequently and fondly.Highly, Highly recommended.

Still lots to see while renovation on. There are great exhibits here, especially the section on Troy and the section of ancient empires (Babylonian, Hittite, Sumerian etc) - while sections are closed for the renovations I would still suggest 2 hours or so for this, especially if later heading to see Troy as it makes more sense then,

Could be more inspiring. Parts of this museum is still currently under renovation and we popped in as part of the 3-day museum pass. Some parts had an odd smell but overall it was a bit dated in the design of the exhibitions (ie glass case of lots of broken pottery with no explanation of the significance) and the layout wasn't logical to navigate round. Lots of promise as there is such a rich history in Istanbul so hopefully the renovations brings improvements.
Currently under extensive renovation. Worth a visit as it gives an excellent insight into the history of Istanbul. The ceramic pavilion is also very good.

An impressive collection. Located close to the Topkapı Palace, this complex includes three museums and a sculpture garden with a very good cafe. The first pavillion is the smallest one, but it includes some of the bass reliefs from the Processional Way that led to the Ishtar Gate - beatiful glazed tiles with lions, dragons and cattle. The main pavillion is a huge construction that was under renovation, making it hard to move through the collection (I had to go back to the entrance by the same path). It is maybe too much information for a single visit: only the exposition dedicated to Troy - its discovery, the excavations, the many layers - could keep a history freak busy for hours. What I liked most about the museum is how the historic artifacts from the Istanbul area are displayed in context with the current locations. I strongly recommend that you visit this exposition AFTER you have taken a few strolls around the city in order to understand its geography.But the best is the third pavillion, the Çinili Köşk (Tiled kiosk): a small building covered with tiles that displays a limited collection of tiles. It is almost a test of how much beauty you can take. While inside the building, take a look at the high windows with stained glass: as you move, the double layer with different patterns play with our visual cortex as the colors seem to intensify and even move around.In between the visit to the pavillions, relax at the cafe in the sculpture garden. Their pistacchio cake, by the way, is quite good.

Three Pavilions. Orient History, A museum of tiles and a museum of Istanbul through the ages. All these are worth seeing. We almost missed the museum of tiles because we did not purchase an audio guide. We made the mistake of buying our museum pass at Topkapi . Much better to buy it here as the lines are much shorter. We were quite happy not having a guide and with not purchasing an audio guide. We had used audio guides at Topkapi and Aya Sofia so we did not buy one here. The order we saw places was Topkapi, Aya Sofia, Blue Mosque, Haggia irene and then this one which I think worked well for us. In the afternoon we went to Grand Bazaar.

Many awards for excellence. You woul not expect such an extensive museum on different civilizations, especially Byzantium. It is one of the 10 most important world-class museums designed and used as a museum building.http://www.istanbularkeoloji.gov.tr/main_page

allow enough time. The archaeological museum is in fact a complex of four separate museums, we did not allow sufficient time to enjoy this complex (excuse for a return trip to Istanbul). The main museum was being renovated when we visited but even so in the couple of hours we had allocated on our last day we had to skip a great deal just getting a flavour of what was present. The museum is well laid out although the descriptions of the artifacts were less developed than we are used to with British museums.

So Interesting. This is the type of museum that you want to visit time and time again because there is just too much to see on one visit. Pick the period of Turkish history you are interested in and focus on that, or be overwhelmed by the whole thing. Wonderful, beautiful collection!

Learnt a lot about early Byzantine history. The museum was undergoing restoration and earthquake proofing. So it was a bit difficult to get round different parts. I have a feeling I missed a large part but I had museum fatigue anyway at that point. It takes you from the Stone age settlements, through the establishment of the early city state, the Greek and Roman conquest of the city, the establishment of Constantinople right through to the conquest by the Ottomans. This is where I seemed to have got lost as I couldn't find anything about the Ottomans onwards but no matter. Well worth seeing.

Interesting museum located right next to Topkapi Palace. I found this museum to be quite interesting with some exhibits more riveting than others. The sarcophagi were probably the more interesting things I found. This visit took me about 2 hours to see everything.

stunning. The British Museum is the world standard of course but these museums are a bit smaller but just as impressive. The difference is that these pieces were found locally, all of them, Greek, Roman, and Ottoman. Sometimes I think that the locals couldn't dig a garden without uncovering a statue of an Emperor. My advice is to NOT take a tour, they tend to breeze in and out. Buy a good book or take a look on line.

Just alright. The Archaeological Museums were pretty cool, but not nearly as exciting as the other sights you can see in Istanbul. If you have the museum pass, it is worthwhile to stop in and see them, but if not, you aren't missing out on too much by skipping it. They are located in a very museum-heavy and easily accessible area, so they are great as a time-filler if you find yourself with a little bit of time and nothing to do.
Extensive Museum. Much larger and more extensive in collections through the Byzantium, Constantinople periods than I expected. Well displayed and presented with adequate information.

Many hours spent in the museum. Archaeological Museum was included in the Istanbul Museum pass and it is worth going if you are patient to spent several hours in the museum. The exhibitions are vast and there is lot to see. Very interesting historical time line of Assyria, Mesopotamia and Persia was presented in the exhibition as well the history of Ottioman empire. Perfect for museum and history lovers!

Major remodeling underway. It's a great museum, but be aware that (as of late May/early June 2014) a number of galleries are closed for a major refurbishing. It was still worth the trip and we especially enjoyed the "Tiled Kiosk Museum" (actually a palace) with a brilliant collection of Ottoman tiles and other ceramic work. It's right across from the main entrance to the museum and might just be the favorite part of your visit. One admission covers both.

Museum Pass. While it wasn't the plan to visit, we were sure happy that we did take the time as it was wonderful. There are artifacts from a number of eras including items dating back to 2,500 BC. It shows you the various cultures that have built Istanbul. Our plan was to visit Topaki and the Sophia museum, but with our pass it allowed us 6 venues and one of the best was the Archaeological Museum. All the venues were within close proximity to each other. We spent 2 days and the pass at 85 TL saves a good amount of money.

One of the best museum on civilisations!. As with any sizable museum, it is impossible to cover every single exhibits and details in a matter of a day. There are so much to see in this museum despite certain sections were closed for restoration works. Even before one enters the Archaeological Museum proper, there is the tiled kiosk museum (Cinili Kosk) in a separate building that houses some of the most beautiful tiles and pottery of Iznik and other parts of Turkey.Some of the important exhibits not to be missed are: the Treaty of Kadesh, Sidon Royal Necropolis including the Alexander Sarcophagus, and the various artifacts in the section "Istanbul through the ages". One can really appreciate the significance of Turkey in the human civilisation by walking through this museum.

Do not miss it. This is a wonderful museum and it is worth spending a half day here. The Museum is in 3 buildings and all are worth a visit. There are wonderful sarcophagi in the main building and early Babylonian friezes in the 1st builing on your left as you enter

Cross road of cultures. I honestly was not interested visiting this museum before the trip. That was until our local friend told us he was extremely impressed with the museum. So we went to visit and it is truly impressive. This museum shows you that Istanbul is really a cross road of different cultures, such as Greek, Roman, Ottoman, and others. It holds many interesting artifacts and has very interesting information on some of the ancient sites.

Huge, spend a day wondering in this large museum. We decided to visit this museum for a less hectic day. We walked up to the neighborhood, passing through little streets off the beaten track. When we arrived there, it felt like we were the only ones. The museum has multiple wings and actually a day isn't enough if you want to examine everything closely. It is a showcase of Istanbuls historical nature and showcases everything it has on offer. Beautiful. The exhibits are very diverse and were of high quality, spanning different subjects and artifacts. There's something for everyone there.

Must be the first thing to do in your istanbul attraction list. If you are interested in archaeology and ancient civilsation's history, museum is the perfect place to visit. Even if you are interested in those it is still a perfect place to visit. İstanbul Archaeological Museum is the third largest archaeological museum in the world. It is famous with piece called "The Alexander Sarcophagus". The tomb does not belong to alexander the great but its reliefs describe alexandria war.It is not an easy and ordinary museum, i can sayit is louvre of istanbul.Entarance fee can seem a bit expensive and museum is worth to penny you will pay
Anatolian History must be seen. İstanbul Archaelogical Museum content is from very different sources. İn the halls about İstanbul's history you can see remains of several civilisations.
Istanbul with Sinon Erol. Very informative -- excellent collection. We did this ourselves...not worth the time if you only have two days to see the city.

Impressive collection. Amazing collection of artifacts and relics from past civilizations and empires all over the middle east and Egypt, dating back 7000 years. I agree with other reviewers that exhibits lacked more detailed explanations but it didn't bother us too much since we only had half a day to roam through the many parts of the museum. We would have stayed the entire day if we could. Not to miss!

Visit this museum if you have spare time. Not one of the top sites.. It is next to the exit of the Topkapi Palace. There are 3 buildings. You can rent an audio guide a the entrance. Nice buildings, I thought the exhibits lacked explanation. Entrance included in the museum pass.Free wifi in the museum cafeteria. Not one of my top places to recommend in Istanbul.

Very impressive!. This is not the first museum you visit in Istanbul but if you are interested in history and/or archeology it is a must. Very impressive collection of beautiful artefacts - and a lovely tea garden to relax in afterwards.
Awesome X 10. There are relics and artifacts from all over the middle east.Egypt, Syria , Iran , TurkeyWe loved them all.
Interesting Museum. Well worth a visit especially if you have the 3 or 5 day Museum Card. Serious renovations underway at the minute and parts are closed. Some amazing objects on display!
Superb - Must visit in Istanbul. This superb museum houses the best and most fascinating exhibitions. It's one of the must visit museum.

Lots of current renovations!. Highlights were the tile museum and the Sidon necropolis. Unfortunately the highlight, the Alexander sarcophagus was not on view owing to building work. Still a wonderful display of historic work and one should make this a "must see" in Istanbul.
Just a bit boring. If you like old artifacts and statues,go! If not, no worries. Personally I thought it was like an old-fashioned classroom. No ambiance whatsoever.

Çinili Kiosk - a full range of historic Turkish ceramics. We visited only this part of the Archeological Museum, having come from an absorbing visit to Topkapı Palace. The kiosk itself is ancient with monochrome tiles of a Seljuk persuasion. Inside, there are several large rooms devoted to Iznik, Kütahya and Çanakkale pots of high quality, and the display is high quality.

India to Turkey Travels - Excellent services for visitors. I had the privilege of visiting Istanbul for a week from 25 May to 1 June 2014. Before the visit I was searching through Trip advisor website for a travel agency which could organise my local tour in and around Istanbul. I came across India to Turkey travels tour organisers and sent them a mail on the places which I wanted to visit. The firm's representative Mr. Yunus was not only very kind and quick in responding to my query but all the went beyond his call of duty and guided me so meticulously not only on the places I should visit but also beautifully arranged all my trips including the one to the historical place Troy, besides all the local sight seeing tours. He was so kind that he visited me personally in my hotel soon after my landing there on 25 May and even went all the way to show me the vegetarian hotel in IST which was close to my hotel. I wish the tribe like Yunus may increase in this world! I wish them all the very best and recommend would be Indian visitors make use of their best services. Rajan N.S. Bangalore, India.

Fascinating, even if you are not an expert.. I loved the museum and appreciated the vision of the man who made it all happen. It was not overrun by crowds, and the interior of the buildings are mainly spacious and cool. I understood far more of the history of Turkey, particularly in relation to the Hittites. A great visit.

magnifies beautifully the profound historical significance of this region. a visit here will not only nurture the Indiana Jones inside you, but it will enhance your understanding of just how much of a huge portion of significant history of the world has passed through this geographical area, and the civilizations that go back to the earliest recorded times, that have influenced almost every modern society that exists now. I am no archaeologist but this was a great visit and I recommend it to all.
worthwile. The explanation of the history of Anatolia and the collection of art was very impressive. Before you go buy a museum card of Istanbul!

Wonderful and fascinating, and you get so close to the exhibits. Loved the friezes from the Ishtar Gates, the Egyptian mummies, the tiled pavilion and so much more. The ancient erotic art was something of a surprise!!

Sarcophages. An unexpected collection starting with beautiful sarcophages. A walk through the more than 2000 year old history of Istanbul. The architecture of the building is outdated and now partly under restauration.

Thorough collection. The museums cover the following topics: Greek, Roman and Anatolian civilizations, Eastern civilizations, and Ottoman tiles. Their collections are extensive and feature the right amount of complementary information for the common visitor. Highly recommended.

Amazing Museum. This museum is huge, just when you think that you have finished there's another floor or building! But with the layers of history in Turkey this is perhaps not surprising. It is well worth spending the time to see all the amazing items and the buildings are well designed to show them off appropriately.

Overwhelming, unbelievable. This museum is an archaeological dream. 3 floors, with the top not quite finished. It has amazing exhibits. Our suggestion, if you like history and archaeological items, visit twice. It is information overload. If you get the 3 day pass, most recommended, you can avoid lines and visit more than once all of the important places. Worth the initial investment and you save money to boot. Do the first floor and return for 2nd and 3rd floors. Floor one is twice the other 2 floors at this time. A great little on site cafe in courtyard amongst the artifacts, statues. Visit before or mid or after or all three depending upon your needs. Take hand sanitizer and use throughout your tours!
Remains of the Day. Some wonderful carved sarcophagi - luckily escaped from being dragged off to the British Museum! If you are in Istanbul for more than 2 days, you must try to fit this one in.

meh. It could have been better laid out as the only way to get out was to go back the way you came (one part). It could have been clearer as well. To me (untrained archaeological eye) it seemed like the same things (marble statues, some old scripts) over and over again. unless you love this stuff, id skip it.

Superb Visit. I had to visit this venue twice as we hadn't been to Troy when we first visited. It was great to go back and see the wonderful displays of the different layers of all nine Troys.Also wonderful sacophogi with equisite decorations and some great marble statues.
Not so impressive. Archaeological Museums are not so impressive as compared to other attractions in Istanbul.. Moreover, one museum is closed for restorations.

Cafe excellent. We loved the tile museum. The archaeology museum lay out left a bit to be desired. I did not like having to back track all the way through the museum to exit. I am blaming that on the current renovation. We spent a couple hours enjoying the cafe next to the tile museum overlooking Gulahne Park. It was so cool and comfortable. The exterior of these buildings are lovely and the sarcophagus collection is world class. It was not crowded at all compared to Topkapi or even the park below. The garden next to the tile museum mixed in discarded columns and sculptures in with the natural plants and it made for a lovely scene.

A highly interesting insight. I was most fascinating to see first hand historical artefacts of the ancient Mesopotamia. This was a special treat for me. The museum was very well laid out with many evocative exhibits which were both fascinating and educational.

oasis in the city. Impressive selection of archaeological treasures of the rich Turkish history, divided over several buildings and the garden. A true oasis in the city, next door to the Topkapi Palace.

Must see museum. This was very close to Topkapi Palace and can easily me overlooked, but don't. The First gallery/ building housed a fantastic acheological history of Turkey and it's people. The next gallery we visited was the Sarcophagus gallery , which was an amazing display of highly crafted sarcophagi. Some of these were a bit eerie given that they were made to house the dead but the craftsmanship was truly stunning. Loaded with narratives and sculpted figures/ forms. Lastly , we looked at the Tile Gallery which displayed various works of tile and ceramics . One Gallery was closed for contruction or repair. This Museum gave us a better understanding of the Turkish people and heritage as well as an appreciation of its arts and crafts.

Very interesting. We went specifically to find the Serpent Oblisk made from the melted Persian Weapons. We found it and a whole lot more. So very interesting. What a great place. The Tiled Rooms are ASTONISHING!

Poorly explained artifacts. The museums have an excellent collection of artifacts but they are not all very well explained. These museums are best explored with either an audio guide or an actual guide. I also found that the museums are not friendly to disabled persons. I am no expert, but I did not find many ramos that would facilitate wheelchairs or strollers. Not every exhibit is thoroughly explained and many artifacts do not have dared or explanations. This may be resolved by using the audio guides.

Excellent in its specialties. This is a great museum, because its highlights are just so spectacular. The "Alexander" tomb, other tombs, gravestones, etc. are all engaging. The upstairs floor that is 50% dedicated to artifacts from the seven layers of Troy isn't presented in a very compelling way (could be updated) but the artifacts themselves are important and along with other finds presented on that floor, you get to the very earliest eras of human settlements in the region. Since I had already visited Topkapi when I got here, the Islamic/Ottoman-era building wasn't very impressive...I'd already gotten my dose of tiles, e.g. Even though there was still some reconstruction underway when I visited, it didn't limit my visit in any way. And, the English signs are good and provide more than enough to read--no audio tour is necessary, unless you hate reading.

A walk through history. A truly great museum, very well layed out and informative, on par with any other European museums. The sarcophagi collection is a jaw dropper! I wish they had a 2-day pass to it (not the 3-day pass to all museums), because 1 day is not enough to start appreciating it.

Will be great once they finish construction.. I really liked this place, but much was under construction. They are retrofitting it for earthquakes, and it messed up the flow of the building. I really liked the blue lions and dragons from Babylon and Ishtar, they were just beautiful.

Archaeological Museum of Istanbul, it is a worthwhile visit.. The Istanbul Archaeology Museums is a group of three archeological museums located in the Eminönü district of Istanbul, near Gülhane Park and Topkapı Palace.The Istanbul Archaeology Museums consists of three museums, Archaeological Museum, Museum of the Ancient Orient and the Museum of Islamic Art. In the most guidebooks, those writing about the museum is very little compared to what will you see. You make a journey into the time 5000 years ago. A large collection of Hellenistic period, Roman, and Turkish artifacts. You can see, the ornate Alexander Sarcophagus, believed to be prepared for Alexander the Great, the Alexander Sarcophagus, found in the necropolis of Sidon is among the most famous pieces of ancient art in the museum. The Kadesh Peace Treaty (1258 BCE), signed between Ramesses II of Egypt and Hattusili III of the Hittite Empire, is a favourite of visitors. It is the oldest known peace treaty in the world, and a giant poster of this tablets containing the treaty is on the wall of the United Nations Headquarters in New York City. Glazed tile images from the Ishtar Gate of Babylon, snake's head from the Serpentine Column erected in the Hippodrome of Constantinople, busts of Alexander the Great and Zeus, fragments from the temple of Athena at Assos, the Troy exhibit, artifacts from the early civilizations of Anatolia, Mesopotamia, Arabia and Egypt etc. It requires a full day to see everything with the right way or the minimum is 3 hours to have a small touch. If you love history it is a worthwhile visit.

Allow a few hours for this attraction. Most attractions in Istanbul can be done in an hour or less...this is one that you should allot a few hours for at least. It houses some very historical artifacts including Alexander the Great's sarcophagus (he's not actually buried in it, FYI) as well as the top of the Serpent Column that you would have seen in the Hippodrome. There was also a mummy of a some king in there....I tried to find more information on who he was online but only found info on his son. Opt for the guidebook, it is needed....it is also a bit of a maze, so be sure you aren't skipping anything.
Amazing collection!. We had a bit of a wait to get in due to a long line, but really enjoyed the museum. Plan on spending a day here, there dis a lot to see.

A Very Nice Collection.. Museum lovers will really enjoy this attraction. There are a number of sections and we were especially impressed with the new section on ships. Even if you are not a museum lover it is a worthwhile visit.

Great Place. The collection here is quite impressive, even compared to similar collections in Rome. While the museum is massive, it's worth a visit to truly appreciate the massiveness of the history of this area.The buildings themselves are beautiful and they have tombs outside the main building you can explore. The Orient Building is especially stunning. Truly, there is a lot of history can be found in this Museum covering a big area where human civilization was established. If you are a history buff, 2 hours is not enough. Great place for lovers of ancient history.

Short history of the human . I am not interested in history but my wife enjoyed so much. The museum is a very big and interesting place. There are so many ancient things, coins, sculptures and so on. And it worth visiting. But there are so many people in a queue. And I spent two hours with my wife in a queue. And she caught a cold. Fortunately it was not a serious problem. Ticket was 15 TL per person. You can take photos without flash. It has 4 floors. You can enjoy wonderful view of museum. I think children will bother inside the museum. Because it takes a long hour to visit the museum. Don't judge me for my poor English

Great Museum. Well worth a visit, it is currently under improvement but a lot of the work is finished and there is much to see. Particularly impressive is the collection of tombs and gravestones from different civilisations and you get to walk right up to them and all around them. The tile and ceramics pavilion is also fascinating and there is a good coffee shop and café in the grounds.

Many parts are currently closed!. The main parts are currently closed for renovation but they don't. Tell you this until you're already inside! Sill a lot of cool stuff to see, especially the mosaic area, but disappointing nonetheless

museum. Superb museum spanning 5000 years of history. All explanations are in English and artefacts well presented. Avoid the café which is overpriced and poor quality. It requires a full day to see everything.

One large lump of stone looks very much like another. Also being 'restorated' which means a lot was closed. The Alexander sarcophagus was most interesting, the rest was poorly explained and seemed to lack theme or development.
Breath taking. A must see place. Some of the exhibits are absolutely stunning. If you're into history a full tour of this facility will take you the good part of a full day.

Arch.museum was superb. Although being renovated, we decided to go to this very special museum.We were completely bowled over. It was such a surprise to see that the museum comprises several buildings and each with such stunning collections of history.The lamb from Manolaus's tomb, one relic of the 7 Wonders of the ancient world. A spot history buffs and the Treaty of Kadish. well, if you like history , this is the place. Allow a few hours and try eating a snack at their Café.One caviat for Ladies, the toilets are a hole in the ground with footprints, and only 3 Ladies toilets of the hole variety. There is a separate handicap toilet in the Ladies, rather use that .

Should be on everyone's short list for Istanbul. This is worth the better part of a day. There is a lot to see. You should definitely rent the audio tour. Conveniently located on the grounds of Topkapi Palace.

History and Art. Extensive museum showing the history of the Anatolian land. Hittites, Lycians, Phrygians, Trojans, Romans, Greeks, Ottomans, as well as Babylon panels. Impressive displays and beautiful presentation. There are several museums here, and though a portion was under renovation, most of the collection was on display. Be sure and look at the tile displays and the funerary art. The curse panels were almost funny.

Not a "must do". This museum is included in your museum pass, but I would not make it a top priority. It is your standard museum with a lot of really cool historical artifacts, but like most museums, it is overwhelming and can take a lot of time to truly appreciate it. If you have a rainy day, then I highly recommend - else, take in all of the other sites in Istanbul!

Rich one.... The museum is very rich. I have been in many museums in Europe but this one seems to be the richest. Statues from Babylon, Hatusha (Hitite city), Mesopotamia etc are extremely beautiful and very well preserved. Also the later antiquity sarcophagus are very interesting, especially the sarcophagus of Alexandre the Great (not belonging to Alexander in fact). That is a century 4 B.C sarcophagus, but looks like carved today. Absolutely the most preserved one in the world I would say.
