Also, if you are a cat lover, the outer space of museum is full of cats and kittens :))) The staff feed them and sometime they use their private rooms to sleep

What can I say...... Fabulous.... and so much to see... well recommended.... a massive selection of sarcophagus, and in a fantastic display. Remember to buy tickets on line it makes thinks so easy! I wish only that some sections were shut for reasons unknown... none the less simply great...

sites. If you choose to tour on your own you can pick up audio tours on site quite often or pick up pamphlets or follow a tour book. You can also hire a local referred by your hotel. Beware of carpet sellers who approach in parking lot just pretending to be chatty, swearing that they only want to make a human connection and not a sale. They are very nice but it's an act. Unfortunately you have to be rude to make them go away. Telling them you won't be buying a carpet, have no room or money for a carpet will not stop them they will ask you to simply come meet a friend for a refreshing drink and hospitality. It's a hoax.

Splendid historical journey!. I love this place!If you have a deep appreciation of the past memory of the Greek, Rome, Persian, and Byzantine, this museum is a must visit.Be sure to read the legendary story of the establishment of Byzantium, Constantinople, and Istanbul.Oh and do take photos in front of the sarcophages of Alexander the Great and the Byzantine Emperors (in front of the museum). A great feeling!
Under renovations. There are great pieces here and lot of history, but because it is under renovations, the exhibits feels very crowded and disorganized.

an average museum.. If you are used to visit museums as the Met, the MoMA or the Louvre, you better keep your expectations low. Other than the two very famous sarcophages, there is very few to admire in here, and the museographic resources are quite poor.

The most extensive museum I have visited. Istanbul Archaelogical Museum is a cluster of museums covering several historic periods from 2000 BC until the Otoman Empire. You will have the opportunity to visit findings from the Babylonia, Assyrian, Egyptian, Hellenistic, Byzantine & Otoman periods. Allow yourselves several hours if you are interested to visit all the buildings!
Istanbul Archaeological Museum. This collection of museums within a central enclosed area is one of my favorite areas because it usually is not extremely crowded.

breathtaking. Loved visiting here, amazing finds and all documented well, lots to see and easy to get around it isnt huge but well worth it and theres a little cafe at the entrance where you can sit among the pieces of history!!!

Exquisite and important - very special. There is so much to love about these museums. They are rich with exhibits that stretch across time and civilizations - so much so that rather then try to list everything I saw I will just say that if you appreciate history and the growth of civilization and want to understand the importance of this region then you are in for a treat. The exhibits are displayed wonderfully - allowing you to spend time up close to examine and appreciate them. Each area and room has a treasure in store. As museums go they are top notch. I spent quite a few hours here but didn't get to see everything. However even if you only have a couple of hours to spend a visit here is well worth it.
Extensive collection of antiquities. The collection spans much of the ancient world: Mesopotamia, Greece, and Rome are all heavily represented in addition to Istanbul, Turkey, and Asia Minor.
Not enough time.. We allowed 3 hours to see this. I would suggest a lot longer to truely appreciate firstly the collection and more importantly, the 'people' from whence it came.

If you have a third day... They have amazing sarcophagi collection as well as some Greek artefacts that will leave you in wonders if you have not seen it before. Couple that with ongoing massive renovation at present, I would give it a miss if you are here only for a few days- you are better off seeing more of present Istanbul like cruising the Bosphorus or taking a food tour:), especially if you are also going to a real archeology site like Ephesus or to Greece.It is included in the museum pass and just outside Topkapi Palace and Gulhane Park (which has the Science Museum, also included in the pass). If you are taking the tram, it is closer to Gulhane stop than Sultanahmet stop.The kids, under 7 loved Topkapi but got bored here after 10 minutes. The audio guide simply parroted out what was written on the information card of each item.The Tile Kiosk was disappointing.
A mind opener. If You think that Istanbul is all about Turks, Ottomans and Islam, be sure to visit Archaeological museum so You can see all the civilizations predating modern Turkey.

Leave plenty of time. Fantastic archaeological museum. Not as awe inspiring as the British museum, but definitely worth a visit of a few hours. Some major restoration ongoing in 2014. The original buildings were built to house the collection from Sidon, Lebanon, excavated in 1887. These include some very impressive sarcophagi, especially the high carved "Alexander" sarcophagus, and the sarcophagus of the weeping women. You get very close to the exhibits, though the lighting is dim. The oriental building has lot of pieces from the Ishtar gate (Babylon, Iraq). It's not as impressive as the construction in the Pergamon museum, Berlin, but there are plenty of impressive animal bas-reliefs, including dragons ( probably the only place other than Berlin to see the dragons?). Use the museum pass to avoid the queues. There was a short line when we visited but it moved very slowly, with only one ticket seller. The audio guide is useful.

Sarcophogi are amazing. This is a great archeological museum, and the sarcophagi are especially amazing. One is so beautifully carved and preserved that the legend is it was made for Alexander the Great. Upstairs exhibits are great also.
Excellent condition, and getting better!. This was our second visit, and they are in the midst of a massive renovation, certain to make this first class museum even better!

Huge!. We were initially not planning to see it as we thought we won't have the time. But we ended up buying the museum pass to avoid the queues at Topkapi Palace and Aya Sofia and the Archaeological Museums were included in the pass. We had some free time on the last day so thought we should use the pass to see this museum. We didn't expect it to be so big and interesting, which was both positive and negative. Positive, because it was a pleasant surprise. Negative, because we didn't have enough time to see it and were very tired by all the walking from the days before. :)Definitely buy the museum pass if you are planning to see this museum as you will most definitely be seeing Topkapi Palace and Aya Sofia. It will end up being quite good value for money and save you the frustration of standing in long lines at the gates of all these places.

Don't miss this. Not your average museum. But the treasures it houses, wow.Easy to miss this one but DON'TIt may be small but it is mighty thanks to the ole toon indie. Good info in English readily available which helped
decent museum. The museum has antiquities from different eras and countries but mostly some incredible sarcophagi. Walking around the grounds is like being in an antiquities scrap yard!

My favorite destination in Istanbul. You can bypass the lines with a 85 Turkish Lera (about 42 dollars depending on exchange prices) which lasts 72 hours and is transferable to others. Worth it in the high season if you are just going to be there for 5 days or less and want to see everything in a hurry. It gets you into many places and in the "VIP" line which is much shorter. Plan to spend several hours in the museum and it's located near the Palace and the Hagia Sophia, and the Blue Mosque to complete a good days travel. Bring your camera and enjoy. Cheers.

So much to see!. Really interesting and loads to see. Great if there's a rainy day as you can be inside for hours looking at the exhibits. We arrived mid-afternoon and queued for 45 minutes to get in, but when we walked past it early the next morning there was no queue at all so get the early to avoid crowds.There are renovations going on at the moment so maybe this means the capacity is lower, hence the queues, but there were only 2 people serving in the ticket office at what was a peak time.

Archealogical treasures abound!. We didn't expect to be wowed by this museum - but once we entered the gates we were totally engaged by all of the antiquities on display! Objects thousands of years old were so trustingly displayed. Commentary and information is available in English and Turkish, though I think audio guides are available in a range of other languages.This museum is well worth a trip. I suggest that you will end up spending more time there than you'd anticipated :-)

Waste of Time and Money. The museum authorities in Istanbul should be ashamed of this place but they seem not to be bothered while the money rolls in. It took us over an hour to get access, having arrived before opening time. There was only one person in the ticket office (who spent a significant amount of the time I could see her texting), 3 security guards manning the gate (to let in 1 whole vehicle that we saw in an hour) and a lady whose sole job was to hold your ticket while the scanner read its bar code. A large part of the museum is shut for repairs and what is on show is, frankly, very disappointing. True, there are some stunning sarcophagi but that's about it. I'm normally interested in these things but the signage and explanations were difficult to read, very tedious and often contradictory. The first floor was a bore. This shambles makes me appreciate what a world class institution the British Museum is but, if you must go and see it, buy a 3 day museum pass which brings you to the front of the queue.

Wonderful Artefacts. Unfortunately much of the museum is closed for renovation. But that which is open is well worth thr trip - right next to Topkapi palace. There are interesting exhibits from Troy and a video about the trojan excavations which is worthwhil. The ceramics from the Ishtar Gate are also fabulous.
must watch for history lovert. Museum is good but I will appreciate more if detailing there guide was good but taking photographs not allowed it disappointed me.
Interesting. Artifacts from different ages and eras. Spanning all the empires that had Istanbul as the capital. Free access with the museum pass. Photography is allowed.
Amazing. Worth visit but please prepare for at least 2 hours as there are so many artefact's from so many historic periods that it is truly overwhelming.

Huge Collection. If you are interested in archaeology, this must be a place. I have huge interests in middle eastern history and that of Ottoman Turkey's but the collection was huge enough although the museum is not fully open. One should spare enough time to observe this museum.

Istanbul Archaeological Museum. Although the Istanbul Archaeological Museum is not included on most tours - probably because of the length of time to visit. I consider it a must if you have the time while in Istanbul. One of the best museums I have visited.

Stunning collection. Visit if only to see the Tomb of Alexandra. The carving on this is unbelievable quality and is in exceptional condition. A large part is closed and under renovation, but it is still worth the visit.

Freebie on Museum pass. This was something to fill a day spare whilst the Topkapi Palace was closed. With the museum pass I strolled past the huge crowd and waltzed straight in - no waiting time at all. Hired the audio guide which was incredibly helpful and set off to explore. The artifacts and history was mind blowing and I thoroughly enjoyed this museum.

History at its best. Great museum that is a must see in Istanbul. Make sure you get an audio guide or a tour guide. So much to learn here. Amazing artifacts in pristine condition that dates back to BC in many cases. Lots of renovations happen all the time but worth the time.
A must. To see the Kadeshi Treaty the oldest peace treaty written on stone and read its contents was a highlight. Also to see the massive Alexander the greats burial tomb.

If you are rushed I wouldn't bother. Although it was nice, there wasn't much information about the objects and personally in hindsight I wouldn't have wasted my time going, since I was there for a short about of time
I expected more. I think a city like Istanbul could have done better. The layout is really bad and the light in some areas quite deficient. I just expected more, but still something you cannot miss.

Worth a visit. A Museum Pass will let you skip the queue. Once inside there are a couple of buildings to visit and a cafe. There is quite a lot on show and information panels are in English (and Turkish). In the main building there is not an obvious order to the way you are directed around the rooms but I enjoyed it all the same.

Good museum if you like archaeology. I visited this museum with my 14 year old daughter, there were some aspects that she found interesting and others that she just wanted to go through very quickly. As it is not a very expensive entrance fee, I would say that it is worth a visit. We rented the headphones, which I found good to explain some of what we saw. I personally found some of the sarcophaguses very interesting.
Under restoration. This museum ıs an excellent museum but due to restoratıon going on at the second floorMany halls are closed to the visit and limited.

Impressive collections. Museum is undergoing renovation but parts are still open. The Royal Necropolis exhibit of Sidon has some highly carved and beautifully preserved sarcophagi that I have ever seen, most looking in pristine condition considering they are 2500 + years old.

If you love dead things - visit here.. If you love coffins, sarcophagi and dead things, this is a great place to go. The Alexander-type coffin is a must see. The history of this region is incredible and you could easily lose hours in here. Even better, its not totally packed with tourists which can be a welcome escape in that area.

It's amazing. The oldest-known love poem was written in Mesopotamia 4,000 years ago and can be found inscribed on a slab of stone in Istanbul’s Archaeological Museum. Istanbul’s Archaeological Museum was the first museum in Turkey but nevertheless ranks as one of the finest and largest in the world with over a million objects. It’s close to Topkapi Palace, on the way to Gulhane Park so very close to Sultanahmet and the other major sights of the city, and is well worth a visit on a day tour of Istanbul. The museum itself is in 3 parts, the main part is in a handsome neo-classical building which houses ancient statues galore from before the Romans, the exquisitely carved Alexander Sarcophagus which depicts the life and battles of Alexander the Great, the evocative Sarcophagus of the Crying Women, the Treasury, Library, coin collections and artefacts unearthed from excavations nearby that form an exhibition of Istanbul through the ages. It stands next door to the 500-year-old Tiled Kiosk which was a royal pavilion beautifully decorated with turquoise tiles and calligraphy, originally the emperors’ private hideaway a little way away from the main palace, and it exhibits ceramics.

Interesting. There was no queue for tickets here when we visited so it was a good place to purchase the museum pass. The audio guide provided extra information about some of the artifacts. There is one section full of sarcophagus and another building full of artifacts found in Istanbul.

The Cradle of Civilization Can Be Found In this Museum. I was not expecting much, but upon entering the museum's main building, was completely stunned in seeing so many thousands of years uniquely laid out for your eyes to feast upon! I came away with a better understanding of the various groups that have fought over and occupied Turkey and left their indelible marks on this fantastic country! Definitely rent the audio for a better understanding of what you will be viewing. In particular, seek out the Kadesh, (first peace treaty), Hammurabi's Code, and the Oldest Love Poem. The various sarcaphagi - magnificent in the carvings and how they are displayed. Stop at the cafe for a good cup of Turkish coffee and a snack. Servers are very friendly and helpful. The grounds abound with many ruins. Be aware that about 1/2 of the museum's main building is currently closed - undergoing earthquake proofing and will not be accessbile. Allow about 2 -3 hours to wander thru the three buildings. It is just a quick hop, skip and jump to the main Sultanahmet wonders - the Topkapi Palace, Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Sunken Palace Cistern, and more!

Still mostly closed.... A large section is still closed!!!!!!!! On and off, they offer a date for the opening of the rest of the museum. Reminds me of Italy, where they close for decades. There is a nice selection but it would be nice if some additional space could be accessed to but a fraction of the collection on public view. Yes, the Alexander Sarcophagus is out - poorly lit in a ghastly dark room. I will not put any of my hopes in living to see the rest reopen...

HOW OLD?. Plan for a few hours in this most interesting museum - 3 at least. There are actually three separate museums that make up the Archaeological Museum: The Museum of Ancient Orient, the Tile Museum and the main Archeological Museum. (WHY? might you ask, is there an Ancient Orient museum in Istanbul? Oh silly, because Istanbul straddles both the European AND ASIAN continents) ... All three museums are as fascinating as the next! The museum is located on the edge of Topkapi Palace (follow the signs around town), and is open from 9:00 - 7:00, but they stop selling tickets an hour before it closes. We were ushered out about 20m before the hour - so be wary of your timing. It's just 10TL to visit the museum (but my preference is and suggestion would be to get the 72h Museum pass - it is WELL worth it if you plan on hitting them all). It's not crowded at all, so choose this one on a weekend day when the other museums are slammed.Not truly into the Ancient Orient, I went into this one with little enthusiasm, and boy was I surprised. The stuff in here is ANCIENT --- like REALLY old. Again --- If I had a little one, I would snag them out of school and make them learn the history of the world by going to Istanbul! Very informative. The Archeological Museum was very, very interesting. You could basically get an entire semester of Anatolia History out of your visit here. The sarcophagi are gorgeous - it is truly amazing what was carved (and still remains) from 300BC. For instance, the Alexander Sarcophagus was originally thought to have been the Abdolonymus (who died in 311BC) Sarcophagus, but in reality this thing was carved BEFORE his death! The artifacts located in the Arch Museum are truly fascinating - things from all over the surrounding area of the Anatolian region. The Mosaic Tile part of the museum was the most interesting to me. BEAUTIFUL handcrafts from AGES ago, including a beautiful, tiled mihrab from the 15th century with the most gorgeous blue glazed tiles you've ever seen.Do not miss this museum experience if you are in Istanbul!

A walk through 5,000 years of History. The cost of the entrance ticket to the Archaeological Museum was money well spent. The museum is walking distance from the Sultanahmet area and the earlier you go the better so as to avoid crowds. I would recomand that you leave 3 to 4 hours for visiting. It is a good idea to rent the audio guide. The museum consists of three buildings, the Ancient Orient Museum, the Tiled Kiosk Museum and the main building and hosts an enormous collection which spans 5,000 years of history. All are worth visiting. We found all the exhibts interesting. The Alexander Sarcophagus and the Sarcophagus of the Wailing Women are breathtaking. If you are interested in history and archaeology don't miss it.

Large collection of artefacts. Included in museum pass(85 TL) walkable distance from blue mosque.Currently 3 blocks including big collection of ceramics.A free battery car service available to move around museums.

manageable and interesting.. this museum has many interesting historic items. be sure to bring your own descriptions on your ipad or a travel book, as very little english is posted. the museum is well planned and maintained. you can get very close to displayed items, unlike in nyc. you can see the most important items in about two hours.
Holy cow! Only $5?!?!. One of the best museums we've ever seen, inside and outside. Lots of restoration going on but that didn't dampen our experience at all. Go early to beat the crowds.

A true historical journey . Although the main building is currently being renovated to protect it from seismic activity, the journey one takes through the history of Turkey and the region is beautifully laid out through marble, stone. pottery, tiles and other artefacts. it is true to say that if you're familiar with museums such as the British Museum, the lower ground area of the Louvre, or the Museum at Delos in Greece, then many archaeological elements will be familiar. However, where this museum excels is a focus on the lands that formed to become Turkey, including specifically the history of the 19th century discovery of Troy and all the many layers within the mound that was recognised as Troy, which has been in constant excavation until almost the present day.

Collection is amazing and space is getting better.. The collection in this museum is fantastic! So much history and so many great pieces. The sarcophagi and sculpture are stunning, and the collection from Troy is also very interesting. The space is being renovated and the ground floor looked very contemporary. The upper floors looked dated, but you could tell that in time it would be an amazing collection in a beautiful space. The Tile Pavilion and the Asian Exhibit were also good - I was especially excited to see the Kadesh Treaty.

get there early.. Not to be be missed. Spent well over 2 hrs there. The oldest peace treaty in the world is there (the treay between the Hittites and the Egyptian King Rameses the Great.) It is very small but so significant. We got there just after 09.00 and it was easy to get round , by the time we left there were long queues to get in
Need more time. It covered the history of the area but unfortunately you need more than the 3 hrs to see and absorb it all. I would recommend 4 hours minimum for this museum.

Marvellous. Maybe you need to dedicate much more time than just one morning or an afternoon. It is plenty of interesting pieces and you can walk along the Istanbul history neighbourhood by neighbourhood. In the Oriental hall you can see part of the decoration of the Ishtar door and the Kadesh treat, but maybe one of the most famous relics is the Alexander the great sarcophagus (altough now we know it was not his)Interesting and entertaining if you spend a few days in Istanbul, but it is not worth if you only spend four or five days.

Outstanding museum. The best archeological museum I've ever met. Huge collection of headstones and sculptures: Roman, Hellenic and Greek. The great collection of coffinettes — Sumerian, Egyptian and others. Wonderful hall with Hellenic little figurines — from 6 century BC to 3-5 AC.Great, nice and enormous collection of marble stones in the yard.

Poorly laid-out, but some beautiful things. The history of Istanbul was a particular high-light, and there are some remarkable statutes from across the Ottoman Empire. The place is under renovation now, and I suspect the lay-out will be improved once that's unveiled.Definitely worth a stop with your Museum Pass. Nice cafe near the gate too, for weary visitors.
Archaeology...under restoration. The bits that were open were nice with some nice artefacts, but much of it was closed for restoration so didn't feel like we got the proper experience

More memorable than the palace. We couldn't see the Museum of Islamic Art, but the Museum of the Ancient Orient and the Archaeological Museum were as exciting and impressive as any museum we've been to in the world, and more memorable than the palace itself. Don't expect to find much in the way of bricks, nails and suchlike here. This is first and foremost a collection of magnificent and/or beautiful objects, splendidly exhibited, which you don't have to be an archaeologist to appreciate. Leave yourself plenty of time - at least two hours.

Fascinating place.. The best place in Istanbul if you like history. Breathtaking sarcophagi and Exhibition of Turkey through the Ages from Bronze Age onwards. Only problem is that's there's too much to see!

Wonderful Collection Well Presented. The presentation of artifacts tracing the history of Istanbul is outstanding and effectively tie together the many periods of this fascinating city. But as others have noted significant areas of the museum were closed for restoration/refurbishment when we visited. Still it was a must see. (We would have changed the recommended length to more than 3 hours if all exhibits were open).
So huge!!. Allow plenty of time to peruse, this place is huge, and its a shame to hurry your way through, beautiful displays

Three in one. Three museums in one, the majolica ceramics museum, the section on the ancient orient and the main building: the archeological museum. I have seen things I never thought they could exist. Before visiting make sure which sections are closed (if you come for anything specific) and plan your visit tactically [archeology section]: Think about taking the lift to the upper floor for Troy going down to the ground floor. If the archeology of Istanbul interest you, go to the second floor and proceed to your liking. And bear in mind: If disabled and holder of an official document of proof, bring it with you. Mine gave me free entry.

Good History. I enjoyed seeing the history here: ancient Roman tombs from Turkey and the Near East, really ancient artifacts from Mesopotamia, and pottery from Iznik. The Roman artifacts were my favorite - most were incredibly well-preserved. My favorite was the Alexander Sarcophagus; it had highly carved reliefs that were entirely intact. Even the people's miniature fingers were still there! The museum isn't as impressive as the "big three" sights (Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque & Topkapi Palace), but it was a nice place to spend an hour or two after the palace since it's right next door.
Very Interesting. A museum full of stone and dead bodies - it is being restored at the moment. Lovely building but not as enjoyable as the Topkapi Palace or The Blue Mosque.

Must see. I was truly amazed by this museum, with the territory and number of ancient valuable exhibits you can find here.Was pleasantly surprised with contents spreading aeound 8000 years of history. Adjacent to busy Topkapi palace the Museum provides breathing space. Plan to visit early in the day with plenty of time to really appreciate the history mix of greek roman and beyound erra. Highly recommended for a history passionate.

A small under-valuated gem in Istambul. After all there is too see in Istanbul this will probably not be, and should not be, in your top priorities but if you are still walking around and you have 1 hour or so check it out. Although the main building is still under reconstruction, the oriental section has some great pieces, Sumerian and Hittite. The Necropolis section has some very impressive and attention catching sarcophagus and overall the museum has very good detailed historical explanations for the whole region.

Amazing Museum. If you love history, you will very much enjoy this museum. The collection that they have on display are varied throughout history and you can easily spend several hours here. The museum is currently under restoration and you will find that there are part which are currently closed, this doesn't mean that there isn't still a great deal to see. For the entrance fee of 10LT it is also one of the best valued places to visit. Entrance is easy to find, there is a gate entrance from the Gulhane Tram station or you simply take a path which leads from the Topkapi Garden on the left hand side (close to the Hagia Irene).While not necessary on my must see list if you have limited time in Istanbul I feel it was very enjoyable and I made a point of visiting it on my second visit to Istanbul when I had some time to really enjoy and view the exhibits. There is a book shop and cafe at the location and when I visited I only saw one tour group.

Must See.... Wonders of Antiquity. This is an extremely underrated, undervalued attraction in Istanbul. The authorities must do something to popularize this more. The wealth of culture, history, knowledge, tradition, romanticism and mystique that is present in this place is mind boggling. There are 3 buildings in this museum complex. The entry feeis TL 10. It can be approached from 2 sides. the first one is through the Topkapi place. As you enter the first courtyard (where no tickets are required) you will see the Hagia Irene church on your left. Just after the Hagia Irene there is a building that is closed off and by the side of this building there is a lane that leads down the slope. This leads to the museums - in fact there is a gate that mentions on top the name of the museums. the other approach is from the Gulhane Park side. As you cross the arches under the wall by the tramline (opposite The Sublime Porte) you will see the entrance gates to the park. on your right by the boundary of the park there is a road that leads up the slope. it turns to the right - just follow this and you will see the museum complex. the first building as you enter (to your left) is the museum of the orient. it has a large number of remnants from the walls of Babylon - the blue bricks and the lion, bull and dragon motifs are still alluring after so many centuries - apparently these are from the Ishtar Gate area. It is awe inspiring to imagine the impact they would have had on the unsuspecting (and even those who knew) visitor when they saw them for the first time on the walls. their magnificence even now is unparalleled. in addition, there are clay tablets (including apparently the oldest love poem!) that not only show you the development of writing but also that of commerce and archiving and contracting. it only goes to show that we have not really progressed that much since those times in certain areas - or to put it differently - the advancement achieved by those old people is a humbling experience.the second building on your left is the tiled pavilion - it has exhibits of ottoman ceramics and tiles. this is the weakest part of the entire museum. there is nothing great here - at least in comparison to the exhibits in the other sections. the building itself is quite pleasing. inbetween these two buildings is the museum shop and a cafe with open air seating amongst old ruins.the last and the grandest building is to your right and centre. this was built specifically to house the collections around the 1880s or 1890s. it is quite a grand building with a marvellous entrance. in the courtyard in front is a marble / stone column that is shaped like a palm tree trunk - if you are not careful you would actually think it is a real dead trunk - the worksmanship is so brilliant even after all these years. the main building is being renovated. however as you enter the main section, to your left is the area for the collection from the royal necropolis of Sidon. in the first chamber you see the two most famous sarcopahgii - the alexander one and the one of the weeping / mourning women. the wroksmanship is just brilliant. even after the ages it still is able to touch you to the core. one must visit this museum if just to see these two exhibits. for anyone who loves history this is manna. for those who love the arts this is sublime. for those who value neither it is best avoided. beyond the first room on the left is the balance part of the sarcophagus collection. there are a couple of good ones here also - two that come close to the two above. a quick look would suffice though. the upper floors on this side were not accesible. on the other side of the building - to your right as you enter are the exhibits related to Istanbul and the general geographical area of modern day Turkey. to me the most important artefacts here were the bust of alexander, the roman statues (inlcuding those of augustus, marcus aurelius and agrippina the elder). they are such beautiful works of art that they converse with you when you look at them and you get the distinct feeling that as you turn away from them so would they to walk with you as in a typical conversation you have with a friend who you meet suddenly on the street and then walk away together.on the upper floors the most interesting exhibits are again the clay tablets and records bearing contracts and receipts from the earliest times including those from the hittite period. these include a marriage contract (a pre-nuptial !!) detailing the moneies to be paid to either party in case of a divorce and a war treaty amongst others. really interesting. this apart the place is literally littered with artefacts of daily life from time immemorial and byzantine columns, arches, mosaics (a few) and busts and statuettes.overall a must must see for those who like history and are willing to transport themselves back to years gone by and marvel at the advanced art and science forms. just looking at the exhibits i mentioned above should take an hour. i spent half a day.

Amazingly Rich Museum of Antiquities. This museum proved to me that this land is not called the cradle of western civilization for nothing. I had not expected anything other than some greek and roman sculptures. Lo and behold, I was engulfed with the dazzling mosaics from Babylon, the precious hierogryphic tablets, the first signed trade agreement ever recorded, the exquisite Hittites sculptures, the skilfully scultured sarcophagus, and many more beautiful Greek and Roman sculptures. It was overwhelming. These are things that I had only read of or seen images in books, but had never imagined that I would get to see them with my own eyes. To those visitors who complained that the museum was not that great because many of the statues was missing body parts. Duh! They probably are hidden in a museum or in some looters' collection somewhere in Europe or America.Four hours were not enogh to satisfy me. I need to to go back there again to do this beautiful museum justice.

A definitely must visit place. This is definitely must visit places of Istanbul if you have more than 1 day to do the sightseeing in Istanbul. We are as a family and friends are quite like history-lovers, and once we made to to this museum we understood why some people call Turkey the "cradle of the civilizations". You can see various type of archeological foundlings right at this very specific museum. It's totally worth it to visit
Do not miss this treasure. Wonderfully dramatically laid out, excellent information, some stunning exhibits, a worthy neighbour to the Topkapi Palace

Educational and unique. I started off visiting the ancient orient section to get to know early civilization artifacts .There are well preserved ancient tablets with early form of writing known as cuneiform ,statues and sculptures from early civilizations -Egypt,Mesopotamia.The main building is undergoing renovation for expansion ,we could still visit part of it .The displays of sarcophagi is interesting ,especially the famous one built for Alexander the Great ,with beautiful intricate carvings .There are several other sarcophagis with different sizes and design , you would wonder the effort that had been put in to contain one's body for the journey afterlife.

Don't miss this museum!. This museum is very well organized and has some amazingly old things, including clay tablets from up to 2700 BC, and other 3-4000 year-old items. The collection is mostly from 600 AD to that year. The large building has an incredible collection of old sarcophagi.

Incredible collection. A really huge and great museum with a rich collection of ancient middle eastern artefacts. Grecian, Roman, Egyptian, Babylonian, Assyrian - everything you learned about in art history class is here! It is a place you should not miss if you are interested in ancient art. You can also learn everything about the history of Istanbul.It is still under contruction/renovation, but still worth visiting. It will be truly amazing once the works are done and you can visit all exhibitions.
Istanbul Day Out. Disappointing as it is currently under going massive refurbishments but what was on display was attractive and well documented.

The British Museum did not steal all the best bits!. The archaeology museum next door to the Topkapi Palace has some of the best large exhibits of Greek, Roman and Near Eastern I have seen. You probably need in excess of a day to get round all the venues.

Good for an Archaeology fan. It wasn't all that great for me. Most of the statues, pillars and displays were broken, in particular, most of the heads were missing. There wasn't much written in English, so it was just plain sculptures to look at. Lacking an interest in Archaelogy, I didn't enjoy this place

A little overwhelming. So much history here, it's hard to take it all in. Well designed, spacious and attractive displays, and it has English explanations! The buildings somehow seemed much more peaceful and quiet than the other museums that I visited, and the calibre of the exhibitions was top notch.

A True Treasure Trove. The Istanbul Archaeology museum has spoiled me. Since then, I tend to compare any other "cultural" activities I partake in to it. It is that good. Alexander the Great's sarcophagus blew me away with just how massive it was.This is the kind of place where every step you take, there's some artifact that is so rare, has so much history, and has such a unique story that you'll probably end up staying longer than you think. This museum deserves to be much higher on the Istanbul rankings. It doesn't matter if you "appreciate" history or not, because I guarantee you will find something here that fascinates you.
Worth a morning. Under renovation now. Some nice exhibits on the archeological history of Anatolia/Asia Minor including Troy and Istanbul.

Ancient history lover's hotspot. This museum is almost exclusively for ancient history though there were a few displays of the Ottoman era. There is a lot to learn and discover in there and the actual location is nestled away near a park so it's very breezy and cool amidst the hot summer temperatures.

Great rainy day activity!. This museum offers a lot of artifacts to browse. It is three buildings full of items for all over Turkey. There is a cafe and a gift shop also. Ticket was 10 TL and the audio tour was also 10 TL. It's a great inside activity for a rainy day. If your trip is sunny, I'd say move on to other activities. It is currently under a renovation.
Closed. For your information this was closed in Feb 2014. Not sure when it will be open again but we were very disappointed that it wasn't open.
Don't miss if you like history. Really interesting with items from Babylon, Assyria and Troy. It is being renovated at the moment so I am sure will be even better in the future.
afternoon coffee and sandwich. The view was amazing, the latte was great too, but when i wanted to order sandwiches there werent any.

Very interesting, especially the Alexander Sarcophagus. Although some of the halls were closed for renovation on the day we visited, there was still heaps to see and spent a few hours wandering around the interesting exhibits. There is a exhibit showing a timeline of all of the periods in Turkish history and artefacts from each, including the various Troy civilisations and the Hittites.
Must see!. So glad we went here- missed it last time we were here. Wonderful antiquities---the first love poem, the iron chain protecting the harbor, the tombs!
Alexander the Great!. nice collection of ancient articles from past centuriestiled kiosk is a must see!check sarcophagi, including Alexander the Great!

Best Museum Ever Visited. This is quite literally the best museum of ancient artifacts and displays I have ever seen. If you are in Istanbul you must take some time to visit this place. There is a lot to see, so be prepared.

Just couldn't really get into it. I usually love these kinds of museums but for some reason I just couldn't really get into this one. I still gave it 4-stars because it wasn't like it was terrible and it wasn't very much (10TL if I remember...). The sarcophagi were neat to see but for some reason the rest of the collections just didn't keep me interested. I also think parts may have been closed or I missed something because it didn't seems as big as I thought it'd be. Sometimes it felt like it was just lacking something that I can't quite explain. Worth a visit if it's something you think you would like but if you are on the fence about it, save the lira and do something else.

Very Interesting. A very nicely laid out museum in the old town of Istanbul next to the Topkapi Palace. It's not as large as other such museums in London, Paris or Berlin but it's well worth a visit to see the exhibits and learn about the local history.Much of it was being restored when we visited in February 2014 but we were glad that we did go. Entry is included if you buy an Istanbul Museum Pass which is good value if you go to see all of the places that i admits you to.

great find. This museum is a great find if you like statues and funeral art from antiquity. The museum was undergoing refurbishment when I was there so it was a little disorganized but their colledtion is stunning. The works are presented enmass rather than being spread out so it is a little easy to get over whelmed especially as some of the labels are good while others less so but this is a great place to spend some time while in Istanbul.

Interesting. If you like history and arhaeology, so this museum is great. There are pieces from all the territory the ottoman empire conquered. You will find here Sumerian pieces, Acadian, greek, egiptian, and even Alexander the Great's tomb, made of marble and a beautiful piece of art.

Best part is the Sarcophagus..... The museum was cold and spacious...multiple building and some construction was ongoing...the best was the many large Sarcophagus...the details were amazing in tack...many floors and has a good representation of the history of the area...

so many beautiful and historical objects. The museum has three buildings each housing a different collection. All three are on a combined ticket and if you use the museum pass to get in you cannot reenter without paying again.The Islamic art building is the smallest, and when I was there (10am on a cold Feb day) empty except for the guards. I was finally able to learn about the history of the famous Izmir tiles and see beautiful examples of them. I missed the Ancient Orient building completely, because I next went to the Archeology museum where I spent over 2 hours (without finishing!) and was completely knackered at the end.So many beautiful and important objects to see spanning approximately 600BC-400 AD. The graceful carvings tell myths and stories which the audio guide and signs help you to understand.The building has two wings (which I didn't realize) so I took my time in the first half without realizing how much more there was to see. However, that was one of the most enjoyable hours of my time in Istanbul, and I do recommend taking your time to really look and enjoy these magnificent pieces.

Do not overlook this museum. When visiting Istanbul, do not overlook this museum, containing significant classical artifacts. The Alexander Sarcophagus alone is worth seeing, as well as a well-done exhibit on the Troy excavations.

Very nice. Tis is a very nice museum. It didn't cost much 10TL . We didn't take the audiotour and we didn't miss it, because everything was explained in english.There is so much to see.We especially liked Alexanders tomb. The statues were so crisp as if they were carved yesterday.
Superb collection of artifacts. Comprehensive collection.Museum being refurbished so some portions of the museum were inaccessible.Need several hours if you are a history buff.
Perfect. If you like museums you will not be sorry you visited. A wealth of treasures. So much to look at and learn from.

Fascinating!. If you like Archaeology, art or history, you will fall in love with this museum.It's really interesting and fascinating!It was a pleasure for me to discover the Necropolis of Sidon (knowing i am Lebanese), and the mummy of Phoenician King Tabnit.

Secret little gem. This Archaeological museum is a little secret of a gem as nobody knows its there, not even some of the locals! It was built in the late 19th century to house the Sultan's archaeological treasures. Its a mini Lourve and British Museum put together yet it has artefacts in it that neither of them have. You will need at least 20 minutes to look and wonder at Alexander the Great's marble coffin. Look for also a little cracked earth tablet, one of two copies of the worlds first written peace treaty signed by Ramases II and the Hittaite King after the battle of Kadesh some 3500 years ago. This place is the best kept secret in old Istanbul if not Europe, whatever you do don't miss it.

First stop on your trip. This museum is actually three: museum of ancient art, archaeology museum and museum of Islamic art.We found it really fascinating, if not mind-blowing. If you know something about history you can just wander around, noticing unique pieces of archaeology such as blue friezes from the Ishtar Gate of Babylon, clay tablets in Sumerian, a marble lion from the Mausoleum of Halicarnasass (one of Wonders of the World) and a snakes head from the Serpentine Column (in the old Hippodrome). These are just a few examples.I also discovered so many new (to me) interesting artifacts such as the Treaty of Kadesh, Alexander Sarcophagus and the history of Istanbul. You should come here first to get a good understanding of the city and its origins. It has so much to see you should spend at least half a day there.
it was informative but a bit boring. it was really amazing and the way they categorized the place was nice but at some point it gets repetitive and boring....visit it if you have free time

Not to be missed when in Istanbul. We returned to Istanbul this year partly as we had missed this museum the year before on our trip to Turkey. While we were a little disappointed as some of the museum was under restoration, they had done a good job of keeping some of the best pieces accessible to the public. The three buildings that compromise the museum all house wonderful collections and help tell the long and prominent history of this great country. We also liked the grounds of the museum. These are adjacent to Topkapi and there is a lovely coffee shop where you can sit outside among some pieces of ancient temples and buildings and enjoy a tea or coffee and a bite to eat after visiting the extensive collections.
Adjacent to the Topkapi Palace. There were some interesting artifacts, statues and art, but I would only visit if you have purchased a Museum Pass. The layout of the museum isn't the greatest.
love the mosaiks. This museum contains a wide array of sarcophagus, mosaics, and local items from shipwrecks and Ephesus.

Stones. The museum lacked any kind of fantasy in connection with the presentation of the stuff there. There is a lot of description on the walls, but feels like reading a school book. The direction of the presentation was not obvious for me and I ended up several times going in the opposite direction than they intended.

Unexpected and interesting experience. The Museum is currently undergoing renovations (as is every tourist attraction in Europe this winter, it would seem) but this does not detract from the experience. There is an extensive collection of artefacts from Turkey's past and the 4th century Alexander Sarcophagus, a staggeringly beautiful piece of work, apart from its historic significance -- ground floor, room to the left of the entry -- is hard to miss. The Museum is a bit of a maze, possibly due to ongoing work, and not well signposted. We had to ask for help to find the exhibition of Ravenna mosaics from the Basilica of San Vitale, Italy (closing end January) which we had come to see. The mosaics are re-creations of course, painstakingly well done using laser techniques and Murano glass, but just too perfect; a little wear and tear would have added to the authenticity. Some of the mosaics are monumental, all are highly coloured, beautiful representations of spiritual life in Byzantium. On the first floor, the exhibition of shipwrecks of Yenicapi is an added bonus. During excavation work for an underground transport tunnel in 2004, the Yenicapi site in Istanbul yielded a total of 37 shipwrecks, dating between the 5th - 12th centuries AD. Four of these shipwrecks are displayed. The cargo they carried, and the remains around the site, has helped build up a clearer picture of life in ancient times in the area. The exhibition is interactive and clearly aimed at students (groups were visiting when we were there) but is of great general interest.Perhaps the best part of the Museum visit and worth all of the 10 TL ticket price, is the Crystal Pavillion (Cinili Kiosk), a beautiful sugar-cube of a building, opposite the current entry to the Museum. It is a calm and beautiful space, a repository for ceramics and tiles of incredible artistry and skill. A painting by Osman Hamdi Bey, founder of the Museum, hangs in a side room, neatly connecting both buildings. Word of advice: Visit in winter. There were a few school groups but hardly any tourists and we were able to look at leisure...

Average Museum. Fairly inexpensive and fairly interesting. The necropolis contains interesting sarcophagus specimens, and the mummified body of a King. Fascinating! But this is given only three circles because as museums such as this goes, the are much better displays in London, Washington, and France. Not bad, but not great either.

So much to admire. Today 30th Jan 2014 me and my girlfriend visited the Museum. It took us about five hours to look and appreciate everything. I would suggest it to anyone interested in history that is visiting Istanbul. It coated 10 Turkish lira each person and its well worth it. I did not need the audio guide as there was info in Turkish and English which for me was enough, follow the arrow signs and you'll understand everything. I suggest you take a packed lunch with you which you can have in the garden in between the museum buildings unless you want to have something from the cafe'. One last thing if any of the showcases aren't lit up, ask one of the securities as it might have a timer switch. Enjoy!

Incredible exhibits, could do with a bit of structure. This is a museum that's stuffed to the rafters with amazing finds, spanning more than 3,000 years of this incredible city. Come in comfortable shoes as there's a lot of walking to do, and do be prepared to retrace your footsteps as, in places there are so many exhibits that you do miss things. In fact, we were left feeling a bit overawed by the whole experience, because there is almost too much to see!As with most places in Istanbul, it pays to arrive early if you can, so you can get ahead of the school parties and tourist groups - and I guess it would also help to miss the hottest part of the day. Definitely a GREAT place to visit!
Large and well taken care of collection. Large collection spanning 3 thousand years of the city and a good sense of establishing a flow of its history. Favorite exhibition I saw in the city.
Iraqi. I live in Istanbul but still didn't go there , but after I saw the photos of some Babylonian treasures I will definitely go soon !
It really worth to go. This museum is really cheap, and you can see things from different ages and different places. It is an important part of the humanity artefacts history in just one place.
Interesting Museum. Lots of fascinating exhibits. Marble statues, pieces of artefacts from historical life in Istanbul. Well worth the visit
Lots of sarcophagi. But sarcophagi are not the only treasures of this exquisite museum. There are several buildings, each with a different focus.

have some great objects but not good at education. the museum has some really nice collections but don't have much labels to explain those objects. There's no exhibition idea in this museum, mostly like a storage space..
Istanbul Archaeology Museum. Very interesting but it's tiring because the presentation of the exhibits is not done in a modern way

Best Place Ever. The best archaeological museum I've visited so far. Small fee (10 TL), 3 separate buildings (with 2 more under reconstruction), great collections devided in eras and locations. Alexander Sarcophagus is a gem!

A must see in Istanbul. Istanbul is the crossroads of world and of history. The Museum is filled with beautiful examples of the artifacts from many of the eras of Anatolia's history. And if you have to been to Istanbul's Archaeology Museum before check it out again because there are always new finds being put on display.

A museum worth to be visited. I did not expect much from the museum and came in only because the rain started on our way back from topkapi palace. But i got really amazed later on by the rich and very interesting collection exhibited in that museum. Strongly recommend

Fantastic. I loved this museum, it was amazing! There were things in their displays that boggled the mind.. things I actually thought were myths I discovered are actually real!! DO NOT miss this museum!

Wide range of items. A well-worthwhile visit. You can normally do this when exiting the Topkapi Palace, but we decided we needed a longer look, so avoided the lines by entering at 9.00am. The sarcophagi were outstanding, including one with a carving of a goat being pulled along reluctantly by a small boy. The Tile Kiosk includes many non-tile exhibits: the two world-famous plates are .... well .... outstanding. And don’t miss the Kadesh treaty tablet.A significant section of the main museum was closed when we were there (Dec 2012) but it did not detract from almost a morning inside, and away from the rain.

Satisfactory. We hadn't expected with this museum so much before visiting, but it satisfied us enoughly. I especially liked small figures from clay, which wasn't attractin peoples' attention on the nook. Only a regrettable thing is that we could'nt see anything from Marmaray construction site.

Leave plenty of time. Leave at least a day to seriously look at the treasures of this outstanding museum - and that is with one section totally closed at present. Highlights are hard to pick - maybe the ceramics in the tiled pavilion, the spectacular collection of sarcophagi, and the panels from the gates of Babylon.

The Prehistory and History of Istanbul. I could have spent all day in there, but we only had two hours on the last day. You will learn about the wall around the city, and the chain across the Golden Horn. If time permits you can go into the archaeology of the rest of Turkey as well. Don't miss the exhibits on Troy.

Quite a good couple of hours. A reasonable place to see many artifacts and lots of sarcophagus, a good way to spend a few hours it was not the best museum I have ever been too but certainly not the worst. It needed some wow factor but failed to do that.

if only there can be music inside the museum, but the collections are GREAT. visiting Istanbul you must have been interested in the history, otherwise it would be just sightseeing without any knowledge input into your head.i enjoyed every minute of it and even though there are some reparation outside the building it did not bother you when you are visiting inside the museum as the area is so big.

of surprising interest. Rooms of sepulchres might not sound interesting, but stop and examine the carvings and bas reliefs they contain and much is revealed. likewise, the tile museum is also a surprising gem.

A good selection. This museum deserves a few hours of attention as reading the signs also takes time. Still, there is not enough information and sometimes there appear to be contradictions in the same room as well as a few factual errors. Nevertheless, the items exhibited are what matter most. The guards are good at watching visitors and prevent flash photography (always a good thing). There are some things worth looking at in the yard outside (which hopefully will be put indoors in future and signposted). The building itself is very attractive and there's a nice café in the yard.

Impressive Lot of Ancient Artifacts!. If you want to see lots and lots and LOTS of ancient artifacts, then you are in the right place! The collection here is quite impressive, even compared to similar collections in Rome. While the museum is massive, it's worth a visit to truly appreciate the massiveness of the history of this area.

Amazing museum collection. It is probably not the most interactive, engaging museum, but the sheer volume of amazing pieces of history all well explained with detailed plaques in English (and Turkish) is simply mind boggling. It is well (logically) laid out to enable a sort of chronologically appropriate exploration of the history of the local area and Turkey as a whole. Probably not a place to visit with young children as they'll likely get bored pretty quickly but anyone with an inkling of historical knowledge and a curiosity about Turkey's past will gain a lot from this incredible collection. It is located adjacent to the Topkapi palace so you can always include both.

Huge collection of greek and ancient orient art. This museum is located right next to Topkapi Palace and the take Müze Card. I had little time left so I spend only a hour there but there are very interesting pieces of greek art and the main attraction is Alexander Sarcophagus which is amazingly well presenved

No 1 must-see in Istanbul. It tells the story of civilisation in this land, 9000 years! It is said that Sarcophagus of Alexander and crying women are the best collection. I do think collections related to Anatolia are the most interesting. We can see collections on Egyptians, Greeks, Romans, and Muslims here, but also somewhere else. But those on Anatolia are not well seen in other places. Istanbul is a harmony mixture of East and West, from thousands years ago till today. Archaeology museum obviously tells this more than all other places add together.

archeology museum. Very nice and big museum with lot of pretty things from Turkish history and history of the closest countries. Amazing stuff have at there and 3 floors full of historical pieces. 3rd floor is little bit boring but except of that it's really good way how to spend time.
Boring. Very silly museum I never liked it ... A waste of money and time so go somewhere else .I didn't like it at all and was very eager to go out of it

Heaps of stuff. AMAZING Artifacts. Upon entering the museum grounds, the first thing you'll notice are heaps of archeological pieces scattered on the lawn. The establishment is bursting with interesting finds,  well preserved artifacts, mosaics, sarcophagi, ancient shipwrecks from the BC/AD era. A history lovers haven. You can easily spend half a day here. Well worth a visit.

excellent history. The istanbul archaeology museum is a very good place to visit for adults and children. The chiodren were very much interested in the history of the egyptians. They were excited to learn and were not bored. I would recommend this place to everyone, especially families.

Another archaeological museum. The museum is not impressive. It has a big collection, probably there are some artifacts, but a part of the museum is closed for renovation. The most impressive things are tomb of Alexander the Great and artifacts from Mesopotamian culture.

Great experience. This is a must see in Istanbul. The building and art is something to behold. A magnificent tourist attraction. When in Istanbul you should try and find a way to visit this attraction.

Beautiful, diversive and well worth the money. Being a fan of pretty tiles the mosaique part was my favorite but the museum offers so many different exhibitions and there is so much to see and learn about the citys great history. The yard and the different bildnings are beautiful and all the statues and pillars "lying around" create a very special atmosphere. It is calm and relaxing. I recommend everyone to go here when in Istanbul.

Yenikapı harbor and shipwrecks--worth the trip. There are many wonderful exhibits in this museum, as others have remarked. Yes, it is undergoing renovation, but some of the buildings are open for viewing. Over thousands of years, this region has brought the eastern and the western cultures together, has hosted the magnificent buildings of the Byzantine and Ottoman Empires to the present, and has maintained its importance during all periods of history, all represented in some way in the museum.The most interesting exhibit I saw is that uncovered in about 2004 for the building of a major subway station at Yenikapi, on the Marmara. This excavation uncovered the harbor of Byzantium and a treasure trove of objects, including 36 boats. Some of the vessels and their cargo are on display and offer a rich guide to medieval life around the Mediterranean Sea.It has been reported that this is the most comprehensive archaeological excavation ever related to the history of İstanbul. The harbor and the Yenikapı shipwrecks, dating from the 7th to 11th centuries, are a fascinating find and worth the trip!I hope the museum will continue to develop this exhibit.

Not to be missed. This place is very nice. You would not go to Istanbul to visit it, and that would be a mistake. We had a great time visiting it. Collections are very nice, and that would tell you a bit more about the culture and the origins of the city. It would also give you a bit of time to relax from the frenetic city.One suggetion, DO NOT EAT at the restaurants down the entrance, this is twice more expensive than anything anywhere else, and it is not good... Even when they show their "tripadvisor" recommendation card.

So much to see!. A great museum with a fresh feel to it. Well laid out with lots to see in each building.We had a museum card so went straight in. The buildings themselves are beautiful and they have tombs outside the main building you can explore. The Orient Building is especially stunning. All the exhibits had detailed explanations in English, we didn't get the audio guide and didn't feel like we missed anything because of this.We had a warming cup of tea in the museum cafe with some soup. Reasonably priced for a museum cafe. Outside seating is available strewn between archaeological relics in their small garden area.

Discover the rich history of Turkey. The collections of this museum consits of artifacts from the various civilizatıons whıch through the ages settled or just past through the region which is today know as Turkey. The exhibition of these wonderfull finds is presented in an accesable way and the lay-out is easy to follow. The museum consits of three seperate buildings. There is the huge main building with all the artifacts like the Alexander Sarcophagus whıch should not be missed. The other two much smaller buildings are the Tiled Kiosk which houses various tile collections and then there is the Ancient Orient Museum. When we visited the main building housed an exhibition of mosaics from Ravenna in Italy. There was also an exhibition of the ships found at Yeni Kapı harbour when they started the excavations for the metro tunnel under the Bosphorus. The museum is located in Sultanahmet in Gulhane Park just behind the Top Kapı Palace. Coming with the tram get off at Gulhane stop or it is a very short walk from Sultan Ahmet if you are staying there.

A Labour of Love. Apart from the incredible detail in the mosaics and the artistic elements, it was also amazing to read about the restoration work and the time-consuming process involved in preparing, exhibiting and protecting these precious artefacts. Take time to read the descriptions for a real understanding of them.

Arkeoloji Müzesi. As if it is a page from ancient times,very pleasant patio surrounded by history and the joy of discovering.there are boutique places around to have a soft drink with a friend to relieve the phew of history.

ISTANBUL DAIRY. DAY 1. PART 1. We started our tour of Istanbul with a visit to the Archeological museum. We bought the museum pass at the gate. This will give you access to the Istanbul Archaeology Museum, Topkapi, Topkapi harem, Haga Sophia and Chora museums. The pass is very convenient and saved us about 20 minutes time of queue for Topkapi and Haga Sophia.There are 2 noticeable themes in this museum. The first is the impressive burial relics- Sarcophagus collection. Look for the 5th century BC Sidon king and Alexander the great sarcophagus.The second theme is the Greek Statue collection. One will be amazed and think that he is in Athens instead of Istanbul. On the 2nd floor, the history of Turkey is displayed . Interesting part, because this will provide a better understanding of the country as you visit the other museums and attractions in the city latter on.A surprise bonus area is the Roman marble section on the ground floor. All the relics found in the museum are more than 2000 years old but very well preserved. The Underwater Istanbul port excavation exhibit is also well designed. There is also a tile pavilion on a separate building.Truly, there is a lot of history can be found in this Museum covering a big area where human civilization was established. If you are a history buff, 2 hours is not enough.

Fantastic. Fantastic museum, absolutely packed with archeological treasures. Allow plenty of time. The Alexander sarcophagus is breathtakingly beautiful. Wonderful, among many other wonders. Great for lovers of ancient history.

One of the best in the world. By comparison with other Museums in UK, Europe and USA I rate the Istanbul Archaeology Museum as one of the best museums in the world. IT is currently in renovation so it is only going to get better. The Alexander sarcophagus, sculpted busts, mosaics and cuneiform scripts are as old as I have ever seen. The displays are well done but I went early and paid extra for an audio guide. I stayed for a long time but stopped for a coffee in the efficient and clean coffee shop. Although it was a little expensive it proved a great refresher and break to take in some more of the old, and beautiful artefacts. Not to be missed.

If you are a history buff, you will enjoy.... Coming from Rome to Istanbul, I was partly expecting the Archaeological Museum to be as impressive as what I could find in Rome. While not quite as expansive, if you are interested in ancient history & archaeology, it is certainly worth the trip.

Very interesting. Very interesting archaelogical finds - my particular favourite were footprints dating back 8000 years!
Would have preferred if there was more clear information about Instanbul's obviously rich history.

Wow! . You will need about thee hours to go through it - even with the exhibitions that are closed right now. Get the audio tour for 10tL. But use your own ear buds. To save money, get one and each put an earbud in your ear. There items that are 10,000 years old! Definitely worth the visit for an unbelievable price of 10TL. Probably the best value for money in Istanbul.

Interesting for archaeology buffs. My husband wanted to visit the museum so I tagged along but didn't find it very interesting. It's definitely not a "general interest" museum so if you're not interested in archaeology, then definitely give this a miss! There are some interesting tombs with detailed carvings and I liked the fact that a lot of the displays aren't cordoned off so you can get quite close to them. You can also take pictures, without a flash, which can be rare in a museum.My favourite part of the museum was the current exhibit of tiled artwork but it's not a permanent exhibit.Also, when we were there a number of exhibits were closed for reconstruction which we didn't realize ahead of time.
Must see!. Give yourself plenty of time for this wonderful museum. We had to go back a second time! So much to see and part was under construction. Excellant

GALATA DUO. Located at the heart of Beyoglu District, Duo Galata Hotel is only 100 metres from the iconic Galata Tower. It offers stylish accommodation with modern amenities and a terrace with city views. Free Wi-Fi is available in all areas and guests can benefit from the concierge desk on site.Decorated with graffiti art pieces and designer furnitures, the units at Hotel Duo Galata feature air conditioning, a flat-screen TV with satellite channels, a minibar and a safety deposit box. Some rooms come with views of Galata Tower. The en suite bathroom includes a shower, hairdryer, slippers and free toiletries.This chic hotel is just a 15-minute walk from Taksim Square and less than 5 minutes’ walk away from Istiklal Street’s shops, cafés and restaurants.Lutfi Kirdar Convetion Centre is 3 km away. Sishane Metro Station and tram stop are within walking distance offering easy access to Taksim Square and the historic Sultanahmet area, 2.6 km away.Duo Galata Hotel offers airport shuttle services to Ataturk Airport, 21 km away, and Sabiha Gokcen, 45 km away, at a surcharge.

A Stunning Museum. Deciding to spend a good part of our 33rd wedding anniversary at the Istanbus Archaeological Museum, we soon found ourselves walking past a friendly soldier with a machine gun guarding the outer portal leading toward the Topkapi Palace and into Gülhane Park, hot on the trail of the museum, where we spent exciting afternoon hours gawking at the wonders on display, wonders it would take a dozen pages to do justice to. Let me just say that the sarcophagi, with their incredibly lifelike carvings, were amazing, and the statuary from Greek and Roman times so beautiful that I would have shot three or four rolls of film if such a thing existed any longer, so I shot dozens and dozens of digital photos instead. Most impressive to us both was the great Alexander Sarcophagus. It wasn’t so named because it had ever contained the youthful remains of the great conqueror, but because it depicted his battles and hunts in beautiful carvings on all sides in deep relief. It had been found in the Royal Necropolis of Sidon and was carved in last quarter of the 4th century B.C. Carvings on one long side showed Alexander fighting the Persians at the Battle of Issus (in 333 B.C.), while on the other side Alexander and the Macedonians were hunting lions with the Persians. Spectacular carvings.  A portion of the museum was under reconstruction when we were there, but there was still plenty to keep us fascinated: anthropoid sarcophagi, grave steles, some with their paint still intact, memorials carved in stone, mosaics, friezes from the Lagina Hecate temple, the mummified remains of Tabnit, King of the Sidons, elegant Egyptian sarcophagus lids, beautiful busts and statues of emperors and gods, a great head of the poet Sappho, the magnificently mournful reclining figure of Oceanus, god of rivers, and on and on. We nipped out for a quick lunch of sandwiches and baclava at a little café in the garden, surrounded by feral cats and ancient stone, and nipped back in to visit the ancient Hittite carvings and Egyptian remnants from several centuries before the Greco/Roman era. It was past four when we finally left, our feet having received the bastinado but our spirits still flying high. Well worth your visit. The Archaeological Museum in Antalya is, I think, even more stunning.
Amazing!. We have just enjoyed several hours inside this magnificent Museum, opportunities to many photographs, very informative and would highly recommend.

Lots of interesting exhibits, great for kids. I was truly amazed by this museum, with the territory and number of ancient valuable exhibits you can find here. My daughter of 12 was very much enthusiastic and impressed and we've spent around two+ hours here - the museum is not one building and you can really find a lot here!

Visit it. I did not know that part of it was still under construction, apart from that..this place is a history treasure, but still can't be compared with the louvre.The building isn't well-maintained but you'd forget about once you dive into those historic pieces.You can also take a break at the museum outdoor cafe, where you'll enjoy the scene.

This place is definitely worth visiting!. Artifacts up to 5,000 years old from Troy going through 10,000 years old from Mesapotamia and Egypt. Kadesh peace treaty, Tiled Kiosk...just to name a few of the must see incredible sights to be had at this wonderful museum.Buy the museum pass which is good for 72 hours as it allows you to bypass lines and is a great bargain if you are seeing multiple sites.

Amazing is an understatement. Was pleasantly surprised with contents spreading aeound 8000 years of history. Adjacent to busy Topkapi palace the Museum provides breathing space. Plane to visit early in the day with plenty of time to really appreciate the history mix of greek roman and beyound erra.

A wealth of treasures. So much to see here. Make sure you have a lot of time for your visit. There are several buildings each with different items to view - porcelain; tombs etc. All are interesting. It would be helpful if something on the exterior of each building gave more information about the interiors.

Interesting artefacts; shoddy displays. There is quite a few gems in the archaeology museum, including a portion of the chain that the Byzantines would place across the Golden Horn to protect Constantinople from attach. The displays are not so great (with a few exceptions), but it a way it makes the museum more interesting.

Do not skip this!. Now this is a Museum, with a capital M. WOW! As a student in cultural heritage institutions I was truly amazed by the depth and intensity with which this museum is set up. The information (in English!) is lavishing and so much more than one can expect. It gives context, background about when ad how objects were found, translations of inscriptions. So extremely good! Do not miss this Museum, it is marvelous.

excellent museum. very rich archeological museum, rich collection of sarcophagus. There is also very modern exhbition from port underwater excavation that is impressive.Together with Topkapi, if you combine both attraction, you can easily plan for a whole day tourism in the area (with lunch, coffee in the topkapi cafeteria etc.)

Interesting pieces. Though not the largest museum, it had some very interesting pieces. Split into three sections, it had things grouped nicely. The Islamic tile section was interesting, as I'd seen nothing like it before. The museum closed far earlier than advertised though.

Far superior to the Topkapi Palace!. If you're a true history buff, avoid the crowds and head here instead of the Topkapi Palace. The spaces are well-organised and the artifacts themselves are top-notch. My only gripe would be with the audio guides - the pieces that they highlighted were explained well, but there simply weren't enough selections. I would have appreciated more audio additions.Other than that, however, try to set aside at least 3 hours to this museum - you'll get completely absorbed by the exhibits and find yourself rushing through if you attempt it in any less.

Not to be missed!. On previous trips to Istanbul we have walked pass the entrance to the Archaeological Museum simply because we thought there were more exciting ‘attractions’ to visit than an archaeological museum as a result this museum never made it onto our ‘must visit’ list, how wrong we were. There is so much to see with 3 museums for the price of one. The sacrophagi rooms were just incredible to see, the detail in the work is amazing.!0tl to see all 3 museums: Archeaological Museum, Tiled Kiosk and the Ancient Orient Museum - a bargain!
Good, but . . .. Wait until the full renovation is complete. If you can't wait, the antiquities on the ground floor have wonderful Lycian and Hellenic exhibits.
unexpected surprise. A museum that i find amazing for the content it exhibits. Highly recommended for a history passionate.

comprehensive representation of ancient middle east. an amazing collection , representing the various civilizations that flourished in the near east . some finds are extremely valuable and rare : first documented love poem ( on a Mesopotamian clay tablet ) , and the first peace treaty in history (Kadesh, The Hittite version )....recently an extremely valuable collection was introduced , summarizing the finds of Port of Theodosius , which back in November 2005, workers on the Bosphorus Tunnel Project-Marmaray- discovered its silted-up remains . it is called the "Yenikapi shipwreck ".i also loved the few -but unique- finds from pre-Islamic Arabia

Great time here. Lots to see at this museum. Several floors to explore and several buildings. Things to explore outside too as the museum covers a wide area. Loved the Palace outside which now is a museum to pottery and china. A very lovely building which I enjoyed more than the pottery. The outside café is also very good serving sandwiches cakes etc and a good selection of food. Well worth a visit and good value.

Oldest peace treaty. We went to the museum specifically to see the Treaty of Kadesh, oldest known peace treaty in the world. But there's so much more at this museum, with exhibits of items from 6,000 or more years ago. Man has been a long time on this land, indeed.

Pleased the Pergamon Museum and British Museum didn't take everything. The Archaeology Museum was pleasantly quiet when we visited, in contrast to the palace next door. The museum has some great pieces and with parts of the museum reopening after renovation since I last visited a little over a year ago I'm glad I returned.Some of the items being exhibited could do with a little more explanation to put them in context, though I noted that the newer displays performed better on this. Definitely worth a visit, particularly if you have already purchased the Istanbul card.

Don't miss it. There are 3 buildings; don't miss the first two for archaeological finds, statues and sarcophagi. The third is most beautiful and is of interest for its lovely tiled walls and colorful glass windows.

Best place to get in touch with the history of Turkey & the whole region. Had to take a quick tour inside, but I was very impressed by the collection which museum has and very well maintained exhibitions. Don't forget to take audio guide for just 10 TRL in case you want to spend more than 1 h.Definitely will visit it again next time.

Amazing artifacts. This is a must see, especially when paired with other historic sites in Istanbul. There are so many amazing artifacts inside, history buffs could spend hours. The sarcophagus collection was the highlight for me as well as the relics from Sidon. Very cool. Use your Muze pass here.
