Istanbul Archaeology Museum. Well worth the time and minimal cost to have a look at artifacts from ancient times. While a part of the museum was under renovation there was still plenty to see.

Unbelievable!. I went to this museum by myself and was wowed! One building is under restoration, am not sure what I missed, but my gosh! Even the outside is full of ancient columns and stuff. It was overwhelming (in a good way), my favorite was the sarcophagi section. I don't think I covered everything because of time constraints, but I will devote more time next time I am in Istanbul. Do not miss going to this museum.
Amazing Museum. You must see this museum. The collection is amazing. Exhibits dating back to 5000 B.C. It contains Alexander the Great coffin.
worth the visit, even with half of it closed. It was a new experience to see Asia/persia/.. as the center and start of culture. Great exposition. The sarcofage section is a must see.

So many things to see. So many things to see and so much variety. I am not normally interested in this type of museum, but went with one of the travelers in the group and having now gone, I would definitely go back.
More than it seems. Better than we thought it would be. Lots of well described history and artifacts. The sarcophagus section is very interesting.

Super Duper Awesome. I really do like this museum. I really do. It may be because I haven't went to such a grandeur museum but yeah, I do really really like 'em. It immediately pique my interest to visit The Louvre.The main highlight is of course the Alexander Sarcophagus. You can't miss it, it is very near to the entrance but don't miss out to make a complete tour of the entire building complex!
We expected more!. We thought it was quite boring, although we're very interested in archeology. There were more people who worked there (who only paid attention to their cell phone) than visitors.

Very good. This was well worth visiting. The third floor of the main building was closed when I was there. Go to the Ancient Orient museum and do the ground floor of the main museum especially the sarcofagi from Lebanon.
Amazing. It is very magical place.. Everyone who visits istanbul must visit there and feel the history ... Amazing

Relics of Another Time. Like all of the major museums we visited in Turkey, this was a model of how valuable artifacts should be displayed and annotated: crisp and interesting descriptions in English as well as Turkish supported by lucid explanatory maps and diagrams. The collection itself, as well as the three major buildings that house them, are of the highest order. The largest is the original museum, initiated in 1881. It contains a stunning collection of Greek and Roman sculptural art focused predominantly on row after row of Sarcophagi ------ large, richly decorated, and superlatively carved down to the tiniest detail. Look out for the Sarcophagus of Alexander the Great ( now known to have nothing to do with the great conqueror), and those of the Crying Women and the Satrap. On the other side of the hall you will find many of the greatest examples of Greek statuary that have survived theft and destruction, notably full-length versions of Alexander, Cybele, and Valentinian ll (Roman), as well as brilliant busts of Alexander and Zeus. A lot of space is given to the archaeological development of Istanbul that turns out to be a nice way of getting to know the details of its complex history. A small section of artifacts from Troy is also tucked away.Opposite this building is the Museum of the Ancient Orient. Started in 1883, it contains acollection of remarkable items from the Babylonian and Assyrian civilizations, including fascinating steles, cuneiform tablets, and huge tiled pictorial animals that originally adorned the famous gate of Ishtar. Examples of Egyptian and Byzantine art are also to be found. Alongside it is the absolute gem called the Tiled Kiosk. It represents an aristocratic Islamic home, and is decorated throughout with tiles, mosaics, ceramics, calligraphy, and sparkling multi-coloured stained-glass windows, and is worth the price of admission alone. This is only 10 TL, but remember that Monday is closing day.

My top rating in Istanbul goes to this archaelogy museum.. If you are interested in ancient civilisations you can not afford to miss this place. One of the star attractions include Alexanders sarcophagus. There is an entry fee of 15 euros.

Plenty to make Ozymandias despair. One of my favourites in last weeks visit. If you are interested in history and the development of both Istanbul and civilisation in the wider area this is a must see. Spread over a rambling site so make sure you visit all three buildings. Used my Eyewitness guide to cherry-pick key exhibits - although audio-tours are readily available. All panels have English as well as Turkish explanations in enough detail to get to grips with content. We found this easy to find having got off the tram at Gulhane, followed the walls back up hill for 50 yards and then turned left into side entrance. We also bought our Museum pass at the entrance (there was no queue) which was worth the money to gain direct access to nearby Topkapi and Hagia Sophia which by contrast were crowded.

So glad we went. Blown away by this place. Didn't come near to finishing the exhibits before I had to leave. Get the audio guide, it's very well done. Can't believe that I saw parts of the gates of Babylon.

know the history !. we went there with my brothers and we love history and archeology old things..amazing place and there are lots of archaeological things.next to topkapi palace easy to find and i guess it was a free to wisit bcos we passed there from topkapi palace's garden
Very interesting place. We went here because it was part of our museum pass and it turned out to be a very interesting place. Sitting in the garden cafe surrounded by ruins. Amazing

Very interesting, a truly learning experience. If you like the city, visit the museum and explore its past, from the sumerians to the otomans to today´s Istanbul, this place has endless information sources, all backed up by their impressive collection of relics, including alexander's sarcophagus, the oldest love poem, the treaty of kadesh, and the tiled animals from Ishtar gate to name a few.Definitely worth a visit

Well worth a visit.. Here you will see some truly wonderful artifacts that rival those on show in many of the world's great museums. Not seemingly as popular as some of the other of Istanbul's historic quarter attractions, no crowds but loads of history.
Must see!!!. This is a great museum of archaeology..I would do this again....so much to see.It's like travelling through the passage of time on each floor....great experience.
It's a must.. Interested in history? You have to see this, and it is not huge but has very important things on display. It is in the inner grounds of the Topkapi Palace.

Many Great Artifacts. The entire time period covered by the items here is astounding. Some items are from Babalon and ancient sites in Lebanon. There is a large collection of burial artifacts, and many sarcophagi. One of these was in fabulous condition with distinct details surviving on the carved marble. The collection of ancient tile items showed a high level of achievement for this craft. The only drawback was the audio tour (15TL). Many of the items were not labeled with the corresponding number for the audio device.. One would have to match the item number on the tiny map and the description title on the plaque, then key in the number from the map into the device. Not much attention had been paid to the ease of use of this feature.

Very Interesting. Lots of interesting and beautiful artifacts. I would definitely recommend visiting the Archaeology Museum. The stone carvings are magnificent.We visited because it was listed as one of the sites we could use our "Muze" pass on (a pass that lets you in specific sites in Istanbul), but I would recommend going to this whether or not you have purchased the Muze pass.

Don't miss this!. Beautiful grounds, amazing pieces throughout the entire museum. There's a wonderful outdoor cafe that's the perfect spot to grab a coffee and sit amongst ancient sculptures...easy to get to from the historic part of town.

Even on a sunny day, a must visit museum. This museum is tucked away behind one of the narrow cobblestone streets near the Topkapi Palace. The museum is actually in two major buildings (as I recall). The sarcophagus of Alexander the Great was incredible with details and color from centuries ago. The tile museum building itself was a beauty unto itself, in addition to the with relics and pottery from B.C. civilizations.

Great museum, poor management. Liked: wonderful collection of artefacts up to 4400 years old, including a stunning collection of sarcophagi.Disliked: the long wait to get in, around 45 minutes. The wait was caused not by the number of people waiting (which was modest) but by the hopelessly inefficient ticket sales office.
Interesting place to visit. Although not all the exhibits were open, I enjoyed visiting and learning about early Turkish history, especially the Istanbul through the ages display upstairs.
Wow. We've been to the great museums of the world and this one ranks right up there. Headphones a necessity as the descriptions (Turkish and English) are low and hard to read

Some Real Cool Stuff. I walked through some of this rather quick as there were so many things to see and I was on a tight schedule. That said, there were some real sweet sarcophagi and other monuments, as well as some real cool historical pieces related to Constantinople (think 3 floors!). History buffs will love it, kids will likely be bored. I went from excited to bored and back again. A lot of stuff to read, give yourself several hours to truly appreciate everything.

Incredible!. Take a few hours to explore these exhibits. We only got to the sarcophagus section...the carvings were mind numbing. I'm sure this museum is often missed because of the others around it. We shared it one morning for a coulpe of hours with no more than 10-12 other

Amazing. Wow! I mean really! When you get to the Old Town in Istanbul, you rapidly understand that people are literally tripping over historical artefacts. The place is loaded with history. But this museum, I mean, it's packed with incredible pieces, some of which are in perfect condition. For example, there is an ancient sarcophagus that is in mint condition, just as if it had been made a few years ago. And what's also very nice, the place is really not crowded. Well worth a visit.
A must. Her you will see relics form the long and exiting history of Istanbul, really worth visiting. You just at least reserve 3-5 hours for the visit
Archeology at its Best. Definitely should be included on your itinerary. The museum was full of artifacts from areas in and around Turkey.

Unexpected pearl. Having read reviews commenting on how parts of it are often closed,this was an unexpected surprise.Excellent collection with good explanations in English.Easily accessible from Gulhane tram stop,even a free shuttle to get up the slight hill.Audio guide good.Shop good.

Interesting!. Turkey is a lovely country and they know how to preserve history!
This museum is great, has many interesting things to see.
The sarcophagus of Alexander, the great, is very special!

Very good museum - even under construction!. This is a great museum - although the main portion was under construction when we went. There are some very cool exhibits - and while many just go because its under the museum card, I say its totally worth it!

Don't miss it!. Some of our group opted out of this as we had seen various ancient artifects earlier. What a mistake! This is a breath-taking collection of enormous burial tombs and amazing marble statues from ancient times. How did they get these things onto boats without sinking them?! The tiled museum opposite is also very worthwhile visiting.

Don't Miss This Museum. This museum has in abundance what most museums showcase. I loved the 3rd floor where it traces from the begginning their entire history. Then in it's own section it gives you the entire history of Troy. A third of the museum is being rehabed but it still is a must place to go.

Shipwreck exhibit was enlightening!. I was stunned to hear that the city was thousands of years older than originally thought. They have found evidence that this city has been inhabited for nearly 8000 years!

Too much to see. The museum is under renovation and many of the parts of the museum are not well connected, but it has the most 5th century BC artifacts I have ever seen, and the Troy section with film is very educational. I also liked the section on the port excavation brought about by the subweay construction

Excellent learning experience and some real good finds.. This is perhaps the most complete museum in the whole of Turkey and in fact, there are even artifacts ranging from Egyptian ones which I personally feel were quite irrelevant and random.Other than that, this museum has a lot of items on display with some rare finds. This includes the original copy of the world's very first contract (peace treaty) between the Egyptian and the Hitties. Amazing stuff if you ask me.There are 4 main buildings here and each display different artifacts. Overall, this is a good place to learn about the history of ancient Turkey.

Hidden Gem -- But Parts Closed for Restoration. This is a lovely museum complex, with a large central building housing all sorts of archaeological artefacts, a second museum of mosaics, and a third with finds from Mesapotamia (specifically tiles from the Gate of Ishtar in ancient Babylon). Overall, this is a delightful place because most of the tourists are busy with the more major sites and are not at this one!HOWEVER, beware that some parts of the museum are closed for restoration. My husband and I came here specifically because we wanted to get a longer chance to view the remarkable finds from Syria and Lebanon, things that one does not normally see in archaeological museums. But the entire third floor (second floor, if you are European) was closed. Most tourists, however, would find the major items, such as the Sarcophagus of Alexander, available. But expect to see a lot of scaffolding and dust.

Do see the Alexander Sarcophagus. This museum is in the Topkapi complex. It has wonderful artifacts scattered in different buildings and it is a steal at 10 TL per person admission. The piece de resistance is the Alexander Sarcophagus. The workmanship is dazzling and the one can identify Alexander without even reading the accompanying legend. Do visit the Tile Pavilion too.

Big!. A museum you have to visit in Istanbul. This is so big you have to take a day to visit everything thoroughly. They are restaurating parts of the museum at this time, but you don't experience any troubles because of that.

Mind blower! More stuff than expected.. I was totally blown away by the treasures and the organization of the three buildings. I thought they were much better than the trudge through Topkapi Palace. You get to see and learn so much about this historic area and you will be shocked by all the cool Roman relics. Full statues of emperors and gods abound. Historic perspectives on the city and relics galore. A truly great stop and right up there with seeing Hagia Sophia if you want to see something really cool.

Quality of collections vary greatly. Roman and Hittite collections are excellent. Collection of Byzantine Istanbul consist of some shards and fragments but very disappointing. Tile museum was very good.

History compressed. Having visited the Asklepion in Kos, the Mausoleum in Bodrum and Ephesus before arriving in Istanbul this museum tied the previous visits together and left me astounded by the content available. Absolute must see.

Archaelogy and Jazz. We visited this excellent museum during the Istanbul Jazz Festival. After walking round the museum, the highlight of which was the new exhibition of boats recovered from the ancient harbour during the new tunnel dig, we listened to a sound check while having cool drink outside.We ended up returning on two separate occasions to here concerts in the wonderful courtyard, surrounded by sarcophagi.Well worth the visit.

ties in to your visits to the historical sites. all of the artifacts, statues and whatnot that are in top condition are here and not at the outdoor sites that you will visit in Turkey. if you wish to get a better sense of what was found on the archeological digs, then a visit to this museum is a must

must see. By most tourists taken as an addition to Topkapi Palace, it is filled with treasures. I would advise you to visit it separately, because after the palace you are going to be quite exhausted, hardly being able to appreciate this magnificent collection.

Must see for lovers of antiquity. Not far from the overwhelming Topaki Palace and Hagia Irene/Eriene holds this museum and the museum of the ancient orient. Here you will find items tombs with carvings of Alex. the Greats battles, and the worlds first peace treaty! The peace treaty was between Egypts egocentric Ramses (he's everywhere in Egypt) with a now lesser known city state in eastern turkey. Folks thought the tomb was Alex. the great for many years. I guess it took a kid to say, didn't the Greeks cremate their dead to revise the theory...haha. It takes mere minutes to a few hours to tour and its slightly off the beaten path. The whole complex is peaceful from the kinetic energy that is Istanbul. Nice one time visit, but probably not a repeatable visit.

Huge and good value. The museum was huge with good combination of ancient and more recent remnants. It covered anything from Arabia to 16-17th century. Remember to turn off your flash and not to touch the pieces. Make sure to visit the garden pieces and take a stroll through the buildings - some of the best pictures I took.

A very interesting surprise...well presented story of underwater finds. Beautiful sculpture installation in the courtyard by Jannis Kounellis , part of the Istanbul Biennal till end of November...well worth the visit..

Do not miss. There are displays in this Museum that explain and show the richness of the societies that lived in the earliest days of Istanbul. The tombs themselves are worth the visit. Part of the Museum was closed for renovation, so I do not know what we missed.

Nice museum for Istanbul history. This museum has a lot of artifacts from the area around Istanbul, and from neighbouring regions of Turkey. However, it is definitely a museum of the archeology of Istanbul, not of Turkey as a whole. It is not a general world-level archeology museum, so don't expect anything from the rest of the world.Still, Istanbul has thousands of years of history and the museum is quite good. Lots of artifacts are presented, and the signs are well-translated into English.Worth the visit.

A place to understand how much we could learn from our forefathers. a 4000 year peace treaty, art works depicting human emotions going back 300 years, beautiful tiles and pottery, units of weight and measure quoted in the bible and historical books...each exhibition makes you wonder about what we call progress!

Interesting, but no special treasure inside. The museum has a lot of items in display, but none of them stand out for being an important historical artifact.Alexander Sarcophagous, wasnt really used to bury Alexander the great. Hammurabi's code is just a copy, used to teach it in ancient times. And although it exhibits some parts of the Pergamon temple, the best parts are in Berlin's Pergamon Museum.Besides that, it is a great archeological museum. Worth a visit.You probably will need 2-3 hours for it.IMPORTANT: it is closed on Mondays
its so interesting ..... its so interesting if you are interested in history. it really makes feel thinking yourself in the past.

Unfortunately going through renovations. Overall a very interesting museum, unfortunately it is currently going through a renovation. It still was a good deal because it was part of the Museum Card program. I recommend you tour this museum as part of the Museum card sites to visit.

Don't miss Alexander the Great's amazing sarcophagus. Only 10TL and well worth a visit. Great artefacts from Troy. Only a short walk from Hagia Sophia. We spent an hour as we had done other tours but you could easily stay there for most of the day.

Awesome. Do not miss this extravaganza of archeological beauties, including some of the most unusual sarcophagus displays, and an exhibition on ancient egypt that included one of the earliest peace treaties signed , cuneiform tablets, fascinating. And unlike most of the other tourist attractions, not at all crowded when we visited, a very pleasant way to spend a few hours,and well worth the price of admission

More great stuff!. There is a huge range of stuff here, well displayed, fairly well labelled. It has whats known as the Alexander Sarcophagous, but the title is not really considered true. The notes about the founder and his work are well worth reading. There is also lots of masonry outside waiting to be catalogued, worth a browse. The islamic ceramic section is also excellent.

Interesting . A great variety of archaeological founds of the Istanbul area. I'm quite more interested in modern history, but for people interested in old history (especially B.C.) its a must-go in Istanbul.

Beautiful and very well presented museum. The Ottoman Empire (modern Turkey) was one of the greatest if not THE GREATEST empire of all times. The museum is as impressive as the empire itself.There is so much to see, so much to explore, so much to understand that it does compete withe the best museums of the world. If you don0t go to this museum you might as well go to another city.

One of the best museum in Europe. I just came back from my Europian holidays and for me, I can say that this museum is top place one shouldn't miss when in Istanbul. This is my favourite museum in Europe. As part of our Muze Pass we visited the place in the afternoon after our Hagia Sophia visit. This place is incredible and very rich in history. Amazing collections of relics and artifacts throughout several eras. One could easily spend 4 hours in this place. I recommend to put this in your itinerary for half a day!

Don't miss this one. We are not really into Museums but his one certainly impressed and we spent half day looking at the exhibitions despite some of the building being closed for renovations. It is well designed and we hired an auto guide which I would highly recommend unless you are able to gain a guided tour.

My Own Heritage. When we went there I thought I will be entering into another ordinary museum until I saw the Sidon part and discovered that the museum was built because of it . I felt proud that the relics of my country lebanon was the cause to the construction of this grand place of history . I recommend every newcomer to Istanbul to go see it.

Just like any other. The Museum is located near the Topkapi palace.Included in the Museum pass.It is just like any other museum and has numerous repetitions of the same thing.Though initially interesting one tends to get rather tired of the broken pots and arches.Some pieces might be of interest to people with an archeological background otherwise spend an hour there.Some construction work was going on so maybe it will have some improvement.

A Good Museum. Due to major work being done, some of it is blocked off, however, it is more than worth your time to visit this important museum along with the two smaller ones right next to it. We visited Topkapi Palace first and took the 5 minute walk to the Museums
Great...if you like pots.. Sadly a little bit dry. The only bit I really enjoyed was the Alexander Sarcophagus and the shipwreck exhibition otherwise it was just lots of broken pots.

Worth a visit. While visiting a museum may not seem the most exciting thing to do, there are several amazing pieces to be seen here. The 'Alexander' tomb is quite stunning - the quality of carving is breathtaking. The displays of the boats and other objects recently dug up during the Metro excavations are also fascinating and very well curated. Lastly I recommend the friezes from the gates of Babylon. remarkable pieces that are so old, saw so much history an dare beautiful

Fabulous museum. This museum contains the Alexander sarcophagus, which is worth the price of admission as is the sarcophagus of the mourning women. My grandson and I spent 3 fantastic hours exploring it.
High value museum!. One can see in this museum pieces belonging to Babylon times, 1300 years before Christ! Do not hesitate to visit this wonderful collection of very important traces of history!

A must if you have any appreciation for the overall history of mankind. Definitely a place to get the perspective on our modern eras brief history. Seeing the treaty of Kadesh, the numerous sarcophaguses - including the stunning sarcophagus of Alexander the Great - tiles of the Ishtars gates... the list goes on and on and on, made at least me feel very humble. The history of the modern man becomes miniscule, the realization of how temporary our current states, languages, nations after all are is stunning. Personally what i found the most touching piece, was a tombstone that a man had made for his dog, appraising their mutual friendship. That brought the individuals everyday -perspective in, assuring that history is not just about nations' major events, but also has the humane aspect that is often overlooked. There were ongoing renovation works, and i think the overall floor plans could have been a bit better mapped, but all in all, this place was astounding.

A must-see. If you are interested in history, don't miss this one. It's huge and interesting all through. Go there right when it opens because it really takes hours to see everything. There's an open-air buffet among the thousand-year old artifacts, have some pause there half-way through, otherwise it's too much to take for one go.

A real treat. We missed this museum on our first visit, and we're so glad we saw it this time. It is filled to the brim with fascinating artifacts, including an interesting exhibit on the history of Istanbul. Definitely worth a visit.
Amazing depth of history -- worth a visit. From reliefs at the entrance to Babylon, to the oldest peace treaty to detailed history of Istanbul through the millennium .. definitely worth a visit

fantastic. It is a huge museum with excellent collections from the region of Turkey and the Middle East in general, from around 3000 BC onwards. Some of them were obtained by excavations of antiquarians in the late nineteenth century, which means that there is too much background information, but there are also other sites interesantímas pieces, including what has been extracted from the various eras of Troy.

Really worth a visit. This is a great museum - so much to see you could spend all day here. Try to pop in even just to see the sea wrecks that have been discovered recently.Purchase Istanbul museum card if planning to visit all major attractions.

One of our top 3 in Istanbul. No real crowds here. The sarcophagi are mindblowing especially the one (wrongly, but not by the museum) attributed to Alexander the Great. Amazed they had some exhibits from the recent harbour excavations already on display. That should be incredible in years to come. The Bosphorus chain was also worth seeing.

excellent archeology museum. The museum should be called the museum of Roman marvels, since all the tidbits of Roman Byzantine history that was tossed out by the Ottomans ended up in this museum, including a complete set of busts of all the roman emperors and a few other famous people. It has funerary coffins, some othe older cultures, and more than enough old marble to fascinate even a small child. It also has a cafe- or had one, that sold cheap food in the atmosphere of sitting in a roman antiquities garden. It is not to be missed. You get there by going into the entrance of the Topkapi palace and going straight to it. It comes before the palace proper.

Wonderful pieces, great audio tour and well laid out. Spent hours looking at the antiquities and listening to the audio tour.The Istanbul exhibition was well laid out in chronological order. The tiles were beautifulAnd the kittens at the cafe adorable!Well worth it.

Museums. Awesome museums , have great Greek , egyptian and Islamic historical things and also it's has a very good information and lots of interactive stuff . Also there is a great casino and restaurant where you can eat inbetween the historcal rocks

Absolutely amazing , buy museum pass to see all Istanbul has to offer. Museum pass allows you to visit many sights in 72 hrs, but best of all no lining up. You get to bypass the hours long wait in the summer heat ! The history of Istanbul and the amount of artifacts and the way they are displayed was amazing. So wish we were still there , so much to see and do

Archeological Museums in Istanbul. I visited early one morning and there were very few people. There are three museums to go though. If you are interested in Troy the second floor has hundreds of items found in the different layers of Troy. Visit Troy and then see the many artifacts found there.
Great treasure. What a find. The mosaics and ancient archeological finds bring history to life. Worth the visit and a good hour or two of your time.

RICH HISTORY. The museum has a very rich and unique content.Many things are from all around Turkey, Anatolia. All the objects exhibited at the museum reflect thousands of years of history. Recently the museum has undergone renovations and has new exhibits now. The venue is also great : the museum stands on the historical penninsula just behind St Sophia Museum, it's at a few minutes walking distance to all the important historical monuments such as Topkapi Palace, St Sophia Museum, Hippodrome, Blue Mosque, The Underground Cistern, The Mosaics Museum. It has a very silent and tranquil atmosphere also with its courtyard where you can rest. This museum is a must see for all visiting Istanbul.
Sculpture in Splendor. Great display of Roman sulpture, with traces of Greece and Ottomon. we did this on our last day and would not have wanted to miss it for anything. loved every display.

See the Alexander Sarcophagus and then die. This is a world class museum and you could spend hours here. I have. But I realize that not everyone's tastes run in this direction. If you are with young children -- I was -- here's a thought. Come here, set your watch (I think it's a tragedy to turn off children to something you probably wish to inspire them) for 30 minutes and simply gaze in wonder at the legendary Alexander Sarcophagus which has room unto itself. This is the outstanding work of art held in this museum and it is reason enough to visit. What is it? It is a 4th century BCE Hellenistic marble sarcophagus with bas-relief carvings, some of which still contain color, depicting Alexander the Great. The carvings are excellently preserved and beautiful. Each side of the piece depicts a different scene from Alexander the Great's life including warfare and hunting. If your children have greater patience -- or you are without children -- then spend even more time in this remarkable museum with its collection of ancient Greek, Roman and Byzantine art. It has one of the finest collections of classical art in the world.

Make this high priority in Istanbul. Liked the recently uncovered artifacts from sunken boats, the sarcophagi and the many more exhibits on display. Dont miss the section on Troy and one of the earliest customs regulations. Too bad a significant portion was under reconstruction and so we couldn't see those items. Even then it was worth half a day for us.

Partial Renovation. This museum is on the Topkapi grounds with a separate admission fee. We went to see the stones taken from Hezakiah's Tunnel in Jerusalem but that section of the complex is under renovation. There are several buildings. The mosaic building was good as was the Greek and Roman sculpture (mostly tombs). There may even have been a skeleton. If you are there, try it. Not a MUST see sight.

Forget it for the moment. The museum is under renovation at present and you are left with nothing more than a disappointing experience. Even if you enjoy the balmy weather outside you will be frustrated by the lack of air conditioning inside that is simply oppressive. I'm a history-head who loves to linger and ponder on the artefacts on display but the soup-like humidity drives you to distraction and also drives you back out the front door. The annoyance is confounded by the maze of beige corridors that ultimately are a dead end and you have to back track all your steps to get back outside. Skip it and return when they've worked out how to better use your admission price.
A museum full of History. Well must say for TL10 entry ticket this place is full of history from the Roman time till present days ..need time but just going through was very educational..

Excellent. This museum has a lot to offer. One needs time to really see all the artifacts and understand the way people used to live back in time. It really offers true lessons of history to the visitors.

Where Alexander the great tomb can be detailed. A very complete set of articles, including the five animals of Pergamo, and the winter palace of the Sultans. Also the original code of hammurabi, and the treaty of kadesh!
Marvelous!. Great collections and a very nice cafe in the shades of big trees. I ended up spend the whole afternoon there.

Good collection | Beautiful setting. We really enjoyed out visit to the Istanbul Archaeological Museum in July 2013. Unfortunately a section of the museum was closed to the public at the time of our visit due to refurbishment, but the areas we saw were great. It is a large museum with lots of ancient tombs and reliefs. We found the gladiator reliefs especially impressive. The set out of the artefacts is good, with lights shining on them, so there is no need for flash photography. Given the number of artefacts held here and the low entry fee, we would definitely recommend a visit to this museum.

Good collection of archaeological finds, very bad presentation.. It has some very nice artifacts to see but it the presentation is bad. It would be nice to have more information about what you are seeing. Overall it's worth going there but it could have been so much better.
So much to see. This museum is chalk full of everything! It was well worth our time. If you like museums, definitely put this on your list.

Lots of Mosaics and the famous Alexander Sarcophagus. Interesting place with so many lovely mosaics.Do not miss the impressive Alexander Sarcophagus.Also the Museum of Islamic Art in the Tiled Kiosk is worth a visit.

An important collection. A very impressive collection of archaeological finds collected form the Ottoman empire. I would guess that the importance of this collection would match that of the British Museum, well worth a look.
Quite boring. Unless you are really into archeological relics, I suggest you miss out this museum. The outside is quite pretty but there are much better places to spend your time.

Very rich museum. You can see the rich museums of archeology museums. So much so that his work did not find a place to put. Take some time for visiting. It is very close to Topkapı Palace. An important recommendation, the Museum box office here is not busy.I advice you take your Istanbul Museum card from there. Everyone waiting in long queues in front Topkapi. Here is not no tail. Everyone is trying to take it from Topkapi.

It it great, yet sufficient.. They have in seul
the tombs of Alexander the great and Anatolia.
Both are magnificent jewels of the past of Turkey
The rest you will have to discover and take a break in the garden cafe.

Don't Miss This Amazing Museum!. We used our Istanbul Museum Pass to see this amazing museum which is just next door to Topkapi Palace. There were no queues at all but it is like discovering Ali Baba's cave, full of treasure and hidden secrets. Some of the exhibits were very old - back to Byzantine era. The highlight must be the Alexander sarcophagus. The closest tram stop is Gulhane Park and from there it is only a short walking distance to the museum.

One of the greatest in Europe!. To get in here, we used our Museum Pass Istanbul for 72 hours. It costs 72 TL and includes a single entry to 9 museums, including Haghia Sophia, The Chora Church, Topkapi Palace plus the Harem Apartments and Mosaics Museum. When you use this card, bear in mind what day the museum is closed. As some of the Tripadvisor reviewers advised, we bought our Museum passes here as there was no queue at the ticket office as it was at the other sites such the Haghia Sophia or Topkapi Palace. That was a great advice and I am very grateful for that. Without any hustle we entered the museum. I did little research before arriving so I was not sure what to expect. Truly, this museum turned out to be one of the greatest in Europe. I would stay here for hours, and this is the place I would visit again if I ever returned to Istanbul. From the colossal statue of Bes (holding up a headless lioness by her hind paws) in the lobby to the very end of my visit (which ended on my way to the toilet) every artefact was a valuable piece of history. The first few rooms contain a number of extraordinary sarcophagi form the sixth century BC. Going further, you find the room with one of the most magnificent sarcophagi here – one of Alexander the Great, so-called not because it is that of Alexander himself, but because it is adorned with sculptures showing Alexander in scenes in hunting and war in vivid 3D. Another outstanding sarcophagus is the one of the Mourning Women (4th century BC). This one shows eighteen members of the harem of King Straton (who died in 360 BC) in various poses of mourning. Other rooms offer some great statues such as the Head of the poetess Sappho and the reclining God of the rivers (2nd century AD). Don’t miss the mosaic of Orpheus of 194 AD where you can see how Orpheus was taming wild animals with his lyre. There are notes in English which come in handy. Unfortunately, my time was limited and I could not see all exhibition rooms but hopefully, I will be back.

Could use some curation help.... The museum is big, and as an archaeologist I always love a good archaeology museum! This one could use some curation help, though. The oriental antiquities section is super old-fashioned, with artifacts gathering dust mostly behind glass cases, proceeding directly and chronologically through history. The main museum is mostly an overload of sarcophagi. They have one brand new exhibit about shipwrecks which embodies everything museology is supposed to be about-- engaging, interactive, multimedia, thematic, interrogative, investigative... But the rest of it plays more like an art museum. Still, I'm an apostle of the 75 TL museum pass which includes admission here, and for that reason, it's definitely worth a visit.
Fabulous Museum. An amazing museum, full of antiquities, statues, burial vaults, etc. The mosaic building is worthwhile, too. Don't miss it.

A Must See. In a city that has almost too much to see and in a country that has the oldest civilisations known to mankind, the home of the infamous Amazon women, the Greek and Roman Empire's the founding of the Christian Church and the Ottoman Empire, to name but a few, any museum is going to be full of amazing artefacts.This museum is full of such wonders as the treasures found at Troy, the tomb of King Midas, Hittite rock carvings and the extensive collection from the Royal Acropolis of Sidon, including the Alexander sarcophagus, a truly beautiful piece of sculpture but almost certainly nothing to do with Alexander the Great.The Istanbul section is also amazing with personal highlights being the chain that used to prevent ships sailing along The Bosphorus and the head from the serpent coloumn, the remains of which are still in The Hippodrome.Don't neglect the beautiful Tiled pavilion across from the museum. It houses a porcelain collection which is interesting, but the building is worth it alone because of the exquisite tile work.

Overlooked, containing one of the great objects of the world. The Alexander Sarcophagus has to be one of the greatest items ever fashioned by human hands. This object alone is worth a trip to Istanbul, never mind to the Archaeology Museum! But the crowds stream by, mostly unaware of their proximity to this gem of antiquity, en route to the Topkapi Palace (which is admittedly special). Those who go into the Archaeology Museum are rewarded with peace and beauty, and the lovely sarcophagus. There are many other beautiful pieces here in addition to the Alexander Sarcophagus, many of them from the same site in Sidon.

Interesting. This museum complex is huge. The lion mosaics from the ancient walls of Babylon are fabulous and a must see! I enjoyed the relative solitude of the museum and spent time with some art students while they scetched the details of some of the impressive sarcophagi.

Worth a visit. Museum is spread over three buildings. All are interesting, give you enough explanation and background to the exhibits. The main building is good and will take about 2-3 hours to see everything. One hour if you go fairly quickly and don't read much. Hands down, the best section was the modern exhibit on the excavations of Yenikapi. While the city was expanding its infrastructure (to deal with the increasing population and waves of tourists) in 2004, contractors dug up some 35 remains of different ships dating from the 5th to 11th centuries. Most are intact and some are on show, cargo included. Awesome.Cost 10 TL to get in (about 3.50 GBP).

Amazing and very rich. Istanbul's Archeology Museum really surpassed all our expectations as we had learnt that it is the world's second biggest archeological museums with more than 2 millions pieces contained and preserved. I strongly urge anyone visiting this city to spend enough time in this spectacular museum.

Interesting museum after Topkapi. After touring Topkapi Palace, we came to the Istanbul Archaeology Museum to see its collection of ancient artifacts. The museum dates back to the 19th Century and seems a little shabby, but its collection is impressive. High points for us were the Royal Necropolis at Sidon and the exhibit on ancient Troy. We are not expert historians but the exhibits seemed well-done to us. We were especially impressed to learn that the museum's founder had persuaded the government to enact an Antiquities Law in the late 19th Century to prevent western countries from making off with more artifacts than they already had.

You won't want to bypass this place.. This has to be in the top 2 or 3 of any museum I've seen in the world. I could easily have spent an entire day but got through everything in a few hours. The availability of restroom access was severely lacking, as was the food in the little cafe, but otherwise this place is outstanding and more than worth those minor inconviences. Just plan accordingly.

Beautiful and Wonderful. I went there with my mo and grandma, and I have to say it was a very good museum. The only thing is that its really big, and takes pretty much the whole day. If only they had told us which place to go first it would be 5 stars!!

see stuff from your history books!. You'd think that an archaeological museum would be a tough sell to a couple of teen age girls. Yet, our girls loved the place, noting several times that, "Hey - this was in my history book!" My personal favorite was the little cuneiform tablet showing an ancient multiplication table. The amazing things range from large to small - ceramic lions from the walls of Babylon to tiny clay tablets like the aforementioned multiplication table. Worth a visit!
Great museum. Plan to spend at least half a day in this beautiful museum, great garden, make sure to visit the museum with blue tiles as well..

A hidden treasure. This is a MUST-SEE museum.From many different time periods, there are millions of historical pieces and artworks right before your eyes. The oldest love poem, the Code of Hammurabi, Alexander sarchophagus, statues, sculptures from archaic era, romans, mesopotamia, pre-islamic egypt, etcSo many things to see. Really overwhelming.If you are not a historian though, it is difficult to understand the importance of each piece in this museum. I would like to go there a second time with an historian/tour guide (Indiana Jones? :)) so I would be able to grasp the whole picture: the stories they are telling us from ancient times.I also liked the museum garden/cafe. Very quite and peaceful, under the trees, surrounded by old statues.Taking pictures without flashlight is allowed in most places

Do not miss!. I spent around 2 hours at the museum and could have easily spent 2 more hours. A lot of local objects from Turkey and the other Mediterranean countries. The sarcophagus of Alexander... the busts of the roman emperors ("headless" Nero was interesting!)... the greek and roman gods... the golden horn "chain".... the beautiful mosaic museum...wow! So much history in once place...do not miss this place, especially if you have the museum card!

Completely unexpected. We had no idea what would be in this museum and were absolutely overwhelmed with the quality of the artefacts and how many there were! Istanbul should be proud of this beautiful museum. Do not miss seeing this. Istanbul through the ages and the sarcophagi exhibits were a huge highlight

A museum not to be missed!. As a long time resident of Istanbul, I can highly recommend that this museum not be missed. It has a huge collection that has more on display now than there used to be. Gradually the museum is going through some long overdue renovation. Do not miss the bottom floors for they have a good representation of what has been unearthed within Istanbul over the years. As other ancient cities in the region, the modern city is sitting on top of some incredible things. Luckily some of this has been preserved. My only criticism of this museum is the Troy collection, which is in archaic display cases. The museum can also benefit with better directions and signage.

Less visited but a real treat. The trip to Istanbul Archaeology Museum was on my last afternoon in the city, feeling like I'd hit all the big sights and having a few hours up my sleeve. It often falls off the tourist radar compared to next door neighbour Topkapi Palace and hence has fewer crowds, however, it is well worth a couple of hours. Given the extent of the Ottoman Empire, the collection covers artifacts and fine arts from a wide area. The upstairs exhibit on the excavation of some 37 Byzantine ships is particularly well put together. Overall, a little gem well worth a look.
Civilization. Gotta see the Tomb of Alexander the Great and you can see even more than you can in British Museum. Also located very close to other "must see" places

some of the best historical artifacts in Istanbul. I only had 90 minutes but could have spent double that time easily. There are many interesting artifacts from the long and rich history of Byzantium, Constantinople, Asia Minor, Istanbul - but the two things that I loved the most was the amazingly intricately decorated Alexander Sarcophagus and parts of the original chain that was used to block the Golden Horn from enemy attack and features prominently in the long drawn siege of Constantinople by Mehmet in 1453 which led to the capitulation of the city and the end of Christian Constantinople! There are many many more interesting things to see so well worth a visit and right next to beautiful Gulhane park and Topkapi Palace.

Imperial museum of Istanbul. I planed to spend 2-3 hours in Archeological museum,but l realized that l need one full day to spend,, it is the best museum l have ever seen in Turkey,lots of objects are from Today's Israel, Syria , no worries there is a book store that you can buy books about the museum ,
Not bad for only 10 TL ($5). After walking all over Istanbul for days, my family needed something slower paced yet still interesting. This was the place.

taken back in time!. So much history here, amaxing that these pieces have survived so many centuries! We spent an extra morning just for the museum, since we could take our time reading and viewing the artifacts! A must see!!

Could spend days in there.. We stopped by the Archaeology museum for a short time, but ended up staying in there for hours. There was so much to see that we ran out of time. Artifacts ranged from Egyptian, to Trojan, Byzantine, and Ottoman. The sarcophagi collection was impressive, and although the ceramic and Trojan sections where a little less interesting, the building that housed the ceramics was a beautiful piece of architecture. If you have an interest in history you could easily spend a day in there.

A few good things to see. Parts are under renovation...which it appears to really need. It was still worth visiting, though there are better archaeological in the world. We spent about 2 hours, absolutely no crowds in the middle of the day!

Definitely worth it!. Many people walk past here on the way to other Sultanahmet attractions, but make no mistake, this museum complex, beautifully situated in Gelhane Park, is worth a visit (admission included on the Istanbul card). Allow plenty of time to get around the three museums - it is riveting, and you won't want to rush it. Thankfully, it is generally not as ridiculously crowded as the other attractions nearby.

A massive complex with some spectacular treasures. You're forewarned - a big chunk of the museum is closed for renovations (which is why I've given it just four stars). However, there's still an exhausting array of treasures to look at. The highlights for me were the sarcophagi contained on the first level, particularly Alexander's Sarcophagus. The top level has thousands of artifacts from Troy that are displayed chronologically. Many of the Roman pieces are also very interesting. The problem is the museum contains so many items that it literally numbs your brain. Pick some areas that interest you and explore them more in depth and skip the restThere are English translations of all displays and exhibits so it is very easy to follow along. A warning - some of the galleries are very dowdy, looking like an old, small town museum and many are also quite warm and stuffy. Make sure to have plenty of water to help you get through.

Not what I was expecting!. For some reason I was thinking this would a really tiny museum with a bunch of rubble. Oh boy was I wrong. Their collection is absolutely incredible. I would recommend taking at least 2-3 hours because this place is huge. Not only is it huge, they have so many pieces. I'm talking statues, vases, completely intake sarcophagi (that are just so ornate). It's like 10 TL to get in there, so do yourself a favor and go! Also, if you can't stand tourists there are not that many here! So enjoy!

must visit. but wait for the renovations to finish. i was sooo excited to visit this museum. when we arrived we were surprised that more than half of the museum was closed due to renovations, so the whole visit took us almost 2 hours when it can take a whole day.the entrance fee is still the same, which is weird because i barely saw half of it !!but for what i saw i really enjoyed it, roman, medieval, early human findings, clays, artifacts, old tools and weapons, you can find all those there.when you see the snake head, make sure to see the excavated column where it came from ( short walk from the museum, found it by accident )i was amazed to see there is a massive area just dedicated to excavations from sidon ( which is in lebanon ) along with excavations from tripoli, baabda etc.. i enjoyed looking at them and the time given to display then, and the details and work done to study them, disappointed to see them there and not in my country, but they look well taken care of there :) anyways, it was a nice visit, bit disappointing but i cant say i didn't enjoy it.

Rich museum, it worth the price.. The museum is just next to Topkapi palace and Gulhane park. Its big, full of history. Well managed and useful notes on each piece.The main building has 4 floors! don't miss them. If you are interested in archaeology then this museum needs at least 3 hours. Also you can bring your camera and use if without tripod and Flash.The entrance fee is 10TL and they accepting Museum Pass.

a must see. don't miss the archeological museum. it is a visit which repays thousand times when you go around the city or inside the country in order to understand thoroughly the culture, history and antiquity. took me 4-5 hrs but this is a time well spent

some beautiful pieces. this is a wonderful place to see some of the best of the best found. However in my mind before i went there, i had been to Ephesus, Afrodisias, and read about pergamon. When at those places they tell you that some of the best pieces had been taken to this museum. i guess i was hoping that when we got there it may have said where it was found, or grouped them as such (even though group by era is of course better) and maybe a photo of where in relation to anything else it was found. There are clearly so many ancient artifacts that they dont know where to put them all. You will even see some in the hallway to the toilet. It's amazing how quickly you become immune to ancient artifacts by age. Instead of "wow, thats a thousand years old, you end up sort of thinking, "blah - only a thousand years old, theres 4000yr old stuff everywhere,whats 1000yrs". It's an interesting sort of mind change to watch - especially with my daughter, from Australia where we dont have anything older than 200yrs old. Nice place to visit for the great pieces but i have seen museums much better set out than this one.

treasures of the city. Great museum includes artefacts uncovered this May when the metro work was being done Beautiful gold and emerald jewellery as well as boats with cargo uncovered in the silt of the bosphorous

Nice museum to relax after Topkapi. This museum was included in the museum card, so we went. There is a 'free' cart that takes you from the bottom of the hill to the museum, but it is only a 5 minute uphill.. The museum was nice but slightly old style explanations were around, but amazing to see so many artefacts found in Turkey and around. It is right next to Topkapi palace so you can visit after. Beware there are lots to see! And also I forgot- it is quite hot in the summer inside, as there are no airconditioning..
Unbelievable. You can spend a day there if you are into historyJust great collection of everythingWe will definitely go there again

Great Museums. Just below the Topkapi palace are the Istanbul archeology museums. You will need at least two days to do justice to them. They deal with the the very long period of settlement in what is now Istanbul looking at the historic fragments from the paleolithic through Byzantium, Constantinople and its transformation, to the present. There is also much from the area that the Ottoman Empire once controlled. It is impressive, ancient and redolent of Old Testament history. In many ways it compares favourably with the archaeological treasures that were spirited away to London, Berlin and Paris. In the middle of the museum complex is a lovely cafe in which to drink tea, play with the kittens, and think about the treasures.

a good place to get some history of turkey. a very interesting museum with a price of 10tl which was one of the better bargains in istanbul. well laid out with several building to see and a courtyard to sit and relax from the very busy streets of the city plan on spending about 2 hours to see everything and there was no line to get tickets when i went which was in the morning ona weekday worth a trip

Worth more than the entrance fee. We had a partial day to fill before we flew down to the Hatay region and some of our group had purchased the Museum Pass so we decided to visit this one - well worth it. Plan on staying for several hours because there is so much to see. Looking at all of the sarcophagus' and the detail on them was entrancing. To see what Alexander's was like now and what it looked like when it was "new" was educational. We also spent a fair amount of time upstairs in the newer part where they have a fabulous display of shipwreck relics they are currently excavating from the Sea of Marmara. They also have a mosiac museum attached and is included in the price.

Some amazing artifacts. We had limited time at the end of a busy day so we did not get to see as much as we would have liked. The museum closed at 5 pm and at 4:30 the guards were starting the hustle people out. As we left right before 5 pm the guards were right behind us. So if you want to see more be sure to allow plenty of time. It would be easy to spend an entire day here.The collection of Ottoman Empire artifacts is incredible and the sarcophagus' are works of art. The original chain the blocked the Bosphorus is there as well. The glass collection that we did not see is supposed to be outstanding.

amazing palce. the museun is near the old palace. it's s wonderful place. definitely worth spend some time there. and know a lot of the history of Istanbul and Anotalia. compared to other tourist sites, this is a quiet place to spend some time alone to get close to history.
somewhere tour group will not go but close to the old palace. Many ancient stuffs for those have interest in looking at museum. We spend 2 hours there and find very interesting.

One of the world's greatest archaeological museums. The collection of ancient artifacts, mainy marble sculptures from all over the Ottoman Empire, is outstanding and not to be missed. It was formed during the final years of the Empire and includes objects from Thasos (Greece) and Lebanon. The finest and richest section comprises sculptures from Istanbul itself ranging from antiquity to the Byzantine period. A part of the Museum is being refurbished and therefore closed. I have two complaints: 1) there are not enough seats for visitors except near the sarcophagus of Alexander and in the Troy section 2) the important exhibits in the garden do not have labels and there is no information about them. A scenic cafe is located in the garden ovelooking the marble collection assembled there.

Superb Exhibitions. This musuem is a very serious research institution and contains a number of large displays covering Anatolia and Istanbul from 10,000 years BC onwards. In a 3 hour visit we did not even scratch the surface of its treasures although I did stand beside the sarcophagus of Alexander the Great. If you plan to visit I recommend you do a little research before hand and pick the exhibition you wish to see rather than try to take in everything in a single visit - you just cannot do that and your brain will trip out if you try.Be warned that this is not a visit for children under the age of 10 - there are no interactive displays, playparks, theme areas or any of the other attractions for children you might associate with British museums. The displays are presented primarily for students or for people with a genuine interest in history/archeology. If you fall in to this category the museum is magnificent and awesome. If you are a casual tourist looking for something to do this is probably not for you.

Overlooked Gem. We only visited as we had the Istanbul Museum Pass (highly recommend) which gave us free entry and we were staying in the area. Wow--this museum is amazing. It is filled with some of the most unique ancient items I have ever seen. We visited the Louvre during this visit and this museum's collection outshines the ancient collection there in my opinion. Crowds are non-existent and you literally are within inches of ancient tombs, sarcophagus (sp?), statures, etc. The museum is currently under renovation (like much of Istanbul) so about half is still closed but it is worth it. To be frank. this impressed us much more than the adjacent Topkapi Palace!! If you have time and interest, drop in!!
Excellent museum, even under renovation. A great collection of sarcophagi and grave markers. Roman mosaics, marbles and an excellent section on Istanbul over various periods. A must.

Go with time and enjoy learning something new. This is a lovely collection of museums with some important pieces, nicely displayed. There is reasonably good printed commentary, and it places the objects and the region in good historic context. The collection is large, so if you're an enthusiast it would pay to do a little research and go directly to your area of interest. But the sarcophagus collection is first rate and there's a pleasant hour here for everyone. Skip the audioguide - it's a bit light.

A nicely organized museum, but parts under construction. I enjoyed this museum, especially the sarcophagi and the exhibit on Troy. A lot of it is currently under construction, but there was still plenty to see even so.

Very nice!. There are some very great pieces here. The star exhibit is that of Sidon, and the star of that is the incomparable Alexander Sarcophagus. They also have an incredible collection of grave stelae, some personalized in a loving or joking or you're-cursed-if-you-touch-this-grave way. The Istanbul Through the Ages exhibit is fun as well, giving you a nice chronology of the city.
excellent. you need a whole day here with an intelligent guide. a lot to here. our guide was an archeologist also so we couldn't get enough :)

Almost overwhelming. This is a wonderful museum just a few minutes walk from the Hagia Sophia. The exhibits there give the visitor a very good perspective on the development of the Bosphorous region and include several priceless gems, such as the magnificent sarcophogi from the royal necropolis in Sidon (present-day Syria) and the purple sarcophogi outside the main entrance which are thought to have held the bodies of early Byzantine emperors. There is really a lot to see so if you have limited time I suggest focusing on one or two of the 8 galleries. If you have any interest in the history of Istanbul itself, the section on Istanbul through the Ages alone is worth a visit. Also, the Tiled Pavilion across the courtyard from the main entrance has a wonderful collection of ceramics and is well worth a visit. There's a pleasant open-air cafeteria, too, to soothe the weary tourist.

disappointed. Too many explanations on one hand, none on the other.The museum could be very interesting to learn about istanbul history but the informations are not well resumed. In many rooms, we had the impression of seeing a catalog of pottery. Of course it's not a history museum but an archaeology museum but we were disappointed.Lack of signage, we hardly found alexander tomb.However, the museum about Iznik tiles and the museum of ancient orient were good surprises.

Great museum but easy to miss. Don't let the busy confusion of the Topkapi Palace and Aya Sofya cause you to miss this gem. We started in the sarcophagus rooms and I wish we'd begun our visit elsewhere. Sarcophagi are fascinating but a little goes along way and this museum has an embarrassment of riches on this front. The tiled kiosk holds many lovely pieces and the first entrance tot he large building has interesting sculpture and other pieces. All in all, a really nice museum.

Awesome artifacts for history buffs. It is easy to miss this jewel amongst all the other wonders Istanbul has to offer, but it's well worth the half day or more if you can manage it.This is comprised of 3 museums - the archaeological museum, the ancient orient museum and the tile museum.Visited the first two with family (including two kids aged 10 & 14) during late June 2013.Highlights: 1. The museum architecture itself is impressive, inspired by the greek neoclassical style. 2. The sarcophagi in the 'Necropolis of Sidon' section - including the amazing Alexander Sacrophogus, the Sacrophgus of the weeping women and the Lycian tomb. Worth the admission fee right there. 3. The glazed tile images from the Ishtar gate of Babylon, along with other antiquities from the great Sumerian and Akkadian civilizations. Worth the admission fee. 4. Portions of the 'Code of Hammurabi' on a clay tablet, dating from around 1750 BC. 5. Part of the 'Treaty of Kadesh' - the first known treaty between two regions. 6. Statues from ancient byzantium, greek and roman times. 7. One of the heads of the ancient 'Serpentine' columnAnd so on ..Lowlights: 1. The internal layout is not very clear or logical, can make it a bit difficult to navigate. 2. There are sculptures and other artifacts scattered outside, in the yard, in the cafe, etc. While this lends a somewhat unique feel to the museum, it also makes it difficult to see everything in a reasonable time. 3. Not all artifacts are clearly labelled or described sufficiently. The audio guide is useful, but inadequate. 4. The 'guides', while helpful, do not seem to be very knowledgeable.In summary, this is certainly one of the great archeological museums around. Definitely spend a few hours here and hit the highlights.

Should really see this..... Don't miss the tile museum inside, and do your research as to what you want to see in the Orient collection, as it is hard to find things and get around as it is under construction. Don't miss the Ishtar gate!

Crowd Free, and Crowded with Treasures. The Istanbul Archaeological Museum is actually three museums: The Archaeological Museum, the Ancient Orient Museum, and the Tiled Kiosk Museum. All of them are worth a visit; one could easily spend half a day here, with a break for a tea in the lovely tea and sculpture garden in the central courtyard. At a minimum, you need three hours to do any justice to this fabulous place. In the Ancient Orient Museum the cuneiform exhibit houses two not to miss items: the world’s oldest love poem, and the Treaty of Kadesh—the world’s oldest extant peace treaty. It also has panels from the Babylonian Ishtar Gate. There is so much more that, as I write this, I feel that one could easily spend 3 hours alone just seeing this collection. The main exhibits are in the Archeological Museum which features, among countless treasures, the justly famous Alexander Sarcophagus, but here too, I was fascinated by the well preserved mummy of the Sidonian King Tabnit (5th Century BC). Looking at this mummy I was impressed, and somewhat disconcerted by the fact that the king’s viscera was mummified as well, nearly filling the hollow chest cavity below the ribs! Make sure to read the history of the genius behind the Archaeological Museum, Osman Hamdi Bey which is presented in the foyer just before entering the galleries with all the sarcophagi. He was perhaps the first renaissance man of modern Turkey, lawyer, diplomat, scholar, painter, intellectual—a totally fascinating man. Lastly, there is the smaller, but nonetheless, wonderful Tiled Kiosk Museum which details the history of Turkish ceramics with beautiful displays; the place is also unusually cool inside, so that on a really hot day, the place is truly relaxing; in fact, the guards had a heater going to warm themselves when we were there. One final reason for wanting to visit this great complex of museums is that, unlike Topkapi, and Aya Sofya which are right next door, the museums are not crowded so that the visitor is free to walk around without being squeezed, which allows for the contemplation of the marvelous treasures.
Very interesting. The Tile section of this museum was fantastic. Also the Alexander sarcophagus and the Mourning Women are not to be missed. The age and workmanship of the exhibits is unbelievable.

Definitely worth a visit. Definitely worth a visit, they have some superb stuff here (I particularly enjoyed the Pharaos). But beware, we came specially to check out the Jerusalem exhibition, but after paying and entering the Museum we were told that it was being renovated.

Lots to see. This museum is split into three buildings and it will take you a few hours to see everything. It is located near Topkapi Palace but I don't recommend doing both in the same day because it will be too exhausting. The sarcophagi in this museum are amazing, definitely the highlight for me. I recommend getting the audio tour because it gives you quite a bit of info.

See the sarcophogus and the tiles. Worth adding this museum to your itinerary. The sarcophagi are from Lebanon. The Alexander Sarcophagus and the Mourning Women Sarcophagus are truly works of art. Take a break from death and enjoy the Tiled Pavilion. The museum is housed in historical structures so you get a bonus.
wow. i can't believe,there are a lot of things.some holly things,nice sculptures,coins,tiles....you must visit there.

full of history. more than an ordinary archaeology museum, also the building of the museum, individually a historic place. more than this there are lots of pieces belongs to babylons and Alexandre the great..
Wonderful collection ... far more rewarding than Topkapi Palace. Terrific under-visited museum with a large, important collection. Far more pleasant place to visit than the over-crowded Topkapi.

Lots of sculpture. They have a very large collection of marble carving from the roman and greek era.Part of the museum was undergoing renovations, so a number of statues I wanted to see we're not on display.A bit of a haphazard display of what they do have.Much of it is too close together so it can be hard to view from a distance.Don't miss the statue of the Emperor Hadrian on the way to the downstairs bath rooms.That about says it all.
Amazing. This museum is one of the best I have ever been in. The artefacts are a real eye opener. I spent a whole day here but could have spent longer! Definitely worth a visit.

Coffee in the ruins, tops it all!. Okay, so I'm a Hittite nerd but I loved this museum. The exhibits were impressive but the scattering of ruins throughout the site make it something special. The outdoor cafe overlooking the park is settled between stone ruins, letting you breathe in the history over tea. This museum is a great respite from the maddening crowds of Agia Sophia and the Palace, and is free as part of the Istanbul Pass.

A wonderful and awe inspiring museum. I can hardly speak highly enough of this museum. It is inexpensive to enter and has a world standard layout. It's airy, not cluttered, well explained and exquisitely lit. The discovered artefacts are very old (as much as the 6th century B.C.) and some of the art work is achingly beautiful. Don't miss this museum if you have time.In common with other Istanbul attractions, photography is allowed. We saw a party of school children enter and instantly there were 3 or 4 dozen phone cameras going. The World has changed and the museum curators here sensibly don't fight it. It means that you can bring home memories of the things that struck you the most. A good logic is of course that 999 / 1000 photographers don't have the capability of producing images that would threaten the Museum's sales ability.
Spend 2 days here. A thorough review of 40,000 years of Turkey's history and culture, essential before visiting any ancient sites.

The necropolis section is excellent. Many of the good finds in Turkey may have been shipped off to Vienna, etc., but the excellent sarcophagi and grave stelae collected in the museum are amazing and worth a visit alone. The museum also includes the Oriental section, with elements from the Ishtar Gate of Babylon and plenty of artifacts to remind you just how many societies have existed in Turkey over the past 4000 years.

Nice museum. I been there 2 times, and I had still news thinks to discover. This museum has great collections from Antiquity artefact and nice pieces from the history of the city. If you go to Topkapi, you definitely have to stop there. (It's lest crowdy :)

Amazing Archeological Museum. The Archeological Museum is located within the garden of Topkapı Palace. It is very impressive array of exhibits covering thousands years of history over an area .You could easily spend few days in this museum.The collections in the Archelogical Museum of Istanbul are breathtaking in general. Alexander the Great's sarcophagus, amazing to be standing in front of the first section on the left side of the entrance.Courtyard of the museum is a beautiful building which houses the tile and ceramics museum together with a lovely cafe which overlooks Gulhane Park. The museum itself is varity of statues and the best collections are on the ground floor. The upper floors contain exhibits relating to Troy.A fascinating museum that takes you on a journey through ancient history. I advise you to buy Museum Pass covers all the major sites ( Topkapi Palace, including the Harem, Hagia Sophia, Chora Church and Archeological Museum ) Cost is 72 TL - but it expires in 72 hours. I believe you can get them online before you travel to Istanbul.I highly recommend this museum to all!

A truly rewarding experience. This museum is truly world-class as well as being located close to the old district of Istanbul, tokapi palace and numerous other interesting sites such as Gulhane park etc. The best time to go and visit is late afternoon during the week,otherwise you will be amongst huge crowds vying to see Alexander's sarcophage etc, especially from mid June until early September. And no I would not cancel my trip because of the present uprisings although personally I fully support what they are trying to accomplish, it would still not deter me from visiting this lovely city, as 99 percent of the population are still going about their regular daily activities.

hidden treasures of istanbul revealed. This museum is so eloquent that you will see how east blends into west. Combined with the historical aspect of the magnificent city Istanbul, you will like the collection of this museum.

Nostalgic remnance of the past. Visiting this while on a short visit to Istanbul is a must. Well preserved relics and sarcophagi with ancient scriptures and carvings gives you goose bumps specially on the account that people that used to use these stone coffins dates back during and even earlier than biblical times. There are 3 museums in one compound and you just need to pay 10 Turkish Lira to enter them all. It's a good deal specially to historians and young people alike who just loves watching movies like "The Da Vinci Code". I recommend visiting this place and I would again on my next visit to the country.

well preserved ruins, biggest collection I have seen. I went to the archaelogy museum quite by chance as all the other attractions were packed. Its located very close to Tokapi palace and is a nice place to get away from the crowdsI am no expert on ruins but this really was a huge collection, of well preserved, and well documented artifacts. The rooms are fairly dark but cool and there is enough space to walk around and take your time to review. I am no expert, or even that interested in ruins but this place definitely kept my attention and there was enough information to help me understand and appreciate what I was looking atThe house of tiles is also within the same grounds.My only complaint is that its not really obvious from the outside, whats actually in the buildings, and it actually all looks closed, so a few signs pointing people in the right direction would have been good!

So much to see. We were short on time so only spent 2 hours here, but we could have easily spent half a day here. There is so much to see and the quality of the collection is magnificent.A nice outdoor café is also located on-site and a great way to take a break from the heat and the crowd. Admission is included in the museum pass, but you should still check it out even if you do not get the pass.

Many museums to be seen but..... Istanbul Archeological Museum is surely one of the most magnificent museums of its kind in the world. The setting couldn't be better - on the grounds of Topkapi, but from the concentration of Roman sculpture to the sarcopaghi of Sidon along with in depth written statements of the 3000 years of this history, surely Istanbul must know it has a gem. This museum is magnificent.
Plenty to see. There's enough to occupy you for 2 hours or more. Perfect if the weather is too hot or raining. The sarcophagi section is very interesting.

Unique Greco-Roman and Mesopotamian antiquities. Blissful reprieve from the crowds of Topkapi Palace.. There are three museums on the grounds with just one admission, which is included in the 72 hour Istanbul Museum Pass. The grounds are very near to both Hagia Sophia and Topkapi Palace making this a great place to take a break from the crowds and hectic atmosphere of both those sites. The Tiled Kiosk museum of Turkish ceramic works can be breezed through, but is notable for being one of the oldest non-religious civic buildings in Istanbul. The museum containing ancient Mediterranean and Turkish artifacts was undergoing renovation when we visited but most of the highlights of the collection were on display including the can't miss Alexander Sarcophagus and a portion of the Byzantine harbor chain.Notable in the Ottoman artifacts are the more delicate pieces of historical sites throughout the city, including the only remaining part of one of the heads of the three snakes forming the bronze column in the Hippodrome.The museum of the Ancient Orient is a must see. The ancient clay tablets are fascinating, and the glazed bricks of the gates of Babylon are beautiful.The museums were quiet and uncrowded when we visited. The garden cafe is a lovely place to relax surrounded by broken bits of classical statuary. If you have the time and the museum pass definitely make it a point to stop by.

Ancient History Revealed. I visit every archaeological museum I can when I travel. This is one of the best. Reasonably priced with few tourists when we visited. Once you are in the Old District of Istanbul, everything is in walking distance.

Amazing statues and sarcophagus. It was a very pleasant surprise!! It compares with the biggest archaeological museums, as it has a unique collection of tombstones, sarcophagus and statues. After visiting the museum do not miss the tile museum (included in the ticket) , it is a beautiful building that deserves several photos. If you are real history fan you can easily spend 4 hours there.

The Hidden Gem of Istanbul Museum. Amazing collection of antiquities. One of the best we've ever seen. There are 3 Museums on the grounds. Do not miss the Oriental Museum, Housed there is "The Kadesh" The original tablets of the first peace treaty in recorded history. Also the worlds "Oldest. Love Poem. Not to be missed
nice. located just at the back of the hagia sophia this huge museum is very elegant and full of interesting peice of art. recommended it
Amazingly rich. Travel among Turkish history and discover unsuspected treasures like Anatolian hieroglyphs, carved monolithes, clay tablets, the sarcophagus of Alexander the Great, and so much more

SO worth the visit!. Even though its under renovation this museum is a must.There is so much to see that you need at least half a day, they have compiled an amazing quantity of artifacts from sooo many eras. I truly enjoyed the visit.
