Partially closed. The Archaeology Museum is a must while you're in Istanbul but be warned that almost a third of it is currently under renovations.We did the Museum Pass with mixed results, it limits your schedule as you have to use it in consecutive days. It was nice to not have to wait in line for tickets first but you still have to wait in line to get in (not a true fast pass!)

Must see, plan to spend 5 hours at least. I spent 4 hours but could have spent an entire day there. Traces history from 3rd millenium BC. If I had known earlier, would have given the palace and Hagia Sophia less priority but thanks to the museumkaart, I did manage this .

One of the best on the planet. No idea this gem existed until we read about it in Rick Steeves. Many of their items are one of a kind, but the Alexander Sarcophagus dates from the 3rd century BC. Still has some of it's original paint and the carvings are second to none!!
Excellent collections. This museum near the entrance to Topkapi is well laid out with wonderful collection from Ancient artifacts

Worth a visit. Visited because we had the museum pass, and got the audio guide because it was only 15 Lira. However, he collections exceeded our expectations. Learned a lot about the early history of Anatolia, Babilonia, and Sumeria. We especially liked the beautifully carved sarcophaguses from southern Anatolia. There is also a good collection from the different Troy settlements. If you have time it is worth a visit.

Not a highlight of Istanbul. There were some interesting artifacts, statues and art, but I would only visit if you have purchased a Museum Pass. The layout of the museum isn't the greatest. Adjacent to the Topkapi Palace.

Incredible!. There are artifacts to be seen in museums all over the world, but the collections here are pristine. If you are interested in ancient antiquities, do not miss this.The quality and condition of this collection is not to be missed. I am concerned that there is no temperature or humidity control evident in any of the cases--hopefully they will see to that so things stay as perfectly preserved.
A great addition to our trip.. Interesting expanse of history. Reminded me of the movie "The Mummy". :) We enjoyed the air conditioning.

SO much history!. Excellent presentation, though much of the museum was closed for renovations when we visited. Especially appreciated the phoenecian (sp?) sarcophagi, which I'd not seen before in any other archaeological museum.

Allow enough time. Came with a tour group and it was "chop, chop". Could have spent many more hours here. Many amazing finds on display from the various civilizations that have called Turkey home over the centuries.

could spend a day here. Many of the museum displays here are beautifully lit and the description panels are full and informative.There is so much to see and enjoy here that I went back for a second look around. There are two things that continue to impress me: first, the collection of beautiful Sidon sarcophagi, including the Alexander sarcophagus, and second, the Treaty of Kadesh, the world's earliest surviving peace treaty.

A must see. Found this almost as an after thought. Amazing collection of artefacts across the ages with a great back story regarding the modernisation of curation in Istanbul. Up close and personal experience with history.
Interesting. very good place to visit if you are into history and monuments and looking at different archaeology things! nice cafe outside to have a cool drink after... need a few hrs here at least.

What a surprise. The museum was one of the best museums I ever visited in so many years. All the pieces I've seen that were completely wonderful. I was surprise with so many pieces of important history were there.

Not Bad at All. B/c it's so close to Topkapi Palace, they have put up a sign saying: "This is not Topkapi Palace" :))) One wing of the museum was under renovation, but two are buildings were open. They have an impressive collection of artifacts. Do not expect to see gems or jewlery, but there are a great deal of statues and sarcophagi that are almost intact, and were quite spectacular. I quite enjoyed it our visit there and you can have some coffee/tea in the interior courtyard, among ancient stones, or simply rest on a bench.Entrance fee is 10 TL/person.

Great. This place is overflowing with "old stuff!" To get to the cafe, you literally have to climb over Roman ruins! Oh, but don't bother with the cafe, tea bags and bad sandwiches, too many beautiful places to eat out on the street to bother unless you are desperate for a cuppa!

Paid the price. Relatively small for a main Turkish archeological museum, but with no lines and the fastest way to buy the Istanbul card. There are some very nice pieces inside, even though many artefacts are in Berlin or London.
Treat for history lovers. Excellent well preserved & displayed history. If you are history lover you need to plan for atleast 3-4 hrs.

Great. I'm not much of a museum buff and usually avoid them so I went along reluctantly with friends. But I was won over - this place was great. If you like old sculptures, sarcophagi and beautiful tiles amongst other fabulous treasures of the ancient world then this is the place for you. I really enjoyed it.

Beautiful museum. This was highly recommended to us and lived up to the hype. Next to the Topkapi Palace, but with no lines, the architectural museum had a very impressive array of exhibits covering thousands years of history over an area that covers much of human's earliest recorded history. You could easily spend days or weeks here, but the afternoon we spent was good for our casual inspection. Apparently, the building was originally built to house the finds of crypts, sarcophagi and headstones found in necroploles near the coast. The whole museum is pretty spectacular and the lack of crowds very nice. As thru most of Turkey, almost all of the descriptions were repeated in english. The entrance fee is covered by the 72 hour pass.

Archaeological Museum. Make sure you book a whole day to visit this place! Loads to look at and admire. Only small Cafe on site. Archaological work on going on site, so may be more to see as it develops!

One of the best archaelogy museums anywhere. The pieces all have good listed information and are accessible to within inches. The outdoor pieces are easy to walk around. The organization of the pieces is also thoughtful

incredible holdings. This place has some of the more unique artifacts in the world from the tomb of Alexander the Great (reconstructed) to the even more valuable exhibits of Summerian cuneiform writing from 4000 years ago, including copy of the Code of Hammurabi. Fantastic collection of Hittite and Asyrian objects that cannot be found anywhere else.

Be selective in what you see-it's overwhelming!. You could spend a year, maybe more! studying all the artifacts but being realistic, you probably will have had enough after 2 hrs because it is overwhelming. I suggest starting at the "Orient" - but keep to 30 min. You get to see some pretty wonderous reliefs and kids will be really grossed out by the mummies! Head to the main building and hang a left... DO NOT go upstairs! unless you are really keen on a lot of pottery, and bits an pieces of Istanbul history or Troy ( actually the movie on Tory was pretty good but the sound system was very poor). Instead, head straight and get down to the Sidon excavations because they are breathtaking! After, go to see the tiles!. They have been pretty selective so you are only seeing a few truly excellent displays. After you leave, you can go out the front gates and turn right - going down the road to the bottom where there is a lovely treed park, or hang a left and go up back toward the main entrance to th Topkapi Palace. BEST piece of advice - get a Museum pass as the one pass covers all the major sites ( Topkapi Palace, including the harem, Aya Sophia, Chora Church, Arch. Museaum and a few more, and saves you hours of standing in line. Just present your pass and walk right by the long lines!!! Cost is 72 TL - but it expires in 72 hours. I believe you can get them on line before you even get to Istanbul - visit www.muze.gov.tr - but we got ours at an automatic kiosk in front of the Topkapi palace - The machines take Credit cards... but a word of warning, the machines seem to be tempermental

Much needed renovation. After seeing many well maintained historic sites. We visited the museum. It is now undergoing much needed maintenance. Unless there is a particular piece you want to see, give it a pass.

Give yourself a day for this museum. It's actually three museums in one, but we only had time to see part of the archaeology museum. A great collection displayed beautifully. Also, in spite of being a stone throw away from the Topkapi Palace, it was blessedly free of crowds.

A gem of a museum,see atleast to the Sarcophagi,but not very well lighted.. A gem of a museum,see atleast to the Sarcophagi. It was jsut amazing,the tiles were great too. But a little more lighting would have been nice.

dont miss it. there are 3 buildings.some people goes to the main building on the right side directly.dont miss the building on the left side .after ticket controle first building on the left side.museum is so big and u need minimum 2 hours to visit.just 100 meters away from topkapı palace.after visiting u can visit gulhane park and 2 other museums inside park.200 meters away.

A wealth of treasures. One ticket allows access to three outstanding museums with a wealth of artifacts from Egypt, Babylon , as well as Anatolia. Rooms filled with massive sarcophagi , amazingly intact after centuries is a highlight. Photography without flash is allowed in all of the museums. The tile museum is housed in a unique building and displays a wealth of priceless works of art on the walls and around the windows. An audio guide is available which offers short, but helpful explanations about the major acquisitions, and explanations are available in English as well as Turkish in all of the museums. Located next to the Topkapi Palace, the museums are less visited and easy to navigate. A very nice cafe outdoors among leftover ruins provided a tranquil, shady repose on a warm day with a refreshing coffee and a slice of pistachio cake.

A piece of advice. If you want to visit more museums go to Top Kapi first, because there they make you a kind of card for vissiting a lot of places and you save money. I visited first the Archaeology Museum and it was too late to take that card...so start your visit with Top Kapi!
Exceeded expectations. I thought that this would be mid sized, but the museum was quite large with numerous buildings covering 7000 or so years of the geographical area. Was a wonderful experience.

You must come here. Ok, this was our favorite location in Istanbul. We came here because the app we used to visit Istanbul recommended it. It's called SoUL Istanbul and was really helpful. They had a wonderful photo of and description of the museum and we followed their recommendation. It was an amazing locale. Great building with thousands of historic artifacts. I learned that it received an award a few years back and it deserves it! Highly recommended.
Quiet Museum. Really good museum which probably is quiet a lot of the time as it is so close to the other major sights and the cruise ships haven't got time to include it in their itinerary.
Sarcophagus fest. Never seen so many sarcophagi but the best exhibit is the chain that used to go across the Golden Horn to close it to traffic. It was huge.

A place full of history - must visit it!. Visiting this museum will make you fell being part of present and history, as well.
You will have to discover your self the wonders, please, do!

Huge Museum. The layers and amount of history in Turkey and Istanbul never failed to blow us away as we visited site after site. The Museum here houses a ranging collection of items including Greek and Roman statues, tombs and portions of temples: a historical range of civilizations from the area: Sumerian/Macedonian/Babylonian items: the tile museum: and a range of items strewn about the property that they don't have space for. It was pretty interested but large and full of information so if you've already visited a major site, you may want to see it on another day so that you can fully appreciate all the exhibits and information.

Surprise. You will be surprised what is here. The artefacts from earlest civilizations facinated me. Then there are the most exqusitely carved bas reliefs on the sarcophagi of kings from 300BC. The only sad note is to realize what treasures were stolen and now reside in Berlin, London and Paris.

Following Two Visits I Want to Return Again !. The collections in the Archaeology Museum, Istanbul are breathtaking. The Alexander Sarcophagus (discovered in Sidon, The Lebanon and so called on account of Alexander appearing in the scenes on the sarcophagus panels) is most popular, however, I enjoyed seeing the original glazed brick reliefs from the Ishtar Gate of Babylon featuring lions, dragons, and bulls. Also worth a look at and dare I say, to touch is a Byzantine iron chain that was placed across the Bosphorus at several strategic points to maintain a secure Golden Horn.

Worth the time and less crowded than most of Istanbul. The sarcophagi collection is worth the visit by itself. The Istanbul over time exhibit was also interesting, but as with most of the displays, the interpretative narratives could be so much better. It was much more relaxed than than most of the other crowded Sultanahmet sites. A visit here followed by Gulhane Park, just below the museum, would make for a very relaxing outing.

Some extraordinary finds that you won't want to miss. This museum has a number of unusual items from middle eastern digs that you just won't find anywhere else.The Alexander Sarcophagus is worth the trip itself. While there are re-creations of what the original colors of the Sarcophagus must have been, the existing colors on the marble itself are subtle and the carvings are the types of work that you might expect after Michelangelo, only 17 centuries before his work. There is much else to draw your attention, including some of the original tilework figures from the Babylon gate. If you are in Istanbul, and you've gone to the major venues, don't skip this one. It's worth your time.

out of the ground. We werent sure we were going to come here, but after we visited we were very glad we did there are artifacts from TROY , and other areas of Turkey, One of the most interesting for me was the Chains used to prevent entry in to Istanbul hundreds of years ago.

This is a great museum. I decided to go to this museum, by chance after seeing the long lines at Topkapi Palace. To my surprise this ended up being one of the best museums I have ever gone to.it has a great collection of artifacts in a well laid manor, many of the descriptions were in English. The courtyard and cafe are a nice place to sit down and relax, to escape the crowds of tourist. Definitely a must see if you are in Istanbul.

Worth a visit. A short distance from Topkapi palce, the Archaeological Museum is well worth a visit. In the grounds is a beautiful building which houses the tile and ceramics museum together with a lovely cafe which overlooks Gulhane park. The museum itself is vast and the best collections are on the ground floor. The upper floors contain exhibits relating to Troy and Istanbul but are not as interesting or as impressive as the ground floor exhibits.

Inexpensive but Impressive. For 10 Turkish lira per person, this museum is a bargain. It has a lot of impressive artifacts from the past few thousand years. The displays explain the artifacts and put them in historical perspective. The audio guide (10 TL) was very helpful, but it could have included commentaries on more of the displays. The museum is not on the same level as the British Museum or the Louvre, but it is very worthwhile all the same. Half a day is enough time to enjoy this museum. As a side note, as with all museum guards, this museum's guards were bored, but they were not shy about calling to each other in loud voices. They also let me sit in their chair when I was tired. This is Turkey!

Big and huge. The archaeology museum is huge in size with many buildings and sections. After having walked a lot in Istanbul one might find it difficult to walk and see all the sections. In May 2013 several sections were under renovation.

Excellent visit! Well worth the money. Actually 3 museums in one area for 10 lira/person. Extremely good value considering the historical pieces and the quality of the artifacts on display. We spent 3 hours here and left still feeling like we skipped over some of the displays. Well worth it. It's actually just a short walk from the Topkapi palace, so visit the palace in the morning, have lunch there then walk on over to the archaeology museum to wrap up your day.
A Must For Those Interested in Archaeology. The collection of Roman artifacts is outstanding and is better than the British Museum. Alexander the Greats tomb is spectacular..

Three great museums at a great price. The price was just 10 TL, or around $5.50 us to visit this wonderful collection of museums. One featured Asian antiquities, one was the museum of Islamic Art (in an Ottoman tile house), and the third had, among other things, the famous "Alexander Sarcophagus," said to be made for Alexander the great. My favorite floor was one that contained countless relics unearthed from Troy. We visited this museum twice during our short stay in Istanbul.

A few great masterpieces. Amongst much that is second-rate, there are some masterpieces of Greco-Roman sculpture that are well worth seeing. The stunning series of sarcophagi are particularly wonderful - especially the one called the Alexander Sarcophagus (though it was not that of Alexander the Great). The separate, Tile Pavilion contains some wonderful examples of Isnik ceramics, and there is a nice little cafe in the grounds in which to relax afterwards.(If you are intending to buy a Museum Pass (72 TL) - highly recommended - then this is a great place to buy it as there are no long queues as there usually are at the more famous sights.)

Great break from crowds. The attractions of this area of Istanbul get very crowded but somehow the Archaeology Museum remains calmer, a welcome relief in the swirling hubbub around. And when you are inside the three buildings display remarkable treasures collected not only from Turkey but throughout the Middle East. I was especially impressed by the section on the archaeology of Istanbul including the chain from the Golden Horn, by the Sidon excavations including Alexander's sarcophagus and the Roman sarcophagi from the humble to the grand. If you have any sense of history, or if yo enjoy the beauty of sculpture, this is a vital visit. The tiles and pottery were least exciting. Allow plenty of time or consider two visits, there is so much to enjoy.
A must see. Was not sure what to expect but it was great. I am not that into museums but this was great. Spend a good 4 hours (took it easy) going through this. A section was closed too.

one of the best places in istanbul. a huge museum with several buildings containing more than one million ancient works.we visit twice in different trips.the first building first floor you can find the unique works.don't miss it!

Interesting. Three buildings and thousands of artifacts! The first floor of the main building was a treasure trove. Beautifully displayed, well described and lit. Upper floors tended to house lesser items and it looked like there wasn't much organization or upkeep. The crowds are much less here so it's easy to spend more time looking.

Mixed bag, but the bldg with the tiles, mosaics is must-see. Actually several different bldgs, with the tiles just exquisite. Another bldg (1st flr) had sarcophaguses from Egypt beautifully displayed and lighted. 2nd flr had interesting objects, but badly presented, old fashioned glass cabinets, with labels, endless. No artistry. 3rd flr had interesting video and objects about excavation of Troy. Skip the 2nd flr.

Great Value. Large museum with 3 buildings full of ancient and modern historical tidbits, no crowds, very reasonably priced, and easily a 2+ hour venture. After Topkapi, head here for more history, but in a completely different package. AMAZING! I'm a history nerd, my friend is not, we both enjoyed it.

AMAZING museum!. I've been in a lot of museums, but none like this one. A painting of Istanbul as it looked when it was a walled city was incredible, along with a piece of the massive chain that went across the harbor, preventing invaders from coming in by sea for centuries. Egyptian sarcophogi, I had no idea how massive these "coffins" were. And Alexander the Great's sarcophagus, amazing to be standing in front of that! A fascinating museum that takes you on a journey through ancient history.

Excellent. The museum artifacts are extremely well displayed in three buildings. Even though some of it is under renovation the artifacts you will see are very impressive. The displays trace Sumerian, Babylonian and Mesopotamian history and include panels from Babylon's Ishtar Gate. The crowds of Topkapi definitely do not venture down to the museum.

Go! Go! Go!. This is the only archaeological museum I have ever visited that held artifacts from cultures and peoples from 7000 BCE to a mere 1800 CE. And many of these are right there in your face! Once you see the Greek sarcophagi, your left will be changed. For a westerner, this is the starting point for rearranging our sense of history. It is almost impossible to remember them all ( theHittities, the Phrygians, Romans, Greeks, Ottomans, ...) but you will certainly leave there win sse of the smallness of pur time in history and the beauty of th art produced for millennia.

A real gem, and no crowds!. This museum has world class finds, and is right next to Topkapi palace. However, the hoards at the palace seem to have ignored this place. You can enjoy amazing things (some of the most beautiful sarcophagi I've ever seen), in peace and quiet.

A bit underwhelming really. After all the hype surrounding this museum, I left a little under-whelmed. Maybe because we'd just been to Tokapi. Maybe because I've visited the Peragamon and so maybe my sights were set too high.
Nice old museum. You can visit a couple of big old buildings with a lot of archaeological objects. Very nice to see. The presentation is the same like many years ago.

Amazing Artifacts. The Istanbul Archaeology Museum is a must-see if you have any interest at all in civilizations that came before ours. Their collection of artifacts is incredible. The complex is actually made up of three museums - in addition to the main archeology museum, there's the Museum of the Ancient Orient and Museum of the Tiled Kiosk. Just fascinating.

More than you can imagine. It would take more than a day to properly see everything in this museum. There are so many Roman artifacts and mausoleums alone. And there is the the whole history of Istanbul told in artifacts as well. There are actually 3 museums at this location, so allow yourself a lot of time if you are a history buff

Very good and interesting museum. This place is really interesting and is worth spending half a day. It is organized in several buildings with plenty of history from the ancient antiquity to modern ages. You can see how the Ottoman empire was powerful and how it is part of the humanity history itself. There are expositions with graves, mummies, paintings and sculptures of different historical moments of Turkey.Unfortunately two buildings were closed for repairs, but it was still amazing. I do recommend.
all in there about past. i had a little shock becoz lots of suprise i seen in this museum take a ticket and discover history again ,u can take photo silently

A Must See Museum. My expectations are always low for museums, but the Archaeological Museum of Istanbul was amazing. The campus is comprised of 3 separate museums which you get admittance to for the low sum of 10 lira. There is a museum for Turkey/Anatolia, the tiles and ceramics, and then another for the some of the surrounding cultures/regions. All three are worth visiting, but I'm going to focus on the main museum. Unfortunately in May 2013, it was a bit early in the tourist season and they were renovating one of the wings, but it did not deter from enjoying the museum. They first floor has a special exhibit for the necropolis at Sidon. The sarcophagi from Sidon are amazing, especially the Alexander Sarcophagus. The other thing that was quite amazing was the layout of the building. One of the levels is laid out in chronological order, showing the evolution of the Anatolia region by period. It's amazing to see the cultural progression as you walk down the hall. You can see the pottery and other artifacts from each period and the transition throughout the ages. Overall, highly recommended. It's perfect for a half-day activity if you're trying to slowly see the various sites in Istanbul. If you're in a rush to see everything because you only have 1-2 days, it's still worth the trip to walk through as it's only 10 lira.
So much to see. We found it very interesting. We used the audio guides and the information was sufficient and interesting. There is so much to see. We wish we had much more time.

Perfect place for historical buff. I stumbled onto this place while on my way to Topkapi Palace. There is an entrance fee for a small amount of Lira. I keep the smart ticket and use it later as bookmark. The museum has a large courtyard where they put ruins and statues excavated from places all over Turkey. I was impressed because the courtyard has the air of Greece in it. I feel like walking in Athens for a while. You can even see rows of sarcophagus outside the museum building, each with their own stories to tell. The inside of the museum really need your 100% commitment. You will be greeted by Mustapha Kamal Attaturk's bust at the entrance. From there, you will spend at least an hour to look at all the sarchopagus of previous Kings and Queens, the hierogliff inscripted on it, the notes describing each items, the illustration from 3D and many more. Make sure to bring cameras because you are allow to take picture inside. Do not forget to have a short visit to the museum shop. There are various unique souveniers here. Things like mugs, bookmarks, books, hierogliff on papyrus (immitation, of course), vases, t shirts, shoes, scarfs and the list goes on. Prices are reasonable.Having said all that, I must say this museum would be a nice place to visit for historical buff. But if you can't even tell where the Pharaoh came from, it would be okay if you skip this one- for this place might be one boring place for you.
Good museum. Excellent large museum that easily takes half a day to walk through. Extensive impressive exhibits from different eras. Worth a stop
Interesting museum, worth visiting!. Wide range of topics and eras presented, nice location. Don't just pass from the rooms, but give it a few hours!
Big surprise.. Didnt expect such an extensive selection especially from Sidon. Musuem undergoing reno's but still worth a visit.
Istanbul Trip. Not to be missed! Best museum visit so far! Everything from mummy to full scale Sarcofogus. Biggest archeological museum in the world, we were told.

Wonderful exhibits. The museum puts everything into context. Many interesting exhibits. They are renovating part of the complex and hopefully that may include improving their cafe facilities as the current one has a limited and expensive (for what it was) choice. The toilet facilities need to be improved as there were only about 5 and some were squaties. The disabled toilet is western and there may have been another.

Such history should not be missed. Do it before the others as it will explain a lot of what your questions will be. Istanbul is soold and turkey is amazing. If you cannot get around to all the historical ruins throughout the country this is a snapshot!
Very interesting. This museum is included in the Istanbul 72 hour card so we decided to check it out. We were so glad that we did. This is a large museum with many amazing artifacts.

Enjoyable. We spent a couple of hours here, Museum is not so wide but quality of content is. There are a few really remarkable and famous pieces and general museum maintenance makes it a nice place to be. It is conveniently located steps out of Topkapi Saray and the gardens. Few people around (probably others are preferring standard Istanbul Turkish spots) but worth the visit, definitely.

Many artifacts to be found. Three buildings: Ancient Orient, showing mainly hittittes artifacts, Archeology, housing many roman and greek artifacts, and the Tiled Kiosk, artifacts from the Seljuk era.

Not a must see but worth a visit. I had time to spare on my last day in Istanbul. The museum has some beautifully carved sarcophagi. Also interesting are the artefacts that form the history of Istanbul. The Tiled Pavilion has some lovely ceramics. Worth a visit if you have the time.
archeologic museum. i was very glad to visit this because all what they have is overwhelming-sarcophaags , artefact from before the era of Jesus Christ, realy worth while

Single best site in Istanbul, by far.. The Blue Mosque is impressive from the outside, but just a big empty room with tourists taking pictures of each other inside. The Aga Sophia is a little more interesting, with one fabulous mosaic on the second floor, but not really worth the cost or the crowds. The archeological museum, however, is the real deal. Fabulous displays (the Alexander Sarcophagus alone is worth the price of admission) in a classic setting on the grounds of the Topkopi Palace can be a full day activity. It can get crowded but if you pick your times, is manageable. Multiple rooms of ancient artifacts cherry picked from sites all over Turkey make this the best place to visit in Istanbul. Go ahead, see the Blue Mosque and the Aga Sophia, but save time for the archeological museum; it's a place you won't forget.

An Istanbul highlight. We loved this place. It was peaceful and fun to stroll though without the hectic pace of some tourists who are in a rush to see everything instantly. The collection of sarcophagi alone is worth the trip. The admission was also a bargain.

World class archaeology museum. Has the advantage that there are fewer queues than elsewhere. Don't miss the amazing Alexander sarcophagus and also the head of Alexander. The sarcophagi from Sidon are amazing. And I loved the grave stela (gravestone) to a Roman's doggy friend!

Sculptures and Sarcophagi. Museum contains the artifacts unearthed in the excavation of Necropolis of Sidon such as the Sarcophagus of Alexander the Great plus others as well as statues. Displays are arranged in chronological order. The Museum of Tiles contains ancient tiles for which Turkey is noted. Be prepared to spend several hours.

Interesting, but not WOW. I am very found of archeological museums, but found this one quite disappointing, considering all the history of Turkey. Since it was included in our museum's ticket, we spend about 1 hour visiting it. Interesting but not fantastic, I would say.

It's a place of ancient and Osman culture. First of all, I think it's a biggest archeology museum in Turkey, ehich has not only the collection of ottoman culture, also the part of Byzantium culture, like the pieces of ancient history of Constantinople destroyed many ages before...

Fantastic museum. This is a brilliant museum with loads to see....in fact, we spent so long there we nearly didn't see everything before we left! A good first stop if you are visiting Istanbul for the first time as you can learn loads about the history of Istanbul which puts all the other sites into perspective when you see them. I would recommend getting a museum pass and visiting all of the places on it that you can, starting with this museum.

Exhibits. Must sees include the Alexander Sarcophagus and the Troy exhibits. A lovely museum, currently being refurbished, small cafe and small gift shop.However there is unprecedented up-close access to the exhibits which is wonderful. Pleasant surprise was the fascinating Hittite tablets with translations.

Ancient empires - up close and personal!. This place is amazing. As other reviewers have mentioned, do yourself a favor and get there early. You can spend all day roaming from building to building and security started herding us toward the exits about 10 minutes before closing. Also, as other reviewers stated, there is a small cafe on the grounds, but if you're looking for a full meal, I would eat elsewhere. It's just a place to rest and have a snack and a cola or cup of tea. The entrance fee, at 10TL, is a steal. For me, the highlights included the Sarcophagus Room, seeing one of the three known tablets of the Treaty of Kadesh (1274 BC!), and the Tiled Kiosk Museum housing ancient painted tiles and pottery. Just being so close to Hittite, Assyrian and Babylonian artifacts was mind blowing. Even after the museum is closed, you can wander around beautiful Gülhane Park and sip tea at the hilltop cafe overlooking the Bosphorus. Incredible! Don't forget that the museum is closed on Mondays!

One of the best museums in the world. If you want to see this museum properly, be prepared to spend a whole day there. There are many buildings, each with their own exhibits. The items are well displayed and labelled, thus it is not necessary to rent the audio machines. A cafe is available on the grounds, but the selection of food is limited. Don't come there with a baby as our group did, since that made it even more difficult to see all the exhibits.

Mind-blowing. There is so much ancient stuff to see here that it is actually kind of overwhelming (probably especially if you're a New Worlder). The Egyptian/Hittite section was my favorite. The outdoor garden was lovely. Troy section very intersting.

Incredible artifacts in here. There are loads and loads of incredible artifacts in this lovely musuem far too many to mention. Tip is to get there early as it can get busy. Photos allowed but with no flash which the guards will quickly and rightly remind visitors.
Superb collection well-presented. High points include the 2nd c. CE sarcophagi from a site now in Lebanon. Don't miss the side building with Iznik tile.

go to there. great collection. half of it seemed to be closed for renovations. just as well -we spent hours on what was open. wide range of stuff from all the stages of the city (and turkey's history). The presentation is a little matter of fact but the content is so amazing it doesn't matter.

A world-class museum. You may need several hours. Everything is fully captioned (English & Turkish) and the audio guide is probably not necessary. Do not miss the Treaty of Kadesh (a peace treaty of 1269BC), the Ishtar Gate mosaic panels (stunning), the Alexander Sarcophagus (4th century BC, spectacular) and the exhibition of "Istanbul through the ages" and the Tiled Pavilion. Toilets available; cafe in courtyard and main block groundfloor - avoid their sandwiches, British Rail do better.

Great collection but not a great museum. Pity about the poor condition of the museum. Hope someone pours money into it soon. Great collection but the museum needs work done on it. Disabled access seems to be an issue.
Turkey 2013. If you love antiquities, this museum is not to be missed! It is definetely worth the time. Plan on spending 1 1/2 hours.

Outstanding. This is one of the best museums I have ever seen. It is beautifully laid out and the exhibits are breathtaking. There are hardly any broken stones, but full sarcophagi and other statues. Turkey can be proud of this museum.

A lot to see and think about. I can imagine that many tourists choose not to visit this excellent museum, but instead go to Topkapi. Don't make that mistake, visit both! You will probably need at least three hours for the Archaeology museum. There is so much to see and I felt the need to go back to certain objects. For me, the most interesting collections were the sarcophagi and the clay tablets, but I am sure that anyone with an appreciation of history could find something worth seeing. We found that the museum was not crowded but, sadly, some of the collections were closed (apparently due to lack of personnel which probably leads back to lack of funds). So be sure to visit and contribute to this excellent museum's survival.  A word of advice, some of the rest rooms for women are not WC's but squat toilets. In the rest rooms I saw, there was one booth with an ordinary toilet and one with the squat model.
Wow. Cant say enough about this. It is one of the worlds top 10 museums and deservedly so. A must for tourists to Istanbul

Completely overwhelmed. So excited that I took the time to go. The amazingly vast collection dating back thousands of years was mind boggling. The sarcophagi collection was the highlight for me. Being a cemeteryphile I was uber excited to see all the beautifully carved sarcophagi. I could have spent much longer than the three hours set aside for it but my husband was getting a bit tired.++++ attraction!
Best Museum!. Loved this museum because the things that were there were from that Turkey, not stolen like the Louvre!

This should be in your top 10!. Sarcophagus-tastic! And it only costs TRL 10...Some ancient stuff here dating back to c30,000 BC - seems the Sumerians invented pretty much everything from wheels to lyres. Who knew?Amazing sarcophagi dug up in Syria in Ottoman Empire times. Well priced (& much needed!) cafe too

A mindboggling national collection. The Archaeology Museum is often compared to the British Museum, and it’s easy to see why. They seem to have so many artefacts that some appear to have just been left outside as bollards or garden decorations! Overall there’s more to take in than can be possibly done in one day, but it’s definitely worth a try. The Alexander Sarcophagus is a highlight, and we quite enjoyed looking around the tiled pavilion too.We also spent some time in the museum cafe, which is a pricey but nice place to have a cup of tea in the sunshine, overlooking Gulhane Park.There appears to be a free shuttle bus that runs up and down the hill the Archaeology Museum sits on, but I'm not sure where it begins, so if you are mobility impaired, it's worth checking with tourist information. Also the Archaeology Museum is covered by the Istanbul Museum Pass which gives you entrance to a number of places including Topkapi Palace, the Hagia Sofia, Chora Museum, and a few others for 72 TL for 72 hours. The pass can be bought from any of these attractions’ ticket booths, and gives you ‘fast track’ entry straight through the gates.
Give yourself a good 3 hours!. It is really worth the visit. The Egyptian section is amazing.... make sure to get the audio guide. Skip the tile section if you are under pressure for time.
Well worth a visit. An underrated attraction with few crowds. However, it has an interesting collection of artefacts, especially the Lycian sarcophagus and the animal relief ceramics.

Definitely worth the time. I thought this was a fascinating (and under advertised) attraction. There were some amazing Roman and Greek relics. I would like to see them develop the museum more, especially the historic remains from Troy as these were poorly presented.

An Easy Walk. It boggles the mind how much ancient art is located in and around Istanbul. Some of the items (like Alexander's Tomb) are just incredible, yet they are just one among many in this collection.
Impressive. A very well maintained and interesting site to visit. Plenty to see and a well recorded history of Turkey.

Touch a piece of history. This is an amazing place. You are surrounded by artifacts that date through the 9,000 yrs or so of people living in and around Istanbul. But more there are so many artifacts that are on display and even ones outside which you can actually touch and know that many thousands of years before someone else did exactly the same thing - amazing!!Many people have heard of Alexander the Great and read books or seen the movies, but here you can actually see his tomb. Sure it doesn't have the glitz of the Louvre of the British Museum but it isn't trying to compete with them. It is it's own place

Awesome!. This was my favorite place in Istanbul. The audio tour is almost essential and only 10 Lira or $5. There are three buildings! So don't miss out! I ended up going twice just to see everything. There are also 3 levels on the main building, even though they are not marked well including a bunch of artifacts from Troy!

Nice surprise. I was nicely surprised with the quality of the the exhibits and the set up. Lots of important artifacts from around the area. Make sure you have lots of time in your itinerary to spend here.
My jaw kept falling open!. After visiting too many mosques and churches, the museum was a breath of fresh air. Very impressive statuary, tiles, sarcophagi, and more. Worth a visit.

ancient history. having a great interest in ancient civilisations and archaeology, i found this museum facinating. There are several parts to it, and the carving on some of the ancient sarcophogi was incredible workmanship.

Hidden Gem!. Make a day of a trip to Gulhane Park to visit the Topkapi Palace, but save some energy for this exquisite museum. This is a must for anyone remotely curious about the history of Troy, it's location in Turkey and the various finds that were painstakingly brought to museum that was built specially for the purpose. It's an incredible collection and feel for history.

the best of Istambul. It is absolutely THE most important sight in Istambul. The most amazing part, for me, are the Greek/Hellenistic/Roman/Byzantian collections, covering about 2000 years of continuous uninterrupted development, where you can see direct transition from the archaic/classical Greek style to Italian Renaissance. The Royal Necropolis of Sidon and the collection of sarcophagi as a whole, are truly unique. There are many other interesting departments. Oriental collections are maybe not as unique (you can see comparable ones in London, Paris, Berlin, and New York), but still extremely impressive, especially the Hittite artefacts. Other departments, such as Troia, architecture of Byzantium/Constantinople, mosaics, etc., etc. also deserve a visit.However, beware that the museum is currently under restoration, so that various parts are temporarily closed at different times. One very important aspect, this museum amply illustrates, is the degradation of art and life under Islam, as compared with ancient civilisations, not to say Byzantium.

Some great artefacts, but overall a little tired. It does have an amazing collection, but would benefit from some culling and more information about some key items.The audio guide was not particularly informative.Be warned - the place is swarming with school groups - might be better to go on a weekend...

So much to see!. I was amazed by the collection and exhibition thi museum offers. We went to the museum in the afternoom and unfortunately did not have enough time to see it entirely. Among the great collections are the Head of Alexander The Great, Alexander Sarcophagus, the first poem ever written, many greek gods and godesses. A must see museum! We bought the museum pass for 72 liras, you have 72 hours to visit all the museum included in the pass (Archaeology Museum, History Museum, Topkapi Palace, Orient Museum, Ayasofya, etc). The pass saves you money since the average price of the museums are about 30 liras each.

Worth several hours.... An old-fashioned museum - one which hasn't gone tabloid or assumed that the average visitor has a mental age of six or the concentration span of a goldfish. Stunning artefacts inside, lots of others lying about outside. Detailed descriptions, courteous security staff. Well worth half a day - and all for TRY10!
You shouldn't miss this museum. It contains many superb things: Egyptian mummies, Babilonian remains, very good roman tombs,... We enjoyed it very much

Interesting. There are some artifacts that are interesting, particularly those from Mesopotamia. Worth it if you purchased the Istanbul Museum Pass, otherwise don't feel bad passing this attraction by, particularly if you have seen similar artifacts in Paris, London, or New York (etc.).

Wonderfull museum. Archeolgial Museum next to Topkapı Palace is one of he best museums in Europe.The well designed not overloaded.The statues are well rxamplrs.Coin collections must be seen.Unfortunately some of the sections in the museum are closed for restoration during 2013.
interesting,. Alexander the great's coffin's if not the rest, is a good reason enough to visit this interesting museum.
Stone and pottery. This is one of the must see sights we are told, but unless you like lots of old stones and pottery, probably not worth it.

World class museum with comprehensive & satisfying collection. I have to confess that, although i live in this city, i could visit this museum(s) just previous month! Actually, it's not just a museum: There are 3 museums inside the complex. 1) Archeological Museum.In archeological museum you can see too many ancient pieces from troia settlements, pieces from pre-islamic arabian peninsula, ancient egyptian tombs etc... You need at least 1 - 1 1/2 hour! 2) Museum of Ancient Orient Creations/Works. In museum of ancient orient creations you may observe ancient economic document, inventories, reform document on terra cotta tablets, various relief works, sculptures of ancient egypt gods, interesting cuneiform documents etc... You need 3/4 - 1 hour!3) Museum of Ceramic Pavillon.This one is the smallest museum between three of them, so i advice you to visit at last. Half an hour will be enough. Inside decoration is gorgeous. I was informed that, to build this pavillon various kinds of ceramics was used.After museum(s), you may also visit cafe and spend at least half an hour by drinking your coffee/tea... in peaceful & relaxing garden.ş

Stunning collection. Collection of antiquities that surpass many of the major museums in other cities. Not the best curation however, the collection makes up for this. Soak yourself in history. I recommend the audio guide which is not expensive.

A world-class museum. I was blown away by this museum. Walking through marveling at the seemingly unending collection of ancient Mesopotamian, Egyptian and Levantine is an excellent reminder of the breadth and influence of the Ottoman empire over the 300 years in which it held sway over lands around the Mediterranean: from just outside Vienna all the way to Fez, Morocco. There's plenty in the museum to keep you busy for hours: mummies, sarcophagi, exquisite burial tombs, statues, examples of hieroglyphics and cuneiform writing, ancient temples, weapons, the list goes on. Well worth a tour.

suprisingly interesting. Left this one to last expecting just piles of old junk like museums in most citys, but so wrong. Anything that is only A.D. could well find its way out in the garden, all the best B.C. pieces filling the inside. Lots of English translations, and for those that have data access you can download information on the pieces with your smart phone. Only 10 TL to get in, and another 10 TL if you want the audio guide, this was a very good value for money. Ended up spending nearly 3 hours inside, and it even has a little cafe that you can drink your turkish tea amongst the rellics. There are some excellent examples of marble sculpture, that you will just wonder at how they did them over 2000 years ago. Some of the pieces that have been put out in the gardens would be other museums prize pieces. There are only barriers around some of the most important pieces, most you can get close enough to rub noses with a statue older than most cities. Plan to visit this place.

A must see in Istanbul. We initially planned to spend a couple hours, but ended up spending 4 and enjoying it immensely. Unlike other sites, this one was remarkably tourist-free. A few exhibits were closed, but we understood that this happens as they continue a large renovation. Tip: this is a good museum to visit first and purchase your 72 hour Museum Pass which lets you skip the line at 8 other museums in Istanbul. This came in handy later in the day when we wen to Hagia Sophia and sailed in without waiting. Good signage, almost all in English made this an enjoyable experience, as did the audio guide for 10 euros (get it). Another hint: the outdoor museum cafe is a nice place for a mid-museum break for a piece of pistachio cake and turkish coffee!
a journey through history. it was amazing especially Istanbul history part and my favorit was coffin of Alexander the great and lots of historical object from bizense

Fine and interesting. The museum displays a huge amount of history - incredibly concentrated in such a small forever-civilized area. We recommend the 3-day museum card to visit all the main attractions.

Excellent way to begin or end a tour of Turkey. On our second trip to Istanbul we made the time to visit the museum, we were not disappointed!! So many of the sites we visited on our tour around the country were represented and explained in wonderful detail. All the exhibit labels are in English and the information is well written and informative. (an audio guide is available) We used the Rick Steves Istanbul guidebook that had a nice map and explanations about many of the exhibits. Overall between the three buildings it took my husband and I about 4 hours to look at everything, although you could walk through much faster and get just about as much out of your visit; we like to linger at each exhibit. There are so many exhibits that each person will have their favorite; I liked the huge impressive sarcophagus, my husband liked the first peace treaty written in stone; there is something for everyone. The value is great, a ticket is only 10 TL (about $5.50 USD), for that price everyone should go!! Another idea to consider is wrapping the museum into part of a day tour. If you get off the tram at the Blue Mosque stop you can do all the nearby attractions (Hagia Sophia, Cisterns, Hippodrome, Blue Mosque, Topkapi palace, textile museum, etc) finishing with the archeological museum. This may seem like a lot but everything is so close and each attraction takes so little time to go though. if you keep heading down the hill you will end up at the new Mosque/spice market (if you are still looking for things to do). Overall I was extremely pleased with the exhibits and the value, I recommend it to anyone visiting Istanbul!

A must see!. If you have a little bit of interest for history, you HAVE to visit this museum. For many this is not on their wishlist I think, but this museum is simply stunning. I walked around and couldn't stop smiling and gasping while looking at everything I saw. Very very impressive....
A pleasant surprise. We were tight for time, and almost skipped because we weren't sure how intersting it would be. Amazing antiquties, beautiful tile, and great space. Highly recommend.

Well worth your time. This museum was a treat to see and they have a lot of nice items inside. You can do it all in two hours and worth it to see all the exhibits. It reminds you how much history there is around this area.

Some very nice exhibits.. Some very nice pieces and interesting exhibits. There was some reconstruction going on during our visit, but the main pieces are still on exhibit. Well worth a half day to see.

Life Changing. It isn't every day that you see things that are 4,000 years old! Wow inspiring. Plan several hours to see everything the site has to offer. Three main buildings and the outdoor garden of relics. A MUST see!

Fascinating Collection. The number and quality of Greek and Roman sculptures is outstanding, and it really helps understand the deep and complex history of Istanbul and Turkey. There are two separate museums here, the Museum of Archeology (with the Alexander Sarcophagus and the Greek and Roman statues) and the Museum of the Ancient Orient. While everyone focuses on the Sarcophagi, the greatest thrill for me was seeing all the Babylonian friezes from the Ishtar Gate. Unlike the Pergamon Museum in Berlin, you can walk up and almost (but don't!) touch these, and there are a number of lions, dragons, and bulls. Their colors are bright, and this little gem was the highlight of our visit (and my day).
must see place if you are interested in world history. Very nice pieces that was almost from beginning of history especially I advise tomb of alexander the great

Istanbul Archaeology Museum.. Part of a museum complex situated in Gulhane Park, the Archaeology Museum itself is currently closed for restoration, but we visited The Ceramics museum and the museum of the Ancient Orient. Both are superb.
Amazing old artifacts. My favorite thing about this museum was the artifacts from Babylon and Troy, really an amazing amount of artifacts spanning back to prehistoric times

We thought there would be more.... Funny to say but with thousands of things here we thought there would be more to see. Many of the rooms have 1 or 2 things in them. The shelves are also very sparse. That being said we are glad we went it is just steps away from the palace which is overcrowded and it was a nice break from that. There was very few people there and plenty of room to see everything.

gate1 travel vacation to Turkey. Turkey has the most well preserved ruins in all of europe! Its not on the euro, so its not expensive. Istanbul is a modern european city, with a lot of history. The Turkish people go out of their way to make you feel wellcome. GATE1 TRAVEL consistantly has the best tours for the best price. They employ only the best tour guides. We have referred friends to gate1travel and they have all been pleased.
Fascinating. Turkey has a very very long history and this place gives you a wonderful insight into it. I have visited three times and still discovered new wonders.

Must visit. This is a must visit museum. Its amazing how much is stored in here. There are 3 buildings full of wortwhile stuff to see. Suggest keep atleast 4 hours for this visit. Guarantee you will not regret.

Worth a visit. I didn't expect that much of this place, but was impressed with my visit. The number of artifacts and antiquity of some of the exhibits is truly astounding. The crowds were much more manageable than some of the other museums we visited (Topkapi Palace). It is probably worth getting the 72 hour museum pass to save time in the lines, if you are considering multiple museums.
Great for Scarcophogi. If you have a wanna-be Indiana Jones and haven't seen Egyption relics and mummy's before this museum is great. Its cheap to visit (10TL) and kids go free.
Must Go!. If you are visiting İstanbul and would like to learn sth about ancient İstanbul and Anatolia, you must visit...

A triple treat on one ticket. These three buildings are just down the hill from the Topkapi Palace. The Alexander sarcophagus is the premier display, but all of the objects are interesting and beautiful. The ceramic (tile) collection is across the courtyard, and next door is the Anatolian collection. Give yourself two hours to enjoy them all.If you are walking there from the Topkapi, look for the (free) temporary exhibition hall on your way -- they had the Chinese terra cotta warriors from Xian on display when I was there.

Fantastic. if you come to the opening (9am), you have the chance to be alone for the visit. 3 buildings to visit, once past the ticket: the main building (second visit) full of treasures, including sculptures. Allow at least 3 hours visit for all (for those who like archeology)

Lots of little treasures. If you have been to the Egyptian Museum or British Museum, you may be a little underwhelmed at this museum. It is really not smart to expect it to be comparable to two of the best museums in the world, but I assumed since it is located in the old Constantinople, I would see more. We were the first visitors to arrive in the morning and had the entire place to ourselves. There were a few very interesting items on display like the world's oldest treaty and various other written contracts, letters, poems, etc. carved in stone. Other items included pieces from Egypt and Rome. Along with the exhibits were descriptions on the history of the region, which I found to be interesting and helpful. Although it may not live up to everyone's expectations, it is still worth a visit, even if only to get a history lesson out of it. It won't take more than a couple hours (unless you really take your time), so it's a great way to start the morning.

Wonderful. Very. Well organized .. The collection is amazing ... Don't forget the tomb of Alexander and the statues of the Greek gods ... Audio guide is highly recommended .. Allow yourself two. Hours for this place.

Want to know why?. How to find out all about the Byzantine and ottaman empires. A good place to start before you visit the sites. There is a children's museum housed in one of the buildings and this has a large scale model of the Trojan horse which children have great fun playing in

A must. Museums can be dry, dusty places. Not this one. Exhibits are beautifully displayed and explanations are clear and chronological. We were particularly taken with the sarcophogi from Sidon, including one meant for Alexander the Great. Absolutely stunning and one of the highlights for all of us.

Must see for classics or archaeology fans. Hands down this museum has some of the finest archaeological objects I've seen. It is a must visit on even the briefest trip to Istanbul for anyone interested in the classics, Greek, Hellenistic or Roman civilization and the archaeology of Mediterranean civilizations. Other reviews cover the wide range of treasures so I'll confine myself to effusive praise for the Alexander Sarcophagus, one of the most important and interesting objects one can see from ancient times. Created in the late 4th century BC this massive object (over six feet / two meters high) is in near-perfect condition. It is carved in the form of a Greek temple and retains highly visible traces of the original strikingly vivid colors. For this reason, it is one of the very few objects from ancient times that give one an impression of what such temples and such ancient art actually looked like. The abstract, white marble one associates with ancient art is about as far from the ancient reality as it is possible to get - in ancient times these marble objects were brightly painted in vivid colors. The extraordinary detail and fine preservation of the Alexander Sarcophagus gives a true-to-life impression of what the temples must have been like, with elaborate roof decorations (acroteria) crowning finely detailed courses of decoration around the roof and brightly colored battle scenes inside the temple's pediments.For people interested in ancient history or art this one object alone is worth the flight to Istanbul. Add the many other astonishing objects in this museum and you have a "must see" museum in a "must see" city.

Surprising Find. On a cold snowing JAnuary morning we were walking through the grounds to Topkapi Palace and saw sum ruins and a building away to the side of our destination.Decided to take a look and get out of the snow and to our surprise we found a superb museum displaying so many artefacts ranging so many eras. Could not believe the quantity and quality of the displays, wishing that our archeologist son could have been there to study the works.There were hardly any people looking around, maybe tourists are more focused on the other buildings, but this is a must see attraction. Don't miss the building opposite as well, magnificent mosaics and colour.Istanbul, what a place, have to return and stay as long as possible.

Unexpected, spectacular objects. We visited the museum using our 3-day pass to the museum, Topkapı Palace, Harem, and Aya Sofia (75TL at the timoe of writing). The grounds have aslightly run-down and carewornm appearance, perhaps because building works are in progress on the site, but don't let that put you off. I had particular interest in seeing the 2,500 bas-relief tiles from the Processional Way leading to Babylon's Ishtar Gate, and these are well presented and did not disappoint, Other artefacts from the region are exihibited there too, presented for the most part so one can inspect them closely.In an adjacent building is the 2.300 year old Alexander Sarcophagus, from Sidon. It is a truly astonishing object, with bas-relief carvings of battle and the hunt of outstanding beauty and in a remarkable state of preservation - it looks almost as if it were executed yesterday. I didn't know this was in the museum and to come to it unexpectedly and see it with fresh eyes was a real delight. No less beautiful, though more understated, is the adjacent Sarcophagus of the Crying Women.There are many objects on view - these are my highlights but whatever your tastes this museum is well worth the trip,.
Treasures. This museum has incredible treasures, for those interested in archeology and history. It's the perfect place to spend an afternoon, or morning.
you need time and clouds. to enjoy this place. It is overhelming in it's bounty of historical artifacts. and that means something in a place where you walk on history.

Very cool experience (if you like archaeology). Large museum right next to Topkapi. Tons of ancient artifacts and really interesting sarcophagi, including Alexander the Great. Recommended if you love ancient history.

Surprisingly excellent museum. This is part of the Topkapi Museum complex, and easy to miss, but I am so glad I added this to my day in that area. The three museums are lined up and do have the most remarkable assortment of items on display. Well worth the time spent here.
Very good place to see. I love going to Museums but this place made me feel such magic as I loved the Otaman History and Byzentine History and this place surely has the best of these worlds

This is a "must visit". I cannot say strongly enough how this is a "must visit" site in Istanbul. There are a number of buildings on the site. I've seen the sarcophagus of Alexander the Great. I've seen sphinxes. I've seen ancient Hittite art, mosiacs, statutes from Egypt and Greece and well as the thousands of Turkish items. It is so well laid out, and displayed. I've seen contemporary art displays in the courtyard and at other times wandered through the ruins of centuries. Visit the Blue Mosque and the Hagia Sophia but don't miss this museum. Just like Ephesus is one of the best ruins in the world, this is one of my favourite museums and museum spaces. Give yourself lots of time and enjoy!
Amazing history. Unbelievable display of artifacts - so many in fact that some are left alongside the building outside. Very much enjoyed.

One of the best museums I have experienced.. Don't skip this wonderful museum. At only 10TL it is an amazing bargain compared to some of the other attractions in the city. The sarcophagi are especially interesting, and the artifacts span thousands of years. I went with my 7 year old and my husband and we stayed for hours.
very interesting. As an archaeology student, this museum was very interesting. It's very big, but it wasn't as organized as I expected to be.

History buff heaven!. If you like History, this is the place for you!
Seeing the Treaty of Kadesh and Love Poem takes you back a few thousand years!
Also, seeing the Sarchophagi of the Weeping Widows and Alexander the Great, makes you really appreciate the work of the master artisans!
Exquisite rendition!

Well worth its high ranking. If I had seen nothing other than the Alexander Sarcophagus my trip to the Archaeological Museum would have been a success nonetheless. When I visited the museum, the sarcophagus was located in the center of a relatively small, darkened room. The sarcophagus itself was brightly illuminated, and the curators had placed benches on all sides for the benefit of persons who, like me, were a bit awestruck by the visual impact of the sarcophagus. Like any number of other tourists I sat there for quite a while. The sarcophagus is a magnificent work of art, and the memories of seeing such beauty may grace the remainder of the visitor's lifetime.The sarcophagus is only one of a myriad of attractions at the museum, any one of which would justify the modest price of admission. My wife and I did make one mistake, however. We allotted only two hours to the museum, and two hours are not nearly enough.

Neolithic Anatolia. Go to the second floor of the main museum to see a wonderful collection of ancient Anatolian civilisations. A surprise on the ground floor was the return of a nearly complete Orpheus mosaic after years in Dallas.

Fascinating. This is a fascinating museum which is well worth visiting, and represents amazing value (10 lira) compared to the 40 lira exploitation of the Topkapi Palace (for the main complex and harem). The Alexander Sarcophagus is particularly stunning.

Istanbul Archaeology Museum. At first we weren't planning on vivid ting this museum but did. There is lots to learn and covers many aspects of history. Very interesting and well laid out. Cost 10TL for admission. Worth the visit.

Priceless collection. Very interesting museum, shows how rich the history of modern Turkish territory was. I was very impressed with ancient statues with some strange alphbeth on them. It really felt like going back in times.

Great Museum. Lots to see and really interesting. You need at least 3 hours to view this museum as Istanbul and Turkey has a lot of history. Recommended if you love learning about the area. The security staff are very helpful too.

Allow plenty of time to take it all in.. The building themselves are worth visiting this site. Guidebooks say allow several hours. I spent nearly all day, I had to keep taking coffee breaks as I found myself being overwhelmed by the importance of different objects in the collection. It is a rare moment in life when you can stand in front of display cabinets that hold examples of some of the earliest written records (clay tablets) on the planet. I felt like I was viewing the birth of Western Culture. It was very comforting to see a poem amongst the account keeping tablets.

Value for money. Normal ticket (10 tl) and many things to see. Of course, the most of the exhibitions aren't turkish, but from other cultures (Mesopotamia, Fryghia, Sidonia etc). It's one step from Top Capi. It's also open on Sunday.

ok. I am not into archeaology went with my husband since he wanted to go. My son was truly bored just kept running around. You should go it you are truly interested. I thought it was a waste of my time. My husband liked it.

Wow!. History buffs are in for a treat here! Turkey is proud of it's place in history and embraces it's past by preserving for the future. Some of the exhibits here are a fantastic journey through human history. Make sure you get the audio tour and have a full half-day available to at least feel that you've tried to give it all justice.

great museum. give yourself plenty of time to do this museum. we were greedy and went the day after we arrived. Jet lag intruded, so we had to leave before we were finished. Dont' miss the Tile Kiosk with ceramic beauties from the great potters of Iznik. I could have moved into this museum for a week or two.

Surprisingly better than expected. It was pouring with rain so we were looking for things to do inside. We enjoyed the museum more than we expected. The artifacts were quite amazing in the main building. It is a shame that the building itself needed some work though. Would recommend on a wet day for sure.
Amazing. I was so surprised that there are lots of (lots of!) archeological monuments. Amazing place. I spend there very nice time with my friends and such a sizable chunk of human culture.

Best 10 TL You Can Spend in Istanbul. Great value and lots to see. Exhibits are well displayed and labelled. Great activity for a rainy day. Some of the exhibit space is closed for renovation, but still lots loads to see.

Very interesting collection. The ground floor is the most interesting part of the museum with a vast collection of ancient sarcophagus belonging to Alexander the great and other kings and leaders. You'll spend half a day inside and wont notice time passing by.Audio guides are also available at the entrance.
A must visit. Dont miss the Alexander the Great Sarcophagus and the necropolis. Although he is in, it is still beautiful That is not to take from the rest of the museum but it is especially great.
Really magnificent. Worth going for the Alexander Sarcophagus alone......and there is so much more. We especially loved the ancient animal wall friezes.

Excellent exhibits and weill worth the 10TL entrance fee. The most impressive section is the sarcophagus exhibits, especially the one belonging to Alexander the Great. The hall of the Ancient Orient also has some excellent exhibits and if pushed for time just do these two, they seem to have run out of money for the upstairs exhibit halls in the main building. There is a small cafe on site but limited choices.
Plenty to see. This Museum is worth more than one visit and it is currently being restored. There are very well preserved sarcophagi and stele.
Perhaps Istanbul's best kept secret. If you like history, you could spend a couple of days here and not see everything. Be sure and rent the audio device to help interpret the antiquities within.
History overload. Could have spent a day here. Cheap entry fee. Too much to see to explain. Need a map to stop getting lost inside

Amazing collection. Especially the Alexander Sarcophogous is not to be missed. Lovers of ancient history will love it. It is a large place so be sure to allow enough time in your day to see everything at a leisurely pace.

nice museum, but.... This museum has a lot going for it, but the physical plant of the more modern part isn't one of those things. Great artifacts, interesting bits of sculpture out in the yard next to the restaurant, next to a lovely park. But the written interpretation (e.g. not audio guide) is fairly minimal throughout the museum complex, and the newer building looks like it dates from the 1960s and isn't really maintained. There's some work apparently going on inside, since part of it was fenced off (but you could see an interesting looking building facade through the separation) but nothing was happening when we were there. It was *hot* outside when we were there, and the building doesn't seem to be air conditioned, though windows open at either end of the second and third floor hallways helped a bit.The older buildings in the museum complex are much nicer and more interesting. This is a good museum if you're on a longer trip - but I'd go to Topkapi, Hagia Sofia, some of the nicer mosques, the Istanbul Modern, etc., before I'd go here.

Never plundered. Stone after beautiful carved stone of a system of gods now languishing, the sculptures of humans whose legacy may be persistant. Makes one proud to give money to the arts. If pressed for time, pick a goal and ask the attendants for direction to your choice. The sculptures are stone but the staff is golden. As you have come this far, the price of admission is inconsiderable. I'm glad I ate and had something to drink before we entered...it did take the afternoon and make it unforgettable. Take your camera, use no flash, make your notes.
Amazing. Excellent Ottoman & Islamic collection if you are interested in archeology. It even contains treasures from old Egypt.

If you like history, you can't miss this.. The museum is next to the Topaki Palace and houses an excellent collection from various periods of both Turkish and neighbouring cultures. The arrangement and interpretation of exhibits is good and is enhanced by the rental of the audio guide.Unfortunately when we visited two galleries were closed for renovation, but we still spent 6 hours there.Make sure that you visit the two outside buildings, the first of which houses an excellent Oriental (ie Egypt and Messapotamian) collection, including the Hittite copy of the Treat of Kadesh.Lacking the crowds of the Topaki Palace museum, the visit was a pleasant stroll through history and a nice way to spend a rainy day.

Magnificient. You can see the history here from the ancient times to near past.There are very surprising items. It is worth to visit there and it is very big.You need to spend at least half of the day.

Mind blowing artifacts. For an American, coming face to face with artifacts dating to 4,000 BC (or BCE if you prefer) was nothing short of mind blowing. This museum offered a great collection and was just as fascinating to me as the rest of Topkapi Palace. I mention Topkapi since the museum is on the grounds of the Palace.
one of the best places in Istanbul. I love everything about this museum and especially the tea garden, in spite of the fact that it has been tarted up and privatized. Well worth a visit.

Excellent Museum. Excellent Museum ”
This museum is much quieter than the others and very large, it has the history of Turkey and many many exhibits from Ancient times until today - Greeks, Romans, history of Troy much to see.

Excellent Museum and So Large. This museum is much quieter than the others and very large, it has the history of Turkey and many many exhibits from Ancient times until today - Greeks, Romans, history of Troy much to see.
Excellent. Great artifacts in the museum. Impressive pre BC artifacts and the Necropolis section is just amazing. Great Islamic exhibit too.

History Made Interesting. The Museum is the perfect way to study history in context and enjoy every moment. The exhibits provide incredible details and the real artifacts that are absolutely amazing. We spent two days there and still have not seen every exhibit.
Not to be missed. Make time for this museum, and not just the main building! Some of the most amazing collections to be seen anywhere.

FULL of things. The museum right know is under major renovation and I found myself lost in the first and second floors, since there is no real sign on where to find the exit. I believe the most interesting parts are the tombs in the ground floor. A must is also the islamic pavillion with the exposition of ceramics and the pavillion of ancient mesopotamia with the First Peace Treaty in History.
Best archeology museum I have ever seen. If you are interested in Anatolian civilizations, this is the place. Greek, Romam, Alexander the Great's tomb, Byzans, Hittite, Lykia, etc.

I Love Turkey!. Excellent archeological museums, sights and places! I can't believe it's true what I was seeing. So worth of visiting and the weather is perfect too! Shopping, u can't imagine and the food? Omg! So yummy!

Interesting. This is three museums in one and good value for money. One deals with ancient civilization, the next is Greek and Roman etc. and the third is ceramics. Plenty to look at and quite well displayed.

2nd visit and still so much to see. A great tribute to the foresight of the Ottoman minister who collected these treasures and planned the building to house them. We enjoyed the restored historic building housing the Iznik tile and dishes from 16th century to present. The grave art and sculpted sarcophogus are amazing. We were glad for the English translations throughout. Had chai in the outdoor cafe before departing.

Amazing ancient art. This museum is packed with amazing statues, moseleums, mosaics, etc. They could have included more information on the pieces, but nevertheless the art is amazing. The museum is a nice quite and cool "break" from the hussle and bustle of the Old Town. The museum shop sells quality gifts.Well worth a visit.

perfect although only 4 rooms are open.. this is the best museum in Turkey.you can enjoy all the timeline history of Anatolia.It has lots of sculpture and all kind of mankind objetcs.although it has limited open rooms it is worth the visit.
Too much to take in. Amazing myriad of history and culture. Far too much to take in unless you're a history buff. Very interesting no matter what your interest in history is.

Extensive collection with minimal guidance. The price for the museum is much better than the prices for neighboring attractions, such as Hagia Sophia or Topkapı palace. Walk as if going to Topkapı palace, and then turn left just after you pass Hagia Irene. There is a main building, a smaller kiosk with Ottoman ceramics, and an outdoor section consisting of grave monuments. It was not very crowded when we went on a Saturday in December, but there were still people behaving rather inappropriately for the location, for instance by talking loudly on a cellphone or taking pictures with a flash when there are clear signs asking you not to do so. Although there are guards in nearly every room, they seemed to have no interest in enforcing polite behavior. Fortunately it was empty enough that the experience was not sullied by the occasional rude person.The archaeological museum has an extensive collection. We spent three hours there, and by the end we had antiquities fatigue and rushed through the last bit. The first part is Greek-influenced Egyptian saracophaguses. After that is an extensive collection of Greek and Roman grave stelae. Another section covers prehistoric times. There are some Byzantine tiles, but this period is sadly rather underrepresented. In some parts of the museum, the pieces are well-labeled in both English and Turkish. This was the case for the stelae. But in most of the rest of the museum, the labels were very cursory, and it was not possible to learn very much about the objects. It isn't always clear what is original and what is a reproduction. The museum is also not very organized; there is no overview and no direction signs indicating the different sections to ensure that you see them all. Sometimes the only way to move to the next section is by retracing your steps. It isn't evident that the detached building housing the Ottoman ceramics is part of the museum.The displays were mostly somewhat out-of-date compared to how things are usually arranged in modern museums, which gave the impression that funds are lacking. You won't find interactive exhibits or movies (which is not a loss as far as I'm concerned, as I feel they add nothing to the experience). The lighting was surprisingly good in many places, however, so it is clear that someone cares about the collection. But what gave me the greatest impression of age was the lack of discussion of ethical questions which are found in most museums with these types of collections. For instance, a few minor pieces which were found at the same time as the lost the Trojan gold were presented without reference to the destruction Schliemann caused to the upper layers. The only evidence of some of the controversy of pre-19th century finds was a large sign commemorating the rightful return of a fresco; if there is any similar debate about pieces which came from places outside of modern Turkish borders, you will not find evidence of it in this museum.It was also distressing to see many old stone carvings sitting outside to be abused by the soot and acid in the air and rain.
