The space is clearly inadequate for the size of the collection. Some objects inside were crammed into too small a space, such as the busts of Roman emperors, Agrippina, and Alexander the Great, which are crammed into a narrow hallway.It is remarkably uncluttered with gift shops and similar nonsense. If you enjoy a good museum visit with minimal hand-holding, this is a good place to visit. You're allowed to take pictures without the flash, which many museums have banned. If you're looking for something which has been packaged for novices, this museum may not be for you. You need a working knowledge of the history of the region to appreciate it. It is probably also more suitable for adults than small children.
Ancient and lovely. Visit here if you liek ancient statues. This is quite like the British Museum and it has great artefacts from the Ottoman Empire and also some Greek and Roman Empire artefacts

Amazing sculptures and mausoleums. As soon as you enter Istanbul Archaelolgy Museum a huge statue is in the lobby showing you already the scale of findings you are about to see. The sculptures and mausoleums include from the fenicians to Alexander the Great period. The lighting is very dramatic. You will get beautiful pictures without flash easily. Do not miss this museum during your Istanbul visit, you find it to your left on one of the entrances of Topkapi Palace grounds.
See it. This is a great value. It has artifacts from all over the middle east. Low price. You will spend 1/2 day here easy.

Worth a visit.. istanbul offers so much to see, and this is one of it not miss at all, the traditional history and culture all at one place.. I suggets to make a pre plan rather than a impromtu visit.

A must see... If you are into history and mythology of the ancient greeks or the empire of Alexander the great... You`ll love this museum. Nice collections of sculptures excavated in modern day Turkey/Syria/Israel and surrounding countries

You cannot miss it!. Very beautiful museum, full of historical remnants of different civilisations that inhabited Turkey in the last 4.000 years. Some of them are really treasures, from the treat of Kadhes, to the huge hittite and sumerian statues and so on.. wonderful!
so much to see. packed with a large variety of artifacts. It took me two visits to see all of it. Well worth the time to visit.

Why did I wait so long to see this?. This museum is huge and very well organized. You can spend one hour or four hours or all day. I didn't do the audio tour, but I wish I had. Well worth the 10 lyra entry fee, and the Tiled Museum, also fantastic, and Ancient Orient Museum are also included in the ticket price.
Nice place, nice things to see.... I was amazed at some of the things they have out in the open in this museum. There are so many awesome artifacts to see and so much history to be told.
Great exibition on Troy. Do you know that Troy was in Turkey? Well, it was. And there is great exibiton in the museum. I strongly advice you to visit.

Kind of boring, but some really impressive items. A large portion of this museum is very dry and lackluster, but the Mesopotamia/Egypt section had sections of the Ishtar Gate, clay tokens with Cuneiform written on them, and the famous peace treaty signed between the Hittites and Ramses II. The import of those items is very impressive, but if you're not interested in said artifacts, the museum can and should definitely be skipped.

worth spending time and money. this museum is so huge, that if u want, u can spend there whole day.Very interesting artifacts, fulfilled with history and amusement, so you can scroll through the history of Ottoman Imper and even more.Very nice location and extraordinary buildings.worth spending time and money, totally

Very old and lots of info to see. This museum was filled with unbelievable marble carvings and headstones and remains from way Before Christ! THe first building was a bit boring so I would suggest head straight for the big museum and enjoy it... it is huge!
amazing.... hi i went to archaeology museum.i spent mak.3 hours but not enoegh .we need more hours because very big museum
Worth it.. I was amazed at some of the things they have out in the open in this museum! There are so many awesome artifacts to see and so much history to be told. Definitely worth it.

Nice place, nice things to see. There are too many to see that it is impossible to see all of them in only one day. Top Trgee: Kadesh plaque, Ishtar gate and Alexander (the great) sarcophagus. You may also be surprised with all the beautiful sarcophagus you can see there.

HISTORY. This museum does requires a full day and maybe a second to see it all. The displays are well laid out and clearly marked. After going to see Troy, this museum makes a lot more sence as to the history there. There is pleany of history here and if you are into history, then this is the place to go and see.
Solid collection. Really great collection of artifacts for such a tucked-away space. Needs a few hours at least to do this properly.

Amazing. This is by far the most interesting thing we saw. We saw tombs from Alexander's time, paleolithic prehistoric pre homosapian man, the three excavation site artifacts of troy, Hittites tablets and the list goes on and on, just amazing and worth 2 days of visiting.

Lots of History. A great museum filled with such old things, its just hard to believe that things are so very old. There are three buildings to go through and a lot to see. Lots of Egyptian history on display, history buffs will love this place.

Nice alternative to Tokcapi Palace. An interesting introduction to the history of Anatolia from the early dawn of history to the Roman era. There are three museums with the Museum of the Ancient Orient as the most interesting showing the first peace treaty and part of wall relief of Babylonian gate of the city of Nineveh.
About all arch. It is opened as fisr archeology museum in İstanbul and you cann see tomb of Alexandre even...Also, there are lots of items, ruins, about Roman and greek times...
Only for people interested about archeology. Only for people interested about archeology. Inside many description in english. I takes 2-3 hours to se all exiibition,

Astonishing! Facinating!. Our family had been in Istanbul site-seeing for a week and our last day was designated for "mopping up," i.e. revisiting the markets for last minute purchases, going back to a favorite restaurant, etc. We ended up with the afternoon pretty much free and so we decided, "what the heck, let's check out the archeology museum." What a fortunate choice! The collections are marvelous and give a fantastic indication of just how "ancient" ancient history really is. Moreover, nearly every single artifact has English as well as Turkish posted descriptions, which made it easy to learn and appreciate the displays. The tile mosaics from the Ishtar Gate in Babylon are wonderful, well-preserved and well-displayed. The cuneiform exhibit had an accounting ledger containing foodstuffs and XX quantities of beer from what is now Lebanon in 2500 BC. Who knew beer was from the Levant? We didn't!My daughter is an art historian and I am a dabbler, my son is a field biologist. In other words, we were wired for this, him, not so much. Having said that, we all were truly dazzled. I think my son was a little surprised to have enjoyed it so thoroughly. What a great way to spend the afternoon!

Mind boggling history. I love history and this is by far my favorite place in the city. I've been in Istanbul a year and haven't found a place like it. You can find/see: multiple spinx, can see the inside of a real 1500 year old mummy, sarcophaguses, statues from King's palaces, ancient copies of significant documents like the book of Proverbs from the Bible and the first peace treaty, plus so much more are all things you can find here. I don't know if you're allowed to touch things, but I did (i didn't see any signs saying I couldn't.)I would go back again in a heart beat.

Undergoing a refit. Loved the Museum of the Ancient Orient as it covers a number of our areas of interest - a good collection with lots of information. The main archaeology museum has so much in it - and it undergoing a refit. If this means there will be even more on display then you might like to plan before you visit or you could spend a lot of time looking at stelae and glaze over before you reach the Troy section....

Welcome to history. You need to spend a few hours if you want to have a good understanding about all of the items at this museum. Babylon statues that you remember from your student books! It is located near the Topkapi!l

Poorly presented. An impressive collection but very poorly presented. With no context given (there are signs in English but they tend to focus on what was dug out the ground when rather than on the significance or context of the works) the remaining impression was of a long sequence of similarl-looking statues and friezes that are hard to place, especially since they are spanning millennia.By the way, the sarcophagus everyone keeps talking about is not Alexander the great's, though that information is sort of hidden.
Very interesting.. There is more than one building though the main one is very interesting with well marked stuff from the whole region. Do not miss the Tile House which is small but has great tiles.
Great museum. Really good. Big place needs a couple of hours to go through it but worth the effort. Not expensive to get in either and a lot to see.
Not for kids.. we visited( family of 2 adults and 2 children) the children didn't enjoy it so much. Very informative and done in a very sophisticated way.

So much history!. We were the only group visiting at the time, so it was nice and quiet. The collection of objects is one of the most impressive I have seen in Europe. The sarcophagus of Alexander the Great was particularly interesting, as was a well-preserved mummy of an 800 year old king. The coffee shop in between the two buildings was quite good and took both Lira and Euro.

A must visit. Simply for the Sidon stuff with Alexander's sarchopagus. Massive and masses of items on display from many periods. Only thing I was missing was Babylonian and Hittite sections and these too have been through Turkey, but still not to be missed.
Amazing. Wooohooo it was suberb time over there! The most butiful museum in the world ever!!! I liked there :) the atmosfer was fabilos
amazing exhibitions!. amazing exhibitions with good information on them. The building itselfis beautifull, and there is a nice coffe in the courtyard. Recomended not only to archaeology fans.
Fantastic museum. Very interesting and so big, I could easly spend a day in this fantastic museum. So much history about the ottoman empire.

The Three Museums. All three museums in this area are worth the visit (Museum of Archaeology, Tiled Kiosk and the Museum of the Ancient Orient). Our guide book said two hours which was not long enough if you are a history buff. Make sure you see the oldest written treaty in existance; the Kadesh Tready.
Amazing!. The price of TL10 (including entrance to two additional museums) is ridicolously low for such value!

Take your time on this one!. My husband and I made the mistake of leaving this to see this treasure as a last minute thing and we were sorry. This is an amazing museum full of relics that will drop you jaw. It also houses an extensive collection of sarcophagi from different eras that leaves any other exhibits of this kind a distant second. We just wish we'd had more time!

3 hours, thousands of years. The museum is amazing..My favorite thing was Alexander the great sarcophogus...Oys really worth to see..2. Floor the exhibition Istanbul through the ages was georgeus..Information sas efficent...
better than expected. Actually thought it was going to be boring but it wasn't. The antiquities were in amazing condition and beautiful. A suprise find.

A Break from the Crowds. This place was pretty much empty, which I found amazing since it had so much to offer. Clearly they could use more of an operating budget; works of art are scattered around, sitting outside, waiting for a touch up. But there are some amazing things to see, and it is a great place to get lost in. I loved walking around and learning bits and pieces of all the different cultures that have inhabited Turkey at one time or another.
Lots to see. If you're interested in byzantine and ottoman history, then this is the place to go to. Otherwise, maybe if you have a lot of spare time.

Jaw-dropping tons of antiquity. you will find many many 3rd-5th century BC antiquity, a must for all history buffs! what I dislike is that too few people visit it the significant collection of treasures.

Interesting complex. Your ticket gives you admission to 3 museums in the same complex. They are all worth seeing. Gave me a good base for knowing the history when I traveled further afield around Turkey. Interesting to see the similarities between the Hittites and Egyptian burials and then the Hellenic and Roman influences. Unfortunately much of Turkey's history has been scattered around the world.

Impressive and varied. The Turkish Archaeologist Osman Hamdi Bey was unknown to us as Westerners ( 'way West - try Australia ) but he seems to have been the Turkish equivalent of Leonardo da Vinci. This museum alone would ensure his lasting, deserved, fame. Probably his single most memorable find was Sinon, from which an amazing collection of sarcophagae, stellae, and other grave markers has been preserved. The condition of these relics is the best we have seen in our visits to several counties. The sarcophagae carvings are high-relief, and be spite some minor damage and missing portions, the carvings mostly look as if they were done recently - some of the marble even retains traces of original paint.This museum also has a wide range of early cultures, Palestine, Syria, and Cyprus, among others. There's also a thorough study of Troy - I am still personally unclear as to which of Troy's 10 stages was the one Homer immortalized, but this museum says that stage 7 was destroyed by fire around 1000 BC. The museum is user- friendly ( by that I mean the exhibits are well-spaced and presented ) and pleasantly uncrowded ) -that is an excellent reason for coming in December! We would still rate Athens museum of archaeology a little higher, based on sheer scale and number of artifacts, but the Istanbul Archeological Museum is one of the most worthwhile visits we have made during our year in Europe.

Excellent museum and no one there!!. Read up on the Hittites before you visit. I found the exhibits fascinating especially the Egyptian collection. To each his own. Access the museum through the palace. The palace is closed on Wednesdays so follow the trolley tracks down the hill from Sultanahmed and follow the signs

Impressive!. Quite impressive and educational to see and read about the deep history of Istanbul, the founder of the museum, and see the artifacts that were so detailed and the advanced level of skill for that time period. HIGHLY recommend. Be sure to read the LARGE wall signs to get an understanding of what you are looking at around you.

A MAY ZING. Look out for the collection of items from the necropolis at Sidon - Alexander's sarcophagus was incredibleGood collection of items including Christ as a young man carrying a lamb.Fabulous sculptures - looked as though they had been created yesterday. What a testament to the past.

A walk through archaeological history. Another must-see, even if you arent an archaeology buff. A walk through the history of the region...including the world's earliest example of an international peace treaty.Lots of exhibits and so many in great condition. Make sure you visit all the areas on the site and not just the main building. The Tiled Kiosk has to be visited, which is opposite the entrance of main museum building.

A "jaw-dropping" experience. This is, in our opinion, the best museum in Istanbul. The sarcophagi are superb, especially the Alexander Sarcophagus (which isn't actually his personal coffin but probably belonged to someone who had been appointed as a local ruler by Alexander). Along with the Pergamum Museum in Berlin, Germany, this is the best collection of archeological finds from Turkey. The section on Istanbul is fascinating--artifacts and information on the evolution of the town from Constantinople to Istanbul. There is one section devoted to the excavations at Troy which are very complicated; a visit here may help in your understanding of the 9 different civilizations or timeframes that have been identified. Many archeological sites of the Middle East (to include Syria, Lebanon, and present-day Israel) are represented here since the Ottoman Empire controlled all that area. This museum is a must for anyone interested in the archeological sites of Turkey.

Well worth a visit!. Try to give yourself at least 2 hours to visit the 3 pavilions here, as well as the artefacts scattered on the grounds. You will gain a good overview of Turkish history through the ages, but also an understanding of the early efforts to excavate and preserve these archaeological treasures.
Wow. This is well worth investing several hours to explore ancient history and marvel over the archeology involved in this.
the best. full of old and historical things very rich collection the best in istanbul its near topkapi palace , i recommended to people who enjoy history

Good museum to visit.. You are really in the hart of history, excellent master pieces of ancient times. Easy access to museum, very close to the historical areas such as Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia and cisterns.

Many years worth of history. This is a relatively small museum considering the years of history it covers. It is steps down the hill from the Topkapi palace and worth visiting. There was one area of the museum that was being refurbished and was currently not accessable.

Interesting and must see!. During our recent family trip to Turkey we visited the archaelogy musuem - we are all history buffs and were very keen to see the museum after reading the reviews online. The museum is well laid out with interesting pieces and it was very enjoyable. You will need to set aside at least 2-3 hours if you really want to see all the sections and spend time reading the historical snippets!

No dust gathers here!. Must admit that I had doubts about visiting here: rocks and stones dug up after centuries.. But the sarcophages and detailed info on finds from Anatolia, Byzantine era and Istanbul area are absolutelu gripping. Recommended.
Not A Priority Visit. Fine to visit if you first went to the Palace. Otherwise, not worth a trip as there are no special attractions mandating a special visit.
Loved it. Tons os exhibits. Have knowledgeable guide with you that will be at ease to give you time to take pictures and observe at your own pace.

Has lots to see. I would definitely recommend to see this museum. Has tons of exhibits and would recommend to spend at least 4 hrs. Having guide that is knowledgeable and also at ease to let you take pictures and observe at your own pace is important!!!!

Totally inaccessible to those with a disability. In fairness, a restoration has started. I did have to argue the case for a free entrance for me and my carer as our country doesn't issue disability cards. Nobody told us that I could not access anything apart from the disability toilet so I paid nothing and got nothing. I was told by my travelling companions that parts were fascinating but the whole could have been better displayed. The day was dry and the archite3cture of the buildings was outstanding so I had pleasant surroundings in which to sit in the wheelchair as my friends explored.

Great, don't understand why it was empty. The museum has 4 floors. The best is the bottom with sarcophaguses and roman statues. They have Alexander the Great's sarcophagus with great explanation. Everything is labeled in English and is easy to comprehend. The next three floors weren't that interesting as they had pots and small things but nothing spectacular. Worth a quick glance. Took 2-3 hours.
A Must See. Do. Not. Miss. This. So much to see in Istanbul, this wasn't high on the list. Thank goodness I did not make the mistake of overlooking it. So many artifacts, so little time.

A Great Museum. This is one of the hidden pleasures of the old city. Set below the busy Topkapi Saray the Archaeological Museum is a wonderful civilised place. The collection is not only from Turkey, the exceptional Alexander Sarcophagus is from Sidon. But also the great treasures of the Byzantine city and Thrace, plus the oriental collection. In the summer no better place for a quiet morning close to the crowds of the old city. Tea surrounded by the broken bits of Byzantium.

Statuary for the Ancient Greek and Roman buff. The statues are in chronological order which helps you make sense of the changes in style. Most of the other exhibits were not very interesting to me, so skip them if you are short of time. The mosaics have their own museum elsewhere.
Take a sandwich there!. This is really astonishing place but very vast so you need to have a lot of time to see it all. Take a sandwich there you'll need it.

A must go. It is true that almost every city nowadays has an "archeology museum" and sometimes it is a waste of time. But not in Istanbul. It is one of the best museums in the world, and certainly the best archeology museum. A must go.

Experience the Region. Here you can find a wide range of archaeological finds from all regions. Go explore around and you'll see Alexander's sarcophagus (Not really Alexander the Great's but one of his general's), mummies, sarcophagi, tombstones, sculptures, and the oldest known written peace treaty (fragments of what is left written on a stone slab). There was much I was not able to explore due to the fact I had 1 hour to walk around for my cruise excursion. The buildings are split up into different sections. So for example one building is Asia (Ancient Mesopotamia, Egypt, etc), another was the Ottoman/Byzantine period, another was ancient Greece, and another was ancient Rome. This is some place that you want to visit if you have some time to spend to explore, and you love history. It doesn't get too crowded so if you don't like crowds this place is for you.

Classical treasures too!. One of the best museums of Greek and Roman art and artefact, including the Alexander and other famous sarcophagi, the Pergamum head of Alexander, youth of Tralles, plus some finds from Troy ans other Asia Minor sites and later material of Byzantine age.
Amazing museum. This is a must visit place when in Istanbul. One of the most impressive collection of objects from many ancient civilizations. The site itself is beautiful also.
Awesome. probably it doesnt get promoted as much as it should, they have a great collection of archeological pieces from all around the world mostly Europe. You will need a whole day to see it all

An Istanbul Highlight. A relief from the crowds at Topkapi Palace. I found the sarcophagi to be the most impressive aspect of the museum, but the museum's collection is so vast there really is something for everyone. For folks traveling to Mediterranean coast, the museum is an excellent primer for the ruins of Lycia.

A top-notch Museum. With the marathon shutting down all public transportation on a Sunday, I went to the Archeology Museum and what a treat - the most extraordinary archeological artifacts, including the Alexander the Great sarcophagus and the sarcophagus of the mourning women from Sidon. Not to be missed!

Very good experience.. It's a wonderful place to visit as I love history. I like the past with all that art affects, different cultures such as, Byzantine, Anatolia, pre-Islamic Arabian art, Mesopotamia and many more.

overwhelming. Allow at least three hours to do justice to this excellent museum. The exceptional sarcophagi alone are worth the entry fee. After travelling through Turkey for over 3 weeks, this was an excellent way to solidify what we had seen at the numerous ruin sites.

We almost missed it.. If you have a spare couple of hours in Istanbul, this place will give you a deeper understanding of its long history. Lots of interesting insights and objects and despite its dry sounding name, all the kids there were loving it too.

it's all historical. i like everything it's really great place should see
you see everything about the Archaeology Roman Empire

amazing museum. cannot be missed....spectacular sculptures, sarcophagi....i could have spent all day in the museum...i learned more about the history of istanbul in this museum....exhibits are well described....

So many things!. This is a great museum, full of an amazing array of ancient artifacts. The bottom floor of the main building is mostly full of large sculptures and sarcophagi/tombs. The second and third floors are collections of excavated artifacts displayed almost like they've just been dug up and catalogued. There is also a nice display of tiny, weird Hellenic sculptures that are fun to look at.

Understand the Civilization. From Egytp to Greek, Babel to Troy for understand the civilization and old world you must visitvia a lot of historical artifact espacially sarcophaus Alexander and sarcophaus crying women must see.

History Lesson. This is the place to go to learn about the history of their development from ancient times.The artifacts they have were unique and there was plenty of english translations to let you know what each was.You do not really need the audio translation although it was cheap.Please also note that the ladies toilets are of a traditional nature and not western standards(ie your squatting) which my wife found surprising

filled with ancient historic treasure. wonderful spaces filled with historic artifacts, and overviews of their history over millenia in this city which has encompassed so many empires. a trip to istanbul is not complete without this place as a guide to the history of the whole region

Interesting place. Interesting museum, gives you very good overview of history of civilizations that once thrived in what is now Turkey. We could not see all of the museum, as part of it currently closed for renovations.
The Best Museum in Istanbul. The tomb of Alexander The Great is worth the visit alone .... but there is so much to be explored in this museum. Quiet and jaw-dropping

AN UNCROWDED TREASURE. Housed in three buildings, this is a treasure trove of historical artifacts from numerous eras. The entrance fee of 10 Turkish liras is cheap considering the number of artifacts you will see inside. Plan to spend about three hours to appreciate the exhibits. To see and read all in-depth would require more time. This is the best archaeology museum I have visited. To gain a better understanding of Turkey, its history and culture, a visit to this place is a must.

Its a world class museum even if it needs renovation. This place should be the magical keyhole before you let yourself get lost in İstanbul and Anatolia.Its like a small resume of the whole human history with all its glory even the buildings and displays need a strong makeover if not a total renovation.London, Paris, New York museums have much more glamour with much less items than this museum.They obviously have tons of "stars" in museum from Trojan treasures to Alexander Sarcophagus. Yet they should be displayed the way they deserve. The museum itself looks like its stuck in early 70's and this rush the visitor to leave the building as soon as they see some articles. There is no surprise effect nor any adventure feeling of exploring novelties ....However as i said earlier this is where to start your own adventure to İstanbul and Anatolia.

Worth seeing. It's one of the best archaeological museum I have ever seen. You need at least 4-5 hours to see everything without being in hurry. The most interesting part for me is history of Constantinople / Istanbul. The entrance ticket is only 10 YTL.
Great journey into the rich history. The museum collection reflects the rich ancient history of the region. It is full of great art pieces!

Alexander The Great's Sarcophagus. Some terrific items to see here, Alexander's Sarcophagus (not his but actually for another middle eastern King and depicting Alexanders battles) is very well preserved and many other items of interest. Well worth the visit.

One of the best I have ever seen. Well laid out. Strictly archealogical so don't expect a more diverse sets of exhibits. The exhibits are in beautiful condition and it will take 3 hours for a good but not indepth review. Well worth a morning or afternoon but watch for hours of operation.

Worth seeing. This is really three museums in one. The first deals with the ancient Middle East (Sumeria, Egypt, etc) and has a limited but fine collection of material from these early civilizations. The main museum is partially open and is being renovated; it was opened in 1891. See the sarcophagi discovered in Sidon, including what is called "Alexander's tomb." It isn't, but it has a frieze on it showing Alexander fighting at the battle of Issus. The Turkish ceramics museum was built in 1471 and has some beautiful examples of Turkish ceramics. A couple of hours in these three should do it.

Troy Re-Discovered. Because Heinrich Schliemann's collection found itself in places like the British Museum, then Berlin, then Moscow, I was wondering if I would ever be able to see a significant display of the artifacts removed from this memorable site. Not only did the Museum in Istanbul feature hundreds of tools, images...they were arranged in order of the layers that were uncovered by the German archaeologists who continued the work, systematically, that HS left behind. From Alexander, Athena, to Augustus, just to start with the A Team, many sculptures and busts are displayed beautifully. We spent three hours there, but it was not enough, never made it to other sections that featured other cultures.This Museum complex, which includes three major buildings, is currently being enhanced by the city. It is in proximity to the fabulous Cisterns beneath the streets of Istanbul, that we were determined to see this time, not included in our tour two years ago. Anyone who sees Medusa's famous head upside down in these amber-lit CISTERNS with over 200 pillars erected into the ceiling, will never forget her.....utterly Bizarre !!We intend to return to Istanbul for the third time...it was briefly featured last night in the Amazing Race, the teams discovering very briefly the Spice Market and the Bazaar which are, like everything else in this unusual city, beyond description !!

4000 years of history in one building. We spent three hours here and had to be ushered out at closing time, there is so much to see! The layout is a bit confusing but the artefacts are quite spectacular. The entrance cost is about €5, there is a nice cafe in the grounds and plenty of cats wandering around in case archaeology isn't your thing! The signs are all in English as well as Turkish and the museum is easy to find, just next to Topaki Palace.

Interesting and quiet. Located next to the Topkapi Palace filled with tourists, I was surprised how quiet the museum was. It is split into three buildings and each has a good selection of artifacts. One was predominantly filled with graves with mummies etc, which my boyfriend found fascinating but was a little too morbid for my liking. An interesting and peaceful sight.
a museum that tell all about the history. the museum contains thousans of precious materials from each ancient civilisations. the 4th biggest archeologhy museum in the world.

Once seen never forgotten. Fantastic, well worth a visit, spent a good two hours around the Museum. Get there early to avoid the queues.
make sure your camera is fully loaded.

you may visit this impressive museum all day long. thanks to Mr. Osman Hamdi, the ottoman intellectual man who started many excavations within the borders of ottoman empire and reserved some (and some of them are in the main european museums now) of the precious historical values for our country and he managed this museum for a long period. I recommend to visit the first "the ancient orient museum" where you can see the civilizations from 5000-3000 BC- Hittites, the must see is the original cuneiform"The Kadesh treaty" and also Ishtar gate. Than you can pass the archeological museum and see the sarcophagus from Sidon (now in Lebanon).You'd better have an museum card, it will be economic if you visit 2 or more museums around.

Istanbul old city. the old city in istabul is nice and good to be seen specialy in March ; you will see the most beautifull gardens and the people are very welcoming ; and for the shopping it is the cheaper city at this moment

Make sure you have enough time!. We hadn't planned to visit this Museum but found ourselves there one afternoon when we had a couple of spare hours. While I am not really that interested in ancient history I did find this Museum offered a lot which 'wowed' me - pieces of the Ishtar Gate, amazing sarcophagi (some with some remnants of colour still preserved), beautiful statuary etc. The tile kiosk is also very interesting. In the end, we hadn't left ourselves enough time to explore the Museum fully so I would suggest allowing at least 3 hours to make sure you don't feel rushed.
So much to see. So much to see for only a few liras. If you have more days in Istanbul be sure you will not regret if you visit this place.

One of the great archeological museums of the world. This is one of these museums that can delight, inform, and wear you out! The building is huge and the collections seemingly endless. Go early in the day when you are full of energy and wear comfortable shoes and be ready to expand your knowledge of history!

From Hittites to Romans. Two museums, one describing the cultures of the Hittites and other peoples who were prominent in Asia Minor's early history, and a main museum full of well-laid out artifacts from 1000BC to late Roman times. Dim lights were necessary for some exhibits, I suppose, but tiresome.

Istanbul history explained. Istanbul's history can be a little hard to get your head around - Byzantines, Ottomans, Romans, Turks and all their buildings and monumenys all mixed up together. It's a bit of a rabbit warren in the main building but when you ghet to the section of Istanbul thru theAges - if you are interested in history - bring a packed lunch. (the kiosk in the grounds isn't recommended for food) There is a LOT of information, Turkish and English texts. A great display on Troy / Truva as well.

Too many things to look at.... There is so much to see in this museum.The Orient house was ok but if you've been to the British museum and seen the Egyptian section then it feels just like this part of the museum.The main building was interesting but by the 2nd floor I was beginning to tire as there was just too much to look at and I could n't take it all in which is a shame because I really wanted to.The tile house was nice and simple.

Quite dissapointing. Considering the rich, long history of Istanbul, through the Byzantine, Roman and Ottoman empires, the amount of exhibits on display was very, very limited and modest. There were a lot of pieces of ancient ruins and sculptures scattered on the ground outside the museum building though, left to rot in rain and the elements,as if they were some builders rubble. We expected to see a lot more and were quite dissapointed.

A quiet oasis in Istanbul. The Istanbul Archaeology Museum is located close to the Hagia Sofia (the Blue Mosque). Our guide suggested we visit it both to get away from the crowds and because it is a very interesting museum. The museum has an incredible collection and it is an oasis of quiet in an otherwise very busy area. Take some time to visit it. It is definitely worth a visit and you will enjoy it.

Very interesting altho hard to find. Lots of interesting stuff. Dont miss the the Tile Kiosk at the far end of the courtyard. My map made it hard to find but it is in the square at one side of the Blue Mosque.

Overwhelming. beautiful objects including some rarely seen pieces. this museum goes on and on and while I was quite impressed with the quality, the amount of art and objects to see defeated me in the end. I just couldn’t take in anymore.Serious museums goers would do well to research this before they go, Huge amounts of Roman, Greek, Macedonian, as well as Pergamon reliefs. Don’t miss the Alexander Sarcophagus

Heart of history. You are really in the hart of history, excellent master pieces of ancient times. Easy access to museum, very close to the historical areas such as blue mosque, Hagia Sofia and cisterns. You can spend hours and hours just passing thorough the excellent evidences of history. Sure if you like history!

AWE INSPIRING EXPERIENCE. The extensive collection offers Turkish, Hellenistic & Roman artifacts to name a few. Too many highlights to list here but a MUST SEE is the Alexander Sarcophagus and Lycian tomb. Artifacts from early civilizations including Anatolia, Mesopotamia, Arabia & Egypt offer an in depth time travel experience. Beautifully exhibited, not crowded, ( I was there at 9.00 am) & had 2 galleries to myself for the first hour. The entry fee of 10 TL, = A$ 5.40 is unbelievably cheap considering you have the opportunity to view over 1 million items. I was so impressed I revisited the museum a 2nd time in 3 days. Don't miss a truly wonderful opportunity to see some of the worlds treasures found nowhere else. ENJOY

Most amazing afternoon. You will not make a mistake if you like history and are interested in the story of this city. The part that explains the history of Istanbul is outstanding. Also, the tiled kiosk (as it is called) is fabulous. Sacorphagi exibition is also great, as well as is ancient orient exibition. You will not find big crowds there neither (I guess it is off the beaten track). Go there and enjoy!

Masses to see, but a bit of a mess during restoration. Lots of stuff to fascinate you here. There are some amazing sarcophagi from Sidon 4thC BC. Their condition is wonderful. I particularly loved the Mourning Women, not because of the remarkable women but for the dignified, solemn funeral procession above the women. The 2 men with their arms gently lying across the backs of their bare-backed horses I found very touching. The tile museum across the way was disappointing.

So much to see. You can spend a day here going through the Archaeology Museum and the two adjoining ones (1 ticket gets you into all 3 museums). The Alexander Sarcophagus is one of the highlights as is the Troy exhibition. You know a museum has too much stuff to show when there are statues in the bathrooms! The audio guide is well worthwhile. We had lunch in the on-site restaurant which was nice.
A Surprise. This wasn't on my list of places to go, but glad we did. Felt it was where I got a better sense of the history of the region.

You must go here. One of our best finds in Istanbul! 3 museums for the price of one and, being Turkey, a very reasonable entrance fee. Where do I start - a kiosk tiled with Izmik tiles, finds from Troy, sarcophaguses and many, many more things to see.

a necessary trip to get a sense of Istanbu's history.. Everything ! To see the findings from 130 years of archeology at Troy and really understand what went on in the area, is fabulous. BUT the museum is tatty and needs to be re-furbished. Get the upholstery changed !

Treasure trove. Clearly a museum for research and study but wonderful finds in every corner. I found the blue and green peacock room that might have inspired Whistler for the Freer room at the Smithsonian...one of my favorite rooms. Many groups of school children but very well behaved. Lovely small cafeteria in the garden with a great view.
OK but somewhat mundane. This museum is a nice place to visit if you haven't been to many archeological museums before, but if you have this doesn't really bring anything new to the table.
From the Ottomans to Mesopotamia...Crete...its all here. So many artifacts, so little time...from the Sarcophogus of Alexander, to the mosaics, the weapons exhibit, well worth the visit
Make sure you have time. Lots here, be sure to allot plenty of time to explore all the nooks and crannys. Be sure to see the 2nd floor above the Alexander tomb.

must do. with the museum pass we had the chance to visit this museum. it's beautiful but if you want to see it all you have to dedicate one half day to this mueseum. it's worth it.
they have a million rare pieaces to share with you.
very impressive

Amazing artifacts. Touring this museum was one of the highlights of our trip. There were so many old and well preserved artifacts to view. It wasnt busy on the morning we went so there was ample opportunity to get close to and really view the various displays. We almost passed up on going to the museum, but I am very glad that we took the time to visit.

Excellent Collection of Ancient Artifacts!. We went on a Friday evening, as the museum is purportedly open until 7pm (but they shooed us out at 6:40). This museum is an ancient civ teacher's dream, and I wish I could have toured it before I retired! Room after room after brought the tired old textbook alive! Highly recommended to aspiring archeologists, anthropologists and other ancient history buffs. Wish I had had more time!

A glimpse into life in the old days. I particularly liked the display of everyday life of the Sultan's family, depicted through clothing, personal articles and written descriptions.Also enjoyed the anthropological section showing vignettes of how people lived through the centuries.

Unexpected delight. This ws not on the top of our list to visit but we were glad we did. An impressive collection of ancient artifacts. We were also intrigues by the upper floors. These might be dull for the casually interested and you really needed to read the plaques to enjoy. I thought the artifacts from Troy would be my favorite, but the other parts of the museum trumped them. I think this is a little appreciated attraction in Istanbul.

Great Museum, but Bring Your Lunch. This is three museums in one complex, and all three are excellent and interesting enough to warrant several hours. One warning-the ticket does not allow you to leave and return, and the only place for food is an outdoor cafe with a beautiful setting and a very limited selection of really bad food, such as an arugula salad with no dressing and a cheese sandwich made from three slices of white bread. I recommend you try and take in some food, and find a nice outdoor place to sit and eat.

A wonderful collection. This is a huge museum and well worth spending at least 3-4 hours there. Situated close to other main attractions in Sultanahmet, the museum is easily reached on foot. There are so many items in the collection and some very special ones. It is a bit like visiting the Louvre in Paris; you can't examine everything in one visit. However, the guide gives you a list of 'Must See' items of the collection. For example there is a tablet of part of the first treaty - the Treaty of Kaddesh which I was particularly interested in seeing as I have read a lot on Egyptian history. The cafe is a little disappointing and it would be good if they upped the selection there to include a few light meals.

Interesting but not fantastic. I LOVE archaeology and anthropology. Love it. So I was looking forward to this museum. It was ok. There were interesting things to see and learn, but overall not the most interactive or appealing example in the area.

If you love antiquity, this is a must. It has the most beautiful collection of Hittite, Phonecian and Lycian tombs and sarcophagi. The gardens are magical and you can linger for hours. This is one of the best and least crowded places to visit in Istanbul.

A must. Although the layout was confusing (some reconstruction going on), the objects are fantastic. The audio guide was not worth it; just read the labels. A full visit will take most of a day. Every time period is represented. Be sure to see the serpent head from the Hippodrome, the Golden Horn chain, the Alexander sarcophagus, and the Persian palace tiles. The tile kiosk is so beautiful.

absolutely stunning. filled with absolute masterpiece of antique craftsmanship this museum will easily require 3 hours for a decent visit. layers and layers of artifacts by the succeeding civilization in the middle east are on display. not always in the most efficient museology approach but still, the quality of objects is immense. the sculpted marble tombs from lebanon are breath taking.

My favorite!!. I could have spent two days here easily, its like time travel! There are several building with things from ancient Rome, Egypt, Mesopotamia, Sumerian, ancient, classical, Muslim, Christian, pagan... so fascinating!
A peaceful oasis. Great museum, very peaceful, and so interesting. Great to visit for a rest from the crowds! They have a small section for children too.
Great pieces. Cool outdoor cafe. If you want to enjoy a little bit more history, go to the Archeology Museum. It has a really impressive amount of items discovered over the years.
Everything that you need to know!. The museum was a wonderful introduction to Turkey and it's history. I highly recommend going there before touring the city.

You need a day for this Museum. We were quite tired by the time we went to this Museum after visiting everything else, but this is well worth a visit, you are taken way back in time and if you love history this will be for you.

Amazing sacrophagi. The wonderful "Alexander" and other sacrophagi make it worth the price of admission. Some aged displays and facilities on the upper floors. The ground floor is where you need to take your time to see lots of the Sidon evacation treasures. Its a little out of the way, but worth the effort to see, if you have time to do so.
Archaeological museum. The archaeological museum in the center of the city, a very nice museum. There were many interesting sculptures. Very attracted our attention.
amazing place. Must visit, great place to visit, great pictures, ladies remenber to bring something to cover your head.

Do not miss. This is an attraction a lot of visitors miss out on and it is definitely worth the effort to walk down the hill. This museum has some of the best examples of egyptian antiquities and the Alexander sarcophagus is amazing.
An overlooked gem.... if you want see great examples of Turkish history, take the time to visit here..multiple buildings, so allow time to enjoy.

INCREDIBLE!!. i am in general a really fast museum person. i go in, i see stuff, i read some things, i take some pictures and i'm out... not this one. i was in this museum and engrossed for 3.5 hours! they have things in this museum like... some of the first written language, some incredible sarcophogus(es?), and things from 3000BC. so not only is there this building that looks like a floor of sarcophogi? (gus-es?) then you take the steps up and there are 3 more floors full of stuff! there's also another building across the way with some incredible tile work and a cafe full of old school stone work.

Mind Blowing. Consider the achievements of peoples living thousands of years ago and it's mind blowing. The place itself was an oasis of peace once the tour of loud youngsters had passed through on their whistle-stop tour.
Very interesting museum. Plan the visit to this museum well ahead as it's huge place. Don't miss the Alexander sarcophagus and Lycian section. Bring your own food with you as the cafe is horrible.

Alot To See. This museum is located right near Topkapi Palace. You can purchase your tickets online for the actual cost and save yourself some time.3 large buildings. Alot to take in and see. Alot of stairs too. Restrooms are at the back.Outside, there is a nice cafe which overlooks a pretty park to rest your feet after alot of walking and standing here.We were there about 3 hours. All good.

Excellent. If you have time do go to this group of 3 museums. The little tiled pavillion has some wonderful ceramics inside. The main museum is full of treasures including finds from Troy and an excellent explanation about the site. It took a whole morning to go round. OK cafe

a TOP 10 Must See in Istanbul. We stopped by here for what we were told was a short museum visit...WHAT'S TO SEEthere appeared to be 3 buildings to visit (1. main museum with Egyptian, Lebanese and Turkish artifacts, 2. a small building with a few ceramics/pottery, and 3. a building housing most prehistoric artifacts).TIMING Took my wife and i 1.5hrs to quickly walk through by ourselves. ADMISSION 10 TL per person POVrecommend skipping this attraction if you prefer touring the mosques around Istanbul as there are simply lots of tombs laid out (to put it bluntly). if you're a history buff who likes artifacts i'd rate this a 6-out-10 still... it's a fragmented collection of items gathered together.
So wonderful. The museum is really amazing, with a great collection. Take at least half day to visit the whole place.

Massive collection, possibly too big. The section on graves and epitaphs was excellent as well as the exhibits from Troy (which we had visited a few days earlier). The museum is huge however and even avid arch/history buffs would struggle to take all this in

Fascinating!. I've visited the Museum in Cairo, and was amazed to find so many mummies and sarcophogi outside of Egypt! The Archaeology Museum has an array of magnificently preserved pieces - the Alexander Sarcophagus is absolutely amazing, with carvings almost all intact still. When we were there the Museum was undergoing renovations so we couldn't visit the top floors,but we were fascinated by what we did see. There's only a 10 Lira entrance fee which is well worth it.

Melting Pot. Turkey is a gorgeous country. I love every bit of it. Id been to some countries, this country tops it 2nd to the US. I love the architecture & history. A must visit country for everyone if possible. Amazing, amazing, amazing...

Perfect interlude in busy day. Schedule this when you have some time to enjoy a terrific museum and it's cafe. Perfect after the crowds of Topkapi. So peaceful in courtyard cafe area amongst bits and pieces of columns and sculptures to savor with a nice cappucino or chai.
great collection. Impressive collection of Byzantine, Roman, Bronze era etc. Highly recommended, easy to overlook if you are tired and overloaded with sites, but try and make time.

I have always wanted to see these things.. When you are a kid studying world history you have dreams of exotic cultures and new lands. When you are an adult visiting a museum featuring these same wonders, you are ecstatic. Such was my experience at Istanbul Archeology Museum. While the Audio Guide might have supplements my visit, I chose to simply view the exhibits. They were well labeled. AND you could touch. Imagine touching a ceramic relief of a lion that has been demanding awe for 3,000 years. It still does. I had not known that the "Alexander Sarcophagus" was in this museum. That alone would have been worth the cost of admission.

Not to be missed. We almost missed this excellent museum. We were a bit limited in time but we could have spent an entire day there. If you are interested in ancient civilzations, the collection at this remarkable museum is not to be missed.

So interesting!. This museum are found just inside the first court of the Topkapi palace.The Museum displays artifacts from the Sumerian,Babylonian,Assyrian,Hatti and Hittite civilizations. Extremely interesting!
Very interesting. A very nice collection of very old turkish rugs and historical items. they aslo housesome very old relics...including pieces of hair!

Recommended in Istanbul.. I prefer this museum to Topcapi Palace because I could learn ancient history. I could see not only Turkish ancient things but also things related with ancient Egypt and Iran. I went to October, rainy season. It is good to stay long in the museum in rainy day. The museum is not included in sightseeing tour courses but I strongly recommend to see..

Worth seeing. It all starts with a large outdoor collection of scuplture among which some real Turkish vans live and wait for tourists' hugs ;-). The museum houses a huge collection of various artefacts from particular times and locations. Worth seeing and then go down to the neighboring park.
Ancient world. Really nice museum. Convenient to our hotel (Prince) and amazing antiquities including the worlds oldest peace treaty.

Slightly old fashioned. This museum reminds me of museums of my youth. There are a lot of items on display, and interpretation boards abound, but you need to invest time and examination into the process to get the most out of it. It doesn't present the information to you in a whizzy video clip or spoken interpretation. Audio guides are available, but I find them distracting - the information boards were fascinating in Turkish and English. The gallery with the history of Istanbul was very informative and taught me lots. I would also recommend you visit the Tile Museum in the kiosk in the courtyard.

So much stuff!. We went to the museum quite late in the day and were not able to see everything. We had no idea how vast the museum was and just how many wonderful things are inside! Give your self the best part of the day to do it and wear comfy shoes. Afterwards head a little further up the hill to Topkapi Palace. Also wonderful.
Simply the best!. Amazing artefacts - I particularly liked the sculpted marbles. If you are interested in history or archaeology you will not be disappointed by this"!
pure history. plenty to see very hisoric items from all over Turkey and surounding area400 years of history that you can touch

Hidden Gem! Worth every Lira. One of the best archaeological museums I have been in, great artifacts from the ancient Greek and Roman periods up through the Ottoman conquest. Highly recommended for a day or two of educational and aesthetic pleasure.

Fascinating. The Tiled Mosque, once the sultan's home, is outstanding in its tiles and ceramics. Choose your favorite Mideastern empire and epoch and the museum can offer something interesting. On the second floor are items from the cities of Troy. There is, however, not climate controls and it can be hot and airless.
free. the best reason to visit that museum: it is free and small. also good located; between Topkapi Palace and Sarayburnu Tea Garden :)

back to the past, a time journey. If you need to change your mood, your dimension, you have a unique chance for it. ıstanbul, city of magic. Istanbul archeological museum is a important part of this magic. You pass a time tunnel, and you can feel your self as a hero of ancient anatolian civilisation legends. You must go there, you must smell there, you must feel there. Returning to the past is the most emotional experience of your Istanbul time

Brought our kids, wasn't the best place for them. There's some neat stuff here, but we had a 3yo and unfortunately there's a lot of things on display with no cases. Basically there was a lot of "oh don't touch that" going on. Aside from that we rushed through a bit and found that while there's placards with information they don't do much in the way of storytelling which makes you feel more educated than having to bring an education to understand what you're seeing. Granted we were rushing a bit and distracted. I'd go back here again to spend more time. The tile museum portion is worth it for the building alone. That is a fantastic structure and they had some of the windows overlooking Gulhane park open. Spectacular views. That is a very neat little building.

I Will Go Back to Istanbul Just To Spend More Time Here. I've been to Istanbul a half dozen times and had never fit this wonderful facility into my plans. What a mistake.This museum complex is without a doubt one of the most outstanding museums I have ever seen. It is huge. Even a cursory visit will take a full day (museum hours are a short 1000-1630)The amount of material presented is vast. The museum is filled with artifacts, any one of which would be the centerpiece at a typical museum. The Alexander Sarcophagus. The Kadesh Tablet. The Chain from the Golden Horn. The Anatolian sculpture display. The list goes on and on and on.And items are displayed in such an intimate fashion. There are few ropes and stanchions. The visitor has immediate and intimate access to artifacts that the Smithsonian or Louvre would display behind layers of security.The buildings themselves are a bit long in the tooth and could use an update. There are few areas to sit in the display galleries. But there are very comfortable rest areas with bathrooms at the end of each gallery. There aren't many docents or tour guides available, but there is an audio tour guide available.Access to the museum is through Gulhane Park and isn't very obviously marked. The walk from the tram stop is a pretty good stretch of the leg. On the good news side, across the street from the tram stop is a pseudo-English pub, The North Shield. A cool Guinness tasted pretty good after walking the museum for a few hours.

Not just a great collection, but great curation. This was recommended to us by our AirBnB host, and he was absolutely correct to point us to the archaeology museum. Amazing antiquities AND clear explanation. We needed more time though so budget at least 2.5 hrs.. (which is something I never say about a museum!)..

Istanbul Archaeology Museum. This museum contains one of the most outstanding collections of archaeological finds in the Near East. The number and condition of the artifacts is surprising. They are well described and the audio guide is highly recommended.

One of the finest archaeological collections anywhere. Because much of the collection is from a single site at Iasos, the collection of funerary and memorial art and statuary is a comprehensive insight into several hundred years of evolving practice and covers all classes of society. Like a graveyard, there are stories in these stones. Allow at least half a day to get the most out of it, as the site also has a lovely tiled pavilion with a collection of Islamic ceramics, and another building with the famous Mesopatamian pieces. Wonderful place - and about a quarter of the visitor density of the British Museum, for example, so you can really get a good look at things.

Hidden gem: not quite a must-see, great for bad-weather day. 3 large exhibition halls. The main hall on the right (ground floor) has the best collection, especially the sarcophagi. The layout of the main hall is not intuitive - some of the best stuff is past a very winding path, easy to miss without a guidebook or detailed map. You can skip the top floor of the main halli if in a rush - there's not much there.The tile exhibit in the middle is only average. There are better samples of tile work in Topkapi Palace and various mosques. Skip it entirely if in a rush, or you can rush through it in about 5 minutes. The Oriental exhibit near the entrance is good, not great. Again, you can do an express tour of it in about 15 minutes if you had to.There's a free coat check, free clean W/C (squat-style toilets), a nice tree-lined outdoor cafe, and many nice park benches outside. I think the price was 15TL for everything.I wouldn't make this a priority for sightseeing, but well worth it on a longer tour of Istanbul or as a stop for bad weather. Right in Gulhane Park, the location is very convenient. One tip: the signs to the venue are sometimes hidden behind the huge tour buses parked by the arch way. Walk to your extreme right as you enter the park via the 3 arches, or you might miss it like I did and walk the entire park! Better still, ask a guard when you pass the arch. (Muzesi nerede? = Where's the museum?)

So much to see!. Make sure you get an audio guide if you have children, it kept my 9 year old interested throughout. Some amazing pieces of sculpture and other artefacts. Could do with a bit of updating, but this doesn't detract.

Past and present are together here.. For me, it's a fantastic place. I love being in history. I like feeling the past with all that artifacts I touch and learn different civilisations, cultures such as, Byzantine, Anatolia, pre-Islamic Arabian art, Mesopotamia and many more.

Excellent. The museum wasn't high on our list of places to visit, but our boys (6 & 8yrs) wanted to go b/c of the Children's museum on site. We learned after entering that the Children's museum closed, however, we spent approximately 2hrs touring the Archaeology museum and it was well worth seeing the collection.

Three museums in one location. The Istanbul Archaelogy Museum houses circe one million exhibits representing varous civilisations of world history. Its location previously formed part of the outer gardens of the Topkapi Palace and is considered as the first museum to house Turkish Art.

The meeting of civilizations.... Unfortunately not a well known destination , the archeological museum is generally neglected after a visit to the Topkapi Palace. I think that even if you visit the Palace, reserve some of your time to this nearby museum. Located right back in the garden of the Topkapi Palace, in ancient Palace buildings, this is the first museum open under the Ottoman regime. Herited to nowadays, it makes its visitors witness the richness and the diverse history lying on Turkey's grounds. You can also be attracted to see the first love letter written in history on display with its translation.

Impressive collection. We managed only a short visit to this museum on our last afternoon in Istanbul, and wish we had scheduled more time so we could have explored beyond the ground floor. We were impressed by the sarcophagi unearthed at Sidon, but were touched by the nearby display gravestones or stelae on which the inscriptions showed how little human emotions have changed across the millenia...."here lies my wife, who was my heart's content."It is worth buying the museum card if you plan to visit all the museums included, since you will skip the queues at Ayasophia and Topkapi Palace. You have to visit all within 72 hours.

Phenomenal. You will not regret going here. Every corner of every building is crammed with archeological gems. The statues and sarcophagi are awesome sights. Just put on the audio guide and walk through the whole thing.
Don't miss this Museum. Every one is rushing up the hill to Topkaki Palace, which is fine, because it keeps this hidden gem of a museum less crowded. The mummies and the sarcophaguses are amazing.

Great history, not so great design. With the history of Istanbul, you'd think the archaeology museum would be stunning and expansive. While I enjoyed the exhibits, the museum is in need of some serious restructuring. The building is old and the historical descriptions between one section and another could be better. You'll have to look for them as they are not easy to find. Skip the audio guide rental, there aren't that many audio stops and the ones they have aren't that informative

Interesting museum about history of Turkey. The museum is divided into three parts (two are history of the region and one is about ceramics). The entrance ticket gives you access to all of the tree areas. Ceramics is pretty uninteresting but the other two are nice to see.

A good place to while away some time. We enjoyed the range of artifacts at the museum. It was a whirlwind visit as our daughter takes things in very quickly. Unfortunately, at least one building was closed during our visit. Lovely setting.

Interesting museum. On a rare rainy morning in Istanbul, we walked around the Archaelogy museum. I concentrated on the pre-history section on the second floor, and the tiled kiosk, while my friend did a quick sweep of the entire museum. Mostly well labeled and interesting exhibits spanning the city and its various eras.

.. interesting, but too dark and repetitive. As a turkish student, it was great to get free entry but i would question if it is worth the lira to enter when there is so many more unique things in istanbul. the surrounding gardens are nice, with neglected artifacts throughout.

Must see. I have a feeling many visitors overlook this because it was not as busy as I would have thought. But it was filled to the brim with great exhibits. My only disappointment with the section upstairs with the history of troy. The whole area looked tired and displays wwere poor. It was also stifling. However another building was being renovated and I have a feeling the exhibits may be moved there once it is finished. So don't be put off. Give yourself a few hours. It really was worth the visit. Youll see things there beyond just turkey.

Wonderful Museum for different periods of history. Frankly that was my first time to visit a museum whivh needed to me a long time to do all the museums inside. It includes of several museums related to several periods specialy bizance. There are a lot of old sculptures very very amazing related to the periods! I recomend to alocate enough time to visit there, It is great. There is also a building for the islamic period started in ottoman which is a must to visit, that is at the entrance door to the museum. Here you can also have camera to take photos.

Trip to ancient times!. I love history and for me this museum was a very joyful trip to ancient times and Middle Ages! with a very moderate ticket price for a very rich historical collection, this place definitely deserves a visit!!

Impressive collection, needs a renovation. The sarcophagi collections are impressive - potentially the best outside of Egypt. Any museum that attempts to cover from the 65,000 B.C.E. to the 19th century is in for a challenge. The archaeology museum has several artifacts that could take days to review, but definitely worth checking out for a couple hours. That being said, the facility is in need of a renovation with some rooms clearly not touched since 1981 when the last addition was put on the site.

don't miss. the objects that are displayed in this museum are extraordinary and so numerous. It is one of the best archeological museums in the world, maybe the best. If you have sometime in İstanbul, forget the other places but do not miss this change to visit this museum and see the very very ancient times of humanity, and see magical objects of Anatolia.

archeology museum. the objects on display are so extraordinary and so numerous that it boggles the mind that one museum can hold so much. I visited in August and the rooms were quite warm but that only added to the dream like state that these fabulous objects put me into. The cafe is a good place to refresh for another floor to explore.

Ancient history. If you like ancient history, you'll be awed by this museum. It holds the oldest peace treaty known to mankind. That was my reason for going to this museum. But I was provided bonuses by seeing sarcophagi of hte ancients, egyptian artifacts and ancient tile-work. Well worth the price of admission.

Unmisable. I had great expectations about this museum, but they were largely surpassed by this huge and marvelous collection of sculptures, tombs, coins, artifacts and so on. Entrance is near of Topkapi one, and Park Gülhane, and cost 10 TL (a bargain, less than 5 euros), few visitants, perfect place to visit. Some parts of museum should be refurbished (change floors, some paint on wall, review air-conditioning, etc), but the collection is astounding… So many things you have seen on school books are there, historical and social information, really good.You can spend several hours there, and will be not enough… When I come back to Istanbul, this will be the first place to visit again.
Amazing. The thousands of artefacts seem untouched and the exhibits are nicely organised. You can slip in once you have finished Topkapi Palace. It is really worth a look.

Overwhelming. This is the only site in the entirety of Istanbul that overwhelmed me. There is just so much content, so many pieces from different time period. It was just so much.It was badly displayed, but that is because there is so much to display they couldn't really do anything else and I'm not going to fault the location for having to much of a good thing.

My Favorite Museum in Istanbul. A series of buildings with fabulous collections, you will need more than a day to explore all of them. Some of my favorites, included the pottery collection and the sarcophagi collection.
sculptures were very interesting.. Place could love those interested in Byzantine history. We very much liked, was very nice. We visited the inside of close to 2 hours.

Very informative, good place to go. A welcome relief after the crowds of Topkapi Palace, this is just next door but much quieter. Some of the artefacts here are stunning in size and decoration. I've read a couple of reviews that suggest you can find the sarcophagus of Alexander the Great here and you can't so don't be disappointed. There is a beautiful sarcophagus of another king that is decorated with images of Alexander and has come to be associated with his name, its a breathtaking piece of sculpture and worth marvelling at in it's own right.As with other museum, avoid the cafe if you want food (12 lira for a dry beef sandwich in a plastic packet), it's a great place to sit and have a drink but the food options are limited and poor. Head outside when you are finished for a much better experience.

Most interesting place. I was surprised to see how few people there were here when I went in the afternoon, just a handful. I enjoyed the ancient section and the antiquity section the most, both were excellent and must sees for anyone fascinated by early history of civilization. Some of the artifacts they've got here are mind blowing.

concise, clean and good presentation.. Don't miss Treaty of Kadesh! Be prepared for several hours visit even if you're in just for museum overview. Worth every minute. Also, great local restaurants nearby.
I didn't expect such a wonderful collection. I loved it! To stand in front of Aalexander the Great sarcophagus made my day! Don't miss it, most of the work in the collection is fantastic!!!

Don't miss this museum!. There is enough here to occupy an entire day, from early Hittite artifacts to early Greek tombs and sculptures, Roman artworks, Byzantine artifacts and more. The adjoining Museum of Ancient Orient (same admission) is especially noteworthy, with actual portions of the walls of Babylon, Egyptian, Assirian and Hittite sculptures, and even a piece of the Code of Hammurabi!

World Famous Museum. This is one of the best museums in the world. I have visited it several times, and each time am in awe at the variety of special artifacts there. If you love Turkish history, you will want to spend many hours here !
What a span of history!. This museum helped us appreciate the long history of Istanbul and the region. Some artifacts date back to over 6,000 years ago! Awe inspiring!
Vast. The museum houses a vast amount of history. With it's collection you can see how Turkey throughout time has been a place of great power and history.

Everyone will find something for yourself. Lovers of history and archeology will be able to walk a few hours and enjoy the artifacts. Be sure to look Sidamara sarcophagi and sarcophagus of Alexander. The museum offers a wealth of objects from various periods of Troy.

Seemed a little poorly maintained. I visited the Museum on a hot and humid day. The Airconditioning just was so poor that I am sure even the statues were sweating due to the humidity. As you got to the upper floors it got worse, honestly I am not sure how some of the paintings may survive in such poor conditions in the future. Whats worse some areas like the restroom as so dirty that they are worse than some public restrooms in a third world country. To make matters worse they had no A/c.
very interesting. Very rich variety and big collectio but the best for me is the department with sarcophagues and exhibits of istar gate of Babylon

Ancient wonders. Need more than one day to really absorb whats on offer here. Endless Sarcophagi of Byzantine Emperors. Ancient Egyptian, Sumerian, Babylonian,Hittite,Urartian and Assyrian cultures. Roman and Greek sculptures also to be seen the head of Alexander the Great and his Sarcophagus and so on and so on This is truly one of the best Museums I have come across.
Istanbul Arkeology Museum. I have visited many museums out of Tuekey, but I have never seen such an interesting museum. It is in the Gülhane Park, very close to Sultanahmet.

Interesting but.... Very interesting but there is a problem of air conditioning inside the museum. At the end of the visit, you don't feel good. The upstairs are too hot and it's very difficult to breathe !!!

So much to see!. The museum lies close to the Topkapi palace and, unlike the palace, has relatively few visitors. This makes it a good place to spend an hour or two if you need peace and quiet. There is far too much to see even in a full day, so be selective. We enjoyed the examples of some of the earliest writing known; astonishing sculptures; the history of Istanbul and Troy.
Staggering. The quality of many of the exhibits in this museum are staggering. It is worth taking time to explore them carefully.

hidden gem in istanbul. between sultan ahmet district, hagia sophia, and topkapi, this museum is just a hidden gem. what I regret most in my trip to istanbul is that i dedicated only one day visiting this museum; it's so huge, you can't just spend one day there. actually it's a combination of about 8 museums (if i remember correctly). and each one is more amazing than the others. there's one for ottoman art, one for turkish history, seljuk era, roman era up to Hamdi Bey and Ataturk. Also the section dedicated to statues is breathtaking!!just give it a visist, you won't regret it

Go See. I went towards the end of the day not really knowing what to expect. I didn't think it would be that big, but it's quite large! There are some important and interesting things to see. It's only 10 TL and though I was super tired and only saw some of the museum, I'm glad I went.

Huge collection. This museum definitely deserves a visit while in Istanbul. Better to read about its founder, Osman Hamdi Bey before the visit. A remarkable man indeed! The museum itself contains many treasures, however not all optimally displayed. The upper floor is in bad need of refurbishing. In the middle of summer, the AC wasn't working properly and it was uncomfortably hot inside. The audio-guide is very useful, and I guess, a proper guide would also be very helpful. The buildings themselves are also delightful. The main building was built after the excavations in Sidon in 1887 and the architect was alledgedly inspired by the Sarcophagus of Crying Women. Go and see for yourselves.

Better than Rome??. A vast and wonderful collection from Ancient Egypt to the Romans etc. Only had 2 hours but could have easily spent half a day. Located within easy walking distance in the old city from other main attractions. Really worthwhile

Fine museum. For a small extra fee, we got the digital audio guide which was quite helpful in providing the context for this extensive collection. A few highlights: the ancient sarcophagi were amazing, dating back many centuries and yet many were in pristine condition. The mosaic building had many stunning examples of that work.
Better to take a guide. These buildings are vast, and we were fortunate to go with a guide who explained some of the artifacts.
Must-see. This museum has a LOT of ancient artifacts, well-organized and in great shape. The items cover a huge time span, starting around 2700 B.C.

Best kept. The museum doesn't attract as much as the other sires but in my opinion it is one of the best kept museums with well arranged exhibits taking you through the ages of Islamic and pre-Islamic history.
one of the world's best. Amazing museum, actually a whole complex of museums, ranging from ancient to modern times. The sarcophagi are world treausres. One of the world's best museums. Don't miss it!

Excellent value. It was quite hot on the day we visited, so we were quite satisfied with people watching from the shaded benches that fill the lovely park outside the museum. We were not disappointed, however, when we ventured inside the museum where its displays were quite remarkable. There were too many rooms to explore in one afternoon, but ancient artifacts from Egypt, Babylon, etc. that were in pristine condition could be examined at very close distances. Among so much, our favorite was a king's sarcophagus, contemporary with Alexander the Great, that depicted Alexander's battles. Beautiful.

Fascinating collection marred by poor direction guidance and not even electric fans to make the place bearable.. The museum is in the grounds of Topkapi but accessed from a road leading from the gates to Gulhane Park. It is a 19th century neoclassical building with extension and some ongoing restoration. Also in the grounds are the Museum of the Ancient Orient with some interesting stone carvings from Mesopotamia and periods like the Hittites. There is also the charming Tiled Kiosk or pavilion which houses exhibits of wonderful Turkish pottery as well as the tiled walls and rooms that give the building it's name. The main museum of archeology houses rooms full of stunning finds from the necropolis at Sidon. The sarcophagi and mausoleum are immense, beautifully carved and remarkably well preserved. Elsewhere there are several exhibits on the various periods of Troy and it's excavations which seem to have been both good and less professional. The video presentation on Troy is excellent and informative. The main issue for us on a July day was the heat. There's no aircon and not even a fan. Also, direction signage is almost non-existent though most of the exhibits have adequate labels in Turkish and English. There is, as at many sites in Istanbul, an audio guide we did not use. I doubt if it would have guided us in and around and out again better than we managed and the labels were quite adequate. I am glad we went; I would not have wanted to miss it; but I do wish they'd consider better direction signage, more chairs/benches inside (there's plenty outside) and some fans. And it is cheap at 10TL.
Overwhelming - allow time. Lots and lots to see but after touring the palace we had run out of energy, so pace yourself.

So much to see!. Excellent museum, brilliant collection! Beware that there is so much to see, so many artifacts and sections and buildings, that you really need the whole day just to get through everything.

Cool. It's a pretty cool museum. It gets hot in there in July because of the humidity. I can see where it might be one of the best archaeological museums in the world. It's not so much my cup of tea. The one thing I thought was super cool was the skeleton of a Sultan (I think) in a glass box, including the guts and all. It's right there by the Palace, so you might as well go by and give it a shot.

Archaeology. What an interesting museum - the only downside was that the cafe was shut which meant we had to leave when hungry and thirsty rather than when we had seen everything - there is a lot to see, even though some galleries were closed for earthquake strengthening - well worth a visit
