Sarcophagus heaven. Do not miss the Alexander sarchopagus. Very intricate and beautiful. I've never seen such a vast collection of sarcophaguses like in this museum. Worth the vist.

Where things almost ended up at the British Museum. Osman Hamdi Bey, the founder, threatened to kill himself when the Ottoman officials wanted to sell archaelogical finds off to the British. So we all owe him a visit to this incredible museum he helped found and preserve.

What a place!. Phewwwwwwwww, awesome!!! I suggest you spend at least half day @ one day here coz its too much to see + too much to absorb!this place is also less crowded than the other museums, but a place not to be missed!

Incredible collection of Artifacts big and small. After spending a day at the major sites, we hit the Archaeological museum the next day, and are so glad we did. Their collection includes old, old, old amazing examples of writing and city life, and lots of large pieces up to the Romans and beyond. It also has a neat little gift shop where I picked up gifts to bring home.
rare find. great museum and easy to manage. the exhibits and treasures are great. a true gem to see
A MUST see. Just a GREAT collection of items that are well preserved not bits and pieces of old ruins.

Don't miss it.. This museum is actually a group of three museums in one ... the Archaeological Museum (which is packed with mostly Greek and Roman era discoveries), the Museum of the Ancient Orient (which contains similar ancient material from other Oriental cultures), and the Museum of Islamic Art (especially tiles, pottery and glassware) -- so you get a lot for your 10TL entry fee.The museum is located just downhill from Topkapi (the site was originally Topkapi's outer gardens and they're joined by a path) in the Sultanahmet - Eminonu district of Istanbul. It's easy to find, and easy to explore.I found the Museum of Oriental Art most fascinating. The exhibits come from all across the Middle East and are all well labelled and described ... from cult statues to codes of law to ceramic tiles featuring lions and mythological beasts - there's a lot to capture your mind here. It has, for instance, the Kadesh Peace Treaty -- said to be the oldest peace treaty in the world. I liked the Islamic Art too. The Archaeological Museum is vast and fascinating, and almost too big to take in during one visit. It contains monumental works like the Alexander Sarcophagus, said to have been made for Alex The Great. When you're tired of looking at all the treasures innside, there's a decent cafe in the grounds outside, set in a unique sculpture park containing dozens of stone objects ranging from memorials to altars to marble palm trees, to sarcophagi of Byzantine emperors. These came from excavations all over Turkey.

Istanbul Archaeology Museum. There is so much to see at the archaeology museum that you are in danger of overloading on history. It is brilliant value for your entrance fee, and you should allow a few hours to go around it.

Dazzling. Incredible collection, a bit too much to see in one session (unless you spend a day). Loved the first building on the left with very early pieces of text (incl. the oldest surviving peace treaty). Also, overkill of tombs, although some very beautiful ones.
Rare gem. In a city that plowed over Constantinople, the fact that such great ruins weren't trashed is very unique.

Give yourself some time here.. Wish we'd had more time here. It's full of one-of-a-kind original works of art and technology. If you're interested in Turkey's ancient history you won't want to miss this. And Alexander's Tomb is so intricate and skillfully made it's just spellbinding. Upstairs theres cuniform writing and early tools and a 10,000-year-old bronz cooking pot. We loved this place!
so much to see. make sure you have good comfortable walking shoes - so much to see. really fascinating place.
So much to see!. There are over a million individual pieces to see and it is a lot to see. Need more than one trip to take in everything, but well worth the time.

Ancient treasures. A huge collection of ancient treasures, well displayed.I particularly liked the glazed frieze from the gates of Babylon and the Alexander Sarcophagus.Dislikes - nil (if you like history museums!)
Fantastic. Amazing if you have any interest in ancient history - all lables in English so made it all even more interesting for us

One of the best museums in the world. The Alexander sarcophogi collection is remarkable, I've never seen anything so well preserved. This museum is not huge so it is manageable and what they have is outstanding. A must if you are into archeology.
Peaceful. The way the exhibits are displayed are easy on the eye and very interesting. The Museum is a lovely peaceful building.
Worth a visit. Great history on ancient and medieval times, with artifacts and statues dating back to 12 century b.c. A must visit for any history enthusiasts.

The tiles were my favorite. This museum has a very impressive collection of sarcophagi, sculptures, and objects from thousands of years of Turkish history, but my favorite area was the building that houses the beautiful tile work that Turkey is famous for.
Great Museum!. There is a lot to see, and you could easily spend days. Definitely check out all the Greek/Roman sarcophagi, and don't miss the Treaty of Kadesh.
huge and impressive. the collection is outstanding... it will take hours to see the entire thing. the display for dig finds from the bosphorus tunnel project was my favorite bit
The cradle of humanity. Don't miss, you'll see the first artifacts humans created when trying to communicate with each other, no it wasn't an iPhone, or iPad...

World-class Museum. This is a wonderful museum, much, much better than the Anatolian Museum in Ankara. They have on display one of only 3 copies in the world of the Treaty of Kadesh (first peace treaty in the world); the Alexander coffin is terrific. They have an entire floor devoted to Troy.

Take a day for this one!. Stupidly we only 'budgeted' a morning for this museum, but it has such a lot on offer that one either needs more time or have to be more selective about what one wants to see. So be aware. Do your research and decide on which parts you want to focus. The museum is thematically organised, as opposed to chronologically. So maybe decide on a theme and start from there. I would say the Old Building is the MUST see with its the Alexander Sarcophagus the highlight. As always the audio guide was of great help. NOTE: during our visit the right wing of the old building was closed for renovation. And for some reason all the museum cafes were closed ... so there was nowhere to chill.
Very nice!. Very interesting but could be missed if you are short of time.
wonderful. One of the gorgeous museums in Istanbul. Definitely should be seen.

The Best Kept Secret in Istanbul. This is probably one of the most remarkable museums we have ever seen. It does not get much hype, like AyaSophia or Topkapi palace. However the exhibits within this VAST facility are breathtaking in terms of variety and scale. It has antiquities from Tuekey, Syria, Palestine, and Lebanon that span many civilizations. One of the most interesting items is the actual Treaty of Kadesh, the first known peace treaty between Pharoanic Egypt and the Hittite Empire. The complex consists of a few buildings, and it took us two full visits to cover the entire space. The presentation is extremely well done and inviting. Highly recommended.

Interesting pieces but can be organized better. The Istanbul Archeology Meuseum is located next to Gulhane park. The rail station just before the Blue Mosque. The items in display in the Archeoloogical Museum are very interesting from different digs around Turkey proper and as well as from different parts of the Ottoman empire (including some artififacts from Mesopotamia). The organization of the different departments of the museum was abit confusing to me. I liked the Museum in Ankara more interms of friendliness and descriptions.

Impressing !. This Museum is really one of the spots that you need to visit in Istanbul, there are unique arts & sculptures with some of them belong to thousand years ago. the cafe outside the museum is a relaxing place to take a tea!

some great things. I recommend the exhibits in the first building on the left, the mosaic building, and the first floor of the main building. These exhibits are very nicely done. We continued upstairs to the other exhibits but although there are many artifacts, they are not organized well. The rooms are dark and not air-conditioned. I'd recommend skipping these.
Worth a look. We missed this on our first visit and so pleased that we managed to spend the time this visit. Great - the old pottery and china is amazing
Very interesting. I really enjoyed visiting this museum. Numerous interesting artifacts and not very croweded. Make sure you have enough time as there really is a lot to see! Recommended!

HISTORICAL OASIS. After battling tourist masses at all the historic sites around Sutnahmet this museum was a highlight. Many wonderful artifacts are displayed in cool rooms with space enough to stand back and gaze in awe: Mummies, sarcophagi, friezes, Mesopotamian and Sumerian artifacts, the Treaty of Kadesh, and much more.

The best archeological museum in Turkey. Tourists seem to skip archeological museums. We don't, but were even more delighted to find this museum much less crowded than nearby Topkapi. There is an enormous amount to see. We took two visits, but one could certainly just hit the highlights. And what highlights there are! The Ishtar gate and Hittite carvings are must sees, as are the Cybele figrues. The cunieform writing and envelopes are exactly what you learned about in elementary school. The Tomb of Alexander the Great is breathtaking (he's in the carvings on the tomb, not in the tomb), and the Greek statues -- Sappho and Minerva being my personal favourites -- are as good, if not better, than anything you will see in Greece. There are also the contents of the tomb from Gordion, a Roman column burial, and Egyptian artiefacts. Whether you want to be educated or just admire the beautiful and the exotic, the is the perfeect place to spend a morning or afternoon. They even have the chain that crossed the Bosporus!
Iskender sarcophage. i liked to see Alexander the Great´s sarcophage, the building is a bit old, but it is a good plan for one or two hours

A broad overview, well done. We did not go on our latest visit but I still remember our visit in 2001. Great space, well designed that really lays out the span of the culture. Maybe not a top 5 visit, but if you have more than 2 days it's a must see.
One of the great museums of the world. Its collections of sarcophagi and of the dig in Troy are just excellent. Don't miss the Treaty of Kadesh in the Anatolia building.

Give it a pass. What a disappointment! This museum is listed as a "top 10" attraction in Istanbul by the guidebooks. No way! This is a very run-of-the-mill collection of antiquities which are poorly displayed and described. The only exception is the sarcophagi collection to the left as one enters. The "Alexander" sarcophagus is stupendous. The archaeology museum in Antalya by contrast is absolutely world class.

Having tea with the residents of the museum. The museum hag a great garden with beautiful arheological objets , sculptures and so on.. It is not as crowded as the other museums of the historical town , Sultanahmet and when one wants to go to a quiet place and see great ancient art.. it is a must..

One of the best in its motherland!. You can understand the whole history of Anatolia starting from Hittite period going on to the Ottoman period...One full day may not be enough if you are a fa of that field:)
A land with great civillation, known to be. Mesopotamia, Egyptian, Roman.'s great craftsmanship can be seen in this museum. A must go too. Plus the entrance fee is cheaper. 10TL.

Just Fabulous. This is an undeservedly overlooked sight in Istanbul. All the tourist go to Hajia Sophia and the Blue Mosque, and this place is largely ignored. It shouldn't be. Even my husband, who is not much of a museum goer, was enchanted with this museum.The famous Sarcophagus of Alexander is here; there are tiles from the Gates of Ishtar; and many lovely sculptures from the ancient areas all over the Levant.I have been in Istanbul nearly every year for the past 8 years, and I always try to get to this museum. I especially enjoy the quiet of the courtyard, sitting and drinking water, looking at the lovely stone carvings on display outside, and watching families enjoying the park outside the museum. It is a place of tranquility and beauty in a city that bustles.
Must See. If you want to know what Alexander or Marcus Aurelius looked like pay a visit to this Museum

Puts it all together..... The museum was virtually empty when we went so I had plenty of time to explore. Although the exhibits are labelled I would have liked a bit more information on some of the items which weren't obvious. It helped to piece together the history and made me realise how many items had been stolen from other countries! The sarcophagus were plenty and they weren't hidden away behind glass and ropes. It really is worth the trip even if you aren't a regular museum visitor.

went back for a second time. so much history and an unbelievable price of 10 TL. A great place to spend a few hours looking at artifacts that are thousands of years old and then peaceful and quiet places outdoors to sit and take it all in.

Fascinating museum and an oasis of calm. We visited the museum at the beginning of June and was a great place to spend a couple of hours away from the crowds at the Blue Mosque and Aya Sophia during the heat of the middle of the day. Great collection of sarcophagi and history of the development of language in the ancient world. Stand out items for me the sarcophagi from the necropolis at Sidon and the tiled pavillion and the treaty of Kadesh.

Another Must See in Istanbul. A beautiful museum with fantastic and huge carpets on display. Some of the carpets are a bit moth eaten and worn but you get the idea. Stop in the coffee exhibit and shop for a taste of good Turkish Coffee with some lokum on the side in a beautifully designed space.

Great museum. I mean "great" literally. We were particularly fascinated by the remains of the Hittites, a people we had long heard about without really knowing much about them. Now we do!There are also some gorgeously carved sarcophagi in the other building. Definitely one of Istanbul's most interesting museums.

A good place fo take in some details.. This was my next to last museum among 20 throughout Turkish coast, Athens and Corinth, and it was my favorite. Small enough to see a lot in 90 minutes. Easy to get though. Just enough details to get an appreciation for art, culture and life.
Lots to see for history fans. Relics from Hitites to Roman-Greco era .... endless to see. Rich collection.
Terrific with Topkapi. Located on the grounds of Topkapi, this is a great museum. The tile pavilion is particularly impressive. Far less crowded than Topkapi or the other top attractions as well.
you need at least half day !!!. we just get tickets on entrance but time was 3:00 p.m. and closed at 5:00 p.m. so huge and attractive museum with all historical pieces and its atmosphere !!!

Definitely don't miss it. One of the gorgeous museums in Istanbul. Definitely should be seen. Discover many civilisations together. Collections, exhibitions,statues, artworks are so beatiful. There are three museums together. Tiled Kiosk, Archaeology and Ancient Orient museum.
Great collections. Who knew--the collections go on and on-fascinating!

Excellent. I was wowed by this very accessible collection of ancient objects...to note the sophistication of objects that dated thousands of years before, say, the european rennaissance, makes one wonder how such culturally sophisticated and advanced art could have been lost for so long.

An understated museum, but many treasures for patient students of history. Oner Ayan.. This is one of those museums left alone under the shadows of the majestic Topkapi Palace; however, don't be discouraged, give it at least 1-2 hours and stroll around, preferably with a knowledgeable guide; you won't regret. Oner Ayan

One of the best in the world. On no account should this museum be missed - it is one of the very best of its kind in the whole world! It comprises three different buildings, the first, as you enter, is a museum of the ancient Orient. The exhibits are not numerous but they are of outstanding quality. Different cultures are represented: Anatolican, Egyptian and Mesopotamian, including striking basalt lions from the 8th century BC Hittite period. The main building houses a collection that is just staggering in its beauty and extent. The objects are too numerous to mention, but look out in particular for the Hellenistic and Roman sculptures and most especially for the objects from the Royal Necropolis of Sidon. Here you can see wonderful sarcophogi of the like nowhere else in the world. The marble Alexander sarcophogus from 325 BC is one of the great treasures of archaeology, the equal of anything in the British Museum. It is massive but the carvings are exquisite in their detail and expressiveness: it will long linger in your memory. A third building is originally from 1472 and houses a fine collection of ceramics, in particular those from Iznik, which are one of Turkey's great artistic delights (for which you should visit Rustem Pasha mosque). Altogether, the whole museum is a gem: in spite of the large number of objects, the displays are spacious and well laid out so you do not feel overwhelmed. But be prepared to go back for another visit since there is really too much for one day. If you want a permament memento (photography without flash is permitted) buy the excellent book on the museum by Dr Pasinli, a former director, which has superb illustrations and a most informative text.

very underrated. It is located on the historic penunsula so easy to pass on when you are in istanbul for a short trip but if you have a free day after sultanahmet / topkapi areas give this place a shot. Great historical facts. Troy, Byzantine and Ottomans and also Anatolian civilizations. It is very informative and interesting.

Never Open. We had neen told the Archaeology Museum was a must see. When we first went there it was closed for 5 days for renovation. Fair enough we would see it when we returned to Istanbul in 3 weeks. We went there again upon our return to find it is closed on Mondays. So we never got to see it and were very disappointed. Next time...and I'm sure we will give it a great review then.
Don't miss if you love history. a museum with an amazing collection. Must be one of the great museums of the world...

A group of three archeological museums. Great collection of Islaminc and orient and Roman artifacts. The Istanbul Archaeology Museums consists of three museums: Archaeological Museum, Museum of the Ancient Orient, Museum of Islamic Art.

Yay for Osman Hamdi Bey!. This was our favourite museum that we visited on our recent trip (family of four). Our children enjoyed it (nearly!) as much as we did, although we couldn't find the life-size Trojan horse that we had read about in a guide book.There was extensive renovation going on (May 2012) it looks like it has been happening for a while and I'm unsure when it will be finished. Despite this, there were some fantastic things to see - the tiled kiosk is absolutely stunning. And Osman Hamdi Bey really put together a pretty mind-blowing and awesome collection. A must see - even more so than the Topkapi Palace in my opinion.

Amazing wonders of the anicent world. The Istanbul Archaeology Museum is well worth the visit! It is filled with amazing wonders of the anicent world. Don't miss any of the buildings and the outside courtyard, each area has amazing treasures tucked inside. The hall of Roman statues with more than two dozen, larger than life gods and goddesses was breathtaking. If you are into reading every plaque and listening to every audio tour comment, I suggest you plan for at least a three hour visit.The audio tour is well worth the price. However, the way the collection and the map in the floor plan are a bit difficult to follow. Also, the numbering for the audio tour doesn't follow the sequence of the floor plan, so it can be somewhat confusing at times. The Archaeology Museum is very much an adult museum. Few, if any exhibits are "kid friendly," most all have plaques with lots to read. If you have young children with you, I'd suggest you save your money and skip this museum.Tip: Visit the Archaeology Museum in the afternoon after your morning visit to the Topkapi Palace (adjacent to the Archaeology Museum and with a separate entrance fee.) This way you will avoid the afternoon cruise ship crowds at the Topkapi Palace (cruise ship groups start arriving at mid-day.) The Archaeology Museum isn't on the cruise ship schedule so it won't be as overly as crowded either way.
A must. To see all the royal sarcophagi including Alexanders was fantastic!
not as expected. the main attraction here is the marble cofins digged and kept here.. you get bored in some time , due to repetitiveness
do not miss. a peaceful area to tour, and have a cup of tea. Very good carpets and a interesting building
Consolidate your visits to all sites. The museum is well laid out and self explanatory. If you have visited several of the many sites in Anatolia then here you can organise your confused information

By all means go. Wonderful collections spanning thousands of years of habitation and cultures. If you're interested in this sort of museum experience, allow many hours. The truly ancient finds (tiny fertility figures,e.g.) are the mostcompelling. Later stuff--Roman versions of Greek sculpturesare generally only nice. One stunning exception--an Artemis--that every woman in the world should spend time studying.She's all about self-possession, power and smarts--andshe's a beauty.Note--museum hasn't much funding (few in Turkey do); in oldbuilding with finest holdings ceilings had crumbled and hadn'tyet been swept off stairways; lighting 'forgets' the works wewant to see; audioguides need major improvement. Don'tbother renting one.

What a treasure!. Huge collection of archeological treasures in beautiful buildings. We saw pieces there from Greece that were better than any we saw in Greece! It is a very easy walk from Hagia Sophia and next to the park.
Interesting. Very informative, very interesting lots to see, very well displayed out

A MUST SEE IN INSTANBUL!. This place is fantastic! I wish we had more time to spend there. It is ranked as one of the most important museums in the world and all yours to see for only 10 turkish lira (about $5.80). You go into 3 separate museums. The museum of the Orient is first, it is great. Go towards the back to the glass case with the love poem, murder verdict, etc. written on a tablet from 400 BC. Next, move on the tile museum and find the peacock fountain of youth. Lastly, the archaeology museum last fantasticsarcophagus in pristine condition. You are allowed to take as many photos as you like, but no flash.
Amazing History. The museum surprised me with its quality and its number of amazing artifacts it has. Well worth the price of admission. If you are a history buff this is a must see!

Museum jam-packed with ancient history. It's a huge museum actually - I wouldn't attempt it all in one go as you might get bored. Sarcophagi are amazing. Also interesting bit on the history of Istanbul...

Fabulous. Incredible valuable work to bring together the historic and cultural patrimony of this region, a tresory of the world patrimony in fact.All contemporary people shuld be thankful for having the oportunity to contemplate all this inestimable objects.
Large and very detailed. Many sections to wander through. Lots of interesting pieces.

Impressive and amazing relics. This museum had items to rival the British Museum! The chain that used to be used across the golden horn to keep ships out, wall hangings from Babylon, statues from the Hittites, and the most amazing sarcophogus I've ever seen. Do not miss this museum!

A great museum. Not far from the Topkapi Palace, the Archeological Museum is in three buildings. The Museum of the Ancient Orient contains some really good pieces - large and small, including tiled images of lions from the Ishtar Gate, which are really memorable. We spent most time, though, in the main building - particularly looking at the sarcophagi from Sidon. The carving on the Alexander Sarcophagus so detailed and lifelike - you can spent ages just looking at the scenes depicted. The grieving women sarcophagus also captures emotion in a way that is difficult to describe. There is a lot to see - including an extensive collection of artefacts from Troy. If you can, put aside some time to visit this museum - it was one of the highlights of our visit to Istanbul.
Dont miss this.. Agian, if you have any knowledge of ancient history, this place will put much of it into context. One of the worlds greatest museums.

Don't miss it if you like ancient history. You need to spare a good time for this museum. At least 3/4 hours. Whatever we learned in world history book in school, we get to see it all here. But if you not specifically interested in ancient history, it's worth checking out in 1/2 hours as well. When I saw preserved ancient statues on ground floor, first thing I realised was how the fashion these days, is repeatation of the ancient fashion! There is big section dedicated to Troy.But just before coming to Istanbul we got opportunity to see British archeological museum's Mesopotamia exhibit visiting Abu Dhabi, so we felt troy section similar.Of course, you get to see lot of ancient art to marvel at in this museum but already whole of Istanbul itself was a museum for us. The byzantine, roman, ottoman history found everywhere is already too much to grasp in short time and then adding whole of archeological museum in that may add on lot more confusion, this is definitely my confession. But people from Europe, Mediterranean background will definitely enjoy it more.

Great museum. Istanbul Archaeological Museum has three parts: Greek/Roman/Byzantium civilizations, eastern civilizations (Sumerians, Babylonians, Assryians, Hittities, Urartus, Egyptians etc). There are many unique charms in the museum such as Kadesh Treatment, Alexander The Great Lahit, the clay-tablets from Sumers etc.

Outstanding!. Incredible collections and excellent displays. The only complaint is that none of the cafes were open and there are no water fountains that I could find. We had to exit the compound and walk to a nearby restaurant to get a soft drink. Not sure how often this happens, but take some bottled water and plan to spen several hours enjoying this fine museum.
One of the best museums. Do not miss this. One of of the best museums we've visited. Our top rating for things to see in Istanbul.
Very impressive. The #2 site requires considerable time to appreciate all the artifacts

DO NOT MISS THIS. They have the most amazing collections of finds, sarcophagus etc that I have ever seen. Even better than the British Museum. give yourself plenty of time to explore all the buildings. Over two hours will not be enough
beautiful. this is the best museum in istanbul. it has some very impressive artifacts going back to ancient greece.
Sarcophagus!. So many artifacts that we lost track. The sarcophagus collection is amazing and worth the entry price just for it. Buy the Museum pass for 6 attractions. Very good cost savings!

Very interesting start to our visit.. We came here on our first day in Istanbul and were very happy we had.
The museum takes you through all the ages of Istanbul and the collection of artefacts is quite amazing.
Took two visits. There is so much to see, plan on spending an entire day.
Nice Museum. As a Greek I m it was surprise for me when I visit this museum.
wow. if you are a bit of history buff then you will love this museum and probably spend hours in it like i did !!

Fantastic Museum. I didnt know too much about this museum before I went. But I am so glad that I did. There are endless relics and some amazing statues and artifacts. It may not be as talked about as other museums, but I will certainly be singing it's praise.There is enough here to spend the better part of a day, but the whirlwind trip will take at least 1.5 hours. As an added bonus, there are a few buildings in the campus so finding somewhere that isnt crowded is easy.

Mythical!. Seeing this museum was one of the best parts of our trip! We saw everything that we had so far seen in movies, read in books about greek mythology, ancient archeology and pre historic stuff. Go there just after your done with your tour of Topkapi, it closes at 5pm so start with the section where you would like to spend the most time. We started off with the greek mythology section and went towards other areas, this way we were able to see most of what we wanted to see, but couldn't get to see the other parts. In the winter, the whole atmosphere has a very very chilling effect, so that season is recommended.
A Must!. Extensive collection of artifacts presented in a modern, easy to navigate, museum. The ancient carpets are amazing!

Excellent for history buffs. I am a history buff so this was eye opening for me. The collections rival the British Musuem with many varied historic artifacts. The Roman Sacrophagi are teh best you will ever see beating those in the Rome museums. The Mesopotain collection is expansive. The ceramics museum is lovely too.The toilets are a bit primative even have one stand up toilet.Some building work is being carried out at the moment so some areas are closed.There are not many places to sit and look at the exhibits.Maybe would not reccommend for the casual tourist.

One of the best things we did in Istanbul. Many people skip this museum because they visit the palace, the blue mosque, and the Hagia Sophia, and that is too bad. There are fantastic exhibits on mesopotamia and Troy, and the Alexander Sarcophagus is mindblowing. There were no lines, and this is a great place to buy your Istanbul Museum pass if you go that route (lets you buypass the ticket line at other museums...note, the line for tickets to the Topaki Palace was 300+ people)

perhaps too much to see. A good museum with lots to see - perhaps too much? There's a lot to take in, and the hardcore archeologists will love it.I chose to dip in and out of it, but still enjoyed it. You can buy the Museumcard for entry to this, Aya Sofia and the Topkapi Palace

A pearl of history. It's located just on your way to Topkapi Palace. You need half a day or so to cover this huge collection which is definitely worth seeing. Pieces from every civilization ruled in turkey could be found here including Egyptians, Romans, Ottamans and so on. But try not to have it in the program the same day with topkapi, you can visit it the same day with Hagia Sophia.

Could spend a week here.. This is a really excellent museum with well set out exhibits telling the history of the whole area and beyond. A lot of care has gone into it and the exhibits are carefully shown.
A lovely museum often unnoticed. immaculately kept, lots of history, great location.

Not a bad museum.... It's hard to tell you not to go here, but if you've been to the Met, the British Museum or Berlin, you've seen better. Still, worth a morning visit (especially if it's raining and you need an indoor activity). The sarcophagi are definitely neat.

great museum. this is the best museum in istanbul. it has some very impressive artifacts going back to ancient greece. and there's a fabulous little tea garden outside where you can sit among ancient greek stele and other ruins. it's so quiet and peaceful- you'll forget you're in a bustling city of 15 million people.

Lost in History. I have visited all sections of the Istanbul Archaeology Museum. There are many good findings from the primitive man through many ancient civilizations of Anatolia. I spent around 5 hours in the museum. If you are keen on history you will be lost in the museum. I recommend you to know general history of Anatolia or else you will be just looking.
lots of tombs to see. very nice area with a park outside to stroll through when you are done. The museum is nice but not as informative as it could be.
Chocked full of Goodness. It was very well organized. The staff was helpful and courteous. The restrooms where clean. There is some much to look at it could take days to see everything inside.
Don't Miss It. Amazing assortment of stone carving of all kinds plus.
Three Floors of History. Visited three floors of ancient artifacts including many from Troy make it well worth the visit. Takes some time to cover the many displays though.
Be sure to go. Very interesting artifacts with great English translations. Numerous sarcophagi with amazing artistic exteriors.

Treasures of antiquity. I wouldn't miss the Museum complex which includes the Museum of the Ancient Near East and the Tiled Kiosk for the world, because The Near East Museum contains some of antiquity's most valuable artifacts. The Ottoman Empire was enormous in its day and stretched from Iran to Egypt - so in these museums you will find unsurpassed objects from many places. There are Sumerian statues, and I think the world's greatest collection of Sumerian clay writing tablets; the world's oldest love letter, the world's first peace treaty and the lions of Babylon which are so well preserved in their bright enamelled painting that I thought they were fakes the first time I saw them. Across the courtyard in the Archaeological museum proper there is a collection from Sidon that beggars belief - the Alexander sarcophagus, and many others fill an entire ground floor. It is absolutely astonishing. Upstairs the entire floors are dedicated to Trojan finds. then the painted kiosk has a few, but beautifully selected, works of ancient art. Wow. You would have to travel to the Met in New York, Berlin or the british Museum to find any museums to equal these.

One of the world's best. This is the museum worth spending time at. It has a world class collection of antiquities spread over 3 separate buildings and ranges historically from primitive man through every great civilization that touched upon the area. The pieces on display are extraordinary. We spent several hours here, but I wish we had planned on an even longer or repeat visits.
A must. Beautiful museum, a must. You need at least 2 hours but easily more. Don't miss the sarcophagi of Alexander

Take the time to treat yourself to this museum. If you visit the beautiful Hagia Sopia take the time to pop down the road to this wonderful museum. We did a relatively quick walk thru and were amazed by the Sarcophagi. You could revisit this museum many times, and enjoy it more and more. What an incredible collection of antiquities.
Ancient Culture. The supreme of history and ancient culture is here....beatifull!!!
A great place.... So much history kept so well..... If you are in Istanbul than surely visit this museum once u go to Topkapi Palace and Gulhane Park.

Sooo much to see. This is a museum jam packed with history. Be well rested, there is a lot to see. Outside are an assortment of capitals and sculpture. Inside the main building are great examples of sarcarphagi, sculpture and architectural elements. There is pottery galore, some old glass and metal. If you like Turkish ceramics, there is a separate building with beautifiul examples.
Outstanding. If all you see is Alexander's sarcophagus you will be enthralled. The quality of the antiquities and the historical significance of all you see is incredible.
History within reach. Loved the statues and carvings. There are nice cases of Syrian glass and artifacts found throughout the region.

Too much history. It's great if you are interested in the history. I spent hours there. I recommend the Istanbul through the ages exhibit, which you have to look for--2 floors but access behind other exhibits.
Great for a wet day or two - so much to see. We will go back when we have more time. There is so much to see here and it is often overlooked.

You'll get tombed out. Unless you're specifically interested in tombs, this is probably best left for a rainy day. Don't get me wrong, some of the sarcophagi are incredibly and beautifully carved, but there are only so many you can look at in one day before your eyes start to glaze over. I think there was some non-tomb stuff too, but there was an overriding grave theme to the exhibits.

Dreams into reality. A must to see in Istanbul!!! So many sculptures' pictures I used to see in the arts books in my childhood are turning real in this museum. I and my 9 years old son spent a whole day moving from one sculture to another and trying to remember the feelings they caused for good. An exellent place

Overwhelming amount of history. Three buildings. Get the tape recorded tour if you like a guide. the Pompei exhibit is a little confusingly laid out, with pompeii on one side and a general archaelogy exhibit on the other - both are worth it. There's a mysterious floor which is hard to get to which has a piece of the chain that ran across the harbor for a five hundre years. The ancient history with it's Babylonian and Assyrian sculture is amazing. Very cold on a cold day. Worth two days for the serious student.

Fascinating sculpture collections. A vast collection of sarcophagi and tomb monuments on the main floor; above an historical 'timeline' of collected artefacts tracing the development of Anatolian civilisation through ceramics and metal tools

Complete Archaeology Museum. Very complete museum, from Pharaoh time, Byzantium, Roman, Pre-historical artifacts Meganthropus time until Homo Sapiens, middle-eastern and europe artifacts and there are sooo many beautiful Roman time coffins made by marble. And it is separated in 3 wings 2 buildings, 1 small one near the entrance and 1 big building looks like a palace.There is a cafe facing to Gulhane Park with Tulip and fountains which provides you a beautiful peaceful scenery and you can also see birds having their nest in the trees and you can also smell the sea. It is located beside Gulhane Park and before the Topkapi Palace.I was thinking that this is the Topkapi Palace itself but I was wrong, we need to walk a little bit further inclining straight to go to Topkapi Palace.

One of the best museums in the world. This is perhaps one of the best museums in the world if your interest is related to the ancient orient. It is well laid out and explanations are given in English.Allow at least two hours to visit to ensure you see everything

Lots to see. This museum had quite a bit to offer, and the venue was very historically important, itself. We found it interesting though, how much Greek and Egyptian antiquities were housed there, considering how much Turkiye wishes it's own items back from Munich, Frankfurt, and London, though.
Better artifacts than the museums in Athens!. This place wasn't nearly as crowded as the Blue Mosque and other sites and it was amazing. I could've spent all day!

So much history in one place!. Museum has lots of interesting pieces, we were short on time, so we used our Top 10 Istanbul guide to spend time on the top articles in this place. They also have an audio guides that you rent. Note that there is a cafeteria inside, with seating outside as well, as expected pretty expensive (8TL for a capuccino)

Great Museum. I have been in istanbul for 6 days and i am really amazed of this wonderful city. My friends had recommended me to visit the archaeological museum in this city and i did my visit couple days ago. What a great museum! It took me 3 hours to see the items and the wonderful statues from the periods of Romans, Greeks and Ottomans. I strongly recommend the travellers to see Istanbul Archaeological Museum when they visit istanbul.

Don't miss the Istanbul Archeology Museums. This museum gets overlooked by many of the tourists in Istanbul. Don't miss it yourself. It has a world class collection of sarcophagi, and Greek and Roman sculpture. It has fascinating exhibits on Istanbul through the ages and the many different cities of Troy. We went expecting to spend a couple of hours there and spent the entire day. If you can, do it over more than one day so you don't get overloaded - it is that good.

One of the main reasons why I came to Istanbul, It is a show stopper!. The Archaeological Museum has of one of the most extraordinary collections of classical antiquities beautifully displayed with the information in English. There is so much to see and experience.One of the highlights of the museum is the Alexander Sarcophagus, called because this fantastic carved marble tomb depicts Alexander the Great winning a victory over the Persians. It is located in the Old building on the right side as you enter the courtyard. When you enter go to the left, it is a few galleries further. The museum of the Ancient Orient contains wonderful artifacts from Mesopotamia. The one that I was searching for was the Code of Hammurabi which dates from 1750 BC, this is the oldest recorded set of laws. However, I was astonished to find out that it was a very small piece of stone with writing, I almost missed it if I did not ask a guide where to find it. Also, included is the oldest standard measures, and various other early writings.Lastly there is large area completely devoted to Anatolia and Troy. One side gives the history of Anatolia the other side of the gallery shows the excavations of Troy. I think it might be a good idea to visit the museum first before going to Troy, you will have a better understanding.My suggestion, is try to book a guide that has a specialty in Archaeology for this museum it will be well worth the cost. I could have spent weeks in this museum if not more. Decide what you want to see first, make a plan and enjoy. There is too much to see in just one visit.
Byzantine treat!. A wonderful collection of Byzantine objects and art, we could have spent days there. looking at the rest of the museum but ran out of time!
A quiet museum. Understanding the nomadic culture helps the visitor grasp the significance and individual charm of the ubiquitous carpets!

Very good museum. Excellent museum, plenty of beautiful and historic artefacts, although some of the translations could do with a revision.The Ancient East annexe is probably the best, some truly stunning mosaics, and the "oldest love poem" in Cuneiform

Please give some of your time for this. Went here in the afternnon after the Palace tour. Preferred it much better. Far , far less people and the exhibitions were world class. Well worth the time ( about 2 hours min ) I was well satisfied.

Fantastic Museum!. The Istanbul Archeology Museum is both huge and wonderful. Many of the sites in Istanbul are great, but often take only minutes to see and walk through. Alternatively, this museum has three separate buildings, the largest of which has three floors of excellent artifacts and antiquities. I'm one of those people who likes to take museums at a brisk place, but I loved walking around this museum for hours. One of the best tourist attractions in Istanbul by FAR!
one of the top museums in the world. best if seen with a tour guide. The amount of history in this museum is mind boggling, back to about 10,000 BCE. the artefacts are well preserved.

Extensive collection of ancient art. My wife is an expert in ancient Greek and Roman art and agreed that this is one of the most extensive collections of those categories in the entire world. Everything is in English which makes it so much easier than trying to figure things out for ourselves. Plan on spending at least half a day here as it takes a lot of time to go through everything.

Very important museum of turkish and islamic culture. Excellent museum most items very well displayed. Stunning carpets and rugs, manuscripts, artefacts and location. It was quiet with a lovely courtyard and good views of the Blue Mosque
History buff or not, very interesting artifacts!. Learned a lot from this visit! So many interesting things to see!
Excellent museum - take your time!. This museum - just go, you will not regrett it - it is as simple as that.

One of the best museums in Istanbul. They have an excellent selection of artifacts from Turkey and the Middle East, including some from Ancient Egypt. A good selection of ceramics from around Turkey as well. Head sets are available for a small fee with additional information about many of the artifacts. There is so much to see that we made multiple trips. The cafe is in a shady garden and is a nice place to take a break.

What a collection!. An amazing exhibit. Well-labelled and laid out, with great audio guides. Having first seen some of the exhibits at the Pergamon Museum in Berlin (e.g. the large blue-tiled walls with yellow horses), it was great to see them at this museum in Turkey (where they originated from). See pics 192-347: http://flic.kr/s/aHsjyeojsx

Some good artefacts but could be better. We found the museum ok on some levels with some great artefacts dotted about especially the Alexander sarcophagus but the museum could be laid out better and it could do with having a less is more approach as it gets a bit samey and dare i say it boring. A must for history buffs.

Istanbul Archaelogy Museum. Fantastic place. Spent 3 hours there and only saw half or less. Couldn't manage any more. Need all day, but you have to be really keen.Dislike - the statues and columns outside - what were we looking at? Almost a complete lack of descriptions. It looked more like the museums junk yard.

Must See. It has a large collection of Balkans, Africa, Mesopotamia and Anatolia works.
You can really see how east and west art influence each other in museum's collection.

All Day!. Whew! There is a lot to see at this museum. Amazing Tombs, mosaics, sculpture, pottery - and oh so much more cover the property. For me, it was difficult to take it all in at once. I will go back and explore some more

A bit chaotic. The museum has countless pieces and artifacts, most of them beatiful and interesting, but even for tha large space they have available, itseems there are just roo many pieces and organization of collections is not the best. One skips from one historical time to another and gets a bit lost in interpreting the collection. The artifacts would benefit from more organisation. Still there are so man important pieces, from roman artwork, to sarcophaguses of differnt eras and even some pieces of the walls of babylon, that it is most certainly worth a visit.
Well displayed. I was thankfull that there is information in English My understanding of Turkish history is increasing.The audio guide gave an extra dimention.
Loved It. There was hardly anyone else there and the exhibitions were outstanding

Must to see in Istanbul. Don't miss this excellent statue collection from antique times. This wonderfull historical pieces comes from all around Antolia and mesopotamia. You will be fascinated by richness of art works presented in this well organized museum. There are many other museums in this district, you have opportunity to spend all day in the area while admiring masterpieces of oriental word. It is an attractive journey for children as well.
Big surprise. Small place nobody goes, but should. The exhibits are great and then there is the terrasse coffe shop to enjoy the view and learn how to prepare 'turkish coffe'

Don't miss this. The Archaeology Museum is an absolute treasure house, and should not be missed on any account. Yet, I suspect that it is, because it is so very close to The Dolmabahce Palace, it is easy to walk straight passed. In fact, there is a notice up stating "This is NOT The Dolmabahce Palace." Do take time to totter round, there is so very much history here.
Excellent. Worth to visit. Evidently, it is a lesson of history of Istanbul and other parts of Europe.

Spectacular Alexander Sarcophagus. If you are interested in art and archaeology, you absolutely can't miss the Alexander Sarcophagus, carved in Sidon (today's Lebanon) for King Abdalonymos in the 4th Century B.C. The museum features a lot of amazing things, but its collection of sarcophagi from Sidon is unparalleled and absolutely spectacular.

A must-see. i spent my last day (of 7) in Istanbul visiting this 4-building museum. If you are interested at all in history, then GO! From the excavations at Troy, to tiled walls and statutes over 6,000 years old, to the oldest peace treaty every signed (13,000 B.C) this place is a gem. Exhibits are well-spaced, and easy to understand. A half-day is the minimum to allot, but when you leave, you can take a lovely walk through the park in which the museum is located.

Great Museum. Just off the palace complex, it has some very interesting exhibits from the old empire era's. Also undergoing some renovation, and in other areas staff shortages cause some exhibits to be closed randomly.

The most fascinating history in istanbul!. You can get up close and personal with most of the exhibits. Great, airy space, wonderful assortment of artefacts, very well labelled and described. Exhibitions constantly being updated and extended. Plenty of freedom to stay as long as you please. fabulous babylonian mosaics and the majestic Alexander sarcophagus.
Historical museum. I found it very interesting to see a variety of things from old history.
do not miss it,,,. i love it this Archaeology Museum and you must visit it,,

A well planned museum with good cafe. Very well laid out, wonderful range of artefacts, carpets, incredible calligraphy and ethnographical exhibits. Definitely worth a visit, and helps to put the huge spans of time into some sort of perspective. The Turkish Coffee experience currently running is well worth a try. Sit on the terrace and sip your freshly made coffee with a cool glass of water and a sweet piece of Turkish Delight while looking at lizards dart around your feet, and the cats jump in and out of the huge jars in the grass. A unique experience.
Worth a visit.. Some very interesting exhibits to see. Quite a bit of rich archaelogical history in Turkey, and the musuem does a pretty good job of displaying some fine pieces of that.

Too many same things.... A bit disappointed here; The museum is large but you just keep seeing the same things.Two highlights; The "mummy" buried with his cat and the first "peace treaty" signed in the world.

Great exhibits pity about the services. This museum is hard to find hidden, between the Topkapi Palace - 500m opposite main Ticket Office ( which itself is well within the outer walls of the Palace), and the main road. It is huge and covers at least 3 buildings and gardens. It should be given a good half day for a reasonable viewing. I was refused the use of the lift in the main building. Disabled access would be difficult and if you are tired after a lot of walking avoid this site. My visit was outwith main tourist season but local children's parties were noisy and unattended.

The way Archaeology should be displayed. I have no idea on how hard it has been to get this museum to its current state but it is truly magnificent from the Weeping Women to the 7 stages of Troy, from the porcelin tiles to the brass fibulae. This is the yardstick by which all such museums should be measured. Allow 2 hours minimum and use the audio guide. This is an absolute must.

An overload of old tombs. Built to house a collection of sarcophagi from the excavations at Sidon, to be honest once you've seen one elaborately decorated classical sarcophagus well....and there are rooms and rooms of them. The rest of the collection is badly curated and very poorly signposted and annotated and the audio guide isn't worth the money. Go to the Museum of Islamic Art on the Hippodrome instead
Archaeo museum. We arrived half an hour before it closed and staff wouldn't let us view all the rooms.
Big, big, big.... So many things inside. Prepare yourself to spend a full day in there.

UNBELIEVEABLE!!! A MUST SEE!!!. Grab an explanatory copy of this museum's treasures and read about the stories carved in the numerous sacarphogi. They are breathtakingly beautiful, mesmerizingly poetic in composition, meticulously executed.
So much history.. There is so much to see. If you're a history and archaeology buff you will find a lot to see and learn.

Interesting collection poorly displayed. This museum is potentially very interesting but at the moment it is undergoing some renovation. I can only hope that when the renovated area opens the displays are vastly improved. The areas that are open have no flow through them and we had to completely double back to leave the galleries.There was inadequate labelling of the items and the audio guide added very little to the posted information, providing no historical context. Visit here if you have plently of time or have a specific interest, but if you are limited in time there are far better things to see in Istanbul

Allow lots of time!. This museum has an amazing collection of Egytpian art, as well as ancient mesopotemian, greek and ottoman pieces. I have only seen half of the exhibit. Each piece is beautifuly preserved and curated, with information. Highly recommend

What opportunites we missed!. The top class ground floor exhibits of this large museum are superb. Stunning sculpture from Ancient Egyptian, to Turkish and Roman. Our mistake was only to allow ourselves 2 hours. Very good value.
Amazing artifacts. Not the most pleasing interior- a bit run down. Did have very interesting artifacts.

Interesting. I learned alot here about Turkey / Istanbul through the centuries and the eras. There were alot of interesting ancient finds of numerous themes. Good value at 10TL and right next to Topkapi Palace. Could have been better laid out as you have to walk through same sections to see it all.

Shouldn't miss it. This has all the things you learned about in school.
Even though some areas were closed, a video presentation of those areas was included.

Almost overwhelming. Even travelers that know some history will be wow'd by the artifacts on display here. To walk around and just "come across" statuary of Alexander the Great or Roman Caesars can be a little intimidating. Careful not to put too much on the same day as visiting here...you could get overloaded
Meet Alexander. I was pleasantly suprised to see so many different exhibits from all around the ancient era.

Excellent museum. One of the better museums I have been to in the world. The Bulk of the collection is Mesopotamian and Egyptian & Turkish. Some really nice Hittite pottery and several Sarcophagus'. It didn't take all day to go through the museums either which I liked. You can take pictures but no flash. The museum card(72 TL) gets you in to all the major attractions like Topkapi as well. You can purchase it at the museum.

Do Not Miss this Museum.... We had 1 cold rainy day left in Istanbul, and took public transportation to this museum. It is beyond world-class, without a doubt the finest archaeological and antiquities museum we have ever seen. And we've been all over the world. It rivals the V&A. The collection is wide, well-kept, you can wander for days, you can take photographs, it is a true gem. There is much to be learned, the documentation for most exhibits is very thoughtful. We came upon many unexpected and interesting exhibits. We wished we had another day, but have our photos for now and have been recommending it to all, we will definitely go back to Istanbul someday, and this will be our #1 attraction. One thing, take an extra roll of film, you will use it!
Archeology Museum. Excellent displays and grateful that all of the signs were in English, a real plus for us.

Great heritage from Anatolian Civilizations!. You can see enourmous number of pieces from ancient throught more modern eras of Anatolian civilizations. Especially tourists who are interested in Anatolian, mesopotamian and middle eastern pre-historia and archaeology MUST visit this wonderfull museum.

DIZZYING Collection, the place for Mediterranean History. The Museum is more of a complex of buildings that is a stone's throw away from Topkapi Palace and the two can be rolled into a single afternoon.Certainly reserve at least 3 hours to get a sense of the place; there's no way you're going to go slowly through the exhibits so it's useful to get a sense of what you absolutely must see; like the Discovery of Troy Exhibit, the sarcophagi, especially the so called 'Alexander the Great sarcophagus' and the Byzantine Istanbul Section. The labeling/description of the displays is a bit limited; not that you're going to read everything there is, but it could be more systematic, neater and engaging. The sheer volume of artifacts though certainly makes up for that. I wouldn't miss this on a trip to Istanbul, but I am a bit of a History / Archaeology buff, still my kids are pretty neutral (I think) and they seemed to get quite a lot out of it.
interesting museum. the sarcophagus of Alexander was the central attraction, I thought. 3 bldgs to look thru; reasonable entry fee.

Well worth a visit. As museums go its quite a bit smaller than I expected but that makes it manageable. On a cold winters day it was nice to wander the heated halls with hardly anyone around. Highly recommend setting aside 2or 3 hrs to visit this place

Unbelievable Treasures. Don't miss this fantastic collection , truly amazing. You will want to visit this when visiting Topkapi Palace but only after a long lunch break. Plan to spend several hours here. There are several places to lounge and rest your feet throughout museum.

A must for history buffs. The most interesting things in this museum are the sarcophargi. Intricate work and some with humongous dimensions. There were also some artifacts from Troy and stone tablets with writing on them. Even if don't like museums, seeing something from 300 BC is astounding. Try to give yourself at least 1 hr or more as there is so much to see.
Need more time. Really need a full day to enjoy all three of them.

Great stuff, poor organization. This museum is a must see for history buffs and archeological buffs, but it seems like a museum in transition. There are some really antiquated almost victorian-looking displays, and lots of haphazardly arrayed stuff in the courtyard. The museum is a treasure trove of stuff and beautiful architecture, but it is a bit ragged around the edges.

What a miracle!. This is simply treasure! So many preislamic artifacts, so many information. OK, maybe its mainly for those who really love roman, greek, akkadian, hittites etc culture, but... For me, it was visit for 4 hours and full of beauty of ancient times.

Not enough time to fully explore!. Huge museum with an "interestingly organized" display of the development of Turkey and life in the area. If you like historical context to areas you visit or you just like antiquities, this is a must visit. You could spend as little as an hour wandering or set aside an entire morning or day to see everything.

Amazing - A Must See!. This was probably one of my most favorite things to see in Istanbul. There are several different exhibits, and my friend and I got lost (not literally) for about 2 hours looking at all the tombs, paintings, smaller sculptures, and ancient ruins. It just seemed to continue on and on. It is RIGHT next to Topkapi palace and both are doable in a day.
Absolutely wonderful for archeology/ancient history lovers. Plan to spend at least 4 hours to take it all in. It really is my favorite archaeological museum. Enjoy.

Fantastic Collection!. Fantastic Collection! I was very impressed with the collection they hold here. It is located on your left after the great church of Hagia Irene and down the hill as you walk onto the grounds of Topkapi Palace. Don't miss this if you like antiquity, there are several buildings on the grounds with different collections that are very well laid out for guests. Of course a good guide book is invaluable but I found the selection of books at the book store to be very good. This might help too, I list the official web site for the museum below.By the way, the little cafe on the grounds make a very good espresso.

Kudos to the management!. Amazingly maintained archaeology museum, one of the best I've ever seen. You can spend a whole day there and still miss out on a couple of things. My advice is to go early because it closes at 4:30pm.

Sarcophagi. Rick Steves highly recommended a visit to this museum, and all for good reason! The sarcophagi in the main level were astonishingly breathtaking. If you can grab his book "Istanbul", it will make the tour of this place easier. This is the best museum in Turkey! If you only have time to visit one, this is it!
Alexander the Great Thumb.... the thumb of Alexandre the Great is amazing and there is lots of greek culture, roman culture and Assyrius and babilonic culture do see.
wow Alexander the greats tumb is here!. I didnt know that alexander the greats tumb is in istanbul, it is very awesome piece of art you should go there and see it!
A Must!. It was fun going into the halls and discovering more and more about historical facts of Turkey and the region!

Perfect collection worth to see. The museum is huge with impressive collection. An advice: take audio guide which is helpful otherwise you'll spend a week roaming around all the exhibits (even with audio guide it took 3 hours for me to check whole museum). There are three buildings on the territory. Ceramic musem is very small and nice. Museum of Oriental Arts is bigger and has good collection of Egiptian exhibits (Kadesh Treaty is must see obviously).Main building is huge with good collection but I can say two bad things about organization in general:1) main building has very bad navigation inside, you'll spend half an hour trying to find the way to "new building" even if you're considered as smart person; 2) the marks with numbers for audio-guided tours nearby the exhibits are very bad visible and it takes time to find them. Generally my impression about this museum is very good, it's must visit for every tourist coming to Istanbul though.

Best Museum I've ever been to. This Museum should be what all other Archeological Museums around the world aspire to. The artifacts are well labeled and the pieces are eloquently displayed. We stayed four hours and I still feel like we could have seen more. Excellent. Don't miss the Sarcophogus of Alexander!

if you are serious about arcaelogy, you have to visit !. One of the best in the world. Yes, it hasn't been as famous as Louvre or British Museum or Hermitage or Metropolitan, but it's not her fault :-)you will be impressed...

Guide Guney Presents. Its fantastic for History professionals, artstudents, especially the ones who wants to do a boy proportion analysis for archeologic freaks or anyone who claims to be authority.For anyone else: You should be interested than its a good optional tour.please do it than at least the whole day with breaks.

Archeological Treasures. The museum has some fine examples from archeology digs around Turkey and magnificent sarcophagi from 4th century BC. I had never seen such fine and intricate carvings before. It definitely puts perspective in viewing the cannon of western art.
Lovely half a day experience. Well laid out and informative signage. You could fill a notebook with things you didn't know.

Well Worth the Trip. A gorgeous museum with so much to see. For users of Rick Steve's guide, from the gate, walk with the cafe to your left, bypassing the first building and head into the big entrance doors of the main museum to your right so that you will start your tour in the right place. If you walk into the entrance with the huge Bes statue, you need to head to your left so that you can start with the sarcophagi, which are really quite extraordinary. Hopefully, you enjoy statuary because this museum is chock full of it. If you were disappointed by other museums in other cities with nothing but headless statues (ahem, Aphrodisias), this will fit the bill nicely. The museum is laid out around a courtyard. The kiosk is a gem like little building - I found the building almost more beautiful than its contents.

Outstanding!. If you have any interest or knowledge of ancient history then the Museum of Archaeology is a must. They have some of the friezes from the Ishtar Gate as well as the stunning artefacts from the necropolis of Sidon. Astonishing.

Amazing and Frustrating. The place is amazing because of its vast collection of artifacts from various periods of Turkey's long history. However, some are poorly displaced, with inadequate light, or behind old, wavy glass. The signage almost never indicates the significance of the piece. A typical sign might say "Ancient figure of a man, 1-4 century BC". Well, most of that I could have figured out without the sign! Did not do the audio tour and can only hope that it gives more meaningful information.
This is a must for museum lovers. This has a very large collection of tombs and other interesting artifacts. There is also a rotating show--we saw items from Troy and earlier times.
One day is hardly enough for this place. Amazing exhibits that will take you back a couple of thousand years in time. Do get the audio guide as its very helpful.
awesome!. amazing collection! if you like old history and statuary, this is a must!
Traditional museum great value. It is worthy to spend a few hours on complentation how long is our history and how wonderful we - minkind - are, irrespectively where we come from

Alexander sarcophagus is stunning. The Alexander sarcophagus is stunning, I felt privileged to see it. Also the ancient Hittite lions were well worth a visit. Not much else to see and the only place where the toilets are to be avoided!

Very Interesting. Arkeoloji Muzesi is a very interesting museum. This is one of the museums that is part of the museum pass and makes the museum pass worth your money. Most of the museums are in one general area and you need a full day to view all the museums. Buy the museum pass for 36 dollars and enjoy Arkeoloji Muzesi.
Do not miss this Museum. We came across this museum by chance and spent over 3 hours there we just loved it. Do not miss this museum!

Lots to see. I loved this museum. Some really great statuary, well-presented exhibits. I think it probably gets passed over by those obsessed with Topkapi. i liked Topkapi too, but the Arkeoloji Muzesi is worth a look too).
Not to be missed. A wonderful museum containing so much history and artefacts. Do not leave Istanbul with out spending a few hours here.

Sine qua Non. In the lower gardens of Topkapi Palace, this magnificent museum is waiting for visitors with great exhibitions of archeologic items... Istanbul through the ages section is just breathtaking...
Top museum in Topkapi grounds.. This is a fantastic place for a rainy day - even a sunny one. Hugely interesting collections spanning millenia - world-class. You have to visit!
Delightful sights. Walking around the buildings, we greatly enjoyed the architecture, archaeological items and the gardens.
A mirror of Anatolian Civilisations. Well renovated, first modern museum in Ottoman History. Must be seen.
Where else?. Been here numerous times, here lies the spirit of ancient middle east. It is too big to be done in one visit and have small items occupying you for hours.

An Unbelievable Store of Archaeological Treasures. This may be the most impressive collection of archaeological treasures under one 'roof' ever. We spent almost 3 hours and only scratched the surface. It is the pride of Turkey and it's easy to see why. If you have any interest at all in archaeology, this Museum will be a most satisfying experience.

No crowds here!. This provides a nice overview of Istanbul's history without the cruise ship crowds of the so called main sites. My hi-lites were the tiles and the treaty of Kadesh. All three buildings were worth the effort.

Not to be missed!!!. Beautiful, thrilling artifacts, including the Alexander Sarcophagus and Pergamon tiles that are far more extensive and interesting than those in the Pergamon Museum in Berlin. Helpful staff. It's a history lesson of incomparable beauty.
Great exhibits and all ancient!. Loved this group of museums. Tile museum well worth a visit. The main building is naturally a people pleaser.
Great collection. Off the beaten track as it is not populated with many tourists when we visited the museum. Extensive collection. Worth a visit and can easily spend half a day here.

Close to sophie mosque, must see!. This museum is at 100 m from the sophie mosque but few people visit it becasue the organized trip don't have the time. This s a pity becaseu it is most probably one of the most interesting thin in istanbul with artfact from Mesopotamia (nont so common) and very inresting objects.

Amazing artifacts and SENSATIONAL Carpets. This museum was first rate, though somewhat less complete than the National Archeological Museum in Ankara. The sweep of Anatolian history from its neolithic past through the Ottoman reign is impressive. Signage and lighting are good. The gift shop is also popular, if you enjoy that.

Artifact Overload!. This place is huge, there is building after building of artifacts, sculpture, art and more. I would say its a must see but be mindful that you do not have to see everything they have. If we were to do it again I think we would concentrate on two or three buildings and just enjoy those.

Amazing Phoenician Sarcophagi from Lebanon. My husband and I greatly enjoyed the exhibit of beautiful, painstakingly preserved Phoenician Sarcophagi from South Lebanon - we have been to Saida (Sidon) and Tyre in Lebanon and we were thrilled to see these amazing works of art and history being so well taken care of in Istanbul. A breathtaking display of several rooms - if you read about the Phoenicians and Lebanon's role in the Ancient world before going, becomes even more interesting.
That's history. Very good exhibition. Fantastic sarcophague from Alexander the great.
A great museum. Some very unusual items and was not as crowded as some of the better known attractions.

If you like stone carvings, this is your place. This old-school museum is filled to the brim and could use some updating to its interpretation, but if you come with some foreknowledge, you'll find real masterpieces.
start here. to get an overview of the long history and wash your eyes in beauty.this is the place to start your expedition

Great but the second floor is a mystery. A great experience, but no one seems to have been visiting the floors above the magnificent collection of sarcophagi. (and I think they are unique in the world)When you arrive at the next floor you step into a forgotten wing of the muesum. It looks like it should have been closed many years ago, but for some reason they forgot about it and it remained open. Someone has been looting the place and just forgot to take the empty showcases. It's interesting, if you want to see how not to exibit things and if you want to see small handwritten notes about some of the items.. Very strange indeed. Spend a few minutes there and wonder! The rest of the musem is a marvel!
Wow. The gates of Babylon are just one of many fundamental icons of the ancient era that you can look upon up close.
great history.. this is a must for history buff. its full of ancient relics n artworks. and a must read too for its rich historical facts.

A peaceful respite. Very much overlooked by travellers, who flock to the nearby Topkapi Palace, this museum can feel almost hantingly empty compared to the other attractions of Istanbul.That is not because there is nothing to see here - history buffs will have a field day - but it lacks the grandeur and drama of the city's palaces and mosques.Half of the museum was closed for remodeling at the time of writing, so it was quite difficult to navigate into the new part of the building, as the map you are given at the entrance does not reflect this closure.I've been to more well-planned museums, but still, I spent three hours here, and could have stayed longer if I had had the patience for so many old artefacts and educational signs.Not suitable for the disabled or hard of walking as there are stairs everywhere.Tiny café in the courtyard is a bit overpriced but convenient if you need a break from the clay tablets.
Don't miss this.. Excellent! My wife said this was the best museum she had ever visted.

Blow your mind.. There is so much here, you will have a breakdown. Plan at least a few hours to absorb it. Bring a guide to steer you to what's important. The tiles building will be a "break". Extremely aggressive cats in the yard.
Beautiful Mosque. An excellent museum to visit. Has a lot of intereseting relic from the past and very educative to.
The Best!. We had an afternoon to kill, so we walked in. Amazing. Don't walk by, go in. You won't regret it.

Alexander? Zeus? Troy?. Off to the side oon the Topkapi grounds and down a steep hill, find this set of 2 museums. Beautiful sculptures from all regionsof Turkey. Highlights are the Alexander sarcophagus (carved for him, but not used) and, for me, the 2nd floor items from the 9 "layers" of Troy. A short video tells of the discovery of Troy, in English.

Not to be missed!. We arrived in Istanbul on the 75th anniversary of the Republic which also coincided with the All Saints/All Souls holiday weekend in many European countries. So Istanbul was packed with tourists for the first 2 days we were there and the lines to get into the more popular sites were outrageous! So we decided to just wonder around and when we arrived in front of the museum we were surprised to see no lines. Because of that we thought there wasn't much to see in the museum, but Oh my we sure had a very pleasant surprise. The Museum is fantastic! It houses an incredible amount of artifacts that are extremely interesting and can walk the visitor through the ages from Troy to the Ottoman Empire. The highlight is Alexander the Great's sarcophagus which is amazing, but there are countless other artifacts just as interesting if not so impressive. We have visited many museums around the world and in our opinion this one is definitely one that must be seen.

If you like archeology visit this museum!. Well laid out museum (actually, 3 are included in price and are inside gate). Unlike many museums of this nature, artifacts are well displayed and not crowded. Highlight was the variety of ancient sarcophigai, most still in excellent condition.

Outstanding museum. Three buildings contain an impressive collection of historic artifacts in this museum compound. We especially liked the Mourning Women sarcophagus in the main building, and the tile collection in the tile museum. A must see.

A marvellous treasure house. It is a very unassuming structure from the outside, though you do get intrigued by the number of artefacts lying in the open grounds. You have to get in to believe it. It is so huge, its almost boring. We couldn't visit all the three buildings, it was getting very tiring. But what an awesome collection. From what we were told, whats on display is less than 25% of the total collection.Wow! Thats all I can say
very nice!. with a lot of exhibits...many of them really great!

Museum fatigue. Probably great if you are a historian.I have been to Cairo Museum and visited it 3 times as it was out of the world despite disorganised. I didn't feel the same way here. Maybe a guided tour would have helped.

One of my favorite museums. I didn't like the part of the museum with the Iznik tiles but the main building was great. Audioguide was helpful. The museum is huge though, so you should plan on spending a couple of hours there at least.

Worth seeing if you are into the history of Turkey. It has a great collection of statues and historical artifacts. The selection is diverse and so worth seeing. We ran out of time and didn't see everything but what we saw was great.

The one in Ankara is much better than that.. If you are going to pass by Ankara, on the way to Capadoccia, you don´t need to go to that museum. If you won´t have the opportunity to know that Archeological/Civilization museum in Ankara and is really interested on that issue, may be you´ll find it a little bit interesting, but it is not so good as I expected.
bit dissapointing. exhibitoion kind of boring, the sight is great though
Great Museum. Great collections fo Greek artifacts. We almost miss the entrance to the museum.

Great Museum. this is a great museum right next to the topkapi palace. they have so many pieces from different eras. Definitely worth a visit. Can take around couple of hours of casual strolling to finish the museum

4 hours minmum. If you are into archaeology this is the place I like the acessibility (elevator)
I disliked the entance the ramp needs fixing leeding into the museum
Must see!. This museum is fantastic. Split into three sections - it's a great mix of istanbul and the area's history. I loved the museum and that the artifacts werent always behind glass cages.

Awesome. I can't say enough about this museum. Don't miss it. They have so much there that there are all kinds of treasures scattered around the grounds for you to touch and marvel at. It's not a huge museum which make it a nice two hour event. Be sure to see the other buildings on the grounds also.
Fantastic. You could stay there for hours and hours. Highlights were the peace contract between the Hetties and Egyptions, and the sarcophagus of Alexander

Hidden jem. Located next door to Topkapi palace this museum gets much less attention so there are no lines and you have the place to yourself. An amazing abundance of treasures from the regions of the Ottoman empire. A must see.

Make sure you fit this into your schedule. Having already been in many parts of Turkey, a visit to the Archaeology Museum helped put things into perspective. Sculptures, grave finds, items from the Sultan's palace - you name it, there here. Lots of information about the different cultures/invaders that controlled Turkey, and make it what it is today. My recommendation is that they need better lighting, especially upstairs. Cost cutting perhaps?
Take An Extra Camera Battery. This is the largest archaeological collection I have seen.
A very special museum. This museum has three parts and all must be seen. The antiquities are very well displayed and you can photograph. The Islamic art museum is small but a joy to visit.

One day in layers of history. Excellent exhibition. You need one ful day. Do not miss one of the first written peace agreement -the Kadesh Agreement- displayed at the museum. It is displayed at the first building to your left after entrance.
Alexander sarcophagus is a must see. It would take a whole day to get through the extensive collection. Go for the highlights.

Recommended by our guide in Ankara.... We were traveling in Turkey for several weeks. When we spoke with our guide in Ankara, he highly recommended this museum. We spent about 3 hours there and were so glad we hadn't missed it. The sarcophagus exhibit from Sidon was fabulous. However, if you are not a museum enthusiast, you may not appreciate this one.
