Do not miss this. We headed to this museum expecting to spend a few hours there, spent the whole day instead -- and still didn't see it all. There is so much, of great variety, and it is extremely well curated.
Must see. Check out the beautiful Alexander sarcophagus it is in incredible shape.

if you like history: just do not miss it. If you are in Istanbul and are tired of the lines .. this is your place. The sarcophagus from Sidon (called the Alexander Sarcophagus) is spectacular. The museum has a few pieces of the Ishtar Gate from Babylon, not as complete as the one in Berlin, but definitely a must. The collection of pieces from Troy were difficult to find and not very interesting. However.. the section that contains history of Istanbul from the prehistoric, Greek, Roman, ... and so on... was very interesting. This is an archeological museum. There are enough explanations in English to make the visit enjoyable. The cafeteria had almost no food.. Eat before you go there.

More than expected -- excellent set-up for travel. This is a serious museum! Yes,k it is long on "the usual" columns, statues, sarcophagi...but whether you are or aren't planning to travel throughout Turkey, it is a great set-up for what it has to offer. We used a guide, who steered us to the "high points" and thus we avoided being overwhelmed.

A historic review. of what happen through the time in Istanbul. Where well organized, even the fact that good part of Turkish archaeology are dispersed between the Berlin Museum, British Museum, Louvre Museum, and the Vatican Museum.Take your time, you could need the entire day to get through all that this museum offers.
An ordinary archaeological museum.. Nothing special to discover. If you have visited other places with an equal archaeological history, then there isn't much new to see in this particular museum.

So Much to See So Little Time. Instanbul weather was cold and windy, so we spent over 6 hours in the museum and STILL didn't see everything. We have been to Egyptian Museum in Cairo and this museum should be their goal. It was laid out well, you had room to observe everything and the Tiled Pavillion and Asian House were amazing. We would go back.

A couple of nice pieces - but over rated in my view. big and a bit boring. some pieces were fantastic - especially the 'tomb' exhibition ( I'm sure I have this description wrong. But sorry - I found it a little dull compared to other exhibitions or sites to see
Well done. A large museum with many fascinating displays. The sarcophagi were interesting, and the halls of statues, and many others.

can spend all day here!. this was an unexpected surprise -- the quality and quantity of artifacts were fascinating. They close early in the winter, so be sure to plan enough time to tour the multiple buildings.
It's a museum.. Ok, lots of sarcophagi, pieces of ruins, and statuary. Well presented, nice venue. A very substantial history of the area, but it's a museum.
Great Museum. Bring's Istanbul's long and varied history into focus. Some fabulous stuff and not too crowded
Archaeology Museum. Impressive collection of artefacts especially the sarcophagas
Go to this museum!. This museum was one of the highlights of our visit to Istanbul and well worth a visit. Wonderful and expansive collection and we practically had the place to ourselves.
Unbelivable Roman Artifacts. The crypts outside the Museum are HUGE. The entire grounds are littered with Roman statues, columns and massive carvings.

A fabulous overview of Turkish history. This is a large and impressive collection - well worth a visit. The building is a little worn but don't let that detract from the fabulous items covering hundreds/thousands of years. We gained a huge amount of knowledge from visiting here and set us up nicely to see the palaces and mosques.
intriguing. A full day is necessary for anything serious; it is filled with antiquities, which are attractively displayed.
Wow!. A great alternative to when the lines at Topkapi are too long. The rich history this museum presents is not to be missed. Don't forget the tiled pavilion just outside of the museum.
Near Topkapi. A group of museums for one price. Fantastic artifacts!

Huge museum!. We stopped into the archaeology museum during our honeymoon in Istanbul beacuse it was part of our museum pass and were amazed how big it was!!! They have a ton of really amazing artifacts that are well-worth a visit. We got a museum pass from our hotel for The Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Mosaic Museum, Chora Museum, and the Archaelogical Museum. The pass is good for 3 days and allows you to skip the line. I would highly recommend the pass!

this museum is awesome. there was so much to see that it just overwhelms you.. this museum is wonderful. if you study history and know the differences between the various periods and cultures. you will be in heaven. just the sheer number of items is amazing. this museum has no peers.
A journey to the past. Ancient carpets, Korans, inlaid religious objects are all shown in an old palace, right off the Hippodrome. Two hours is plenty of time to see this.
Incredible. So well laid out, give yourself plenty of time as this is a must see destination.
Excellent and exceeded expectations. Not that many people but FILLED with antiquities of really excellent quality that one would not expect to find. Would recommend an entire day here.

Expansive-bring a snack. The Iskandar Tomb and everything excavated from Sidon is impressive, They have a nice collection of Hittite and Egyptian artifacts. There were some primary school groups, but it wasn't nearly as crowded as Topkapi, BM, and Hagia Sophia.

Highlight of the tour!. The museum is well laid out with plenty of room to really view each piece. Excellent and not overdone English descriptions for each piece made it easy and enjoyable. The best part is the area which takes you through the history of Istanbul using artifacts and coins; this really helped with overall understanding of this wonderful city's history.
Don't miss this. Three museums with some of the best anciet art, the Treaty of Kadesh, Lions and mosaics from the Ishtar gate. Allow a couple of hours and get the audio guide.

Archaeology Museum. Not a large museum, but need a half day or a day to go thru it. Record history of Turkey and its surrounding area. Learn the events happened dated back to 10000 yrs ago.Very informative but the museum is kind of dated.

Has some interesting stuff! :). Spent a few hours here. Its closed on Mondays so keep that in mind when planning your intinerary. We had two small children with us (4 and 5 years old), and its still easy to keep them entertained by pointing out fascinating bits and pieces. Invest in one of the audio guides, its worth it :)
Excellent. Alexander's sacrophagus was the chief attraction, so is the first peace treaty. Other objects on display are also worth paying a visit

To know what European and Asian art come from. The great collection including exhibits depicting ancient Greek and Roman art as well as Ancient Oriental art. Antique sculptures and reliefs, Babylon monuments and reliefs... If you can feel the power of art, please, visit the Museum. It is worth it.

much to see. so much to see here.really fascinating.there are passageways and cabinets and statues that go up 3 levels.cant really stop and read all as there is so much history here.Interesting.And affordable.

Felt a bit cheated but all in Turkey is worth it. We were expecting more but it was the end of the day. We were told Alexandre the great´s sarcophagos was inside. It is that name but it is just called that as it is not his, it is from a general (?)The rest is filled more and more sarcophagos and some extra items from various eras.Overall a place that is not expensive (10 euro per pax) and something different inside.
Worth seeing. Last time i viaited was almost 15 years ago. Improved so much, exhibition objects, lightnings, dip notes are much more professional now.
Loads of stuff. An absolutely massive collection of things from various periods of history. Great to do on a damp day.

A Trip into the past. When we visit cities we spend a lot of time in the museums.We had about 3 hours to wonder and tahe in the arttifacts. The Arkeoloji Muzesi will be on our bucket list when we return to Istanbul
Worth every Minute. This museum really reflects the many influences of different cultures. This museum is a must.

A fantastic way to view the artifacts as well as the buildings.. To see the various historic artifacts of design and daily life in the context of the history of the city is elemental, much more meaningful than when they are viewed at a large museum in a distant city.
marvellous. This is an awesome musem. It is really combination of museums. Also the envoirment, the garden is very peaceful.Make sure you are wearing comfortable shoes..
Excellent collection. Take your time and enjoy the history. It's worth the visit.
Alexander's sarcophagus amazing. The sarcophagi on the ground floor are amazing. Unfortunately the rest of the museum was a little worn and dated.

Very rich in objects of interest, a little overwhelming. This museum has an amazing collection of objects, but it is big and somewhat confusing in its organization. I would highly recommend visiting it after either (1) a fair amount of familiarity with the history of Turkey (Greek, Roman, Ottoman) or (2) after a visit to the archeological sites along the Aegean sea. It is less meaningful if you are not versed in this stuff. I was unfortunately there early in my visit to Turkey and focused mostly on Alexander the Great's sarcophagus, but would have wanted to go back after fulfilling items (1) and (2).

Very big museum. This museum is huge. Do plan many hours for a visit. There are some beautiful sarcophagi that should not be missed. There is a lovely café in the garden when you can take a break (you will need one due to the sheer size of the museum!)

Expected better. The museum was good, but honestly I was just expecting more. They hadsome great pieces in the museum and they were amazing to see, butoverall I just didn't enjoy it as much as I thought I would. I enjoyedthe Turkish Islamic Arts Museum more. We used our Museum Pass to seethis museum.

Worth a visit - some archaeological "gems". Situated alongside Topkapi Museum, this museum has some historical masterpieces from a wide range of Anatolian and Middle Eastern sources. Highlights for us were the Sidon Gallery and Alexander Sarcophagus, Tiled Pavilion, Babylonian Gate, and current Byzantine Exhibition. Much understated and a little haphazard and disorganised at times, had to make a second visit and spent four hours exploring. For those interested in Eastern Mediterranean history, this is a must. Closed on Mondays and a 10 TL entrance fee. 9am til 5 pm. Cafe in courtyard. A great way to relax away from the crowds in Topkapi and Hagia Sofia. Nearest tram stop is Gulhane in Sultanahmet area.

good dose of antiquities. Well-laid out with a great variety of very old and not so old artifacts and antiquities. Note that a guidebook (DK Eyewitness) has a picture of the Treaty of Kadesh. Well, unfortunately, this item had been moved, and apparently in the move it BROKE! So what you'll see is not what is pictured in the guidebook. We went here after spending 6 hours at Topkapi Palace. Big mistake - too tired to do this grand museum justice. Go with fresh eyes and legs.

A great insight on the evolution of Turkish culture through the ages. This is the perfect place to spend a half day away from the sometimes overwhelming crowds at the more popular attractions. I highly recommend hiring the audioguide. My favorite section was the chronological display of who was ruling Turkey and at what time. The pieces recovered from the 9 periods of Troy were also interesting. There are also very good displays for Egypt and Mesopotamia.

Definitely worth a visit. We spent a good two hours here. Friends suggested this and we are so happy they did. It is not a terribly crowded museum so you can spend time at the displays. We found it amazing how many items are just sitting around outside. This is well worth your time while in Istanbul. I enjoyed it far more than Topaki Palace.

Worthwhile visit, helps to have the audio guide. On the outskirts of the old palace, this museum is a must-do. Purchase the audio guide as the pamphlet they provide is totally useless. Nice to see that there are items that weren't removed from the country (i.e. to the Louvre or London) over the years, and has remained 'in house'. So much history in the area, they do a nice job of highlighting the pieces, and the building itself is lovely as well.

A huge collection absolute stunning ancient objects.... This museum is conveniently located just next to the Topkapi Palace... While the topkapi palace, the aya sofia and the blue mosque are flooded with tourists, this wonderful museum was really quiet... while the collection is absolutely stunning... We only spend about 2 hours in the museum (it was the last day of our city trip)... but it's really worth spending more time than that...

Don't miss it.. Although in the grounds of Topkapi Palace on the right as you enter the first gate, the museum is bereft of tourists who race past it. It's a collection of 3 buildings - beautiful in their own right. It is very relaxing and (warning!) quite large so don't try do it in the same day as Topkapi as your legs would never stand it. Take the audio guide (10TL) as it is informative and worth it. Tea in the garden is lovely too - and with very few tourists.

A marvellous adventure. This is a place which clearly dwarfs the famous archeological museum in Athens. Please be prepared to spend at east five hours to enjoy the wonderful world. You will love this place if you have a prior knowledge about ancient kingdoms in Turkey. It is great and it is wonderful!! You will love the rich history of Turkey. One thing. You may want to bring some food for your lunch because they only sell very small sized sandwiches at the museum.

Amazing collection - pity the kids' section is currently closed. An astounding range of antiquities, in beautiful surroundings. There's a pleasant (overpriced) outdoor café too. Unfortunately the kids' museum, which apparently has a trojan horse kids can climb on, was closed.

Wonderful items from Niniveh, Ur, and Egypt.. This museum, housed in two main buildings, was a 19C construction designed to bring some Western-style culture and historical awareness to the Ottoman Empire of the time. The buildings are magnificent, very well laid-out, and the contents are just amazing. Tiled lions from the Ishtar Gate of Babylon, over 4,000 years old; cuneiform tablets, Egyptian sarcophagi and mummies, all the bits and bobs and gatherings from the Ottoman Empire's diplomatic service throughout the Middle East. It's all very well laid out and explained, and non-flash photography is permitted. There's also a beautiful building, a Tiled House, that is a superb example of Ottoman architecture. It's worth climbing the steps to view inside, and appreciate the skill and subtlety of the tile-makers of the time. The third and biggest building currently holds an exhibition on the history of Istanbul, from its earliest Neolithic traces through the various empires that have controlled this gateway between Asia and Europe. Again, the exhibits are well displayed, with excellent information plaques and a good layout. The museum displays contain enough information to please an informed amateur archaeologist, but even a casual tourist cannot fail to be impressed by the immense sweep and age-span of the collections.
A must to see museum for history enthusiasts.... If you are a history lover, or even if you are not, this museum is still a place which must be seen by anybody who comes to Istanbul.

Enjoy a trip through history. Istanbul Archaeology Museum is one of Istanbul's best attractions, this museum is rated among the top ten best museums in the world, it's amazingly beautifuly built, has a huge collection, and is easy and fun to browse especially with the walkman's you rent that walk you through the museum and provide you with info about selected pieces. The museum requires quiet some time to go through fully (i myself needed about 6 hours but that's me), there are plenty of places to rest, even two cafe's ... it's not something to be missedThe good thing about it it's never crowded and the ticket que is never long. I enjoyed sitting on the benches outside the museum building enjoying the sun and the scenery ... try not to miss the TILE KIOSK MUSEUM, it's breathtaking
WORTH 2 VISITS. Three museums in one. Superb Near Eastern artifacts.

necessarily must be visited. excellent structured. includes archaeological treasures that can not be seen anywhere else. contains a huge restoration work, settlement chronological and detailed explanations (especially on the upper floors). for full understanding must be visited for several days.

Very complete, thorough museum, especially for enthusiasts. The Archaeology Museum is quite massive in size, number and quality of articles in display, so do plan your visit - if you have little time, don't follow the "natural" visit path - explore the more recent ages, it will be quite worthwhile!
Great artifacts. Well worth the visit.. Bring your own water. In retrospect we should have paid for the audio tour. You get a discount to several museum and sites if you buy a pass.

5000 years of fascinating history in an engrossing museum. My wife & I visited the Museum on an outstanding private tour (Sea Song Tours) on 8/16. The Museum displays 5000 years of fascinating history with well organized, engrossing exhibits. For example, we were amazed at the details of the "Alexander Sarcophagus," which does NOT contain Alexander the Great, but which has remarkable battle scenes from ~300 BC. And we also thought that the Tiled Pavilion was well worth the time to see the evolution of Iznik tiles and other Turkish ceramics.By all means use an audio tour or a tour guide to enhance your experience.

Amazing collection. This place is a must see in Istanbul. Incredible stuff, much of it lifted from Lebanon and Syriaduring the days of the ottoman Empire. Too much to take in at one go, I would suggest 2 afternoons.

A treasure trove!. This is the kind of museum that knocks your socks off from the door. Never seen an image of Cleopatra? How about a coin with her face on one side and Mark Anthony's on the other? A one story statue of Zeus? Right here! Alexander the Great? Not gorgeous, but he's in there. You will be amazed at what they've got crammed into this place.

Fabulous!. This museum is a must see if you are planning on visiting sites in other parts of the country. It is full of many of the artifacts from these sites and is so interesting to see. We visited after we had been to about 15 historic sites and found it amazing. The tomb of alexander is not to be missed, but we found the maps hard to use. We visited the same day as the Topkapi Palace and our feet were killing us at the end of the day. I recommend this as the only walking site you visit on a day as it is major and not be rushed.
Allow yourself plenty of time to see it. It's a very beautiful museum worth a visit. Sadly we did not see it all as our schedule was rather tight. Next time we will allow more time. Recommend it.

AWESOME. This is an awesome museum.The Archaeology Museum is close to the Topkapi Palace.is a fine collection of Asian and European cultures, with various Greek sculptures, ancient Mesopotamian artefacts and Hellenic works of art.
Not to be missed!. As it is situated on the grounds of the Topkapi palace, it can easily be overlooked; don't miss it as it was the best museum in Istanbul.

Huge collection of antiquities, representing almost all ages and civilizations in history. In fact there are three museums: the Archeology Museum, the Ancient Orient Museum and the Islamic Arts Museum (Tiled Kiosk). Together, they have more than one million of objects in their collections, representing almost all ages and civilizations in the world history. It is located in the Topkapi Palace gardens and was founded in 1891, during the Ottoman Empire. The most important objects are:- Alexander Sarcophagus- Sarcophagus of the Crying Women- Sarcophagi of Tabnit and the Satrap- The Palmyran Tomb- Parts of the Ishtar Gate (Babylon)- Ancient statues from the Roman Era, from Aphrodisias, Ephesus and Miletus- Ephebos- Parts of statues from the Temple of Zeus (Bergama)- Treaty of Kadesh- A statue of a lion, from the Mausoleum of Maussollos- A snake's head from the Serpentine Column (Constantinopla Hippodrome)- 800,000 Ottoman coins, seals, decorations and medals- Artifacts from the early civilizations of Anatolia, Mesopotamia, Arabia and Egypt- Siloam inscription, found in a water tunnel from the Siloam Pools in Jerusalem. All three museums are so interesting, that I would recommend a whole day to see all collections. I spent only one afernoon there and it was not enough. The museum is very calm and peaceful, even in the touristic high season. There is also a cafe in the garden, among many antiquities and stone columns - very beautiful and expensive. I also recommend a visit to the museum website before actually going there, so you can plan which objects are most interesting to see if you have limited time: http://www.istanbularkeoloji.gov.tr/main_page

Even jet-lagged, this was an awesome museum with tons to see. We arrived in Istanbul at 9AM and our room wasn't ready, so we decided to down some coffee and hit the museum. Even exhausted, we thought it was really fantastic-- one of the best we've seen and we've been to 25+ history/archaeology museums recently. Incredible sarcophagi (Egyptian, Greek and Roman), sculptures from all over the country (really fun if you will later be visiting other parts of Turkey), a really interesting section of translations from headstones (i.e. 'he was a very honest man but died an untimely death."), and just generally packed with artifacts. We spent about 2.5 hours going through at a pretty quick pace.

Millions of artifacts from various civilization - world's biggest.. At last I've convinced myself entering the archeology museum in Istanbul! And, am I so glad I did.Consisting of three museums, the Istanbul Archeology Museum is located before the Topkapi Palace and on the upper side of the beautiful Gulhane Park. It is one of the must-see sight in Istanbul, and I just foiund out about that!!! . It could consume half of your day or even a whole day to see this huge museum housing more than a million of artifacts representing various world civilizations --- or almost all THE civilizations. If that doesn't sound interesting enough, I don't know what. You really have to see it. Small stuff, huge stuff. Those huge sarcophagi -- intricately carved and intelligently designed, esp. the sarcophagus of Alexander - truly impressive. The amount of treasures displayed in 3 buildings is marvelous.A small coffee shop on the side or infront of the museum entrance overlooking the Gulhane Park down below, very expensive hot bev and croissants, but nice atmosphere, like sipping your coffee amidst the ruins.The museum building consist of the Archaeological Museum which is in the main building, the Museum of the Ancient Orient, and the Museum of Islamic Art in the Tiled Kiosk.Besides its importance as the “first Turkish museum”, it has an importance and specialty of being one of the museum buildings that are constructed as a Museum in the World. Today, it still protects its outstanding place in the World’s biggest museums with its displays of more than a million belonging to various cultures.Entry Fee = TL10 only -------- which for me is more value than the separate entry fee for the harem part of the Topkapi Palace. Save that for this one.

A wonderful museum experience. We loved our time at the museum and in fact spent half a day here. Had we not become quite overwhelmed with the overall scale of the place we could have spent longer1The buildings housing the exhibits are magnificent in their own right and the grounds are a lovely place to wander and ponder what is on display.We would recommend hiring the headphones so that you can get a comprehensive understanding of the items on display as you wander through.Alexander's sarcophagus is specatcular and we loved the Tiled Pavilion (Çinli Kösk)

A great place to better understand our ancestors through these remains. I absolutely love the Istanbul Archaeology Museum as a study of the expression of art dating as far back as Alexander the Great. There is so much to see and reflect on the expression of civilization at any given time. For anyone that has a passion for history, this is a fascinating museum. I have been to the Acropolis Museum in Athens, which is beautifully designed, and by comparison, this museum, because the artifacts are so different, will hold any patron's full attention.
A must see for archeology lovers. A must see for archeology lovers. The exhibits provide a view into the Anatolian culture from all perspectives.

a bit confusing. This museum is gigantic and hard to figure out. You go up and down and around, it's huge! Not many explanations so you get a bit lost and there is sooooooooo much stuff, it's too much to appreciate. It sounds strange to say that but it was a bit overwhelming and it didn't feel like they put much effort into the displays (except for the special exhibits).But make sure you see the other two buildings at the same place: the Ancient Orient museum and the Ceramics museum. The first one IS interesting and well done (much much much smaller) and the second is absolutely gorgeous! If you like ceramics, you won't be disappointed.
Lots to see. This complex of museums needs a few hours to explore. Our brief visit whetted our interest and we'll be going back next months. At TL10 admission, it's excellent value.

Make this a "must-do" on your trip itinerary!. If you're a history buff, or an art lover, you do not want to miss a visit to this fabulous museum. We didn't know what to expect when we entered... we ended up spending 4 hours leisurely strolling through the many rooms and displays. All I can say is this is a most excellent museum, among the best in the world...

Mediocre with a Few Good Finds. After visiting the Archaeological Museum of Athens, this museum was a little disappointing. The audio guide was a complete waste of money at 10 Lira (and I’ve never felt that way about an audio guide before) because very few objects had numbers to prompt the audio guide and what was available was not thoroughly explained. I used the self-tour in the Rick Steves Istanbul guidebook and found it to be very satisfactory. There are a few key items, like the Alexander Sarcophogus and the lion reliefs from the gates of Babylon that are interesting, but it feels very small and sparse. I wandered leisurely through the whole museum reading in the guidebook and listening to the audioguide and was done in an hour. Don’t skip the Tiled Kiosk though—it’s real Turkish culture and a quick visit.

An Outstanding Museum.... Not knowing what to expect at this Museum, we allowed the whole day here.This museum was outstanding and it took us several hours just to see most of what is on display.There is so much that we broke the time up with lunch at the little cafe just left of the entry. The tea garden outside was closed for the winter season. Bathrooms are down near the Troy exhibition.The admission fee is a very reasonable 10 TL and worth every lira!Unlike the other museums in Istanbul that had huge crowds, here the halls, rooms and gardens were virtually empty in comparison.This allowed us to meander in and around the exhibitions with ease and as photography is allowed (no flash), we were able to bring home lots of memories. Most of the different displays were spread into three buildings, which are the Archaeological, Ancient Orient and Islamic Art (enameled tile Kiosk).Among the most memorable treasures here were: -Main Building:Alexander Sarcophagus, the gallery of statues (several rooms), sarcophagus of the Crying Women, Busts of Alexander, Zeus with many more old age funerary tombs.Ancient Orient:Tablet archives, Arabic, Mesopotamian, Egyptian and Anatolian art displaysKiosk:The building itself is beautiful with external mosaic tiling, lovely inside architecture, ceramic - chinaware objects and art spread over several rooms.This was a remarkable museum with a superb collection of artifacts. It was much more than we had expected and one of THE best museums we have visited!

Amazing artifacts here. We felt like we were the only ones in here, maybe we were outside the typical tourist season. Were able to have a close-up view of some of the amazing things on display here. Don't miss the Kadesh treaty, Roman statues, or the sarcophagi.

interesting place. The museum is divided into 3 buidings. Al containing interesting artefacts. The hightlights for me, were the amazing Sarcopagi, The oldest love poem and the oldest peace treaty, some things never change!!! However, the displays for the roman, greek and above all Byzantine period, were dismal. Were displayed in a haphazzard way, and no way inviting. Even the display on Troy, an exciting period of history, was very dull. Do not get the audio guide, no more information on it than on the displays. Overall an interesting place.

Worth Visiting Over and Over Again. Indeed, this museum comprises of 3 different museums, all located in the same courtyard, each displaying artefacts of different periods of time. The buildings themselves are very impressive, each exemplifing a different architectural style. This complex of museum, where more than 1 millions artefacts are exhibited, has been granted many museum awards from all over the world. Its large courtyard serves as a classical music concert hall in summer, which is a great experience as well. Surprisingly, it's very calm when compared with other touristic destinations of Istanbul and in good wheather, its serene courtyard can be a great choice to grab a sandwich and a drink for a short outdoor lunch. Its small and cosy coffee shop is also good. There are a lot of artefacts that are not displayed and throughout the year, as new pavillions are readied, new parts are opened. So, the museum can be visited more than once as there will always be a new section. For instance, the artefacts of the newly discovered Istanbul harbour area have started to be displayed recently. There is also a section for children. Don't miss this museum once in Istanbul

For Us History Lovers.... Quiet an impressive collection can be found in this lovely museum. Four hours was not enough for my wife and I to see it all. The relics of ages past and civilizations that existed in the area of modern Turkey are well represented. The Sidon sarcophagi are particularly impressive as are the displays on the classical world. The wing added in the 70's is an architectural disappointment and unworthy of the artifacts it houses... the displays too need to be updated in the sense of making them better appreciable. The display on Troy needs work as do the ones on the Byzantine period... a bit disappointing... amazing objects but put out for viewing in a very lackluster way. Nonetheless the museum and the gardens around, with many columns, statues and the tombs of emperors no less are a very import place to visit if in Istanbul. When I return, I will definitely visit again and spend even more time in the museum. Photos were allowed, which was good and the toilets were acceptable.
Excellent - don't leave Istanbul without seeing this. A super museum with some really interesting displays, we enjoyed our time there - great little coffee shop as well.

Musée incontournable pour qui aime les cultures antiques. Gréât muséum and it was really impression to see the sarcophage of alexander who is very well conserved. Therefore the price of the entrance is high and There is no Reduction for the young and old people. Also the explications are only in turkisch or english

great!. The Istanbul Archaeology Museums is a group of three archeological museums( Archaeological Museum, Museum of the Ancient Orient, Museum of Islamic Art) located in the Eminönü district of Istanbul. The museum has a large collection(over one million objects!!) of Turkish, Hellenistic and Roman artifacts.This is a MUST in Istanbul. You need 2-3hours to see all of the exibits, take some good guide book or read sth about it. Ticket cost 8TL

Worth a visit. Disappointing by Topkapi Palace and its crowds, I visited the Archaeology Museum and was pleasantly surprised - only a fraction of the crowds compared to the palace, I was able to view and enjoy the exhibits without being pushed or shoved by masses of tourists ... unfortunately I didn't have enough time to view as much as I would have liked, so I would recommend no less than 3hrs for a visit.

A world class museum: A must-see gem of Istanbul. I was not a fan of a museum until I saw this one. Istanbul Archaeology Museum is so spectacular, beautiful and huge with lots and lots of incredible collections. I had never thought in my life I would ever fall in love with an archaeology museum... :D I even consider this place as one of the best tourist spots in Istanbul, along with Hagia Sophia.I only planned 2 hours to look around but instead I spent almost 6 hours taking pictures and enjoying the moments I had never felt anywhere else. If you don't enjoy taking pictures as much as I do, I would recommend to allocate at least a 3 hours in your schedule to visit this museum. And if you want to, there is also records that visitors can borrow to listen to. I did not borrow it because I was not into the history, instead I was so cought up in how beautiful the pieces are. My favourite part of the collections are the marble statues and (especially) marble sarcophagi. The Alexander's sarcophagus is breathtakingly beautiful... (I also never imagined I would like a sarcophagus, OMG) :)I aggree with the previous reviewers that this museum is so much better than the Topkapi. The collections are not limited to archaeological findings inside Turkey but also from the neighbouring countries. I highly recommend this museum to Istanbul Travellers. Don't forget to wear comfortable shoes. The admission fee is 10 Liras if I am not mistaken. So cheap compared to the beauty we all can see inside. And don't miss the small museum building near by the entry/exit gate, the one with the pharaohs. I almost missed that one.

Better than Top Kapi. If you are pressed for time in Istanbul and want to see something surprising, visit the Archaeology Museum, just down the hill from the entrance to Top Kapi. The old palace complex is a must of course, as are Hagia Sophia and the blue Mosque, and numerous other places; but... this museum left me in awe of its exhibits. The so-called Alexander sarcophagus and some other classical sculptural exhibits still retain some of their original colour, and the sculptures are truly exceptional. If you have any knowledge of ancient portraiture you will instantly recognise old faces. Marcus Aurelius jumped out at me, and there is a magnificent full size bronze of Hadrian. Late antique Byzantine statuary is fascinating too. I challenge even the most disinterested of people not be be astonished. All the other exhibits are world class too, and if I had to choose the experience here or in the British Museum, I'd have to go for Istanbul. It really is that fine. Don't miss it.

A treasure!. This museum is a treasure for history buffs and is a good place to absorb the pagan and Christian history of Istanbul (Constantinople of the eastern Byzantine empire).The musuem helps one understand the importance of Istanbul as the bridge between the east and the west on so many levels.Wonderfully designed and wonderfully preserved it has some amazing artifacts that its founding curator and archelogist Osman Hamdi Bay presrved for Turkey by saving it from European plunderers to take away to French and British musuems.

Magnificiant - almost better than the raki experience. I am very much into art, ruins and history. I have been all over the world and many different museums in my life. The two things I can't forget about my trip to Istanbul was the dinner I had in that fish restaurant with raki (the traditional Turkish alcohol) and the the magnificent pieces that the Istanbul Archeology Museum has. Room after room you see the unbelievable pieces that just takes your breath away. I am planning a trip again next year just to soak in all that rich presentation. I highly recommend to everyone!

Save time for this gem!. The Archaeology Museum is one of my few regrets about my trip to Istanbul - the main cause for regret is that I'd only allocated two hours! If you enjoy historical artifacts, or even just have a passing interest in Near-Eastern history, VISIT THIS MUSEUM! And for heavens' sake, give yourself AT LEAST 3 hours.If the Ottomans were there, this museum probably has artifacts from it. Most impressive were the many, many, many Greek statues, in varying degrees of completeness. Also engaging was the extensive display of ancient artifacts from Mesopotamia and Egypt. They also have an abundance of displays on all the major cultures in the area throughout the past.It's easy to miss, sandwiched as it is between the better-known Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace, and Justinian Cistern, but it's the rival of any of them. Don't miss it!

Awesome collection. Only had about 2 hours here and never got to see even 1/10th of the exhibits. The collections of highly decorated sarcophagi were amazing. The relief carvings, showing scenes with Alexander the Great, are the best I've seen anywhere in Greece, Italy or Turkey. Don't miss the pottery and tile exhibits in a building across the courtyard. Unlike most places we visited in Istanbul, this museum wasn't crowded, and you could really enjoy your time here without fighting crowds for a look over several layers of shoulders.

Awesome. This is an awesome musem. It is really combination of museums. Also the envoirment, the garden is very peaceful.Make sure you are wearing comfortable shoes. Must see if you like museums.By the way, I have to say many of the listed activities such as "Tours, Cooking classes, Leather" etc. maybe good but they are companies who provide services. I would say pay more attention to the listings that are "Mosques, Churches, Bazaars, Museums and goverment or municipality owned or operated activites."

Definetly should be seen if you ever come to Istanbul..... If you ever come to Istanbul this museum is the one should be seen which takes around 1 full day together with the near museums.Inside the museum;Tiled Kiosk commissioned by Sultan Mehmed II in 1472 is the first and the oldest Ottoman structure in Istanbul, featuring Ottoman civil architecture and was a part of the Topkapı Palace outer gardensAnd also in the museum Kadesh Peace Treaty (1258 BCE), signed between Ramesses II of Egypt and Hattusili III of the Hittite Empire could be seen. This treaty is the oldest known peace treaty in the world, and a giant poster of this tablets containing the treaty is on the wall of the United Nations Headquarters in New York City.The ornate Alexander Sarcophagus, once believed to be prepared for Alexander the Great, is among the most famous pieces of ancient art in the museumPlus the garden and coffeehouse among the sculptures and under the huge trees is perfrect to rest and think abt yourself.

History - All in one. Istanbul Archeology Museum is a fine collection of Asian and European cultures, with various Greek sculptures, ancient Mesopotamian artefacts and Hellenic works of art. Sidon Necropolis and sarcophagus of Alexander the Great are to mention, especially.If you are in Istanbul, visit Archology Museum for a tour of history, all in one.

do not miss the masterpieces. The Head of Sappho, an example of the portraits from the Roman Era, belongs to poet Sappho, born on the island of Lesbos (Midilli). Between 7 to 5th centuries BC, there were many lyric poets. Sappho was the most famous poet of that era, but only one of here poems, a hymn to Aphrodite, remained as a whole since then. Sappho, who lived far away from Lesbos, in Sicily, during her youth, became the teacher of a group of women worshipping Aphrodite after her return. According to a legend, she killed herself by jumping off cliffs when she was rejected by her beloved man.When the Macedon king Alexander the Great, who lived between 356 and 323 BC, ascended to the throne, he was not even twenty. The legendary commander, who died at the age of 33, has never been forgotten during the twenty-three centuries passed since then, thanks to his glorious and great conquests during a short period of kingdom. He overthrew the Persian Empire and established a great empire extending from Macedonia to India. The cities founded by Alexander, who spent most of his life in Asia, as military bases turned into cultural and commercial centers later and played an important role in the spread of the Ancient Greek culture up to India. The era of Alexander the Great, of which artistic influences can be followed as well, was a transition period between the periods of Classical Art and Hellenistic Art. The Head of Alexander the Great, dated to the 2nd century BC, was found during excavations at the Lower Agora in Pergamon (Bergama). His head is inclined towards his shoulder, the lock of hair from the front of his head, slightly pulled back, resembles a lion's mane and his hair is irregularly waved in both sides. This is the hairstyle of Alexander the Great. All of the aspects such as his heavy eyelids and round eyes, thick eyelashes, slightly open mouth that does not show his teeth are characteristics of the statues of Alexander the Great. This is the style of portraits made by the sculptor Lysippos, who lived in the 4th century BC and led the transition between the Classic Art and the Hellenistic Art. The artist worked for Alexander the Great and he was the only sculptor of Alexander. The deep forehead lines call the big problems faced by the king despite his youth to the mind. This work is reflecting the typical characteristics of the Pergamon sculpture school during the era of King Eumenes II.  The Statue of Marsyas, dated to the Hellenistic period, was found in Tarsus, a historical city in south-central Turkey. He is depicted as hung from a tree and his muscles stretched due to torture draw attention. So to say, he has a physically silent but angry expression. The original version of this special statue should have been placed to the center of a group of statues including the statue of Apollo sitting on his left side and a slave sharpening his knife in order to skin him on his right side. Marsyas, the main character of an Anatolian story, is depicted while bearing the consequences of his rivalry with Apollo, the god of music. According to the story, Marsyas claims that he plays his flute better than Apollo plays his lyre. Neither of them wins in a musical contest, but Apollo asks Marsyas to turn his instrument upside down and to add his own voice. However, Marsyas cannot meet this challenge and Apollo wins the contest. Angry because of being challenged by a mortal, Apollo skins Marsyas alive and hangs his skin to a pine tree. However, he feels sorry later, breaks his lyre and turns Marsyas into a river. Ephepos statue is the statue of an ephebos, i.e. a male teenager. Probably he is an athlete and after a heavy exercise, he rests against a long, rectangular column, which once had a relief or herm. He should have just finished his exercise, since he wears a mantle-like cloth for protection. His small and round head is the most component of the statue. Eyelashes are apparent, eyes are big and the lips are slightly open. It is one of the unique ancient artifacts found until today. Probably, it was used to decorate a gymnasium. It is an important example, since it shows that not only gods, goddesses and emperors, but also ordinary people who were important for the society were portrayed in the ancient era.

Just breathtaking. I can't recommend this museum enough. Room after room of astonishing exhibits, including the Alexander tomb, which I sat and gawped at for nearly an hour.The signs are really informative and interesting, bringing to life the complex and fascinating history of the areas which used to be part of the Empire.If you go to Istanbul and don't spend an afternoon here, you're mad.

Best museum in Istanbul - don't miss this one. The Archaeology Museum is close to the Topkapi Palace - just go down the hill towards Gulhane Park. I didn't have particularly high expectations, but found it absolutely brilliant. It's good value compared to other tourist attractions, just 10 lira entry charge.On the ground floor of the main section is an impressive collection of sarcophaguses (sarcophagi?) - massive tombs with intricate carvings on the sides, including the famous 'Alexander sarcophagus', which supposedly shows Alexander the Great in battle. There is also a sequence of rooms with statues from various periods. Really I felt the collection was better than at the British Museum in London (which I've visited quite often), particularly in view of the lack of crowds. You can get right up close to all the exhibits.Upstairs there is a massive (really massive) collection of finds from Anatolia, Troy and most of the Middle-East, going right back to 4000BC. Far too much to take in - case after case of ceramics and jewellery in remarkable condition. You could spend all day there and not see everything. It was completely deserted apart from the security guards, which was a shame.There is also a decent cafe and gift shop.

Great museum. This has to be one of the best archaeology museums in the world. While I would not put it on the same level as the one in Athens or the British Museum, it is truly a great museum and I enjoyed it a great deal. One of my favorite things in Istanbul.
A genuine must see. The collection of Roman artifacts is outstanding and is better than the British Museum. Alexander the Greats tomb is spectacular.

A Must For Those Interested in Archaeology. This is an incredible place! There is so much to see from all of the ancient civilizations of the Middle East. Especially if you have a knowledge of the Old Testament, you'll all kinds of things from the kings who menaced the Israelites - Sargon! Tiglath-Pilesar! Highlights include the inscription of Hezikiah's tunnel in Jerusalem and the Kadesh Treaty. I was especially suprised by how kindly they treated Schliemann, the one who first unearthed ancient Troy, in one of the exhibits. He stole many of the artifacts from the Turkish people, and was rather distructive in his digging methods, but they give him a great deal of credit for his discovery and work.
